Title: 1889 September 20COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Lilly
Creator: Caroline Mary Cope Lewis:  1865-1953
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; MorrisCOMMA Elliston P. (Elliston Perot)COMMA 1831-1914; LewisCOMMA William DraperCOMMA 1867-1949
Unidentified People: J and R.
Subject: Betrothal; Love; Courtship
Notes: Related file: hsc0025f
Transcript:
Awbury.
Sept. 20. 1889.

My dear Lilly. I know that thee has thought it strange that I have never written to thee all summer. but one thing and another always turned up. & [---] the days go by without doing so – now that I really have something to tell thee perhaps it won’t be so hard! but I wont go on like Elliston Morris – but will get to the point of my tale which is simply that I am engaged to Will Lewis! The engagement is not to be announced for a long time yet – This is especiallyimportant on Will Lewis’ account and I am sure thee will help us to keep it quiet and be very careful not to let the children or anyone else suspect the truth! It does seem strange that I should be engaged to one whom neither thee or Chellie know – but I Sincerely hope you will soon know him and learn to like him as one of the family! My happiness is so complete that I can scarcely realize all that has happened – that what I have prayed and longed for for so many months has actually come to pass and I am engaged to him whom I have loved for so long a time – it has all been Sosudden! the Change – that I feel as if I was in a dream & cannot realize the truth! Our own immediate families are the only ones who are to know anything about it for the present – so please be very careful not to mention the subject – I really think it would be better to talk about it as little as possible – for "little pitchers have big ears" thee knows! of course thee won’t have anyone to talk to about it now. but I meant especially when J and R. go up & after you all got home.
The mail is about to go –& news is scarce at present – so I wont continue scrawling.
With love – I am thine
very affectionately
Carrie.

Title: 1867 August 18 and 20COMMA NewportCOMMA to Father
Creator: Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; HartshorneCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1823-1897 ; MerrittCOMMA George F.; WilliamsCOMMA MaryCOMMA 1795?-1871; CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA  1857-1897; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; LongstrethCOMMA Thomas KimberCOMMA 1851-1883;
Subject: Sailing; Children and the sea; Family; Outdoor  recreation; Voyages and Travels; Transportation; Nature; Saltwater fishing; Fishes; Private libraries;
Notes:
This letter contains two separate sections: one dated 8/18 and the second dated 8/20.

Beaver Tail is a lighthouse located in JamestownCOMMA Rhode Island. For a description of many of the geographic locations mentioned in the letterCOMMA see Newport and How to See It (Newport: Davis & PitmanCOMMA 1869).
Transcript:
NewportCOMMA 8th mo.COMMA 18th. 1867.

Dear Father
I thought I would write to thee this afternoonCOMMA in case I should not get a chance before the steamer leaves. Not that I’m so very busyCOMMA but since I lie down every noon when I get home from bathing in timeCOMMA and in the evenings we have Mary Williams’ lamp incased in the same little plain bonnet so that we have no chance either to write or read after darkCOMMA unless we take a lamp and go up stairs.
On 6th day we ordered the boatCOMMA but were not able to go outCOMMA on account of the rain. In the morning Alfred had the pleasure of witnessing a little sail boat upsetCOMMA the man who was in it managed to get on the bottom untill a sail boat came to his assistance. In the afternoon the rain slackened some and we made up quite a large party and hired the omnibus to go to the south Shore and see if the horn spoutedCOMMA we had George and thecarriage beside. When we got there the horn did not spout at allCOMMA but the waves were very fineCOMMA and towards the latter part of the timeCOMMA when the sun came outCOMMA very beautiful the sun shone on the spray making nearly half of a rainbow. We staid till quite late stopping on the way home at the boathouseCOMMA the sea there was not nearly so fine though. On seventh day morning we made up a small fishing expeditionCOMMA consisting of AlfCOMMA HazenCOMMA Tom LongstrethCOMMA George and myself. We went about a mile above the poor house anchoring in a little cove near the rail-road. We had quite good luckCOMMA and caught about 24 fishCOMMA including 2 star fishCOMMA several ChaucksusCOMMA and one very fat eelCOMMA which I had the gratification of catching. Since we have been here we have seen two very curious fishCOMMA one called an “old maidCOMMA” which is about 1 foot long and white underneath; the other is a “swell fishCOMMA” and looks very much like other fishCOMMA except when you turn it over and rub it gentlyit becomes inflated and is puffed out like a small air-baloonCOMMA it is about 6 inches long. The fishermen on the point have had a reading room and small library established for their benefit in a back room looking out on the bay at “GodderdsCOMMA” (I don[t] know whether I have spelt it right or notCOMMA but if thee pronounces it the way its spelt thee will know where I mean) by a Miss or Mrs. Gibbs. They take the daily and some of the illustrated papersCOMMA and I noticed a number of the “British Gardiner” I think it was on the table. Well to come to the point at once; uncle Harry was invited to deliver a sort of a lecture to them on last 6th day evening. George Merrit seemed very desirous that the ladies would come up and hear the discourseCOMMA which some of them did. The speech was very grand the subject being “WaterCOMMA” I dont know whether the fishermen properly appreciated itCOMMA since I heard one remark afterwards thatCOMMA “it wouldtake a purty smart man to follow him.” I believe uncle Harry proposes to deliver some more during this week on Light and Air. 20th 3rd day. Yesterday we took a sail over to the Dumplings and landed those that wanted toCOMMA the rest of us going on downCOMMA towards Bever Tail. This morning we proposed sailing around CanonicutCOMMA recruits came in slowly since they had been all finished by the expedition to the Light shipCOMMA however as it turned out there was not enough wind and we had to defer it untill tomorrowCOMMA and go bathing instead. This afternoon mother contemplates going sailing if George thinks we are not going to have a squall; at present it looks very much like rain. I suppose Mother has told thee all about the storm they have been having at home. I hope we’ll not have it here. And now since I have used up my sheet I will stop. affecty thy son
T.P. Cope Jr

Title: 1896 August 3COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Frank
Creator: Witmer Stone:  1866-1939
Subject: Birds--Research;  Ornithology;
Transcript:
[Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia Sept. 1. 1896

Dear Frank.

I think it would be best to prepare your paper this fallCOMMA and add what additional information you may get in the future in the form of “Notes.”

I think it best to call it “Breeding” or “Summer” Birds of Susq. Co. and would therefore mention the migrants or stragglers as the [Bothonotary?] in the introductory part & not include such species in the body of the listI shall be very glad to see your manuscript & make any suggestions that may occur to me. It will be no trouble at all! I think you are right about the [----] position of the county.

Indeed I do not call to mind any Carolinian elements. If there are any they must occur in much lower ground than is found about Dimock.

I shall be at the Academy from now on as I returned from the Catskills last week.

Sincerely yours

Witmer Stone

Notes:

Letter date unknownCOMMA probably 1805-1809.
Transcript:
Dear Henry

I have been writing or rather Scrawling to William and CarolineCOMMA & thought I would Stain a little more paperCOMMA how is our dear Francis He has had an afficting trying timeCOMMA I hope it will be the lastCOMMA and thee has had thy Share in simpathising with himCOMMA and attending on him which I hope will have its use thee sertainly will have thy reward for thy kind attention to an afficted brotherCOMMA give my best love to him I want much to see youCOMMA I expect to see the in a few weeks I hope I Shan’t be disapointed we are all faver’d with HealthCOMMA the Rebeckah is come and I expect has made a good voige I dont know of any thing new to tell youCOMMA with Desires for your wellfare I remain your Affectinate grangmother

Rachel DrinkerFor
Henry Cope
Weston

Title: 1879 January 6COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to RuthAnna CopeCOMMA Germantown
Creator: Richard Randolf
Subject: Bible--Study and teaching--Society of Friends;
Transcript:
247 North 12th St.
Philada 1/6.1879.

My dear friend:
As I did not gather from thy message when I last called at Aubrey that thou wouldst have declined seeing me if not unusually occupiedCOMMA and as I deem it one of the first duties of social lifeCOMMA if not the very firstCOMMA to seek so to supply one another (to honour a figure from astronomy.) with the elements of our several orbitsCOMMA that we may always know as exactly as may beCOMMA where to find one another; and as a stubborn lamenessCOMMA some still more urgent engagementCOMMA and the recent icy walking has combined to prevent my again calling as I have ever since desired; under these circumstances I feel at liberty to send thee another brief letter. Had I succeeded in seeing thee at that last callCOMMA I should perhaps have had little to say but
I had not presumed on tasking thee with any perusal or examination of this MS. I left for H.W.S.COMMA and that there was a method--something I trusted of the gospel "decently and in order"COMMA even in the seeming caprice of my movement. I could not but be conscious of my own appearance of insensibility; but I may humbly and thankfully assert that I was and am at least sensible of having a fixed object in livingCOMMA which reaches even to the relationship of such comparative strangers as thou and I must as yet confess ourselves to beCOMMA and which is even necessaryCOMMA (coupled with confessed infirmity) to account for some show of vacillationCOMMA or spasmodic irregularity. For instanceCOMMA I hope not to leave the world without doing something to the formation and definite recognition of an "inner circle of friendship" in which superlative epithetsCOMMA such as "dearest" &c. will not be regarded as necessarily exclusiveCOMMA and into which a subtle form of witchcraft whichI must not here particularize (for the BibleCOMMA as the Westminster Review justly claimsCOMMA "must stand or fall with the doctrine of Witchcraft") shall not be able to enter. And how difficult must the steadfast upholding of such a doctrine be in a community whose Social CodeCOMMA and whose very theory of the familyCOMMA commit it to the assumption that universal tithe shall be the weakest rather than the strongest!
I am not now sure but that like one of old I shall have to appeal from ecclesiastical indifference or oppositionCOMMA to the "Cesar" of public sentiment. A recent Essay on "Stages of Faith"COMMA tracing the course of consciousness from the experience of physical or outward immunity (i.e. the Salvation which is common to "all men". 1 Tim. ivCOMMA10) to that of spiritual power and causationCOMMA and recognizing the intellectual element as both the social and the mediatoreal phase of ChristianityCOMMA and LoCOMMA through the continued presence of our Lord with his followers "to the end of the world"COMMA the ground and surety of an uninterrupted progress to that dread but glorious consummationCOMMA--in short recognizing that element as being the witnessing of "the water" (1 Jno. v.8);--such an EssayCOMMA I sayCOMMA has been offered by me to each of the weekly Philadelphia Journals claiming to represent QuakerismCOMMA and declined by at least two of them. Even if the other two shall do likewise I mean to look for the sympathy of some of our fellow professors in publishing itCOMMA and would like to include some of the Cope familyCOMMA if I have not already overdosed them with my manuscripts and my manners. I must notCOMMA I supposeCOMMA ask thee to write meCOMMA even on their behalf. If thou would only call to see my sister M.COMMA I think I might regard it as a token for good. I feel sure she could not have a more acceptable visitor--at any rate not beyond her nearest kindred--Please give my love to thine with theeCOMMA and believe meCOMMA very sincerelyCOMMA though too untruly (some hair-splitting or nail-splitting is needed there) thy friendCOMMA Richd Randolph

To R. Anna Cope
Germantown

Title: 1865 April 11COMMA BCOMMA to Mother and sisters
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; ChestonCOMMA Margaret CareyCOMMA d. 1874; TysonCOMMA Jesse; LytleCOMMA HannahCOMMA 1814-1899; ValentineCOMMA JuliaCOMMA 1808-1892; ThomasCOMMA James CareyCOMMA 1833-1897
Unidentified People: H. King and Miss M.
Subject: Society of Friends; Freedmen--United States; Clothing and dress; Baltimore (Md.)--History; LincolnCOMMA AbrahamCOMMA 1809-1865--Assassination
Notes: This letter was dated incorrectly ("64") and edited in another hand. The correct date is 1865.
Transcript:
B – 4/11

Dear Mother & sistersCOMMA
I think I shall take to writing to you in a journal formCOMMA as I often have little times when I can sit down for a few minutes & no longer. I recd thy letter Carry of the 9th wh. was very nice & also the cuffsCOMMA wh. were also very niceCOMMA & I am very much obliged to whoever did ‘em & that person was mother I reckon & it was very good of her & they were just what I wanted. & now if you can only send me a white skirtCOMMA I shall be so [g---] for I can hardly get along withoutCOMMA as I find the one I brot will hardly bear another washing.
On 4th day eve. I took tea at Mart. Chestons & had such a nice time. Altho’ she is so feeble that she washardly able to sit up all the evenCOMMA she insisted upon inviting a few others to make it pleasant for me – & I thot it was so kind in her. The party consisted of H Lytle (who is such a nice & good person) Julia Valentine Dr Thomas H. King & Jesse – & we had such a nice home-like timeCOMMA & such an elegant tea & Ice cream & all. I thought it the nicest visit I have paidCOMMA & then in the evening as it was rainy she wd. insist upon sending us home in the carriage & she asked me so kindly to come there any time when I felt like itCOMMA that I felt quite gratified. It rained so much the afternoon I was to go out to Careys – that it was deferred so I have not been yetCOMMA & I believe I have’nt done anything in particular elseCOMMA since [---] wrote last. While I think of it Caroline Ill ans. thy questions. There are 200 chil’n in our sch. & 4 teachers wh. makes 1 to every 50. Mine is the least advanced class & consequently the least interesting. AgesCOMMA frm. abtCOMMA 7 yrs. to 15 or 16. & strange to say the smallest chil’n in my sch are generally the best scholars. The greater proportion are boysCOMMA about a third girls. They are children of this place who have not hitherto had the advantage of free schools.
End of first sitting.3rd day – 18th
I have laid aside my letter for two or three daysCOMMA – for we have all felt so sad since hearing the dreadful news that I cld. not feel like writing abt. ordinary things & there seemed little to say on the one great subject – the presidents dreadful deathCOMMA wh. seemed dreadful enough to strike every one dumb with horror & astonishment. It seemed so near to usCOMMA & the more so because the very day after wh. it occurred we had planned to make a little excursion to Washington for the day having been invited by one of Miss M’s frds. who often goes down. So you can judge of our horror when a few min. before setting outCOMMA this dreadful intelligence was brot. to us. The feeling here against the seccessionists has been intense as they have been heard to rejoice in the sts. at thedreadful newsCOMMA & to have prophesied a few days since that our rejoicings wld. be turned to sorrow. The city was under martial law for a day or two – but by the strict vigilance of the authorities was kept quiet. but they compelled every secessionist as well as union on the principal business sts to drape their stores in mourning & [if] the appearance it presents is very solemn & sad. I suppose it is the same in Phila. – & everywhere. It seems really a more horrible thing than some we have shrunk frm. reading in books of history. People here seem to be sanguine about the new administration – & the prospects of peaceCOMMA but that does not take away frm. the horrible fact that there can exist in our midst such a wicked & fiendish spirit.
4th day morn — our school has been dismissed to day on account of the solemnities wh. are to be observed in the churches & elsewhere
We also had a holliday on 2nd day & Jesse Tyson very kindly took advantage of it to take us a very beautiful ride to a lake abt. 7 miles frm. here wh. is situated among hills & woods as beautiful as any Iever saw. I had no idea there was anything of the kind so near to the city. It was delightful to get a sight of the beautiful spring in the country. The trees are just putting out their first leavesCOMMA & look so lovelyCOMMA & we cld. not but enjoy it in spite of the mournful circumstances wh. have been so much in our mindsCOMMA Jesse took us past his placeCOMMA where he wishes to erect his model house. It is a very beautiful situation indeed with views of the city & the bay &c.
I suppose you (that is some of you) are in the midst of yearly meeting now. but the sad newsmust have thrown a great damp over every thing.
We have been spending two or three afternoons this week at the meeting house sewing for the refugees. The friends have a sewing machine thereCOMMA & meet every day this week to sew. & they will get a good deal accomplished no doubt. Julia Valentine seems to be very active & is a very nice frd. I [am] [you] [will] try to call on [Tamy] Miller when she is in P again as she — Aunt has been so kind in asking me to come out there &c.
Clementine Cope.
If you can find out when [Tamy] will be in P I have no doubt she wld. bring any package. I want to go out this morning to get one or two thins so I will bring my letter to a close. Hope I shall get one frm. you today but suppose you have felt unlike writing as I have. But for thisCOMMA I shd. have written to Tom this weekCOMMA tell him. Give my love to Cous. T. & all enquiring frds. am glad to hear you miss me a little some times. Yours affec Clemmy
I miss you very much

Title: 1911 April 2COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Lilly
Creator: Caroline Mary Cope Lewis:  1865-1953
Identified People: EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; CopeCOMMA Anna StewardsonCOMMA  1822-1916; LewisCOMMA William DraperCOMMA 1867-1949; EvansCOMMA Rachel  Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA  1852-1944; FooteCOMMA Eleanor Tyson CopeCOMMA 1879-1973;
Unidentified People: Miss RichardsonCOMMA Susan StewartCOMMA and Miss Moses (all nurses)
Subject: Voyages and Travels--Health aspects;  Bereavement in old age; African  Americans--History -1877-1964; Letter writing; Health;
Notes:
Date written in pencil.

The Colored Summer Home mentioned may be a cottage on the grounds of the Institute for Colored Youth in CheyneyCOMMA PA (now Cheyney University). The cottageCOMMA financed primarily by a $3000 donation from Susanna BrintonCOMMA housed students attending the Institute’s summer sessions. By July 11COMMA 1911COMMA fourteen students lived in the cottage. Information from Charline Howard Conyers’ A Living Legend: The History of Cheyney UniversityCOMMA 1837-1951 (CheyneyCOMMA PA: Cheyney University PressCOMMA 1990).
Transcript:
Awbury –
April 2.nd.

Dearest Lilly –
I don’t know what thee has thought of me for not thanking thee before for thy Most generous Contribution to our Collection for the Colored Summer Home – it came on the day of the evening when Jonnie was stricken. & I forgot about it entirely until the following TuesdayCOMMA the day of our CollectionCOMMA & I should have sat downright then & written. but Anna was writing to thee & I sent a message. & thought I would wait until I had more time to write a longer letter. but that time has scarce seemed to come until now! We have just finished dining at Mother’s – & while Mother is engaged in her usual occupation with the dishes in the pantry. I had sat down in the library with Tom & Will who are both reading. to write to thee. Anna was so long ingetting her letter off to thee. I imagine the Contents told everything up to within a day or two – Chellie is very wonderfulCOMMA– perfectly calm & like herself – but she looks badly – & I fear as the days go on & she realizes more & more what has happened. that she will show it even more – but she is blessed with four devoted Sons who are looking after her in every way – Miss Richardson of CourseCOMMA as thee knows is with them – & they kept theNurseCOMMA whom they had for JonnieCOMMA until yesterday. Anna too keeps well. & so far is entirely natural – but Miss Richardson watches her like a hawk. & never lets her be alone long – they want her to go away.– but she does not want to.– & Miss R. told me yesterday that they would not insist upon it – which I am glad of – for I think we cannot always judge what is best for others at these times.
MotherCOMMA I am thankfulto sayCOMMA is very well – & with Anna & my being here alternately she has gotten along very well with the new maid whom Anna got for her – but of course she is not a Companion – or a trained nurse – and I think we are going to be able to get Susan Stewart out next week for a few weeks until she (Susan) goes to the Hospital – We may be able to keep her until Mother goes to North EastCOMMA but thatI Cannot say – Chellie was in hopes that Mother would [heed] this nurse who has been with her this week. & if she liked her to have her go to Northeast with her. but Mother was strongly opposed to it – I think largely because she was a stranger – now we had proposed Miss Moses’ name. & she wants her – So I expect she will be gotten – I had had a talk with her. & she is entirely willing to undertake it if she is wanted. & both Mother & Tomseem to want it – tho’ Tom says he wants nothing except what Mother wants – The trouble is about Miss Moses she will have to [leave] Mother to be home by the first of October – I am quite sure she will be a very devoted nurse – and I think it will be very hard for Mother to let her go – I only wish we could get a permanency – Before Jonnie died Miss R. had told Mother that she would come back to her in the fall. & I think Mother ishoping for that – but I feel that is not to be counted upon.
Please forgive such a lenghty epistle – Mother has now returned from the pantry – the men have departed & I must say goodbye to thee –
Please give my love to Ellie & much for thyself –
from thy loving sister
[Care]

Creator: Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944

Notes:

Wickford is the local name for North KingstownCOMMA Rhode Island.
Transcript:
Newport 8th. mo. 26th. 1867.

Dear father
I rec’d thy letter 5th day morning. Thy accounts quite make me wish to see England some time although I dont know that that time will ever come. On 4th day we sailed round CanonicutCOMMA and since Lilly says she has given thee a condensed account of our tripCOMMA I will copy our log by way of variety. The officers were: Capt. Geo. F MerrittCOMMA 1st mate T.P. Cope Jr 2nd mate A Cope Jr; Seaman T.K. LongstrethCOMMA Cabin boy F.H. Cope. Steward M. C Collins. Cook V. Hartshorne and 6 passengersCOMMA A NewhallCOMMA M NewhallCOMMA M FarnumCOMMA H CarterCOMMA M. CollinsCOMMA & E.S. Cope.
Log of the Canonicut Party – Yacht “TCope [Deferred]”
(Rations limited)
Started from the pier at 8 1/2COMMA A.M.COMMA arrived at the lighthouse at 8.40. there met M.C. Cope and party in a row boatCOMMA who wished us joyCOMMAand desired us to report all new discoveries; soon after we commenced telling fortunes. 2 m. of 9 o’clock saw a porpoise on the starboard side. 9.22. off fort AdamsCOMMA weatherCOMMA calmCOMMA thin canopy of cloudsCOMMA at this moment it was proposed to “put more steam on.” Three persons forward of the “Lobster Box.” progressCOMMA “slow but awfully sure.” 10. o’clockCOMMA interesting information concerning the compassCOMMA by Capt. Merritt. surf seen at Bever TailCOMMA fears entertained for the health of the party. Some excitement caused by the appearance of two fishCOMMA which produced restlessness on the part of the cabin boy – 10.11. opposite the Dumplings. 11 o’clock opposite Castle Hill the game of quintettes played with interest by the 1st mateCOMMA cookCOMMA and several of the passengers; the steward seiged with headache – at this time doubts were expressed by the captain as to the probability of the winds changing before 6 P.M. weather still calm. [8] m after 11. met a sailing vessel commanded by captain Henry MerrittCOMMA rowed by the capt. and sculled by Henry Merritt jr who hailed usCOMMA and threw a small lobster into the boat one of the passengers was badly bitten which caused great excitement untill she was rescued from the jaws of the carnivorous creature. 11 1/2 A.M. Slight windthe South and visibleCOMMA stood off to welcome it. Party regaled themselves with rations. 12. M. South wind continues. candy handed. Met a schooner and were saluted by a dog on board. Long swellsCOMMA health good. 12.10. conversation on the weather prohibited– a number of the passengers retired to rest – Cabin boy reclining on a passenger– cook on the dinner basket– 1st mate absorbed in a book. 12.45. Point Judith lighthouse in sight. After serious consideration it was decided to pursue our journey on which account three cheers were given. 12.50. Passing Bever Tail. three more cheers – passengers happy – saluted by the horn and a towel was waved to usCOMMA which compliment was returned passengers waving handkerchiefs. 2. P.M. Dinner – great dispute on the subject of ringing the triangle. 2.45. from “Lobster Box” end– dinner accomplished satisfactorily leaving the voyagers in a quiescent state of mind– dinner consisted of 9 courses closed with sour-drops– opposite M. Williams’- Bay comparatively speaking very rough! Fast passing Wickford – Slight excitement Fortunes being told again aft. The 1st mate has just restored the cabin to orderCOMMA after dinner. Aft becoming very impudent. Bow hair dressing. 1st matesweeping and thereby discomboberating all – 2.55. Patience in sight. sentiment in the bowCOMMA 3.12. Approaching the end of Canonicut Greenwich off the larboard bow. Patience and Rocky Pt. ahead. the breeze delightfulCOMMA and all of the party very comfortableCOMMA some readingCOMMA some working zephyr work. 3.20. Rounding the north end of Canonicut. Three cheers given by all the party. 3.35. P.M. Rounding Canonicut. Newport in view – on our homeward trip – breeze good. some of the party wishing to land we are going to (we did’nt) 3.38. Met the Providence steamboat- Needless anxiety on the part of the passengers. Now dashing gaily towards Newport. 3.55 Proceeding fondly – just played games of authors and consequences. 3 m. of 5.P.M. off the Lighthouse. health good. Fine breeze- Band tuning up for a song before we reach the pier. Arrived at the pier at 5.P.M. On first day evening we took a walk to Tammany Hill. we started after a 6 o’clock tea but were not able to get there untill dark or dusk. It is the first time I was ever there. We saw the lights at Point JudithCOMMA the Light ShipCOMMA Bever Tail and the Break water. Yesterday was splendidlyclear. In the morning we took a short floatCOMMA I cant call it a sail there wasn’t any windCOMMA after which we went bathing. In the afternoon I made up a small sailing party consisting of Alice CarterCOMMA Abby NewhallCOMMA Tom Longstreth and AlfredCOMMA we went out to the Dumplings and landedCOMMA & afterwards came back to take Caroline Mary her first sail. She could’nt have had a more pleasant evening it neither too cold nor too warmCOMMA & there was a splendid breeze. We went around Rose Island and got back in good season. though not strictly obeying her mothers instructions about being home at half past 6. This morning we went bathing as usual and also engaged the boatCOMMA Alfred preferring to go to Coddingtons Cove to bathing. Thee will observe that I’ve been getting about as much good out of boating as possible this season. Since we arrived Alf has become a staunch friend of Geo. Merritt’s and Hazen of Geo. Barlow’s. Its quite remarkable how devoted Alf isCOMMA he spends the big parts of his time at the reading room with George. This morning I got a new key fittedCOMMA formy valiseCOMMA having lost the other since my arrival. We were not able to mail these letters in time to go by the [La---] so they will have to take their chance by going via New York. There are 24 folks going to Philadelphia the night we goCOMMA which will make a pretty effectual change in Mary Williams’ boardersCOMMA and there will be no one left but Tom Longstreth to do the honors of the occasion. We are rather puzzled as to what to do if we were left by the 7 o’clock train from New YorkCOMMA since the 10 o’clock train has been taken off the line. We will have to run the riskCOMMA I supposeCOMMA of getting the 8.40COMMA Washington trainCOMMA stopped at Frankford. Having run out of news and since mother is also writing I will stop.
affecty thy son
T.P. Cope Jr.

University of Pennsylvania.

PhiladelphiaCOMMA July 17COMMA 1905

Dear Sir:--

Title: 1831 August 1COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Sister
Creator: Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Identified People: CopeCOMMA JasperCOMMA 1775-1856; StokesCOMMA MaryCOMMA 1825-1847; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890;
Unidentified People: Henry; Maryann; Frank; Anna Braithwaithes; Caroline; Jeremiah Hubard; A. Barker; Joel Woolman; Caleb; Abbeyann Cope; Martha;
Subject: Health; Letter writing; Family;
Transcript:
Philada 8th. mo 1st. 1831

I dare sayCOMMA my dear sisterCOMMA thee has felt inclined since we partedCOMMA sometimesCOMMA to apply to me the old adage with regard to promising people vis. thatCOMMA
“A ready maker
Is a ready breaker:”
since the offer to write to thee was entirely voluntary on my partCOMMA and yet I have suffered two weeksCOMMA nearlyCOMMA to pass without making an effort to fulfil my engagement.- As usualCOMMA I am rich in excuses--the most prominent of whichCOMMA is the impossibility I found in obtaining a certain direction to my letter; and either imagining the epistleCOMMA when completedCOMMA would be too valuable to be thrown awayCOMMA or else deemingCOMMA (I did not stop to analyze feelings)COMMA my time too precious to be expended upon that which would profit my correspondant nothingCOMMA I concluded to defer writing altogetherCOMMA until Henry came up to thisCOMMA our quarterly solemnity.---

And nowCOMMA having got thro’ the most important and generally most stupid part of epistolary communicationsCOMMA vis. the prefaceCOMMA let me dash at once into my stock of newsCOMMA and cull for thy benefit such pieces of information as will be likely to interest thee. I greatly fear the selection will be a small oneCOMMA for summer is a particularly unsocial seasonCOMMA unless it is with our most intimate friends and of courseCOMMA we hear but little of what is passing in
the world without.- I suppose thee will say it is respecting the movements of friends thee would wish to be informed; and if they would only do somethingCOMMA in the least degreeCOMMA and of the common lineCOMMA I should take great pleasure in transmitting an account of it to thee; but they are all pursuing their usual routine of occupationsCOMMA enjoying themselves in a most provoking state of quiescenceCOMMA and doing and saying nothing that would give use to any comments.----- Maryann tarried about two weeks at [Calcon]- HookCOMMA and she says passed her time very pleasantlyCOMMA notwithstanding the ungracious soundsCOMMA issuing from young master Frank’s mouthCOMMA which occasionally saluted her maidenly ears.-- I believe she could sayCOMMA very patheticallyCOMMA “I am never merry when I hear such musicCOMMA” she thinksCOMMA I imagineCOMMA that we need never apprehend consumption in the case of our little nephewCOMMA adoptingCOMMA as I opine she doesCOMMA Anna Braithwaites favorite maxim that all our facultiesCOMMA bodily as well as mentalCOMMA may be “strengthened by reason of use”.-- FatherCOMMA MotherCOMMA the aforenamed cousinCOMMA and myselfCOMMA spent a day with Caroline not long since.-- She seems quite comfortable and very well; she is fattening on cottage cheese and “lovelyCOMMA rich cream.” and fortifying her bodily powers by riding frequently on horse-back- Her darling son looks admirablyCOMMA walks boldly alone and chatters at a most rapid rate.* [Note at bottom edge of page: “lest thee should be led into the mistake of supposing himCOMMA even a more marvellous child than he really he isCOMMA I must state that his conversations are carried on in a language peculiar to himselfCOMMA and are quite unintelligible to ordinary hearers----“] I must do him the justice to say that he behaved himself very gentlemanly during the whole period of our visit and struttedabout in his apron of thy purchasingCOMMA (with whichCOMMA by the byeCOMMA he is delighted)COMMA with quite the air of a person of importance---------

We had a considerable collection of friends at our mansion during the whole time of the conference—Jeremiah Hubard and his wifeCOMMA two female friends from ProvidenceCOMMA and cousin A. Barker lodged with usCOMMA and they attracted others during the day—so that we had a real miniature yearly meeting-- With the consignment from your houseCOMMA we were allCOMMA I believeCOMMA much amused—Oh! if thee had but been present at the relation of their courtship given by the husbandCOMMA and heard the gentleCOMMA deprecatory tone in which the wife endeavored to ward off the narrationCOMMA & the very singular intonation of her voice in her exclamations of “ohCOMMA JeremiahCOMMA now dont”!! It was absolutely irresistible!—She has now gone with “cousin [Nat]” to visit her relations in VirginiaCOMMA and her better half has taken refuge from the intolerable heat of our cityCOMMA at Joel Woolman’s.—Now thisCOMMA I should say was “a bitter changeCOMMA severer for severeCOMMA” for a more exposedCOMMA comfortless-looking country dwelling I have seldom seen than the residence of this same milkman.--------

I hope the purchases I have made for thee will prove satisfactory—the cambricCOMMA I procured as nearly like Henry’s cravat as I could.—Do take notice of the beautiful picture on the cologne water bottle.- I have often heard of the angel of health coming with healing in his --
wingsCOMMA but the idea of being kicked into “salubrity” (to use Caleb’s phrase)COMMA is quite novelCOMMA and from the position in which the ministering spirit here standsCOMMA I should suppose the virtue lay in his heels—Uncle Jaspar’s family have been very regularly heard from.—Abbeyann is much better but Uncle’s eye still continues bad and they fear he will be obliged to have an operation performed when they reach Cincinnati.- I saw Martha on sixth day and never saw her look better--- Mother is somewhat improved—She and Father have at last fixed upon this week for leaving home.- the latter part of it I expect.—Mary Stokes is added to the party---- I have almost filled my sheet and have not said a word about the fire we had had—It was “horribly beautiful” but terribly allarming

Rachel R. Cope
DealI must refer thee to Henry for particulars.---- I am glad to hear the boys areenjoying themselves-- Give my love to them and tell them not to be tooventuresome.-- I dislike apologies about lettersCOMMA but in looking over this I cannotbut be struck with the triffling nature of its contents.—HoweverCOMMA the weather is too warm to be intellectualCOMMA even supposing I had it in my powerCOMMA and it is only on rare occasions that I am sentimental. Such as it isCOMMA I hope thee will deem it worthy an early reply to thy attached sister
Eleanor

Title: 1806 February 8 to Henry CopeCOMMA WestownCOMMA PA
Creator: Rachel Drinker
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881; CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; DrinkerCOMMA Henry W. (Henry Waln)COMMA 1787-1866
Unidentified People: ThomasCOMMA Arthur (born mid 1780s; son of John and Hannah Thomas); [Catherine]; cousin Lydia; MaryCOMMA Mary’s fatherCOMMA motherCOMMA and brother
Subject: Education; Society of Friends; Family; Ocean travel; Quakers--Travel; Transportation; Westtown Boarding School; Grandparent and child; Outdoor recreation; Faith
Notes: Though the date "1806?" has been applied to the letter in pencilCOMMA it seems more likely that it was written in 1807 or later because of the reference to Alfred Cope who was not born until April 1806.
Transcript:
Philada 2nd mo 8th [1806]

Dear Henry

I receivd thy letterCOMMA and am Pleasd to hear that there is a day set apart for letter writing as I hope we shall hear oftener from youCOMMA as writing is next to seing and talking with youCOMMA to tell you (for I include Frances) that I love youCOMMA and long to see youCOMMA would be like a tale twice toldCOMMA

your Cousin H D wrote from New Castle the 5th of the 2d moth that he was just setting of and expected to be at sea in 48 hoursCOMMA was much pleasd with the CaptainCOMMA they were detaind 2 weeks by the IceCOMMA He seemd to go of in pretty good speritsCOMMA as he went with the approbation of his FriendsCOMMA I have the pleasure to inform the that he appeard to be in an improving wayCOMMA I hope he will be preferred and kept in the road that leads to peace

I am glad to hear that the is contentedCOMMA and willing to stay and get all the instruction the canCOMMA I hope thee will get through all the branches so as to come home next Summerthe river is froze over and I saw a number of people on it as I return[e]d from Meeting this morning

Arther has not got into any Buiseness yetCOMMA & is Desir[ou]s of paying you a viset If he can get a Horse.

your Father & mother is wellCOMMA Caroline & allfred very livelyCOMMA mother is well of for help—Cousin Lydia is with me still and Sends her love to the and Francis as does [Catherine] except of a large Portion From your loveing grandmother

Rachel Drinker

mary’s Father and Mother & Brother have been commited to jail on suspion of Murder how it will go with them we can’t tell now I think I have told you all the news good and badHenry Cope
Westown
give my love to Friend
Sharpless

Title: 1858 August 4COMMA to Ruth Anna Cope
Creator: Julia K. Reeve
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903;
Unidentified People: Edward Biddle; Cousin Frank; Aunt Racel; Cousin Elizabeth; George; Cousin Thomas; Aunt Susan; Cousin John; Unlce Edward
Subject: Family;  Health; Letter writing; Child rearing; Europe--Description and Travel;
Transcript:
Awbury 8 mo 4th [1858]
Fourth day night

Dear NannyCOMMA

Its frightfully lateCOMMA and if I say so--thee may be sure it is late; my eyelids have told me so sometime sinceCOMMA and bedCOMMA over yonderCOMMA looks wonderous inviting--but remembering Uncle's last injunction to write-- I begin forth withCOMMA though thee must'nt expect much from sleepy folks--I only am going to deliver Uncles messageCOMMA which I have tried to remember and transcribe exactly in his words-- "We only desired thy return with Edward BiddleCOMMA thinking thee might not have another opportunity for some timeCOMMA if thee chooses to run the risk of another escort do so--" I have just been repeating this to Cousin Frank & he saysCOMMA oh tell Anna there will be some way of her getting home and to stay longerCOMMA if she wishes it--We
do not want thee at home till thee gets better--and get along pretty well without theeCOMMA I don't suppose Aunt Rachel fares quite so well as if thee were here--but I do try to do my best--Cousin Elizbt's letter of last eving told thee she was'nt quite well--she is some better to-day--and I hope tomorrow will be better still--(Oh my! There--I've actually fallen asleep over my letter--thee wont feel much complimented I'm afraid) Tell Clemmy we got her first letter--and think we are very remiss not to have ex[patiated] on its sweetness for [-]
Wellm [--rsis] Mother is on--some of us have called upon her yet--somebody must tomorrowCOMMA as she returns home Seventh day.
George sends his love--and I expect the folks generally wouldCOMMA
I forgot to ask them--
Farewell--I'm so dreadfully sleepy--thine Julie--

Oh my! I must wake up and tell thee we got letters this afternoon--Cos Thos expected to start in a sailing vessel from Havre on the 24 or 26th--So he's on the ocean now--tossing about--Poor fellow! Frank was travelling about in Scotland when last heard fromCOMMA and cousin Thos has advised him to return in a steamer thinking he could not reach Havre time enough to sail with him--Is'ent this too bad--to come home this wayCOMMA piece-meal--Cos Thos seems real blue--but rejoicing at the thoughts of home. he cannot be here before 30 daysCOMMA Uncle saysCOMMA
what a long time to wait--Is'ent it-- The [----] of love to Clemmy and Aunt Susan--and all the rest--tell the two former I hope they are attending to their [-obes]--the 29th is most here--and they're both going to have written invitations--they're names are down on the list--but the invitations are not written yet--
Anna thee must come home prepared to be very brightCOMMA and help me to remember my friends those to whom I must send cards--Cousin John thinks he cannot have his children now--tho he would like to go up for thee very wellCOMMA if they [---] well--They are very restless at nights--We expect Uncle Edward 6th or 7th day.--

Title: 1911 June 29COMMA DundaleCOMMA to Alg
Creator: Joe (Joseph Paul) Morris:  1879-1919
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911
Subject: Condolence notes;  Bereavement--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; Death
Notes:
Watermark: “Holland linen”

Algernon’s brotherCOMMA Ernest Mervyn EvansCOMMA died on June 28 after being injured in a subway accident.

Joseph Morris wrote the letter from DundaleCOMMA the Morris family estate in Villanova. Now part of the university’s campusCOMMA the mansion was erected in 1890 as a retreat from the city for Israel Morris’s son Theodore (who had just attained the presidency of Morris & WheelerCOMMA his father’s iron company) and his many children. The building currently houses the development offices of Villanova University.

All information from Stokes’ Stokes Cope Emlen Evans Genealogy (1982)COMMA the printed eulogy of Ernest Mervyn EvansCOMMA and various Villanova University websites. A picture of Dundale may be found online at www.villanova.edu/maps/bldgs/dundale.htm.
Transcript:
Dundale
June 29COMMA 1911

Dear AlgCOMMA

Thee and all the others know in part how I love you. I wish that my love and the love of all your friends were strong enough to be able and wise enough to know howCOMMA to come now and take your burden and bear it for you. We are bearing it with you.

But may He Whose Love is infinitely Strong and who doesunderstand and who is so close to youCOMMA give to all of you the assurance that He is indeed with you nowCOMMA bearing it with you and for you ever more than you can yourselves. May He put his unfailing arms around you and give you His Strength and His Comfort and His brave peace. And I know He will.

Dear ErnCOMMA still he will be ever near to me as I know he is to you all. May Christ always bring us nearer to Himselfand so nearer to each other. Dear AlgCOMMA I can only send thee and every member of thy family my truest love from my heart.

Thy lovingCOMMA
Joe.

Title: 1839 March 6COMMA to Elizabeth W. CopeCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Mary Stokes:  1825-1847
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; ComstockCOMMA Nathan D.COMMA 1821?-1839; KiteCOMMA EdithCOMMA 1777-1861; WalnCOMMA JosephCOMMA 1762?-1824?
Unidentified People: Benjamin Sharpless (two possibilities exist: B. SharplessCOMMA d. 1852COMMA member of Birmingham Monthly Meeting; B. SharplessCOMMA d. 1858COMMA member of Rock Creek Monthly Meeting); Uncle Samuel; Aunt Lydia; Cous. L.
Subject: Westtown Boarding School; Cold (Disease); Measles; Death--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; Tuberculosis; Funeral service--Society of Friends
Notes:
(in pencil: 1839 Eliz. Stokes married Jos. Hall & [later?] our [8th?] grandfather T.P. Cope; from Aunt Mary Stokes to “Aunt” 2nd wife of Thos. P. Cope)

Elizabeth Stokes Waln Cope was Mary Stokes’s great-aunt.

Thomas KiteCOMMA whose wife and daughter were mentioned in this letterCOMMA had two daughters. Susanna Kite Sharpless was the daughter of his first wife and was married by the time this letter was written. Rebecca KiteCOMMA later BrownCOMMA was the daughter of his second wife and was fifteen at the time the letter was written. The daughter mentioned is more likely the daughter of his second wifeCOMMA to whom he was married at the time of the letter.

The watermark is as follows: AmiesCOMMA underneath Phila and a drawing of a bird with a branch in its beak. The imprint is too faint to decipher.

The following text was written in pencil on the mailing information portion of the letterCOMMA in another handCOMMA probably that of Elizabeth Stewardson Cope: 1839 Eliz. Stokes married Jos. Hall & [later?] our [8th?] grandfather T.P. Cope from Aunt Mary Stokes to "Aunt" 2nd wife of Thos. P. Cope
Transcript:
3d moth 6th 1839

My Dear aunt

I expect this will be the last letter I shall write to thee this session as the time is drawing near when we shall go home. we are now reviewing and it is not so hard as I expected it would be we have to be very industrious [about] our studies as some of them are very hard particularly the history and I am very much afraid I shall fail in that at examination as the greater part of it I have not learned for I have not been in that classCOMMA all the session. Thomas Kite’s wife is here spending a day or two and her daughter also. I suppose thee has heard of the little boy who has been so ill here he was taken with the measles and that layed the foundation for the consumption and after suffering for a long time he was taken away at three o clock in the morning of the first of spring we had no school on six or seventh day but we all went to our school rooms and red our bibles and on seventh day morning we were taken into see his corpse and he was buried on seventh day afternoon his name was Nathan Comstock and he was an orphan he lived in Lockport New York he has a brother and sister here and his sister is a lovely girl but I know very little about his brother. Benjamin Sharpless was here to thee funeral and he asked me if I had ever seen him at Tommy Cope’s and I told him no.COMMA but I have often heard of him. I am looking for uncle Samuel to come and see me as he has been away so long and I think he might come to see me this session
Aunt Lydia is not at all well she has a very bad cold and a good deal of pain in that lump on her face and she keep her bed the greater part of the day but she is rathe better at present than she has been lately I think she would of been better if she had not of gone down to supper last night through the cold entry. I have some things to write for and I do not think I shall have any more time to write to thee. Cousin L sends her respects to all of you. but I send my love to all be lieve me as ever thy affectionate niece

Mary Stokes JrThomas P Cope
For Elizabeth W Cope
No 272 Spruce St
Philadelphia

Title: 1867 July 28COMMA Laurel HouseCOMMA to Father
Creator: Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; BrownCOMMA JohnCOMMA 1800-1859; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; StokesCOMMA Tom (Thomas Pym Cope)COMMA 1843-1918;    CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; EmlenCOMMA Eleanor CopeCOMMA 1854-1920; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1850-1924; CopeCOMMA MargaretCOMMA 1856-1948; CopeCOMMA RuthannaCOMMA 1834-1879; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA WalterCOMMA 1861-1902;
Unidentified People: Georges? (might be a hotel name)
Subject: Family; Overweight children; Health; Mountains--New York (State); Dentures; Outdoor recreation; Brothers and sisters; Quakers--Voyages and Travels; Transportation; Nature;
Geographic Subjects: Newport (R.I.); Halifax (N.S.); Boston (Mass.); Albany (N.Y.);  Adirondack Mountains (N.Y.); Lake Placid (N.Y.)
Transcript:
Laurel House
7th mo. 28th. 1867.

Dear Father
Lilly and Chelly having been keeping up such an active correspondence by the last two steamersCOMMA I thought I would reserve my efforts untill they had got through.
We received a letter from uncle Tom inclosing a letter from thee informing us of the loss of thy masticatorsCOMMA it would have been remarkably unfortunate if thee had not had an extra set with thee. I hope by this time thee is enjoying thyself on terra firmaCOMMA but since the difference of time between where thee is and where we are is so greatCOMMA we find it hard to guess what thee is about. We received letters from home last nightCOMMA dated the 25th.COMMA saying they were all well and preparing to leave for Newport on 5th day. Mother had also received a letter from thee mailed at Halifax
On last 6th day we rode to Stony CloveCOMMA an entirely new place to meCOMMA about 10 miles distant. The road is quite roughCOMMA and runs between two mountainsCOMMA one of which rises almost perpendicularly about 1000 ftCOMMA as near as we could judgeCOMMA and on each side there are large rocks under which we found ice: they say the sun never gets there and the ice under the rocks never melts during the summer. On approaching this place the air becomes perceptably cooler and on leaving it becomes warm again. We took dinner at a little farm house and although it was plain weenjoyed it very much. After dinner we had to leave right away for home. Going back we had a splendid view of those distant mountains you see on your way to the Plauterkill Clove.
Yesterday morning weCOMMA that is Tom StokesCOMMA HarryCOMMA some other gentlemen and myselfCOMMA walked down to Bastion Falls to take a bathCOMMA thee remembers what a fine basin there is at the foot of the fallsCOMMA well it was there we went in; the water was pretty cool on first going in but after we had been in a little whileCOMMA and had kicked around a good bit we got quite warm and all in a glow. We went under the fall where it hit the rocks for a second timeCOMMA but even there the water stung like hail-stonesCOMMA and I preferredthe pool to getting such a warming as that. In the afternoon we walked over to the Mountain House to see the viewCOMMA on starting it was beautifully clear but when we had gone about half wayCOMMA two cloudsCOMMA very consideratelyCOMMA came rolling down upon usCOMMA one from North and one from South mountainCOMMA and by the time we got to the precipice both the view and ourselves were completely mistified; we accordingly went into the House and got weighedCOMMA and since thee will not object to hearing how much some of the members of thy immediate family weighCOMMA I will give thee part of the table:
R.R.C. 125 lbs. E.S.C. 98 lbs. T.P.C. 90 lbs. Rachel has gained 7 lbs. since last sum- merCOMMA and its becoming quite dreadful; I'm afraidCOMMA if she goes on gainingCOMMA we will be obliged to have her put up in a barrel and roll her home from Newport. Tom StokesCOMMA EllieCOMMA MadjieCOMMA and Walter are going home tomorrow morning: the rest of us expect to leave here fourth day and go to AlbanyCOMMA we will stay there that nightCOMMA and go to Boston the next day; leaving Boston 6th. day afternoon we will arrive at Newport in time for tea. I suppose mother has told thee that she succeeded in engaging both the Georges during our stay there. The weather here has been very warm and showery; to day it is very pleasant but it has been so very showery we were afraid to try going to walk. Aunt Lizzie received two letters from the Adirondacks to day one from cousin Clemmy and one from aunt AnnieCOMMA giving an account of a trip which they had taken to lake Placid by the way of John Brown's grave; aunt Annie said the grave was very plainCOMMA there was a tombstone with some engraving on it and on a boulder nearby was the plain inscription "John Brown - 1859." She also said cousin Clemmy was a good deal stronger and was able to bear fatigue as well as the rest of them They were both very much surprised to hear of thy sudden leaving for England. Lilly and Chelly send their love. We are all well and have had a most splendid time considering that our "pa" is on the other side of the Atlantic and now having given thee all the news I can remember I will stop.
affectionately
thy son Thos P. Cope Jr

Title: 1839 January 10COMMA West HaverfordCOMMA to Anna S. BrownCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Thomas S. Brown:  b. 1828
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916;        SmithCOMMA Daniel B.COMMA 1792-1883; DavisCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1814; DavisCOMMA IsaacCOMMA 1783-1849; DavisCOMMA Mary W.COMMA 1785-1864; StewardsonCOMMA RachelCOMMA 1793?-1839; StewardsonCOMMA AnnCOMMA 1798?-1883
Subject: Education; Family; Haverford College--Students; Health; Outdoor recreation; Brothers and sisters; Obedience; Tonics (Medicinal preparations)
Notes:
Letter is written in three different hands.

Notes probably written later:
“1.10.1839 –
Uncle Tom & Uncle Will write to Mother from Haverford. Elizabeth Davis daughter of Isaac ” the SuperintendantCOMMA afterward because Eliz. FarnumCOMMA also writes & tell how the little boys are getting on.”
Transcript:
1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are all wellCOMMA My cold is quite well. Freind Mary Davis sends her love to Mother. I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so much better andCOMMA I hope that she will continue soCOMMA and I am glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out How is Aunt Hannah and uncle ThosCOMMA and Harry Where is Williams slipers I think ought to be done. It snowed last night there a little. The green house is nearly finished but the plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good sleding. It is tirsome work to write a letterCOMMA Dan B Smith give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as thoes that thee expects to attend he showes us so many pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to have a kiss from Fanny I will send her one down below I expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to I [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou I remain thy aff brother
Thos S Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his letterCOMMA inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding page – Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or twoCOMMA in consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye – It was occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in the hand of one of his companionsCOMMA & seem’d at first rather disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly that it occasions no inconvenienceCOMMA & is but slightly discoloured – He seems to think that eye is particularly unfortunateCOMMA as it is the same one which was hurt some time ago – I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about itCOMMA as we shall try to take all necessary care of himCOMMA if any more is needed – In regard to being careful himselfCOMMA he needs some few cautionsCOMMA tis true – but I will tell it to his creditCOMMA that for an activeCOMMA adventurous little boy he is very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises to adopt itCOMMA isCOMMA I believeCOMMA very scrupulous in fulfilling them. He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement in doorsCOMMA by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have found it quite entertaining – I think it arrived just at the right moment – So much for Thomas –. now for Willie – with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit in our parlor – He tells me – he is more comfortable than formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved – what this cause wasCOMMA I do not know – but he looks so pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not depressed by any great weight of troubles – They are very different boys but both have found means to interest me warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.

Jeremiah Brown
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee for some time I am glad to see that thee is so much better than thee was when I last heard from thee I was astonished to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much. Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in this letter I was disapointed as well as thyself for I expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company staid out a half an hour I hope when thee gets perfectly well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one of thee boys I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete baby house with old black [---] amongst them I hope by the next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly well I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the holy land in two volumes by an American I found it very interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a botany for William but I never received it and I should like to know wether you sent it or not Tom is very much pleased with his present I have no more room sister so I will haft to bid adieu at present thine [ever] – W.A. My dear Anna
I promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his letterCOMMA inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding page – Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or twoCOMMA in consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye – It was occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in the hand of one of his companionsCOMMA & seem’d at first rather disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly that it occasions no inconvenienceCOMMA & is but slightly discoloured – He seems to think that eye is particularly unfortunateCOMMA as it is the same one which was hurt some time ago – I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about itCOMMA as we shall try to take all necessary care of himCOMMA if any more is needed – In regard to being careful himselfCOMMA he needs some few cautionsCOMMA tis true – but I will tell it to his creditCOMMA that for an activeCOMMA adventurous little boy he is very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises to adopt itCOMMA isCOMMA I believeCOMMA very scrupulous in fulfilling them. He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement in doorsCOMMA by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have found it quite entertaining – I think it arrived just at the right moment – So much for Thomas –. now for Willie – with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit in our parlor – He tells me – he is more comfortable than formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved – what this cause wasCOMMA I do not know – but he looks so pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not depressed by any great weight of troubles – They are very different boys but both have found means to interest me warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy affectionate
E.H. Davis.

Title: 1839 January 10COMMA West HaverfordCOMMA to Anna S. BrownCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Elizabeth H.  Farnum:  1814-1898?
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916;        SmithCOMMA Daniel B.COMMA 1792-1883; DavisCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1814; DavisCOMMA IsaacCOMMA 1783-1849; DavisCOMMA Mary W.COMMA 1785-1864; StewardsonCOMMA RachelCOMMA 1793?-1839; StewardsonCOMMA AnnCOMMA 1798?-1883
Subject: Education; Family; Haverford College--Students; Health; Outdoor recreation; Brothers and sisters; Obedience; Tonics (Medicinal preparations)
Notes:
Letter is written in three different hands.

Notes probably written later:
“1.10.1839 –
Uncle Tom & Uncle Will write to Mother from Haverford. Elizabeth Davis daughter of Isaac ” the SuperintendantCOMMA afterward because Eliz. FarnumCOMMA also writes & tell how the little boys are getting on.”
Transcript:
1 moth 10. 5 day 1839
Dear sister

I hope you are all wellCOMMA My cold is quite well. Freind Mary Davis sends her love to Mother. I am glad to hear that Aunt Ann is so much better andCOMMA I hope that she will continue soCOMMA and I am glad also that thee is getting well enough to walk out How is Aunt Hannah and uncle ThosCOMMA and Harry Where is Williams slipers I think ought to be done. It snowed last night there a little. The green house is nearly finished but the plants are not yet aranged. we have had some pretty good sleding. It is tirsome work to write a letterCOMMA Dan B Smith give our class a lecture evry 5th day on chemestry and they are [very] interesting and quite as much so I expect as thoes that thee expects to attend he showes us so many pretty experements with all sorts of gases I would like to have a kiss from Fanny I will send her one down below I expect she had a lot of presents and pretty ones to I [like] Rollo very well and I have read it all through and part of it to E Davis I send My love to all ofyou I remain thy aff brother
Thos S Brown
Kiss


Haverford–
My dear Anna
I promised thy little brother to add a postscript to his letterCOMMA inasmuch as he thought he should be unable to fill the sheet – but he has left me so much room that I believe I shall have to call in William’s aid to clothe the preceding page – Thos. has been in the parlor for a day or twoCOMMA in consequence of a bruise he has received on his eye – It was occasioned entirely by an accidental blow from a stick in the hand of one of his companionsCOMMA & seem’d at first rather disposed to be troublesome – but by a faithful application of lead-water yesterday it is nearly recovered – so nearly that it occasions no inconvenienceCOMMA & is but slightly discoloured – He seems to think that eye is particularly unfortunateCOMMA as it is the same one which was hurt some time ago – I do not think thy mother need feel uneasy about itCOMMA as we shall try to take all necessary care of himCOMMA if any more is needed – In regard to being careful himselfCOMMA he needs some few cautionsCOMMA tis true – but I will tell it to his creditCOMMA that for an activeCOMMA adventurous little boy he is very well disposed to take advice – & when he makes promises to adopt itCOMMA isCOMMA I believeCOMMA very scrupulous in fulfilling them. He has beguiled some of the hours of his confinement in doorsCOMMA by reading “Rollo’s vacation” to me – & we have found it quite entertaining – I think it arrived just at the right moment – So much for Thomas –. now for Willie – with whom I am becoming better acquaintedas the ice is now broken – & he frequently pays us a visit in our parlor – He tells me – he is more comfortable than formerly – & that the cause of his unhappiness is re-moved – what this cause wasCOMMA I do not know – but he looks so pleasant & happy that I am inclined to believe he is not depressed by any great weight of troubles – They are very different boys but both have found means to interest me warmly for them – & I think I shall not soon cease to love them – Tom is sitting by me begging me to proceed – but the end of my paper warns me that I may already have tired thee – therefore will take the hint after desiring my love to thy mother – and assuring thee of
the friendship of thy affectionate
E.H. Davis.



WestHaverford
Jan 11th.

Jeremiah Brown
Philadelphia
For- Anna S. BrownDear – Sister
I received thy letter on 5th day morning and it was very acceptable for I have not had one from thee for some time I am glad to see that thee is so much better than thee was when I last heard from thee I was astonished to find that Aunt Ann was so much better – I had no Idea that she was able to walk out I dare say from thy accounts that thee enjoyed thy walk thee other – day very much. Elisabeth Davis has been kind enough to write to thee in this letter I was disapointed as well as thyself for I expected we would have fine slaying for sometime however we all had a slay ride half an hour long that is each company staid out a half an hour I hope when thee gets perfectly well if [their] is good slaying thee will come out with one of thee boys I expect Fanny Brown is highly delighted with her presents [and] I expect she will fix up the old closet in the nursery with pillows and curtains and have a complete baby house with old black [---] amongst them I hope by the next letter we will receive news that thee has got perfectly well I have just read travels in Arabia [Peatrea] and the holy land in two volumes by an American I found it very interesting thee sent word some time ago something about a botany for William but I never received it and I should like to know wether you sent it or not Tom is very much pleased with his present I have no more room sister so I will haft to bid adieu at present thine [ever] – W.A. BrownI thought I would haft to stop but Elisabeth Davis proposed to me to cross it I have accordingly done it The snow as not yet left us and we had a little more on 4th day evening last How is mother and father I have not heard from them for sometime somehow or other thee always leaves them out in thy letters Aunt Rachel is better [she] says I should like to know what is the matter with her for her diseas seems very changeble dont thee think dear sister that it is singular that I never write to my Aunts and uncles for most other boys do I have never yet attempted it however I suppose it is just as well that I should not but I think I would like to write to Grandmother or father some of [these] days but I dont know I dont suppose that I should hardly know how as I never done such a thing. My cold has now got very well indeed at least It is all gone now. I now often go into Friend Davis’s parlour and I found it very pleasent I am at present here and spend many a happ evening I expect that they will be surprised to find three difrent hands in this letter and I am rather inclined to think that it was worth the postage. I will now haft to end in good earnest

Title: 1806 June 19 to Henry and FrancisCOMMA Weston
Creator: Rachel Drinker
Identified People: CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; ThomasCOMMA John D.; ThomasCOMMA HannahCOMMA 1760-1806
Unidentified People: cousins  (too many to list); Arthur (probably Arthur ThomasCOMMA a cousin of HenryCOMMA FrancisCOMMA and John); Henry (probably Henry Waln DrinkerCOMMA 1787-1866)
Subject: Bereavement--Religious aspects--Society of Friends;  Family; Health; Quakers--Death; Westtown Boarding School; Quakers--Travel; Faith; Society of Friends
Notes: Written by two different authors; announcing the death of Hannah DrinkerCOMMA 1760-1806.
Transcript:
6th mo 19th 1806.
Dear Henry & Francis
I have been to meetingCOMMA cald at your houseCOMMA after it broke up your dear mother handed me a letter from FrancisCOMMA she was so kind as to send me Henrys last letterCOMMA where I was affection[ate]ly rememberd and expressing a desire that I should not forget you no be asurd I never Shall while I retain my sencesCOMMA I have Had a great deal of trouble since I saw you I have seen a dear loving Daughter go before meCOMMA. to enjoy the fruits of a well Spent lifeCOMMA I Continue with poor Uncle and JohnnyCOMMA thay request me not to leave themCOMMA we have had pleasent accounts of the Conduct of of your & CousinsCOMMA and are in dayly expectation of seeing themCOMMA poor lads they will be much affected when thay comeCOMMA they will not be likely to hear of the chang that has taken place since they left us till they arive. I want very much to see youCOMMA I hope you will come and pay us a visitCOMMA I am still Favoured with HealthCOMMA and that you may enjoy that Blessing is the Desire of your affectinate Grandmother
Rachel DrinkerDear Cousins

Our dear Grandmother is Kind enough to permit me to add a few lines to her letter– I wish it was in my power to communicate to you something that would afford pleasure. But alas! I have lived to see the melancholy period that death has seperated from me one of the best of mothersCOMMA whose affection I believe I possessed; and that I loved her with sincere affectionCOMMA affords me no small share of consolation– She suffered much during her illnessCOMMA but such was her Christian fortitude that she never discovered the least impatienceCOMMA and constantly maintained her usual cheerful serenity of mindCOMMA which was her characteristic through a life of trials. It was painful to see her suffer so much bodily painCOMMA but infinitly more so to see her breath her lastCOMMA a[l]though she suffered not the pangs of deathCOMMA but passed from this terrestrial world to one where peaceCOMMA happiness and pleasure reign triumphantly; and where she now enjoys the blissful harvest of a spotless and well spent life– Such has been the immutable decree of heaven to deprive me of an affectionate Mother and you an affectionate Aunt– We are still blest with having our dear Grandmother to cheer us– She enjoysher usual healthCOMMA which I hope she may enjoy for years to come–
The last letter we received from Arthur states that he and Cousin Henry are both wellCOMMA and expect to leave the West Indies very shortly; we of course expect them daily–
Uncle is at present in good healthCOMMA and I hope will long continue so; here I must close this short epistle and hope that I will see you before long – I remain your affectionate
cousin
John D Thomas6 mo. 19th 1806
Henry Cope
