Creator: Joe (Joseph Paul) Morris:  1879-1919
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939;        EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA Jacqueline Pascal MorrisCOMMA 1886-1947; Dorcas (Biblical figure);
Unidentified People: Nat GrotonCOMMA Miss Richardson (a nurse?)
Subject: Ocean Voyages and Travels;  Voyages and Travels--Religious aspects--Christianity; Bible--N.T.; Crusades--ThirdCOMMA 1189-1192; Tipping; Palestine--Description and Travel;
Geographic Subjects: Jaffa (Tel AvivCOMMA Israel); Haifa (Israel); Palestine; Beirut (Lebanon); Damascus (Syria); HermonCOMMA Mount (Lebanon and Syria); Galilee (Israel); Sabastiyah (Israel); Jerusalem; CarmelCOMMA Mount (Israel); Acre (Israel)
Notes:
Letter is from the steamer Dalmatia. Stationery bears crest in blue with the word“Vorwaerts” (forwardCOMMA in German) under an anchor and crown. Underneath crest are the words “Oesterreichischer Lloyd. Triest.” Large watermark depicting a crown and the words “Imperial Century.”

The city of Acre was captured by King Philip Augustus of France and King Richard the Lion-Hearted of England during the Third Crusade (1189-1192).

BakshishCOMMA stemming from the Persian for “to giveCOMMA” means to tip.

The stories of TabithaCOMMA Simon the TannerCOMMA and Peter’s vision are from Acts 9:26-10:15. Peter raised Tabitha (also called Dorcas)COMMA a charitable womanCOMMA from the dead in the town of Joppa. He stayed there at the home of Simon the Tanner (today the house is open for visitors)COMMA where he had his vision of animals trapped in a sheetCOMMA which the Lord bade him to eat. When he refusedCOMMA protesting that the Lord had designated some of them unclean for consumptionCOMMA the Lord repliedCOMMA “What God hath cleansedCOMMA make not thou common.” Following this visionCOMMA Peter visited a Gentile named Cornelius and widened the scope of Christian ministry (then practiced within JudaismCOMMA as it was considered unclean for a Jew to minister to a Gentile) to include those outside the Jewish faith.
Transcript:
Str. “Dalmatia”COMMA Oct. 28COMMA 1911.

Dear AlgCOMMA

I meant or wanted to write to thee soonerCOMMA but thought I would wait until we were really touching Palestine. I have my map at hand in the case which thee presented meCOMMA and I think it is going to be fine. So far nothing is blocking our plans – neithercholera nor fanaticism aroused by war – and we are due at Beirut tomorrow to go on to Damascus and take a two or three weeks’ trip across country to HermonCOMMA GalileeCOMMA and SamariaCOMMA and so down to Jerusalem. To-day we have been lookingCOMMA from our shipCOMMA up at nothing less than Mount Carmel. Haifa as thee knows is built at its foot and is of course very picturesque. Part of the mountain’s sides is bare and brownCOMMA ratherCOMMA but part is covered with small treesCOMMA carob and oakCOMMA I believeCOMMA which isa very pretty sight. Six or seven miles up the coast we can see Acre with all its crusading associations. And as we have been thinking of some of the associations of Mount Carmel it is of course intensely interesting. I have a fine pair of number eight binoculars which add to our enjoyment greatly.

Nat Groton and I get along very well. He is very patient with me; my awkwardness and unnecessary anxiety in giving fees must be a great source of trial tohimCOMMA but he bears it well. With all these fellows coming after you and towards you and around you for “bakshish” all the timeCOMMA it is very trying sometimes. Yesterday I had my first – and I hope my lastCOMMA as it is not pleasant – experience of being cursed up and down and out and out by one of the fellows who brought us out again to the Steamer from JaffaCOMMA for giving too little bakshish.

We went ashore forpart of the day yesterday at JaffaCOMMA or JoppaCOMMA which was our first contact with Palestine. It was not calculated to be sentimental. The disembarking is not easyCOMMA for there is no harborCOMMA and the rowboats are hard to get into from the steamer. As I stepped downCOMMA the boat happened to sink in the trough of a wave and I had the queer feeling of stepping down into space.We were rowed in in a pelting rainCOMMA tooCOMMA which made the little streets of Joppa literally inches deep with – not mudCOMMA but filth. The old tomb of Tabitha was only discovered recentlyCOMMA but is old. The “house of Simon the tanner” may well have been in a different place from the one which is shown you. But after you think it overCOMMA these things make no difference. It is Joppa. And the tanner’s house was just the sort of one which is shownCOMMA and hisbusiness was a tanneryCOMMA I suppose to make leather bottles for water and wine. His house no doubt opened out on unclean courtsCOMMA and he was contaminated in Jewish eyes by touching dead animalsCOMMA swine at that. So where was a better place than such a little houseCOMMA with its unclean factory in the midst and its flat roof looking out to sea and its host none the less hospitable for any of these thingsCOMMA for Peter to be prepared for his wonderful vision? And in this needyCOMMA little town Tabitha did live. And thesame intensely interestingCOMMA picturesque life goes on its crookedCOMMA little streets and alleys to-day. We saw a man sittingCOMMA grinding meal between an upper and a lower mill-stoneCOMMA small onesCOMMA the upper of which he turned by hand. We squeezed by long strings of camelsCOMMA and walked through swarms of turbaned Arabs. There are lots of other interesting things in Joppa which stay with you in spite of the filth through which you wadeCOMMA and the variegated odors which assail your nostrilsCOMMA but I must stop now. Please give my love to thy motherCOMMA and AnnaCOMMA and HaroldCOMMA and my kind remembrances to Miss RichardsonCOMMA and if I may still trouble theeCOMMA much love to Jac and EdCOMMA and thyself

from Joe.

Title: 1905 August 27COMMA Northeast HarborCOMMA MeCOMMA to Jonnie
Creator: William Draper Lewis:  1867-1949
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976;        MikellCOMMA   William EphraimCOMMA 1868-1945;
Unidentified People: Henry Lewis; Kratz
Subject: Law students--United States;  Weather; Health;
Notes: Watermark reads “Old Berkshire Mills 1895”
Transcript:
WD. Lewis
8 mo 27. 05

North East HarborCOMMA Me
Aug 27- ‘05

My dear JonnieCOMMA

We have not heard from the crime paper. EdwardCOMMA howeverCOMMA I happen to know has a [--] in itCOMMA as Mikell used his paper as a model for the person he secured to read the other papers. This is not publicinformationCOMMA though there is no reason why Edward should not know. You ought to be proud of that boy. He has not only done well -- he has done splendidlyCOMMA and I understand that either he or his friend Kratz leads the class with higher marks than we have given in the first year for several years. Good brains have helpedCOMMA - but hard steady work has been the realfactor. Two things gave me special satisfaction; one that I did not know his handwritingCOMMA and the other that I had marked him higher than anyone else in my subjectCOMMA writing across the face of his paper just after reading it: “a Jim dum dandy man”.

Father is a great deal better – up and about. I have just returned from Narragansett. Weather perfect here.uppose it is also with you. All send love.

Affectionately

Wm. Draper Lewis

Title: N.D. to Chellie
Creator: Joanna Sophia Buffum
Identified People: EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939;        BuffumCOMMA Joanna Sophia
Unidentified People: Mother (Joanna’s mother); Baby William [Buffum]; Anna; Mary Jane
Subject: Child rearing;  Nannies; Clothing and dress--Cleaning; Women domestics; Domestics
Notes: Undated.
Transcript:
Dear Chellie –
I was very sorry not to answer thy note myselfCOMMA but under the circumstances knew thee would not expect it. But Mother wrote thee I suppose all that was necessary – If thee will write to me a little nearer the timeand tell us when & where to meet Mary Jane and her trunk I shall be much obliged. If she should turn out a satisfactory nurse for the childrenCOMMA I should be very much pleased. Of courseCOMMA I shall be with them most of the time myself tooCOMMA as I fear I belong to the [measy] class of mothers. We have beenwanting a Protestant nurse as my experience with the Romanists is that when pushed to the wall they will sometimes tell an untruth. I thought of giving Mary J. $2.00 a week for the first two months & $2.50 for the next two. Then if she should not wish to go home with youCOMMA & I should wish to keep herCOMMA she would be entitled to full nurse’s wages. Won’t thee please tell me what that ought to be? The nurses from New York here get such an enormous amount that I thought she might be willing to take what the Philadelphia nurses do - Her duties will be most of the care of the babiesCOMMA the mendingCOMMA & a few things of the baby’s to wash; this with her own wash & her own room will be about all.
ThenCOMMA as we have never had a Protestant servantCOMMA there is anotherquestion I want to ask. Would she probably be satisfied to go to Church in the evening regularly instead of 1st day morning? Then I could go myself in the morning – and what shall I give her in the way of “days out”? I don’t know anything about nurses but our two other servants expect an afternoon a week and most of every other Sunday – Now this wouldbe very inconvenient for a nurse to do; & if she would be satisfied with any thing lessCOMMA it would be better. I am anxious to begin the way we mean to keep onCOMMA as changing ones rules after once starting is not very easy to do.
If it is not too much bother I should be ever so much obliged if thee would adviseme a little on these points –
Baby [William] & I are doing very well. We think him a great addition to the family. The weather is not sufficiently mild yet for him to don Anna’s pretty little cap & take a strollCOMMA but it will not be long before we will both be out in the fields –
I am so glad you are to be in the Dea’s [Cotage] this summer – It is quite accessible from here & I shall often get hold of Anna –
In haste Believe me
Affectionately Thine
Joanna Sophia Buffum
Greencroft. Fifth day morning.

Title: 1865 April 25COMMA BaltimoreCOMMA to Net
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: BeecherCOMMA Thomas KinnicutCOMMA 1824-1900; YarnallCOMMA Francis CopeCOMMA 1830-1890; CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; CareyCOMMA SusanCOMMA 1821-1913; BeecherCOMMA Henry WardCOMMA 1813-1887; M’KimCOMMA J. Miller (James Miller)COMMA 1810-1874; MatthewsCOMMA Susan; KimberCOMMA AnthonyCOMMA 1824?-1917; EdgeCOMMA Elizabeth D.; YarnallCOMMA Mary
Unidentified People: Alford CoaleCOMMA Mary PennymanCOMMA Jenny HarrisCOMMA Lizzie HopkinsCOMMA Mrs. [MCaff---]COMMA and Ellen Carey
Subject: LincolnCOMMA AbrahamCOMMA 1809-1865--Assassination;  Clothing and dress; Bible--Study and teaching--Society of Friends; Freedmen--United States; Society of Friends
Notes:
“64” written in pencil and is an incorrect date.
CrosshatchedCOMMA and stricken throughCOMMA are the words “They have very nice school books” — the crosshatching matches the orientation of the text on the front page of the first sheet and is perpendicular to the text on the back page.
crosshatched along left side: “[this?] [scribble] [week?] & think I should write to”]

The lack of connection between subject matters in the first two and second two pages of the letterCOMMA the different sizes of the two sheets of paperCOMMA and the style of pagination indicate that the sheets may be from two separate letters. AdditionallyCOMMA the letter has no closing.

The town of Athensville is mentioned in the letter. Situated several miles from PhiladelphiaCOMMA Athensville was named in 1811 by Dr. James AndersonCOMMA a local landholder. Athensville was rechristened Ardmore (Gaelic for high ground or hill) in 1873.
Transcript:
Baltimore 4.25.

Dear NetCOMMA
I have just got thy letter of the 1st to the 19th inclusiveCOMMA (where has it been so long?) Its very well I did’nt go on with the great scold I began yesterday — I thotCOMMA I wld defer it one day longer & see – Why I dont believe you know how long you’ve been neglecting meCOMMA & thee must remember while thee’s journalizing that thy writing every day is’nt my getting itCOMMA. However it was very interesting if not very late news. Thee does’nt say a word about having got either of my last lettersCOMMA I hope the one containing my elaborate sketch of the Environs of the city & my room as a centreCOMMA did not get lostCOMMA as it wld. have been a waste of artistic effort.
The presidents death has indeed made mourning in our land. The ways of Providence are very inscrutable. I told you in my last letter of the feeling produced hereCOMMA so I will notrevert to it.. The day of the funeral procession here was very solemn. We dismissed our schoolCOMMA & went by particular invitation to where we cld. have an excellent view of the whole as it passedCOMMA at the store of an old gentleman in market stCOMMA where we had a room to ourselves & refreshments provided wh. seemed rather singular but is his custom. It was the most touching & mournful procession I ever saw Perhaps you saw it in Phila. It will take a long time to forget the grief & horror of this sad eventCOMMA– but work has to be done & yesterday our sch. began [afresh] after the interruptions of the week beforeCOMMA & while sch. lasts we are forced to forget every thing but the work before us. It is what you might call intense work. & wld. be wearing [--] [----] [----] if incessant. Thy description of getting homeCOMMA & the nice clean room & all most made me home-sick. I miss great many of the little home luxuries and cleannesses hereCOMMA– but cannot expect to have them in boarding. We dont get any good Mrs [Mcaff--] [----] [butter] &c — excepting when we get invited out to our rich frds.
I was perfectly charmed with my visit at Carey’s last 6th day night. Their place is perfectly magnificent & the house keeping altogether princely compared to this. I went out in the afternoon & returned next morning. Their house situated on the tip top of a [very] hill seems like something up in the airCOMMA & the view splendidSusan Carey has gone to Phil. & expects to return next 7 or 2 day. She very kindly offered to bring anything for me — said she wld. have room for any sized bundleCOMMA so that I might get my silk skt. But it is so late in the season that I think I can do without itCOMMA & I shd. not like to ask her to bring so large a thing. I wld. like tho’ to have my old blk. silk body & I wish thee wld send me a little brown grenadine bag of horse hair in the right hand corner of my upper beaureau drawer. These things however are not very importantCOMMA & you need not send them if inconvenient.+ [+Perhaps you can send them by T Miller instead.] S Carey stays at Anthony Kimbers cor. 13. & Arch. I yesterday recd the skt. sent by Alford Coale for wh. I am much obliged. Mary Pennyman called yesterday & was very pleasantLizzie Hopkins of the house where Lizzie EdgeCOMMA Jenny Harris &c staidCOMMA called to see me alsoCOMMA & some Matthews wh. lives in the country said Lizzie E had written to her that I was here & that she intended to invite me out to her place in the countryCOMMA a very pleasant one I understand. A gentleman called here night before last — Miller M Kim whom you have perhaps heard of — one of the Freedmens board in Phila. & [----] me a message frm. Cous. Frank whom he had seen the day before. Tho’ a stranger he seemed quite like somebody from home. To night I am going with H Lytle to the frds. bible classCOMMA meeting at Dr. Thomas’ — it is attended by frds. mostlyCOMMA altho’ Ellen Carey who is an episcopalean & one or two others attend. They say it is very interestingCOMMA tho’ I have’nt been before. A few days ago I went to hear Thomas Beecher a (brother of H Wards) speakCOMMA but was disappointedCOMMA as it was nothing very interesting. I cld. not make out by thy journal exactly when your visit to Aunt C’s began or endedCOMMA but am glad you had a nice time. Give my love to them & tell them I hope they’ll ans. my note. Love also to Cous. F & M. You were quite enterprising to walk up to Athensville. I am going to try & write to Tom

Title: 1806 June 9 to Henry and FrancisCOMMA Weston School
Creator: Rachel Drinker
Identified People: CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873; CopeCOMMA JasperCOMMA 1775-1856; CopeCOMMA Rebecca ShoemakerCOMMA 1781-1853
Unidentified People: “Auther” (probably Arthur ThomasCOMMA a cousin of HenryCOMMA FrancisCOMMA and John); Henry (probably Henry Waln DrinkerCOMMA 1787-1866); Lydia Cope (dates and relationship unknown)
Subject: Urban health; Caribbean Area-History-To 1810; Capture at sea; Weather; Ocean travel; Sailing; Great Britain--Foreign relations--19th century; France--Foreign relations--1792-1815; Shipping
Notes: Written by two different authors; The date with the address has been changed/written-over to read "6" mo rather than "9" mo.
Transcript:
9th moth 9th 1806
My Dear Henry & FrancisCOMMA

I address yo bothCOMMA as I have not paper for 2 lettersCOMMA I am indetted to your Brother William for this [s]crapCOMMA I receiv’d your letters and am glad to find by the contents that you are well and contentCOMMA we are all in perty good health – your uncle Jasper and wife din’d at your house yesterday and i understand intends to return home in a day or two – Auther expects to sail the Begining of next weekCOMMA for Saint Thomas isCOMMA Henry seems content to stay at homeCOMMA I receiv’d a very affectinate letter from Lydia Cope she says I was allways dear to herCOMMA and absence has increast her love and affection for meCOMMA now I hope it wont have the Contrarya affect on youCOMMA I hope that time nor absenceCOMMA will not lessen the love I feel for youCOMMA and you for me.
I handed your love as directed which was receiv’d pleasure your Cousins Seem very throng one going to sea the other going in the Contry [i] beleive will not have time to writeCOMMA perhaps John may If he dont you must be content with this poor scrowl from your Loveing Grandmother

Rachel Drinker
Dear CousinsCOMMA

By the permission of grandmotherCOMMA I take this opportunity of indulging myself in writing a few line to youCOMMA which I should have done previous to this and in a more particular mannerCOMMA but my time has been pretty generally occupied; and as my health has not for this some time past been as good as formerlyCOMMA I have not given so much attention to my promise of writing to you as I otherwise should have done – The City in general is unusually healthyCOMMA which I hope is not a presage to any malignant fever: The weather is not at present very favourable after so much rainCOMMA it is too warm–
Arthur I expect will sail in a few days for St Thomas’sCOMMA where he intends selling vessel and cargoCOMMA the sale of the former will depend upon the price she will bring – The voyage will be attended with less danger than the former one to Cape Francois; they will be liable it is trueCOMMA to be taken by the English and FrenchCOMMA by the former because the port is a French oneCOMMA by the latter because they had been to the Cape; however if they are careful to avoid all vessels in due time and conceal the name of the sloop and her having been to Hayti they will escapebeing captured– The Sloop sails very fast [and] will in all probability reach the port without any accident from man; the fast sailing of the vessel will not quell a storm: then thay must use their skillCOMMA do what lies in their power and not be dismayed–
One would almost be induced to suppose that nothing new or strange can take placeCOMMA that every thing that is extraordinary has pastCOMMA and that the mine of wonder is exhaustedCOMMA for there is nothing but a series of old occurrences revolving upon the face of the inhabitable and navigable world– Here I must resign my penCOMMA and close this uninteresting scrawlCOMMA with wishing you the blessing of health and happiness –
I remain your affectionate cousin
John D Thomas

N.B If you cannot read my writing (as I call it) when you come to Philadelphia I will read it for youCOMMA with remark and improvements –6 mo 9th 1806
Henry Cope

Title: 1877 November 20COMMA GemantownCOMMA to Clementine CopeCOMMA Steamer Pennsylvania
Creator: James E. (James Evans) Rhoads:  1828-1895
Unidentified People: Walter Robson; Margaraet Rhoads
Subject: Ocean travel;  Faith
Transcript:
Dear friendCOMMA
Clementine Cope--
Please find enclosed a note of introduction to Walter RobsonCOMMA who [-----es] cheerful wishes to contribute to thy comfort on your voyage in any way needed. Margaret unites with me in wishing thee a prosperous and successful journeyCOMMA and a safe return.--The Lord is in every placeCOMMA and I trust thee will both find Him ever nearCOMMA and keep near to HimCOMMA who is so loving and able to preserve us--

very truly thy friendCOMMA
James E Rhoads

Germantown 11.20.77

Transcript:
1863
Catskill Aug. 30th
1st day eve

My dear Mother

I had to leave off writing very suddenly last timeCOMMA as thee must have seen by the letter having no direction. We got to writing in bed at West Point as we woke up earlyCOMMA & were not going to take breakfast till 8 1/2; but we had to go at 9 1/2COMMA & as we were very pokey we did not get down to breakfast till 9 o’clock-hence my great hurry. We left West P. in the boatCOMMA the rest of the way up the Hudson was not however nearly so interestingCOMMA we soon got out of the Highlands & then it seemed very tame. This is the most magnificent place we were everCOMMA or are likely everCOMMA to be in; The view from the front of the house is very extencive & beautifulfrom one place we can see the top of Mount Washington with the opera glass. The house is quite a large one tho’ mostly old fashioned except the parlor wh. is up stairsCOMMA & has I think most probably been altered the passages are the most intricate I ever was inCOMMA & sometimes I feel completely lost. We are on the very top of the mountain with dreadful prespicise’s all around usCOMMA & it is the most dreadful place to get up to that ever wasCOMMA thee knows its a twelve miles drive up the mountain from the landingCOMMA & how long does thee ’spose we were getting up? 5 1/2 hours- just think of it the horses walked nearly all the wayCOMMA & stoped ever few minut[e]s to rest; after we got fairly to the foot of the mountain within about three miles from the house father & Tom got out to walkCOMMA “& the consequence was” they got here an hour & a quarter before us.the last part of the way poor RachCOMMA was dreadfully sickCOMMA the boat & stage together were too much for herCOMMA & as soon as we got there I helped her get right to bedCOMMA she slept pretty well however after she once did get to sleep tho’ she suffered dreadfully poor childCOMMA thee knows her headaches are so hard to bearCOMMA but don’t worry she’s quite well to day. This morning they had service in the parlor to wh. Cous. ClemCOMMA Chell & I went with papa’s leave. the sermon was pretty good & I must confess I think it much better that poking round all 1st day & going no whereCOMMA if you can’t go to meeting go to church – “thems my sentiments.” After service we all went out to take a ramble & after a good deal of hunting round for paths & scrambling up them when foundCOMMA we at last arrivedat the top of South Mountain It was a beautiful walk although it seemed to scare poor aunt Annie terribly to see us so near the edge of these awful prespicise’s wh. surround us every where; the rocks covered with fernsCOMMA mossesCOMMA litgens are really beautiful. We passed through what they call “[Pudding]–stone Hall” a large cleft in the rocks formed of pudding–stone & also through the lemon-squeezers another crevise. We are altogether enjoying ourselves very much I think & propose staying here till 3rd day afternoon when we will probably leave for Saratog[a]COMMA & thence to Lake George. at least those are present prospects but as we have changed our plans several times to day I wont say certainlyCOMMA if we p[u]rsue the plan now proposed wewill stop at Belloes Falls on our way to Boston & spend next 1st day at Nahant if we can. We have rather a funny time altogether about our meals & sleeping apartments here things are not extremely cleanCOMMA & it is so crowded we have to come to the second table & therefore have to take our breakfast at ten & dinner at four & now about 6 the supper bell has rungCOMMA but I ‘spose we’ll come second class there to. We are quite glad of our thick dresses MotherCOMMA & have worn nothing else hardly since we left home. its right cold to nightCOMMA & we have to wear shawls & things all the time to keep warm. It is getting almost to dark for me towrite any more dear Mother so I think the[e] must let me close. I hope we shall hear from home tomorrow we want to hear very much how you all are. I shall try to write soon again if we get to a stopping place we have been going so steadily that there has been hardly any time to do any thingCOMMA but see the sights Please excuse all defects – & with love to all I am
ever thy loving
daughter Lily

Title: 1905 August 14COMMA Bridgewater CottageCOMMA to My very dear friends
Creator: Sibylla T. Morris:  b. 1826
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916;CopeCOMMA Susan L. NewboldCOMMA 1805-1872; WalkerCOMMA Sarah MillerCOMMA 1799-1874; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; CarmaltCOMMA SarahCOMMA b.1795; PriceCOMMA WilliamCOMMA b. 1788
Unidentified People: Elisha K. Townsend; Priscilla Townsend
Subject: Westtown Boarding School;  Letter writing; Age factors in disease; Dental schools
Geographic Subjects: Hampton (Va.); China; Philadelphia (Pa.); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.)
Notes:
Annotated in pencil.

[HamptonCOMMA VA]

The letter appears to be written to both Caroline Elizabeth and Annette Cope.

The Philadelphia Dental College was established in 1863 and operated under that name until 1909COMMA at which time Temple University (which had purchased the school two years earlier) renamed it the Temple University School of Dentistry. Information from various Temple University websites and Jean Barth Toll and Mildred S. GillanCOMMA eds.COMMA Invisible Philadelphia: Community Through Voluntary Organizations (Philadelphia: Atwater Kent MuseumCOMMA 1995).
Transcript:
Bridgewater Cottage
8.14. ’05 —

My very dear friends –
I was very glad to hear again of youCOMMA– tho’ sorry to learn of your semi-invalidismCOMMA– in which I can fully sympathiseCOMMA– but I am overwhelmed – by your generous check – which was so thoughtful – & so useful! – I cannot express myself with sufficient gratitudeCOMMA & can only say that it is accepted in the same loving spirit in which it was sentCOMMA & for the inherited friendship of our re-spective parents & grandparents.–
– Did you ever knowCOMMA or hear among your family traditions of the strong intimacy there was between yr. grandfatherCOMMA– Thomas P. Cope – the shipping merchantCOMMA– & my grandfather – Philip Price the Superintendent of Westtown SchoolCOMMA nearly 100 yrs. ago?– My grandfather had a large family of 10 children to educate & c.– & when his eldest sonCOMMA– Dr. Wm. Price rec.d his diplomaCOMMA– yr. grandfather gave him a double position on one of his ships going to ChinaCOMMA– those of Dr. & also of supercargoCOMMA– & he made 2 tripsCOMMA– each for 3 yrsCOMMA– It was a great event in the P. family
I am glad you are having a pleasant summer in your quiet retreat.– I am preaching "the simple life"– more as weknew it in our quiet country homesCOMMA or in the simplicity of Friends.– I enjoy social life in a quiet way with good neighbors & a few friends calling in the evenings – but the constant round of it all day & every day is wearing.
– What halcyon days we used to have at WoodbourneCOMMA– and my children have no knowledge of it &COMMA only the older ones – have a bare recollection of dear Cousin SarahCOMMA with none at all of your lovely Mother.– What a sunbeam she was!– I have some lovely memories to look back uponCOMMA but I don’t seem to acquire in my old age the gentle loveliness of so many of our old FriendsCOMMA tho’ I am frequently called upon to say with a dear old cousin of my Mother’s – Priscilla TownsendCOMMA– (whowas the Mother of the Dentist Elisha K. Townsend who founded the Philada. Dental College–) "Let me number my blessings!"– And another saying of an old Irish neighbor we had – who had many trials & sorrows – but would end up her stories with – "but sureCOMMA Welcome be the Will of the Lord!"–
– But I am too reminiscent for young peopleCOMMA & this letter is terribly egotisticCOMMA so I will stop but your kindness & dear Annette’s letter have brought back many delightful memories.– The years are rapidly rolling byCOMMA & I have now entered my eightieth. –
Good byeCOMMA– with dear love to you both & many thanks I remain
your old friend
S. T. Morris –

10 mo 2nd 1868

Dear Lilly

I havn't got my [spool]-case yetCOMMA I wish it would come. Alban and me played this morning. Alban has a pair of pantaloons [----]- I didn't finish the letter because I didn't want to. I hope mother 'ld come back & I hope thee will too. I'm glad father's at home. Maybe TomAlexis is coming this eveningCOMMA I hope he is. There were some beautiful roses in father's bed this morning. I wish I had a knife. Affectionately Lilly I think I 'll stop- it's a very short letter I know-
Anna

My dear Miss CopeCOMMA

Jonathan E. Rhoads
908 Franklin Street

WilmingtonCOMMA Delaware
10 mo 30 1910

Dear Cousin Jonathan Evans

Remembering our conversationCOMMA when we met at Alfred Garrett'sCOMMA on the Revised DisciplineCOMMA I merely wish to refer thee to the Article on the Institution of the Discipline in first vol. of Friends Library. I suppose it was prepared by thy dear FatherCOMMA as he was one of the Editors of that workCOMMA and its perspicuous style would indicate.--I do not suppose thee thought of setting aside all rulesCOMMA but some of those relating to conductCOMMA including marriage. As to this latter the introductory remarksCOMMA written by Thos P CopeCOMMA explain the reasons for the rules very clearly in a concise manner.
I enjoyed meeting thee and the other
*see in new or former marriage rules
members of our family connections at Alfred C.G's.

With love thy cousin
Jona. E Rhoads

Title: 1865 May 3COMMA BaltimoreCOMMA to Mother and Sisters
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; JeffriesCOMMA Lydia; ChestonCOMMA GallowayCOMMA 1806?-1881; ChestonCOMMA Margaret CareyCOMMA d. 1874; MatthewsCOMMA Susan; TysonCOMMA Jesse; WalkerCOMMA Sarah MillerCOMMA 1799-1874
Unidentified People: M. Wilson; Judge Bond; Francis (possibly Clementine’s cousin Francis Reeve Cope or her cousin Francis Cope Yarnall); Mary/Cous. M (possibly Clementine’s cousin Mary Drinker Cope Haines or her cousin Mary Anna Cope Carter); Alice Murdock; Miss [Sarah?] Field
Subject: Clothing and dress; Quakers--Social life and customs; Needlework; Letter writing; Baltimore (Md.)--Social life and customs
Notes:
1865 written in pencil at top right
parentheticalCOMMA in pencilCOMMA below: “(To all her Sarah now)”

Some significant portions of the letter are unreadable.
Transcript:
1865
Baltimore 5/3
Dear Mother and sistersCOMMA
I am very glad to find yr. letter to day that you are at least conscious of your deficiencies wh. have been very apparent to me lately. I did not write at my usual time this weekCOMMA for I was determined to stand upon my dignity & not write until I hear from you. The long-looked-for- howver camr this morn. & the mention of M Wilsons nameCOMMA caused in a measure my forgivenessCOMMA as I well know what her name means. &COMMA Nat I fully sympat with thy sentiment on the disgusting nature of clothing. I have to stick up in my room here every spare minute [---] tho' I thout I was pretty much ready for spring yetI have to keep up a [----] all the time. &c. The prices of things are perfectly tremendous - no decent bonnet ribbon to be got under $1. +$1.50 pr. yard. In consequence of wh. I am broke. Can't you send me a V or an X in next letter? I find it necessary to get several things [----] she's "cream of Baltimore society." is so [highly?] dressy that its very troublesome. [----] The last few days we have had an inpouring of invitations. No less than three this afternoon. 1st to go out to Susan Matthews' a friend who lives a few miles in the country & who invites us to come out in the [Carr?] to take tea tomorrow 2nd - to another frds' by the name of [Janney?] - 3rd to Cous L. Jeffries. 4th - to Judge Bonds - & 5thly to a [?] of Jesse's [ellegant?] dinner parties. At least we have reason to think that there is onevery near at hand. As usual they all come together. Now if I only had my silk [?] it would come in [?]. but by the time I cld. get it even if I sent it by express the [sprees?] I fear wld. be over. I had no idea when I [came?] of doing so much wishing. Jesse has been exceedingly polite taking us ridingCOMMA ice-creaming &c. wh. is a part of the cream of society I enjoy our entertainment at home being rather poor sometimes we appreciate outside treats.
Last 7th day afternoon I took a very pleasant excursion with the Kings (Francis his two dhrs. & his two brothersCOMMA eligible young bachelors?) out on the rail road 6 or 7 miles where we had a very nice afternoon pic-nic. They told me abt. Phila. Mary said she was [?] pleased with them Carrie & with S Walker. She's a very nice girl in deed. Galway & M. Cheston called in their carriage & took me to ride & [she?] [?] totea with them. wh. I thought was very kind. I have no tell Cous M that her Aunt thinks she is improving. Alice Murdock called to see me. The people here are the greatest callers. & make the most immense calls. I ever heard of. We are often kept in the whole afternoon. wh. accts. for my having to send you such [?] I meant to have written Cous Mary & to Tom this week but have not the time. Mother thee need not fear that I shall injure myself with teaching as it does not tire me so much as at first. I shall [enjoy?] the rest of home. I believe. Must stop. Give my love to Father Edgar You & all enquiring frds. Yours affec[?] Clemmy.

Title: 1732 February 6COMMA Caln in Chester County in PensilvaniaCOMMA to Uncles Thomas & Joshua Pim
Creator: William Pim:  1692-1751
Identified People: PimCOMMA ThomasCOMMA 1721-1786; PimCOMMA JoshuaCOMMA 1686-1749; PimCOMMA JohnCOMMA 1688-1773; MendenhallCOMMA SarahCOMMA b. 1719
Unidentified People: Jo. Gavin; Thomas McChur? and wife; William Glaiston; Ja. Nicholson
Subject: Child rearing;  Domestics; Family; Health; Quakers--Death ; Widowers; Bereavement--Religious aspects--Society of Friends; Smallpox; Textile industry
Notes:
Co. Laois lies in the ancient province of Leinster in IrelandCOMMA and is also known as Co. Leix or Queen’s Co. The Dictionary of Quaker Biography lists Lacka House as the residenceCOMMA four miles outside the town of MountrathCOMMA of the birthplace of William Pim and the home of his grandfatherCOMMA John Pim. Mountrath was founded by Sir Charles Coote in the seventeenth centuryCOMMA who established a manufacturing and industrial center on his estate. The town supported over the years an ironworksCOMMA an oil millCOMMA two distilleriesCOMMA a breweryCOMMA a linen manufacturing businessCOMMA and a cotton spinning business.

The town of CalnCOMMA PACOMMA lies in Chester County and is named for CalneCOMMA WiltshireCOMMA EnglandCOMMA where many of the town’s original inhabitants emigrated from. The meeting house in Caln dates from 1726. A century after his emigrationCOMMA William Pim’s descendants remained in good standing in Caln. In Eugene L. DiOrio’s Chester County: A Traveler’s Album (MarcelineCOMMA MO: Walsworth PublishingCOMMA 1980)COMMA Richard Pim is listed as a prominent landowner in 1837 who built a still-standing six-sided schoolhouse for his children.
Transcript:
Caln in Chester County in Pensilvania
the 6th. of ye. 2nd. month 1732

Dear Uncles
Thomas & Joshua Pim /

I wrote to my Bror. John &c the 17th. of last mo: aqt.ing them of a great alteration in my ffamilyCOMMA wch. letter I supose went in a ship just then ready to sail to Ireland and now I acquaint you that it hath pleased Divine Providence to remove my wife from me by DeathCOMMA She was taken Ill of (that Dreadfull distemper) the smallpox about the 4th. of last moth: & departed in the night between the 14th. & 15th. of ye. same being Sorely afflicted wth. the distemperCOMMA but verry sencible all the time & I hope made good use of sd. timeCOMMA often praying & praising GodCOMMA & tho: in the time of her health she did not seem as fully as I cou’d a wisht to Joyn wth. ffrds. (tho she- went to no other worship that I know off since we came here but severall times to ffriends meetings) yet in her Illness she was desirous of the company of sollid ffrds & severall of such did visit her & I think are generally in good hopes that she Dyed in Peace & I believe few who knew her here were streangers to her former circumstance for my part I did not endeavour to conceall the truth from Honest ffriendsCOMMA and before I pesumed to appoint her buriall I requested leave of ffriends to Bury her in their groundCOMMA which was soe readily granted that they told me they thought it needless to ask itCOMMA phaps you may desire to know wt. I recd of the debt due to me I cannot say yt. I recd. none tho: (I thought more was dueCOMMA) for Just at lastCOMMA she desired it might be forgot or forgiven wch. I think implyed some acknowledgment I think for above a year past she grew the most sollid & sober yt. I have known her at all – & I cannot but admire how much her loss is lamented in this neighbourhoodCOMMA for she was a verry oblieging neighbour & skillfull in many things

I mentioned to my Bror. &c [---] [---] of the Illness of my youngest ChildCOMMA we thought it was dying the next day after its mothers deathCOMMA yet it continued for fifteen days longer for the most pt. in great extremity & then DiedCOMMA wch. long Illness I believe helped to wean me from itCOMMA soe that its Death did not affect me soe much as I believe it wd. if it had a died soonCOMMA for it was a verry pleasant ChildCOMMA it was 7 months old when it fell sick

I mentioned in a former letter to my Brother the Death of my servant Jo: Gavin who was the first of my ffamily who was taken IllCOMMA & Died about a week or 6 days before the next began my ffamily then consisted of 12 psons (i:e: before this sickness) whereof 7 was to have itCOMMA & of the 7: 3 is deadCOMMA wch. we may conclude was a great stroakeCOMMA tho: I may tell you that it does not yet seem soe hard for me to bear as wt. I formerly boreCOMMA but the Death of my poor wife seemd a greater exercise than I expected it wd. a beenCOMMA however I still endeavour to be patient & content wth. what Providence permits to be my lot in this troublsom world

I am through [meny] greatly favoured wth. Health & my five Children are now pitty well tho: my Son Thos. has had a hard time & a narrow escape with his life thro: the smallpox

I have been verry well furnisht with good neighbours during this trouble pticularly Thos. M.cChuns wife (being a nurse) did not see her own house for two weeks of the time of my poor Babes IllnessCOMMA I have this comfort that my poor Children seems verry to’rdlyCOMMA & my Dtr. Sarah considering her age verry pitty as to her knowledge in the way of HouskeepingCOMMA & on her and my maid Mary Turner. I think that pt. must pitty much depend at [pesant]

now Dear Uncles I shall use some further freedom wth. youCOMMA this Cheange in my ffamily ocasions many thoughts in my mindCOMMA one whereof is to this purpose that since the cause of my leaving youCOMMA my ffriendsCOMMA & my native CountryCOMMA is now remov’dCOMMA why shou’d not I return there againCOMMA least I shou’d be taken from my Children & they left more destitute a mong streangersCOMMA but in answer to thatCOMMA can I think that I should be brought all the way to this remote pt. of the world for no other end than to bury my wifeCOMMA this Country I find more agreeable to my Health (else it is wth. working harder) this Country also is governed by more agreeable Laws than that here are plenty of good ffriends (tho: not my near Relations) who I believe wd. take care of my Children were I taken from themCOMMA & phaps I may have opptunity to [---] be of more servis here than thereCOMMA & thu---] reasoni--] concerning wch. I desire your sollid Consideration & answer as [---] as PossibleHowever if you please to Inform me how the woolen trade is now in Ireland & whetherCOMMA I am freed from that holding wch. I was liable toCOMMA I am as I mentioned to you before pitty much Involvd. in Debt & do find it hard to pay Debts wth. this way of living. corn being low & money scearceCOMMA but do think my self now more at liberty than before to consider of some other way of making my life EasierCOMMA but not by any alteration soe suddenly as [y.] year

I desire a pticular account of your [---] familys & my Cousin Wm. Glaister & of our ffamily in Generall & of ffrds & neighbours where any alteration has happen’d since my leaving youCOMMA

Soe wth. Dear Love to you all I Conclude your Loving nephew & affectionate ffriend

Wm Pim

P:S: the Smallpox continues to spead over this Country this being the 3d. time of its being here since settled by the EnglishCOMMA it mises but few ffamilyesCOMMA & takes off many heads of familyes especially men in their primeCOMMA here are many widdows now in this County I am in expectation of Ja: Nicholson in a little time [p] whom I expect an act. from Irland & if he dont bring me a servant or servants I shall be in great want for I am soe nowCOMMA I hired. an Indifferant hand lately at Husbandry & it Cost me 36s for 4 weeks (& diat) this has povd. a hard winter & Spring [fother] is now verry scearce wth. many people but mine holds outCOMMA tho: I lost one cowCOMMA yesterday & the night before here fell a great Snow wch. seems streange to the peopleCOMMA

W.P—

my Love is to my Dear Brother John
who I desire may se this –
To Joshua Pim In Mountrath Queens County Ireland

Title: 1840COMMA March 14COMMA ParisCOMMA to Rachel R. CopeCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Sarah B. Corbit
Identified People: CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; PleasantsCOMMA Caleb E. (Caleb Emlen)COMMA 1805-1842; ReeveCOMMA RuthCOMMA 1764-1845; LeedsCOMMA MarthaCOMMA 1810?-1888; PerotCOMMA Caroline R.COMMA b. 1825; OgdenCOMMA Emma CorbitCOMMA 1827-1874; CorbitCOMMA Henry C.
Unidentified People: BoltonCOMMA Rachel (Scull) (Sarah’s mother/dates unknown); ReeveCOMMA Samuel (Sarah’s cousin/dates unknown); Richard and Ruth; Doctor Lowell; Aunt Margery
Subject: Boardinghouses; Americans--Foreign countries; Europe--Description and Travel; Family; Voyages and Travels; ArtCOMMA European; Quakers--Travel; London (England)--Description and Travel; Paris (France)--Description and Travel; Paris (France)--Social life and customs
Notes:
Although the text of the letter indicates the letter was written in ParisCOMMA the postal information lists the sending address as Poland.
Notes penciled in another hand read: “3/14/1840 Sarah B. Corbit to her Cousin Rachel Cope. Supposedly mother of Caroline Perot & Emma Ogden.”
Transcript:
Paris 3rd Month 14th 1840
My Dear Cousin
I suppose you have through the medium of letters to some of our family heard of us and our safe arrival in EuropeCOMMA but in compliance with thy request and my promise which has not been forgottenCOMMA I thought (altho at a late period) a breif sketch of our [pastimes] in our new location would be acceptable hoping that you retain a feeling of interest in our welfare. We arrived in London after a short and altogather pleasant voyage passed ten day’s there was buisily engaged in visiting the many objects very interesting to strangersCOMMA the TowerCOMMA Westminster AbbeyCOMMA St Paul’sCOMMA House of LordsCOMMA and various other placesCOMMA We then left; after a travel of four days thro an interesting country we arrived at ParisCOMMA during which time we were all favoured with healthCOMMA and our children were very good scarcely uttering a word of complaint of fatigue or any thing elseCOMMA this thee may well suppose enhanced our pleasureCOMMA or at least diminished our difficultiesCOMMA When we arrived in ParisCOMMA we took posession of apartments engaged for our reception in a French family who speak EnglishCOMMA the family consists of this and five American familiesCOMMA who form a pleasant domestic circleCOMMA they are all plainly disposed peopleCOMMA some very interesting a Doctor Lowell with his wife and daughter who have visited most of the countries of EuropeCOMMA EgyptCOMMA PalestineCOMMA are with usCOMMA English is spoken at our tableCOMMA this altho very pleasant retards our progress in the acquisition of the french languageCOMMA
We are situated in Rue de Rivoli opposite theTuileries the garden annexed to the palaceCOMMA the residence of the royal familyCOMMA our location is very pleasantCOMMA excepting that we are in the fourth story of the house (this in America would not be considered respectable) not so in Paris the population is so great; that highly respectable and even wealthy families occupy apartmentsCOMMA consisting of several rooms on a levelCOMMA so that a house (of course large) will accommodate many familiesCOMMA a very small proportion of residents occupying a house as we do in AmericaCOMMA this I felt to be a great abridgment of my domestic comfort
My ignorance of the language and the uncertainty of our continuance induces us to boardCOMMA I do not wish to encumber myself with domestic caresCOMMA for the management of a family in Paris is attended by much careCOMMA for one who would not choose to leave every thing to the regulation of servantsCOMMA There are several hundred Americans in Paris who form a pleasant societyCOMMA it is customary here for those who keep house to set apart one evening in the week for the reception of their freindsCOMMA who receive an invitation to visit them on that evening whenever inclination dictatesCOMMA this promotes great sociability among those who meetCOMMA the simplicity of the entertainment is to be admiredCOMMA consisting generally of a cup of tea and cake onlyCOMMA very seldom serving any other refreshmentCOMMA in other respects not so simpleCOMMA as a great regard is paid to personal appearanceCOMMA DressCOMMA DressCOMMA seems to engross their minds to the exclusion of other and better considerationsCOMMA
Our two daughters are at a school of high repute and we think deservedly soCOMMA they are improving in their studiesCOMMAWe have visited several churchesCOMMA Catholic and protestant This we feel to be a very great privationCOMMA to have no place of worship to resort to in accordance with our own views where we could commune with our own hearts and be stillCOMMA but we feel the necessity of recurring to the dictates of that inward guideCOMMA which if obey’d will lead out of all errorCOMMA We have visited a great many of the places of interest to strangersCOMMA there are many galleries of paintings very fineCOMMA there is at this time an annual exhibition at the LouvreCOMMA of new piecesCOMMA some private collections also
I have in my silent musing’s in immagination revisited most of your dwellingsCOMMA Dear Aunts Ruth and Margery very frequently present themselves before meCOMMA when we left home they both seemed feebleCOMMA I hope their lives may be prolonged to the comfort of their children by whom they are surroundedCOMMA but it seemed to me [that] the sun of their day was near [setting] in a tranquil eveningCOMMA if My Dear Cousin this excites sufficient interest in thy breast to induce a replyCOMMA information of them as well as many other members of our family would be grateful to us who are situated so far from many they still hold dearCOMMA please remember us affectionately to them AllCOMMA Richard and RuthCOMMA Caleb and MarthaCOMMA Samuel HenryCOMMA and thy children from thy attached Cousin
Sarah B Corbit
Henry’s partners will inform how to forward letters to usCOMMA if you wish to read our letters to our family. Mother who resides in Arch St above Ninth will willingly show them to you
Poland

Henry Cope
Philadelphia.
For Rachel R. Cope

Notes:
LC Conference Name: Jamestown Ter-centennial Exposition (1907). (I’m fairly certain this is the event Sibylla refers to in the letter...I can’t think what else it might be.)

Link to scanned map of Philadelphia to locate 1 Walnut St.

SydneyCOMMA Nova ScotiaCOMMA is located on the island of Cape Breton. Known as “the Steel CityCOMMA” Sydney is the third largest city in the province of Nova Scotia and is home to the Dominion Steel and Coal Company. A number of railway lines travel through Sydney.

“Both girls” who join Sibylla in greeting the Cope sisters are Sibylla’s two daughters Annie Sayne and Mary Morris. Her two sons working on the railroads are Frederick Cox Morris and Caleb Carmalt Morris.
Transcript:
Bridgewater Cottage
Hampton – Va: –
Nov: 20th 1907 –

My very dear friends —

We have just finished reading in the Montrose papersCOMMA which my daughter Annie Sayne brought down to me this p.m. – the account of the Dedication of dear Clemmie’s donation to all the people of old Susq: Co: & under its inspiration I feel that I must immediately x x x x –––––––––1908 Jan. 4th –

— To prove that my dear friends have not been entirely forgottenCOMMA – I have the audacity to continue this letter – begun so long ago as almost to be forgotten unless it be for this purpose! – An interruption occurredCOMMA during which time Minnie told me that she was writing or had written to youCOMMA & when I asked where she wd. address itCOMMA she said "OhCOMMA in c/o Misses Biddle – they are in Montrose". — I demurredCOMMA but neither of us knew theGermantown address & altho’ I said "No. 1. Walnut St." always held a clue – & had for nearly 100 yrs. pastCOMMA – but she laughedCOMMA – said that date was obsoleteCOMMA – & now I doubt if you ever did get her letter! – I wish I cd. see youCOMMA & I think our tongues wd. travel fastCOMMA – Writing has become rather irksome to meCOMMA – particularly with pen & ink as my fingers have very much stiffened in my old age – so I generally write with a pencil(when I think my frds. will not objectCOMMA) & I do not write muchCOMMA except to my two sonsCOMMA – who are in R.R.d business at SydneyCOMMA– Nova Scotia. —

— We have had such a hard summerCOMMA– partly owing to the delusions these conceited Virginians hadCOMMA– that "all the world & his wife" wd. almost break their necks to get here to see their wonderful state & its historic surroundings – then their disappointments & losses were not cheerful or conducive to cheery letter writingCOMMA & I hate to write doleful letters. —If it were not so patheticCOMMA– it wd. be very amusing to see the downfall of the hopes they all had of making such enormous fortunes.– Hundreds & thousands of dollars have been lostCOMMA for the whole thing was a complete fizzle & not being completed until away into OctoberCOMMA & therefore but little attendanceCOMMA– those who did come disparaging itCOMMA & the day after the gates were closedCOMMA it was put right into the hands of a receiver!! – Virginia has not had such a staggering blow since Appomattox! –

— We have seen very little ofMiss Walcott altho we attend the same churchCOMMA but she lives at the farther side of our town & the trip involves a trolley ride- a ferry across Hapton Creek & a walk to each end of the line.-
I am so sorry to hear of Carrie’s increased deafnessCOMMA - & descouraged too.- for I have grown very deaf myself. & when she had all the medical faculty of Europe to consultCOMMA & they did not cure herCOMMA - it is not worth while for me to try. - Is it hereditary with her?- I don’t remember either of your parents beingafflicted in that way. – The strongest point in my memory about them – is your father’s good sound "orthodox" dignity – always so cheerily smoothed overCOMMA by your Mother’s beautiful almost angelic smile which brightened almost everybody & everything around them. – I don’t wonder he went to bedCOMMA when she was taken from himCOMMA & could never be persuaded to rise again. – I must close this now for my messenger to take to the post office. –

— How I do wish you would come to see us. I hardly know any one who would be more welcome. – NowCOMMA think it over & see if you can’t comeCOMMA– particularly if a cold wave strikes Germantown. —

Good bye – in which both my girls joinCOMMA – don’t ever doubt meCOMMA but believe me always your loving & affectionate friend
Sibylla T. Morris.

Title: 1841 AprilCOMMA to FrankCOMMA Philada.
Creator: Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; LambCOMMA CharlesCOMMA 1775-1834; HartshorneCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1823-1897
Unidentified People: Dun StuartCOMMA Fanny Ell---
Subject: American poetry--Quaker authors; Classical literature; Quotations in literature; Quakers--Humor; Letter writing; Newport (R.I.)--Description and Travel
Notes:
Throughout the letter the author quotes liberally from other writers and sources. A partial list of identifications follows.
“greatness sympathises with greatness”: essayist William HazlittCOMMA “The Indian Judges”
“you can’t get a barrel of praties into a bushel basket”: aphorismCOMMA origin unknown
“some are born to greatnessCOMMA some achieve greatnessCOMMA and some have greatness thrust upon them”: William ShakespeareCOMMA Twelfth Night
“Tantaene animis coelestibus irae?” [In heavenly minds can such resentments dwell?]: VirgilCOMMA The Aeneid
“Memory is mortal forgiveness divine” [this is perhaps a restatement of “To err is humanCOMMA to forgive divine”]: Alexander PopeCOMMA “Essay on Criticism”
The Biblical admonition to “turn the other cheek” may be found in Matthew 5:38-40.
“cold obstruction” [in reference to death]: William ShakespeareCOMMA Measure for Measure
“Wellerism” [“a form of comparison in which a familiar saying or proverb is identified with what was said by someone in a specified but humorously inapposite situation” : from characters in Charles DickensCOMMA Pickwick Papers (definition from Oxford English Dictionary)
“No man is a hero to his valet-de-chambre”: Marshal Catinat or Madame de Corneul

The watermark is as follows:
J Whitman
Turkey Mill
1839

On the last page of the letterCOMMA the following text is written in pencilCOMMA in another handCOMMA probably that of E.S.C.: 2 letters of Chas. Tabor to Francis R. Cope - 1841 (F.R.C. aged 20 - C.T. about same age - ) C.T. had published in “L’Entreprise”COMMA a seranade written by F.R.C. When advised of the theft F.R.C. sends another poem entitled the “Thief.”

For a description of many of the geographic locations mentioned in the letterCOMMA see Newport and How to See It (Newport: Davis & PitmanCOMMA 1869).

A “fippenny bit” is a corruption of “five-penny bitCOMMA” a Spanish coin worth half a real or 6.25 cents. It was called fourpence in New EnglandCOMMA fip in PennsylvaniaCOMMA sixpence in New YorkCOMMA and a picayune in Louisiana. (Webster’s Dictionary)
Transcript:
Dear Frank
Somewhere in the Month of AprilCOMMA AD 1841

If you are in want of a mystery profound enough to merit the attention and task the scrutiny of your powerful mind - endeavor to ascertain if you can what whim has led me to take this mammoth sheet for my letter instead of confining myself as heretofore to the narrower limits of a [Quarto] It has puzzled me – I thought first of greatness in the Abstract – how greatness Sympathises with greatness – How you cant get a Barrel of praties in a Bushel Basket – and wondered if that was the reason – Some I reasoned Are born to greatness – some achieve greatness and some have greatness thrust upon them – and I have come to that conclusion that struggle against it as I may in spite of all I may do – greatness is my destiny. ------

“Tantaeni animis celestibus irae!!” as [Maro] said when the Caelicoli plagued poor Aeneas half out of his wits. --- I know Francis that the provocation was extreme – like unto the emotions of a female Tiger robbed of her young by some felonious and ruthless hand – some Yankee Menagerie-Keeper – who reflects (not the Keeper but the Tiger) that her striped Darlings will be exposed to the vulgar eye far from their native land. far from her and from her caresses. – who knows that in them she has lost perhaps the prop of her declining years and feels that she is altogether lonely –

“They will never come she said”
“She said I am a-weary a-weary”
“Would God that I were dead”! –

like unto her heart-rending emotions are emotions of a Poet moaning over the loss the abstraction by unhallowed hands of his fancy’s creations – his children of the Brain She whet her incisors – He mends his pen –
Her sullen growl resounds thro the forest. = fearful flies the trembling thief – the invader of their domestic hearth and social joys. – She sees him in the blue distance farther than any eye can pierce save the eye of a Mother bereaved of her offspring -- Guilty wretch! and dont thou expect such crimes to prosper – Fly as thou may the avenger is behind – She springs from the tangled Brush – one blow and her little ones are free and the blood of the ravisher = washes down his bones – The Poets eye rolls in indignant fury – He paces up and down – and much Ink must be shed. Black ink – to expiate his wrongs ------

But Frank I quote from “L’Entreprise No. 8” “Memory is mortal forgiveness divine” – There is a difference between the charity of the Christian and the blind revenge of the beasts that perish – and I see that thou art well acquainted with the precept concerning the smiting of one cheek and the subsequent turning of the other – since – when thou wast informed of the use I had made of thy Serenade thee sends me on another piece which I am sorely tempted to appropriate to the same purpose – viz. “The Thief” an Indignation ode -----

But “L’Entreprise” is of the things that have been = its star has set – When it again rises and illumes our horizon once more – any pieces you may favor me with will meet with particular attention and speedy insertion – To Encourage your Modesty I will only hint
at the numerous encores and complimentary remarks which I appropriated at its reading in our Junto. – I must confess I had some conscience pangs – at thus robbing you of your due and ventured to hint that they were entirely mistaken about the Authorship – But all that was attributed to my modesty and I could not make them believe it – So any more Serenades you want inserted or Indignation Odes – either – send them along and I’ll father ‘em with pleasure ----

As to that little Biographical sketch in the “Ledger” the idea pleases me exceedingly – It is not always the fate of Genius to hear its praises Its requiem is rarely listened to – till Death has untuned the Ear to praise and “cold obstruction” chilled the heart and closed the eye – But sometimes Fate decrees otherwise. -- & To your hands I commit with pleasure myself and my memory – and to encourage you I think you would make considerable of a Buzzy – I had thought some time since I could trace thy classic pen in that respectable Journal – Sometimes perhaps in the Poet’s corner – and again I have suspected thy assistance (as Charles Lamb and Dun Stuart have done before thee - ) [Reparter] “compiler impromptu” composer and Wellerism manufacturer at a fippenny bit a head

Dont forget Frank to put in how like twin puppies we hunted the Muses together – How “hand in hand we climbed the steep ascent of Parnassus” – and drank from the same pitcher of the sparkling fountain – and if thee wishes it I dont know that I shall object to thy inserting that chaste production of thy blushing and almost virgin Muse – the ode to Fanny – Though I bethink myself that piece would better become the columns of the “Little Genius” – for there was about it an independent air – a noble boldness which some – nayCOMMA many – are too narrowed by the conventional and affected delicacy of the day fully to appreciate and which the Little Genius so openly advocates and patronises –

With this I send you a critique on a Philadelphia poet one who “blossomed in the desert air” of our unfriendly climate but who like a wise prophet sought honor elsewhere – No man is a hero to his valet’s deschambre and Pliny would never have sucked Parnassian pap to advantage if he had lived and died a Teacher at Providence School – What a blight this “Times” man seems to want to throw upon poor Pliny’s Laurels. – No mincing matters Regulae cut & slash. – When I see such an article I always fancy the Burden on my own shoulders – Just Fancy some of your Serenades served in the same style – Not kidnapped – eloped with out of pure affection but barbarously mangledCOMMA murderedCOMMA its throat cut from ear to ear. – Like to a Tiger &c &c (on the other page - )

New England Yearly Meeting of Friends is held at New Port from 7th day the 12th of the 6th month to 6th day the 18th inclusive commencing with the Meeting for Sufferings – which however thou knowst is only patent to Cardinals and chief priests of the synagogue First Day is generally “the Yearly Meeting” par eminence and is usually a great day at New Port. Then may be seen straight coats of the strictest sort – straight coats of a more accommodating
curve – straight coats which one would hardly know were straight and it grieves me to mention – some utterly devoid of straightness – Broad Brims blackCOMMA drabCOMMA or otherwise from six inches in diameter to a lesser number – or a fraction – Bonnets which the unsullied snow wreath could not rival in maiden purity setting off eyes of all colors – noses of all shapes – and mouths of all degrees of prettiness – interspersed with some of the adornment of the daughters of vanity ------ flitting past in crowds – and every now & then the youth of the company indulging in cachinnations calling down upon them with speedy rebuke of the more serious & elderly – while old peaceable looking chassis and wagons drawn by the most demure looking ponies in the world string along through the streets and all bound to Yearly-Meeting – New Port has many other attractions besides Yearly Meeting however – The ride on the Beach – the Glen the [Fort] and the Sail in the Harbour take away considerably from the tedium of the long sittings – and besides Paradise & Purgatory can be visited – much easier than was done in the times of Hercules & pious Aeneas – as to the girls I have often told them that I worship them
“as stars

Whose purity and distance make them fair”
and thee must get another pilot when thee comes on such sounding but I do not despair however and may perhaps with a few Lessons from thee become “a nice young man”
All this I put forth expecting you to come & visit us then – If you will be there – day & month aforesaid – I will meet you and I think I may promise you a pleasant week – Harry I suppose put more faith in Fanny [Ell---] than in any one else – so he will hardly affect a Yearly Meeting of the spiritually “Exercised –

So no more (and quite enough) from
thy friend Charles TaberFrancis R Cope
care of H. & A. Cope
No 1 Walnut St
Philada.

Title: 1910 November 1COMMA WilmingtonCOMMA DelawareCOMMA to Jonathan Evans
Creator: Jonathan E. (Jonathan Evans) Rhoads:  1830-1914
Subject: Westtown Boarding School;  Haverford College--Students; Faith; Bible--N.T.
Transcript:
Jonathan E. Rhoads
908 Franklin Street

Jonathan E Rhoads
11 mo 1.1910

WilmingtonCOMMA Delaware
11 mo 1 1910

My Dear Cousin Jonathan Evans

Thine of yesterday is at hand--I am not sorry I wrote to thee as thy answer assures me there was misapprehension on my part as to thy expression. We had spoken of the discipline at Westtown and of the laying aside of rules there and at Haverford which were difficult of enforcement and some of them unnecessary to proper order. AfterwardsCOMMA if I recollect rightCOMMA thee expressed thyself in favor of rescinding all rulesCOMMA the word discipline being used; which I supposed referred to that of our Y.Mg. when I now think the discipline at Westtown may have been in thy mind.
I am glad to be correctedCOMMA and to have thy opinion of the Revised Discipline as given in thy letter.--I greatly long
to have unity of belief and effort in upholding essential Truth and its principles by FriendsCOMMA and increased recognition of the intent of our Lord and Master when He taught His followers the deep meaning of "The Kingdom of Heaven."
Some few practices of the most substantial Friends I am willing to leave to individual conscience for adoptionCOMMA if their rejection does not contravene any plainly stated law or principle in the New Testament. Thus in dressCOMMA simplicity is conformity to the law of Christianity; and truthfulness is necessary to speech when addressing others.

With love thy cousin
Jona. E Rhoads
