Transcript:
[Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia Jan. 9. 1897

Dear Frank

I have been looking over the membership of the Audubon Society & find your sisters are not on the list.

Cannot you induce them to sign the card & sign one yourself. We want all the names possible & every one helps If we can get a membership of 1000 we will exert a much greater influence than if we have only 100.

We want gentlemen as well as ladiesCOMMA for we are going to try toobtain better game laws & support all matters relative to the protection of birds.

I enclose a card for your signature.

Sorry you did not get in Thursday we had a gathering of 23 & elected DeHaven Pres. & Shylock Secty for the coming year

I want to see you & Justice in the Active Membership & am working to that end

Sincerely yours

Witmer Stone

Title: 1856 April 27COMMA Iowa FallsCOMMA to Cousin Annie
Creator: Charles Pemberton Pleasants
Identified People: CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865;        CopeCOMMA Rachel ReeveCOMMA  1794-1863; WetherillCOMMA Benjamin K. (Benjamin Kite)COMMA  1832-1898; ReeveCOMMA Julia K.;
Unidentified People: Miriam Thompkins [Marion Tompkins?]; Benjamin Talbott (a  Benjamin Talbott was identified through The Friend and  Hinshaw’s Encyclopedia of American Quaker GenealogyCOMMA but a  definitive match could not be made); Susan
Subject: Clothing and dress;  Floods; Weddings; Country life; Rural  poor; Mills and mill-work; Livestock; Hoosier (Nickname);
Geographic Subjects: Iowa Falls (Iowa); Iowa River (Iowa); Chester (Pa.); Iowa
Notes: The Iowa River begins in the northern middle section of the  state near Crystal Lake and flows southeast into Lake  McBride near Iowa City.  The river continues into the  Mississippi River.  Iowa Falls is located on the banks of  the Iowa River.
Transcript:
Iowa Falls 4 mo 27. 1856
My Dear Cousin Annie

A great flood has washed away mills and houses along the Iowa River carrying every thing before it but what a puny flood it was compaired to the flood of tears I shed on hearing of the marriage of Susan (how my hand trembles as I write the name) thy letter of consolation came as a balm to my wounded heart and I will try and take thy advice not to cry after spilled milk.
Affairs are going on in the old way in this section of the globe nothing of much interest is stirring except the wind which to day is particularly severe I never had an idea that the wind blewCOMMA as it does across the praries it realy exceeds the blowing at "Our old House at Home" otherwise called "Bleak House."
Thy letter of information was replete with accounts of marriages and I can do no better than return the complement by telling thee of an intended one between Benjamin K Wetherell & Miriam Thompkins both of them are young and friends they will be married in about 4 weeksat our meeting house (ie the residence of Benj Talbott.) it will no doubt be conducted in a novel style. I am not at present able to give any information respecting bridesmaids but will at a future time give a complicated description of dress and cerimony. The groomCOMMA or intended groom rather is from ChesterCOMMA Pa I was at Westtown B SchoolCOMMA with him. His is the only face I have ever seen beforeCOMMA since I came into Iowa.
Thee would smile to see the inconsistency in dress of the females of the society in this part of the country I observed one in meeting this morning who wore a plain bonnet and shawl a red calico dress made surplusCOMMA and to crown all a cheap plated silver breastpin not small in sise with a large red stoneCOMMA or glass rather set in itCOMMA!!! I had to smile. An other peculiarity in meeting is the presence of numerous "babies" and small children who enliven the meeting with their sonorous (?) music. I might enlarge much on the peculiarities of the west but time and space will not permit But one expression I will tell thee when tellinga story to any fair dame. if it proves to be rather a remarkable one she replyes "I want to know"! with an emphasis on the word to also repeating it with a slight nasal twang.
One word about western life in some of its stages a few weeks ago having occasion to go about 20 miles north of this place into the "wilds of Iowa" I had to stop all night at the house of a "Hoosier" his cabin was about 18 by 16 without a window 7 small children stood around the fire with their mouths and eyes open as I entered the room was also without a floor unless a hard surface of earth might be called a floor in one corner stood a bedstead a calf was tied in an other corner whilst a "pig" had the entire range of the house. in such quarters I was compelled to eat and lodge for one nightCOMMA and only one thank fortuneCOMMA as there was no other house within 8 or 9 miles. After "tea" (what’s in a name?) I amused myself with looking into the fire and listening. to the oldest daughter (aged about 16) who stood by the fireplace chewing her bonnet string whorelaited the hair breadth escapes the pig had from being hooked by the "old brindle cow" and how Jonny (the next to youngest) got lost in the "bresh" when looking after the cows. a bed was at last made on the floor for my companion and myself where we soon forgot all the world and the rest of mankind in sleep.
But this is not all Iowa I am as comfortably fixed as can be expected.
While I write some inteligence just comes which has cast a gloom over the whole town it is the inteligence that a steam mill which was intended to be erected in place of the water mill removed by the water during the freshetCOMMA will not be erected excuse more at presentCOMMA the town will be evacuated by a great part of the inhabitants their indignation is so great. I dont know what my next move will be
Love to Uncle Henry Aunt Rachel Julia and all thy affectionate cos
Chas P. Pleasants

Title: 1802 October 21COMMA DowningtownCOMMA to Henry S. DrinkerCOMMA near Bristol Pennsylva.
Creator: Elizabeth Sandwith Drinker:  1734-1807
Identified People: DrinkerCOMMA HannahCOMMA 1774-1830; DrinkerCOMMA HenryCOMMA  1734-1809; DrinkerCOMMA Sarah SandwithCOMMA 1761-1807; DrinkerCOMMA WilliamCOMMA 1767-1821; SmithCOMMA JamesCOMMA b. 1750; RushCOMMA BenjaminCOMMA 1746-1813

Subject: Family;  Health; Ocean travel; Epidemics; Voyages and Travels--Health aspects; Parental influences; Farmers; Americans--Foreign countries
Geographic Subjects: India; East Indies; Great Britain; Philadelphia (Pa.)
Notes:
Written on back side of letter:
Downingtown Oct. 21. 1802
From my dear Mother
14
Transcript:
Downingtown Octor. 21. 1802.
My very dear SonCOMMA

This ridiculous whim which thou hast adopted has given me more pain than I can expressCOMMA I cannot conceive what should induce theeCOMMA who is settled in the way thee wishedCOMMA on a good farmCOMMA which thee knows so well how to manage and improveCOMMA without paying rent: To take it into thy mind to leave thy all; a young family of precious childrenCOMMA and parants in precarious healthCOMMA to go 9000 miles on a tempestuous seaCOMMA in the most dangerous season of the yearCOMMA art thou insane? What can be thy inducement: compare thy situation with hundred that are quite happy and contented; Why art thou not so? Why this unsettled idea? – If thee puts this scheme in practiceCOMMA I hardly expect ever to see thee again in this worldCOMMA – even if thou should be spared to return to those of thy friends that may be left – Thee wrote before we left town on this subject to thy fatherCOMMA But I never saw the letterCOMMA WD. told me thee talk’d of going to IndiaCOMMA I expected thy father had wrote theeCOMMA and that it was the thought of a moment that was now given over; thy letter to thy father and brother rec’d yesterdayCOMMA I might have readCOMMA but that to William was enough for meCOMMA to think thou art in earnest is more than I canCOMMA at times well bear – consider wellCOMMA my dear son what thou art [preparing]: perhaps on thy returnCOMMA if thou should be so favouredCOMMA thee may find thy parants no more; and some of thy little ones gone &c. This is thee may say looking at the worst side of thingsCOMMA but pray inform me what is the best sideCOMMA I see no good that is likely to result from it– Can thy scheme be a view of money makingCOMMA if soCOMMA will the little gainCOMMA thy hardships may obtainCOMMA be equal to the loss and devastation that may occur during thy absence– do my dear Henry give up this wild notionCOMMA be thankful for what thou hastCOMMA make the best of itCOMMA and I trustCOMMA more will be addedCOMMA if ‘tis necessary for thee.– thou hastCOMMA according to my ideas great cause ofthankfulness – thou mayst have trials that I know not ofCOMMA but going to the worlds-end will not cure them – If “an exemption from evil is a real good” how many evils art thou exempt from? – be content and resign’d. – If the former desire of a trip to Great Britain had revived in thy mind (tho I should hardly think it would in thy present situationCOMMA and in those times of trouble) I should not oppose itCOMMA at a suitable time of the yearCOMMA if thou could leave thy family and farm with propriety: but this East-India notion may be ruineous if put in practice – There is no one that loves thee but would be grieved at such a procedure – not a single word has past between thy father and myself on this businessCOMMA till [ye] day he recd. thy last letterCOMMA when I mentioned my very great concern on thy acct. he say’d it was a rediculous foolish whim – Do my dearest Henry give over all thoughts of leaving all that is near and dear to thee for a phantomCOMMA and if thee doesCOMMA I am of the first oppinion thee will never have reason to repent it. – Thee may remember when thee first concluded to be a FarmerCOMMA I oppos’d itCOMMA wishing thee near me while I lived – but seeing thee seem’d fixed in that wayCOMMA I gave up my wishes – and sinceCOMMA the frequent attacks of malignant fever in our CityCOMMA I think I may truly sayCOMMA I have been thankful thee was so well and happilyCOMMA as I thoughtCOMMA settled on a good Farm – where I hope thee will content thyself and remain. – Jacob Downing has been several days in and near the CityCOMMA he wrote to Sally that the fever was worseCOMMA a greater number of new casesCOMMA than at any other timeCOMMA Dr. Rush told him it wd. be very improper for our family to returnCOMMA as there was several illCOMMA not far from us. – Joseph Downing has been very unwell with fever and pain in his headCOMMA not yellow feverCOMMA he is rather better – last week we had concluded to return home on first or second day lastCOMMA but hearing of the death of a baker not far from usCOMMA and two cases in Elfriths’ AlleyCOMMA and several in [Keys’] alleyCOMMA thy father gave it over for [ye] presentCOMMA ‘tho he is very desireous of being at home – To be seperated from my Children at those times of difficulty is a trial to me. Our dear Nancy who has been at times unwellCOMMA has been much in my thoughtsCOMMA ‘till Iread thy letter to thy brotherCOMMA which has filled my mind with little else but thee – Thy dear father has had many attacks of his old complaintCOMMA and frequently disordered bowelsCOMMA has taken liquid ladanum every night for some weeks pastCOMMA he is at present better of the gravelly complaintCOMMA but not well in his bowels.– A LetterCOMMA or rather small packet directed by thee to James Smith came here by some mistake with thy other two – thy father has sent it back to the City – I hope ‘ere long to see theeCOMMA after mature deliberationCOMMA fully convinced of thy mistake – which will be a very great satisfaction to thy trully affectionate mother E. Drinker

No one here knows any thing of thy intention that I know ofCOMMA not a word of it has been mention’d – indeed it is a subject that we cant bear to talk on My love is to Hannah and the Dear Children –Paid 10
Henry S. Drinker
near
Bristol
Pennsylva.
Mail

Title: 1878 June 28COMMA SunnysideCOMMA MayfieldCOMMA near AshbourneCOMMA EnglandCOMMA to My dear Friend
Creator: Joseph Simpson:  1835-1901
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; SimpsonCOMMA AgnesCOMMA 1839-1925; RaphaelCOMMA 1483-1520
Subject: Europe--Description and Travel; ArtCOMMA Renaissance--Italy; Florence region (Italy)--Guidebooks; Florence (Italy)--BuildingsCOMMA structuresCOMMA etc.
Notes:
The Cathedral of the Grand Duke’s Palace has been called by several names during its long history. It is now known as the Palazzo della Signoria and serves as the town hall of Florence as well as a museum.

John of Bologna’s masterpiece is held to be his bronze engraving of Mercury.

“Angelo’s Night and DayCOMMA” to which Joseph Simpson refers in the letterCOMMA are likely Michelangelo’s sculptures of Twilight and Dawn (completed in 1534) in the Medici Chapel in the Church of San Lorenzo in Florence.

From Christopher HibbertCOMMA Florence: The Biography of a City (New York: NortonCOMMA 1993) and Michael LeveyCOMMA Florence: A Portrait (Cambridge: Harvard University PressCOMMA 1996).
Additional information from J. R. HaleCOMMA ed.COMMA The Italian Journal of Samuel Rogers (London: Faber & FaberCOMMA 1956).
Transcript:
Sunnyside.
Mayfield.
near Ashbourne.

Jun 28. 1878.

My dear FriendCOMMA
I have been waiting till thy beautiful gift came homeCOMMA in its Oak FrameCOMMA before sending thee in words the warm thanks which I feel for such an evidence of thy kind thought. It wasCOMMA indeedCOMMA a surpriseCOMMA to me when dear Annie returnedCOMMA and I shall value the gift not only for the kind giver’s sakeCOMMA but for its own intrinsic beauty.
I wish thee could see it in the Hall – in the place of honour nearthe Dining Room Door. It is mounted in whiteCOMMA with plain gilt beadCOMMA flat oak frameCOMMA unvarnishedCOMMA andCOMMA as all admitCOMMA it is just a household treasureCOMMA nothing less. Didst thee know my weakness for Raphael? I have seven of his CartoonsCOMMA [famed] & his own portrait besides! So thou seest what a treat thou hast given me! Ere long I hope [thee] will see the "Candelabri" where it now hangs. –
And you are now in Florence – close by the Cathedral – & the Grand Duke’s Palace – & John of Bologna’s masterpiece – & the Pitti & Uffizzi galleries! OhCOMMAwhat would I not give for a quiet day at Fiesole just now? Of course you have been thereCOMMA & seen these chasteCOMMA quaintCOMMA spirituelle works of the saintly Angelo. I enjoyed them exceedingly. Almost as much – tho’ in a different way – to Angelo’s Night & Day &c in the Church of St. Lorenzo. By the wayCOMMA I hope you have Childe Harold with you and Roger’s Italy. Do read both on the spotCOMMA and when you next go to the [----] Room (I forget its [right] name) at the Pitti pray makeCOMMA on my behalfCOMMA a salaam of special reverence before its priceless treasures.Agnes will tell you all our domestic details. We should much like to hear how my dear friendCOMMA your Sister ClementineCOMMA now is. If she comes to England during your absenceCOMMA please send us wordCOMMA for I should feel it a pleasure to offer her a welcome to England on her arrival in L’pool.
Annie has given us delightful accounts of your adventures. I trust you both suffer no longer from the cold. Won’t you let us see your art mementoes on yr. return? How rich you must feel!
With our united love to bothCOMMA – & renewed thanksCOMMA I am thineCOMMA sincerelyCOMMA
J. Simpson

Title: 1865 June 7COMMA BCOMMA to Mother and sister Annte
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; TysonCOMMA Jesse; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth Waln StokesCOMMA 1823-1902; WalkerCOMMA Sarah MillerCOMMA 1799-1874; TysonCOMMA James WoodCOMMA 1828-1900; DrinkerCOMMA Fanny (Frances M.)COMMA 1811?-1879; YarnallCOMMA Mary
Unidentified People: Cousin Mary/Cous. M.; Mr. (Leander) Waterman; Mr. N[?]
Subject: African Americans--History--1863-1877;  Freedmen--United States; Society of Friends; Education; Clothing and dress--Care; Women educators; Weddings; Love; Baltimore (Md.)--Social life and customs
Notes:
This letter appears to be a response to letters written by her mother and sister responding critically to her description of the party at Jesse Tyson’s house.

Wynndown is likely the home in OverbrookCOMMA PACOMMA of the Edward and Caroline Cope Yarnalls. The finding aid of MS Coll 1170 lists Wynndown as the 1873 home of Francis Cope YarnallCOMMA Edward and Caroline’s son.
Transcript:
B 6/7—65—

Dear Mother & sister Annte.

I think I’ll address you collectively this timeCOMMA as I suppose Caroline’s head’ll be turned with weddings & unable to appreciate common topics. I recd. yr. very interesting & spirited epistles this morn.g & reply at onceCOMMA in order that you may not have cause to complain of remissness this timeCOMMA & upon what ground you did it lastCOMMA I must say I cld. not discoverCOMMA as I think I have been up to the mark quite as much as you have. Thy remarks [a] on properness &c were quite edifying. I expect thee wd. be charmed with the Baltimore people. They are certainly most social & charming in their mannersCOMMA tho’ I dont believe afterallCOMMA when you come to the foundation of things that there is any more good substantial material among them than among some of that despised class denominated "the proper." As to the gentlemen I cant say that I have met any whom I consider very deeply interesting As far as gallantry & politeness go they are certainly very attractive Bt if we cld. only introduce a little more of these elements with some of our [imperturbables] I incline to think these wld. be found quite as deep in the long run. I must say it is refreshing to get hold of some thing that is more [impressible] than a stone & I intend to [---] up Baltimore ways loudly when I get home. Tell Cousin Mary she must hurry & come down as fast as she canCOMMA or I fearI shall not get to have my sprees with her. This morn the new teacher who is going to take my sch. arrived & I was promoted or depressed I dont know wh. to the rank of assistant to Mr WatermanCOMMA the principal of the sch. It is a splendid change for meCOMMA as his room is much pleasanter & I have none of the discipline to do but only the hearing of the lessons—intellectuallyCOMMA it seems a most magnificent advance frm. a-b only to geography and arithmetic & I shd. be quite willing to teach there for weeks if it was’nt for the hot weatherCOMMA as it isCOMMA howeverCOMMA considering the [--] &c I think I had better not stay much after the three months are up wh. will be abt. the mid of June--& very soon—as you will perceiveCOMMA so you may make preparations for meCOMMA soon after that time—I hope you’ll havepleasant little surprise prepared for me in the way of a closet—wh. wont be the linen closet—I have to keep up such an everlasting foolding and unfolding here that I shall be perfectly delighted to get a place to "hang up" in.

I expect I am indebted to my frd. Jesse for this release frm. the infants—I said to him in joke some time ago that I thotCOMMA I shd. give "notice" soon for them to get another teacher & he took it in earnest but I am very gladCOMMA on some acctsCOMMA as I shd like to get some ideas about older teaching frm Mr. W.

I expect you’ll enjoy [Mr. N’s] wedding most as much as Lilly’s—There was a young gentleman here the other day who told somebody that he thot L’s wedding was dreadfully stupidCOMMA & that he thot’ one or two of the bridesmaids (he did’nt say all) were the ugliest girls he had ever seen—not a very complimentary speech I think.
As I shall probably come home so soon it will not be worth while to send the things by express—tho’ if I cld only have had them now they wld. have been exceedingly useful -- I think maybe I’ll try & get myself a beige skt. here & we shall not be likely to have many more tea parties now the warm weather has come -- We’ve never heard any more abt. Jessies strawberry party & we’re afraid he’s forgotten it. He took us to a small one out at his bro. James’ night before last. We went in a buggy & pair & came home by moonlight—quite romantically -- The buggy is only used on very romantic occasionsCOMMA I believe. Its so nice here moonlight nights—the ladies all dress up in their whites & sit out on the front door stepsCOMMA & go round [seeing?] one another with beaux or beau less just as it happens.Has Fanny Drinker gone home? I reckon she has & where is Cous. Sarah? Give my love to her if she is about still. I ought to have written to her. Give my love also to all the Wynndowners also please give my love & congratulations to all the bride cousins & tell them I’m very sorry not to be giving them anything-- Maybe if I aint so lazy I’ll make em something after I get home. But dont tell em that. I believe this is all I have to say at present—will write and fix the day of course before I come. If Cous. M. comes soon please send the shawl and the [b----] skt. as I [---] much love to all—yrs. affec

ClemmyI shd. be pleased to have some [---] my return & also before my return

Title: 1846 January 21COMMA New BedfordCOMMA to F.R. CopeCOMMA Philada.
Creator: Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Identified People: CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; RodmanCOMMA EdmundCOMMA 1824-1903; OsborneCOMMA   CharlesCOMMA 1818-1891;      CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; HowlandCOMMA   Robert BowneCOMMA 1826-1916; TaberCOMMA AugustusCOMMA 1826-1898; RodmanCOMMA   Thomas RotchCOMMA 1825-1905; BarkerCOMMA BenjaminCOMMA 1822-1897; EddyCOMMA   Job Abraham TuckerCOMMA 1825-1885; HusseyCOMMA John BowneCOMMA   1826-1909; HusseyCOMMA William HowlandCOMMA 1824-1919;
Subject: Letter writing;  American poetry--Quaker authors; Voyages   and Voyages and Travels; Dating (Social customs); Mate selection--Humor;
Notes:
Note in another hand: Chas. Tabor to F. R. Cope - 1/21/1846.

The letter contains Charles Taber’s original poem “man & consequently woman.”
Transcript:
Dear Friend
New Bedfor[d] 1 mo 21 1846 –

Your letters were as duly received as unduly attended to. Not however that I did not make search for the subscription paper. actual[--] mon ami by two reasons one to comply with your request & another to trump up certain delinquents whose names were therein appended to certain generous figures which have not as yet been Transferred to my Pocket Book. -- Troubles in the family have since then as you surmised interfered with all other matters and hence. -- -- --. But if I cant find it. put us down viz. W.H. Hussey Jack do. Ed Rudman Tom do. S.R. Morgan Ben Barker Job A.T. Eddy. Rob’ B Howland. Ch. Osborne. Aug. & myself for the whole amot. –

Warned – I am armed. But Frank you need a rib. When I consider the imminent danger – you are in Every Sunday. of blowing away walking home from Meeting alone. I wonder at your remaining single. Let her be somewhat solid. – an anchor to windward – then no matter how the storm may rage. mignon you may under [bare] [poles] you know ride out the galeCOMMA rocked in the cradle of the Deep –

But a fig for your predictions – What satisfies me of thine felicity is in the 1st place & chiefly. I. am dreadful pertikler myself. & 2dly (see over the leaf.)some others are so likewise – "man & consequently woman"

Every creature likes his ease
English French & Roman
I’ve seen men were hard to please
& consequently Woman –

Womenkind will have their way
Even tell you go! man!
I like to hear men say their say
& consequently woman –

But marriage is a happy lot
He who doubts is no man
Men in plenty may be got
& consequently woman

You’re a good boy never fib
Gamble [----] & soCOMMA man!
Go and get yourself a rib
& consequently woman –

As for me you never fear
Sure I shant be slowCOMMA man!
Get some money – then – oh dear!
& consequently woman
Write me a systematic letter. -- I abominate this way you have got into of diplomatic correspondence. Every word of which you might publish in the newspapers. Hows [Con—cervis] my next leisure momentCOMMA shall be tak[en] up with a letter to him. Give New B. my best respects. whither I [go] on to Balt or not shortly. is doubtful. as every thing else is in this “wale”. but if “i” do I shall pop in to your counting room some fine morning –

Write me first. about the crops & the weather & business & all that sort of thing you know. a real interesting sensible sort of a letter. but – the girls –

with much regard.
yours’ &c
Charles Taber
F. R. Cope
H & A. Cope & Co
Philada.

Title: N.D.COMMA to Henry and Francis
Creator: Rachel Drinker
Identified People: CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; PerotCOMMA SarahCOMMA 1764-1806; YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816; ThomasCOMMA HannahCOMMA 1760-1806
Subject: Health; Grandparent and child; Poisonous plants; Poison ivy
Notes:
Dates 1805-08 written in pencil by archivist. Letter cannot be written after 1806COMMA because Sarah Perot died in 1806.

Transcript:
My Dear Henry and Frances

I am now Set down to talk a little with youCOMMA in the first placeCOMMA Frances how came thee Poisond I hope it is not badCOMMA I wish the would be more Carefull & not go where the poisen vines are I was much pleasd with thy letterCOMMA and hope it wont be the lastCOMMA and now my dear Henry I address myself to theCOMMA I was grattyfy’d with thy kind rememberance of me in thy Las[s]t letterCOMMA with Desires to see meCOMMA be assur’d you can’t Desire more to se me than I do to see youCOMMA but my way seems block’d up at presentCOMMA I thank thee for the Picture the sent meCOMMA I wish I could send thee something more than bare thanksCOMMA we all enjoy the blessing of health Except your aunt she continues in a very poor wayCOMMA our Cousen Sarah Perot is likewise in a very poor way your father intends writeing to youCOMMA Caroline will will hardly let me write she wants me to be done she say’s give my love to Henry and Frances & except a great deal from your Loving grandmother - Rachel Drinker
To
Frances Cope

Title: 1865 January 24COMMA To Henry Cope and Alfred Cope

Respected Friends;

Charles [Bouxall] interposed to save the property at the entrance of Fairmount Park from falling into evil handsCOMMA that would have devoted it to purposes to pollute the public morals. He designs to Convey it to the City to be kept as an open space as part of the park. The property was bought at a fair price; and if the cost be reduced the city will no doubt accept it with some burden. He will call to see if you will take an interest in the matter.

I am very truly &c.
Eli K. Price
1 mo 24.1865

Henry Cope
Alfred Cope
Henry CopeCOMMA
Alfred Cope.

Title: 1853 April 4COMMA to Clemmie
Creator: William Newbold
Subject: Faith;  Letter writing;
Transcript:
April 29COMMA1853

Will thee dear Clemmie accept this little book as a token that I appreciated thy patient endeavors to gratify my request; & also as a companion of thy sorrowful thoughtsCOMMA who would fainCOMMA with the blessing of GodCOMMA lead thee to peaceful meditations.--
Especially note the introduction. Thee will find some passages marked; these struck me as applicable to thy feelings--But do not feel compelled to read
because I give; rather seek its counselsCOMMA as thee is drawn by a sense of need; and perhaps thee may find a fountain of joy which thee has never know yet. But it will only be as a guide to the everlasting spring of peace which is in Jesus our Saviour.
I opened my Bible to find a promise for thee & this was the verse which met my eye. Isa xxxv 4 "Say to them that are of a fearful heartCOMMA be strongCOMMA fear not: behold your God will come with vengeanceCOMMA even God
with a recompense; he will come and save you."
Will thee not bend a listening earCOMMA and a believing heart to such a gracious message?
I have added a few thoughts on the last leaf of the book; and with them wld. give the warm affection of

Thy Cousin
Wills

Title: 1815 August 10COMMA Cape MayCOMMA N.J.COMMA to Thomas StewardsonCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: William Sansom
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873; CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816
Unidentified People: George; George Vaun; Joseph [Lowry]
Subject: Death; Drowning; Family; Grief
Transcript:
Cape May August 10--1815--
7 OClock Evening

Dear Brother

Thomas P Copes son FrancisCOMMA & his brother William were bathing in the Surf about 11 this morningCOMMA & Francis is no moreCOMMA they were about middle depth & an unexpected wave took them both off their feetCOMMA separated themCOMMA forced Wm to let go his hold of FrancisCOMMA& overwelmed them both out of their depth--William was unable to recover his BrotherCOMMA who sunk & disappeared into a watery grave--every attempt at recovering the body has hitherto [------] without success.--
dear Wm is in the deepest afflictionCOMMA but has recovered a becoming calmness of mind--his friends here have advised him to remain a day or twoCOMMA which he has reluctantly acquiesed inCOMMA & his underst desire to return to his Parents & friends will be without much delay--
These melancholy tidings I tho't it best to get thru immediately to communicate to dear T P CopeCOMMA who with his wife I hope will be supported in resignation to the Divine will in this trying dispensation--As nothing can now be done here in the case here I do not expect any of the Family would think of coming downCOMMA & they would likely
miss of William on his way up home
George and my self are well & trust will in due time see you again in healthCOMMA with dear Love to you all I conclude Thy affectionate Brother
William Sansom

Their will remains no other communication has been made to Thos. P Cope-- [-----] the [-----] it seems likely William will have a seat in a waggen hired for Joseph [Lowry] & FamilyCOMMA to leave this on 2 day morning--
Thomas Stewardson
or in his absence from the city
George Vaun
No 90 Arch St. near 4th St.
Capt. Bennet will deliver this himself Philadelphia

Title: 1906 DecemberCOMMA Cunard R.M.S. IverniaCOMMA to Rachel C. Cope
Creator: H. Simpson
Unidentified People: Anna; H. Simpson (author)
Subject: Ocean Travel; African American domestics
Transcript:
[12. .1906]
Cunard R. M. S. "IVERNIA"

Tues. Morning.

My dearest old Chellie.
If only I could have thee within earshotCOMMA even if it was but by the agitating telephoneCOMMA how I could pour forth to thee! But instead I'm afraid it will be rather a sorry makeshift as my mind & hand are far from steadyCOMMA- both of these show up worse on paper. Dear heartCOMMA I don't know how to tell thee what all this loving thought has meant to me this past week. It seemed as
if it literally "encompassed" me- such dear words by letter here [-ailing] with those exquisite flowers & then the sweet little book- it was all most heast warming & dearer of thee than I can say- Bless thee again & again - & oh! how very good is the [--------] deepCOMMA true love that I know all these things represent! I saved the little book as I saidCOMMA until we got well awayCOMMA & each day’s sweet thought has been so cheering through these rather dismall days. Thy own dear wordsCOMMA best of all-in spite of Dora Greenwell’s perfect understanding of the deep things of friendship- Anna’s packet has been a perfect delight to us & hope to tell her myself if possible. But we still roll so badly that writing is not very easyCOMMA & we have left it until almost the 11th hour hoping for better things [we] mail this at [-------]. We found most capital staterooms waiting for usCOMMA & started forth quite gaily with so many little last hand shakes from our kind friendsCOMMA but that first dinner is the only meal we have taken in the SaloonCOMMA & we have kept ever quietly to our rooms except for a few hours on Sunday when we could sit on deck. Not that we have had any stormbut it was very coldCOMMA snowed a little the first three daysCOMMA & we had high seas. This with a heavy cargo of grain has kept us rolling hard all the way overCOMMA for a large export of cotton that would have steadied the shipCOMMA failed to arrive in timeCOMMA we hearCOMMA & also we are not properly ballasted. But we are making good timeCOMMA & hope to be in tomorrow (wed.) evening probably too late to get homeCOMMA but in time to lay our heads on a steady pillow!
In spite of all the knocking about we have hadCOMMA trunks traveling across the floor &c. we have neither of us been down to the crisisCOMMA but intense nausea has made a complete coward of meCOMMA & L has had no ambitions! She sends her dear love & hopes to write soon her thanks for the lovely carnation & roses. My dear love to you allCOMMA that often
I have recalled my [coming] visit to you! Fare thee well thee very dear person always thy loving old
H

Title: 1867 July 21COMMA Laurel HouseCOMMA to Father
Creator: Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson) Cope:  1848-1937
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1850-1924; CopeCOMMA RuthannaCOMMA 1834-1879; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; EmlenCOMMA Eleanor CopeCOMMA 1854-1920; StokesCOMMA Tom (Thomas Pym Cope)COMMA 1843-1918; CopeCOMMA MargaretCOMMA 1856-1948;
Unidentified People: Carry Rowland
Subject: Clothing and dress; Postal service; Outdoor recreation; Country life; Nature; Weather; Family; Food habits; Health; Rural transportation
Transcript:
Laurel House July 21st/67

My dear FatherCOMMA
Tom has written to thee so very latelyCOMMA that I fear I can hardly find enough of interest to fill a second letterCOMMA & besides I am almost afraid to write one to go so farCOMMA & cost so much; but perhaps a little Cattskill news would not be unwelcome. We have been here for several days but owing to the unkindness of the weather have not been able to accomplish as much as we could wish – we made one very successful expedition to Haines’ falls on 6th day morningCOMMA we took a carriage or rather an express-wagon & rode over thereCOMMA & had a fine scrambleCOMMA we went down the stream to the lower fallsCOMMA & scrambleddown to the footCOMMA Tom concluded not to go all the way as it was so rough & hardCOMMA & one after another gave out until when we arrived at the foot there was no one but HarryCOMMA EllieCOMMA Madge & I leftCOMMA but we were very glad we persevered & thought ourselves well repaidCOMMA you never told us last fall how beautiful it was. We did not get home till after they had gone to dinner so were obliged to go in just as we were in our mountain dressesCOMMA & as we were all prepared concluded to go under Tom’s guidence to visit Bastion falls afterwards. So about 4 we set off prepared to have a very jolly timeCOMMA Tom went ahead and cleared the wayCOMMA & we followed jumping over the logs & stones which Thomas declare[d] were not there last fallCOMMA & must be the result of last winters slide;Just as we arrived at the head of the fallCOMMA & were congratulating ourselves on the prospect before usCOMMA what should it do but begin to rain! At first we thought it would only be a little showerCOMMA & took shelter under the trees as there were unfortunately no overhanging rocks – this did very well for a little whileCOMMA but instead of stopping the rain got harder & harderCOMMA & at last began to find its way through the trees & onto us – we soon found ourselves getting very moistCOMMA & began to confer on measures of reliefCOMMA it was at length concluded as we were already quite wetCOMMA & there was no sign of stopping to start for home. At first it seemed to slacked a little & we pushed bravely onCOMMA but it got faster & faster & by the time we reached the foot of Cauterskillwe were thoroughly drenched & in despair at having to ascend all those dreadful steps – I wish thee could have seen us as we came up to the house too tired to run any more dragging along all dripping & hotCOMMA looking as much as possible like drowned rats. The gentlemen on the piazza were so polite as not even to smileCOMMA but I’m sure I could not have helped. it. I don’t think we any of us suffered for it thoughCOMMA & I did not even feel tired in the eveningCOMMA this mountain air is so invigorating. Yesterday it rained perseveringly & we had to amuse ourselves as best we could readingCOMMA & walking on the piazza. The company here is not as congeneal as we could wishCOMMA & we often envy Aunt Annie & Cous. Clem in their Adirondack society. One young gentleman regaledus last night with some Scotch songsCOMMA but it was very inferior to Carry Rowland’s performance. I think Tom told thee that we have the same room you had last yearCOMMA & enjoy it very muchCOMMA it is so nice having that beautiful view always before usCOMMA I think I enjoy it much more than the map in front of the Mountain House; it is so constantly changingCOMMA sometimes that distant mountain will be entirely hid by the cloudsCOMMA & it is so beautiful to see them coming & going; we have had no perfectly clear weather since we arrivedCOMMA & have become almost discouragedCOMMA & the chamber-maid told me by way of comfort yesterdayCOMMA that it sometimes rained strait aheadfor a weekCOMMA however it really does look like clearing nowCOMMA the clouds are drifting awayCOMMA & there are great patches of blue-sky. If it is clear tomorrow we have planned an expedition to the Plauterkill which I hope will be a success. Tom Stokes & Harry had intended starting on a fishing excursion yesterday but after routing out of their beds about 4COMMA & eating sandwitches preparatory to startingCOMMA were obliged to give up on account of the rainCOMMA & go back to bed in disgust. We have only received one letter from home which reported all wellCOMMA but by the time this reaches thee thee will have received more recent news. All send their love & wishes for thy welfare wh. means I suppose that they hope thee is not awfully sickCOMMA in which I heartily joinCOMMA Thee must notimagin from my description that we are not having a good time for we are only the rain was a little dampening but since the sun has come out we feel very lively & up to any amount of of scrambling. Write by every steamer & tell us every thing.
Thy very affectionate
Lily

Title: 1896 June 30COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Frank
Creator: Witmer Stone:  1866-1939
Unidentified People: Stew Brown
Subject: Birds--Collection and preservation;  Ornithology; Outdoor   recreation;
Notes: Letter is written on Academy of Natural Sciences of   Philadelphia letterhead.
Transcript:
[Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia June 30th 1896

Dear Frank

I am greatly pleased to hear of your success in adding some more birds to your listCOMMA and especially that you keep up your enthusiasm sufficiently to keep up active search for birds. I know from personal experience that there is a tendency in summer vacations to become lazyCOMMA but I hope the mountain air is gong to keep you active. Water-thrushes alwaysCOMMA so far as I have heardCOMMA breed among the rootsof upturned stumps. If there are any such in the swamp it would pay you to examine them carefully. I hope you preserved the bird to make sure which species it was. I suppose it was the small billed one though the Louisiana species does go as far north as the Water Gap. The Snow birds you need not regret so seriouslyCOMMA the loss of two will not materially affect them & they will be very interesting as indicating more clearly the possible relationship of the Penna bird to the Carolina [Junes]. I should like to see themCOMMA if you can bring them with you in the fall.

And now I wish to ask a favor If you should go over to theElk Mt. region I wish you could get me a young Snow Bird – they have speckled breasts – I am very anxious to secure the first plumages of all our birds & have nearly all now except those which breed in the mountains.

If you come across any young Warblers (except Chest-sided & Black & White) or any young Thrushes or Savanna Sparrows I should be just as thankful to get one of them.

I don’t think it is as bad to kill a young bird as an old one during the breeding seasonShould you get one you could remove the entrailsCOMMA put in a little cotton with some carbolic acid (or plaster) & send it by mail it will carry all right. Don’t put yourself to trouble however.

I saw Stew & he greatly regrets his inability to accept your invitation as you have doubtless heard from him by this time. He is organizing quite an expedition of Phila & N.Y. botanists to convene at Pocono Mts on the 4th

I am always glad to hear from you and will try to keep the bird interests stirred up by writing to you

With regards to your family I remain sincerely yours

Witmer Stone

P.S. How does the Guitar progress? (?)

Title: 1817 June 13COMMA StoddartsvilleCOMMA to Thomas P. Cope Esq.COMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; MinerCOMMA CharlesCOMMA 1780-1865; FoxCOMMA William
Unidentified People: Heller family; Stoddart family; "Aunt"
Subject: Voyages and travels; Nature; Roads--Pennsylvania; Voyages and travels--Health  aspects; Quakers--Travel; Shipping; Boardinghouses; Banks and banking; Transportation; International trade
Geographic Subjects: Wilkes-Barre (Pa.); England; Easton (Pa.); Bethlehem (Pa.); Nazareth (Pa.); Wind Gap (Pa.); Tunkhannock (Pa.)
Notes:
Notes in another hand on back of letter: “Henry W. Drinker Stoddartsville
Pa June 13th [received] 17th 1817
Pge 12 1/2 ct.”
Transcript:
Stoddartsville June the 13th. 1817–
Dear Uncle.
By William Drinker who pass’d Here on the 9th I receivd thy remembrance of the 3d inst– What Charles Miner has done or is now about I cannot precisely say not hav[ing] seen Him or any of his friends since [my] Last
I question the Establishment of the proposed Bank at Wilkes barre & beleive also that if it ever does go into Operation it will be by compromise and by a [di----] of the few offices of [---] attatched to it– Humble merit will I presume stand but a poor chance–
Mr Arndt on whom I depended for [the] Hemlock Bark Has not yet ground it but I hope He will attend to it shortly– if it in any degree succeeds [in] England it will be Highly important to this Count[r]y as well as convenient to ship overseas– I beleive that the mak[ing] pot & pearl Ash might prove an advantageous thing to us more than to any other persons [We] owning the nearest Large Body of suitable timber for the purpose – if it will pay for its mak[ing] & a reasonable sum for outlay & superintendance it will answer us as a means of clear[ing] Land –
I am glad that thy mind is made up for a peep at this quarter of the world – I think it will be likely to be beneficial to thy Health as also to Aunts – Some Rough travell[ing] there will no doubt be – but generaly speak[ing] the Roads are tolerable to the mouth of Tunkhannock– Thereare no excelent Taverns on the Route so far as I am acquainted– I think the one Here is the Best & likely to be the most pleasant for the Residence of aunt– Gentlemen can be well accomodated at Easton & at Wilkes barre at Mr Whites in the first nammed place & at Mr Arndts in the second in Both Houses there is Rather too much noise and Drink[ing] to be entirely agreeable to Ladies – Here also we have more noise than is pleasant– There be from 15 to 20 of Stoddarts work[ing] hands quart[ere]d in the House –
The Road by Easton is Rather worse than that by Bethlehem & Nazareth & I think generaly the accommodations are better on this last Route– from Nazareth to Hellers at the Wind gap at which House I have generaly procured tolerable Eating & pretty clean– from thence about 17 miles to William Sox’s upon the top of Pokono – where th[e]y make prety good coffee & give you what ever they may Have in the House in a tolerably cleanly stile– from thence to this place say 12 miles –
The present is about as pleasant a Time to Travel in this county as any other Dur[ing] the summer – ere the grain is cut which will not be Done before the Last of next monthHowever the Weather is now variable and we may expect occasional RainsCOMMA until after Harvest –
in the Last of August & to the middle of September is generaly more settled weather – as to the [Gnats] they Have already come & in the woods Bite sharply– This [they] will continue to Do until September – But out of the woods we do not find them Troublesome– There are not any curiosities worthy a name from Philada to this place– The Habits & manners of the people on the Route may perhaps afford Something novel – The scenery also & general Aspect of the County will be new – [marbly] nature in Her Roughest garb will surround you – you will have pure Air & pure water & I doubt not to good [appetites] as to enable you to Encounter much coarser fare than usual – in the neighbourhood of Easton-Bethlehem & Nazareth is a lime stone county – & I would have you beware of the water – it is no doubt wholesome but to persons [unaccustomed] to it it is often unpleasant in its effects– if I know when you intend com[ing] up I will endeavor to join you at Hellers – I have been constantly interupted since I began writing which must excuse this scrawl–
affectionaly thy nephew. H.W.Drinker –Stoddartsville
12 1/2
June 14th
Thomas P. Cope Esq.
Merchant
Philada.

Title: 1864COMMA HomeCOMMA to Annie
Creator: Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866

Notes:

HarryCOMMA AllowedCOMMA ConsideringCOMMA SkinCOMMA SmoothCOMMA AmidstCOMMA SentencesCOMMA BoundCOMMA DegreeCOMMA SimplicityCOMMA SearchingCOMMA BrainsCOMMA MeaningCOMMA VarietyCOMMA FollowingCOMMA ClosedCOMMA RelishCOMMA AcquaintancesCOMMA ClosingCOMMA ExercisesCOMMA SleighCOMMA CarriageCOMMA Sitting
Transcript:
Home 5th Day eve [1864]

My dear Annie

I scribbled a little note to thee this morning about the nurse they had for cos R Pearsall but could not get it into the dispatch box as I wished. So will tell thee nowCOMMA that aunt R P [-] says he was a very nice person indeedCOMMA satisfactory to them in all aspects. He was to leave the house today but can be heard of them. I [----] of Arch [St] above 15th I believeCOMMA but I am not sure of the exact number. I was very glad to hear from Edith Collins todayCOMMA whom I met in the storeCOMMA that Harry was better & had a good appetite. I hope cos Lizzie is better too & that your [aux-----] are lessened. I imagine thee and Clemmy a pleasant evening together this ever. I enjoyed
my visit much & have been retelling the various items of news to our circle at home. I came home at two [oclock]COMMA after a varied experience in street crossing &ct. The walking defies description. Lizzie & I lacked about for sometime in front of the Phila Library unable to effect a landing & finally gave up in despair. The gentlemen were very polite. The policemen vice versa. But our colored man exceeded the last named so much in gallantry that we concluded “a respectable white man might be almost as good as a colored one” – And now my dear I must confess our fault[s]. I was so absorbed with the difficulties of locomotion & some other thingsCOMMA that I never once thought of the errand at “Gutekunsts” till I was on my way home. I am ashamed of myself but will try to repair the neglect. Dear [Anne] to thee & thy sister[s] E & Clemmy. Write very soon tell me how your [---].

Thy loving [a-------] S S Reeve.

Title: 1843 March 4COMMA WashingtonCOMMA to Thomas P. CopeCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: John Sergeant:  1779-1852
Unidentified People: Judge Thompson
Subject: Businesspeople
Transcript:
WashingtonCOMMA Mar. 4. 1843

My dear SirCOMMA

It grieves me to inform you that in the case of Vidal v Mayor (Girard case) the Chief Justice announced this morningCOMMA that the Court directed the cause to be continued to the next termCOMMA for a reargumentCOMMA and to give time to the Court for a more deliberate consideration of the matter. This is all that was saidCOMMA and all that I know. ProbablyCOMMA the factCOMMA that Judge Thompson left Washington soon after the argumentCOMMA and that there were but six Judges remainingCOMMA may have had some influence.
I expect to be at home in a week or ten daysCOMMA and will be glad soon after to see the CommitteeCOMMA and communicate any thing further which may come to my knowledge.

Please make known the contents of this
letter to the Committee and the BoardCOMMA andCOMMA if needfulCOMMA file itCOMMA tho written as a private letter.
I never doubted that there would be a clear decision in our favorCOMMA and the announcement this morning was as unexpectedCOMMA as it was painfulCOMMA to.

V. very truly
John Sergeant

Thomas P Cope Esq.
From John Sergeant

Thomas P Cope Esq.
Philada

Title: 1894 November 16COMMA SunnysideCOMMA MayfieldCOMMA AshbourneCOMMA to My dear Friend
Creator: Joseph Simpson:  1835-1901
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth Waln StokesCOMMA 1823-1902; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; HarrisonCOMMA SmithCOMMA 1818-1883; SimpsonCOMMA AgnesCOMMA 1839-1925;
Subject: Europe--Description and Travel;  LincolnCOMMA AbrahamCOMMA 1809-1865--Childhood and youth
Notes:
The workpeople that Joseph Simpson mentions in his letter are likely the people working at his spinning mill at Mayfield. Joseph and his brother revived the ailing mill and built housing and reading rooms for their workersCOMMA gradually improving relations between the workers and themselves and increasing the mill’s profitability. From the Dictionary of Quaker Biography.

The “bairns” of whom Joseph sends good news are likely his children Agnes Alderson Simpson (b. 1871)COMMA Sara Mildred Simpson (b. 1874)COMMA and Joseph Simpson (b. 1875/6).

Francis Reeve Cope sent the following book to Joseph: John Torrey MorseCOMMA Jr. ...Abraham Lincoln. Volumes 25 and 26 in the American Statesman Series. Boston: Houghton MifflinCOMMA first published 1893.

Awbury is the family enclave of the Cope and Evans families and their relationsCOMMA located in GermantownCOMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA PennsylvaniaCOMMA and founded by Henry Cope.
Transcript:
Sunnyside
Mayfield
Ashbourne

Nov.16.1894

When I received thy very welcome letterCOMMA & the handsome volumes which accompanied itCOMMA I felt once more that strong desireCOMMA which often stirs meCOMMA to visit AmericaCOMMA & to see again those dear friends whoCOMMA nearly thirty years agoCOMMA received me there with such unbounded kindness. Some of these have passed awayCOMMA but a few are leftCOMMA and of these thouCOMMA my dear friendCOMMA with thy good Brotherand your dear WivesCOMMA are kept in very cherished remembrance. So it was delightful to get thy letterCOMMA & since its receipt I have spent several hours in readingCOMMA with great interestCOMMA this excellent Life of your great President. How it has recalled the old days! I have gone over so much that had lain dormant so longCOMMA & am more than ever impressed with Lincoln’s marvellous development from his miserable early surroundings. How could any man so outlive his environment? And who could have believed that any man with such aparentageCOMMA & such debasing influences around him in early lifeCOMMA couldCOMMA by any innate powerCOMMA or any outward circumstanceCOMMA become the great man Lincoln proved himself later on. We are slow to learn God’s lesson that He chooses his instruments very differently to ourselves.
So far as I can test Mr. Morse’s accuracyCOMMA he is very just; neither hiding Lincoln’s shortcomings nor wishful to make out “a caseCOMMA” pro or conCOMMA but to act judicially. I hope to give our Workpeople an hour’s talk this WinterCOMMA based largely upon this interesting Biography.Thanks for thy kind message to Agnes & the [baines]. All are well. How I wish they could see thee in the fleshCOMMA for they often hear thee quotedCOMMA and are familiar with thy faceCOMMA through the Portrait which is hungCOMMA with Uncle Smith Harrison’sCOMMA in our Library – the much valued gift of thy good sonCOMMA Hazen – to whom please give my love.
I trust you are all well: it would be a real pleasure to see you all againCOMMA butCOMMA at presentCOMMA I see no chance of getting away. With our united love to all our friends at AwburyCOMMA I amCOMMA
ThineCOMMA very sincerely
J. Simpson.

Title: [1865 May ?]COMMA 190 Calvert stCOMMA to Mother and sisters
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: TysonCOMMA Jesse; CopeCOMMA EdgarCOMMA 1838-1895; WalkerCOMMA Sarah MillerCOMMA 1799-1874; CopeCOMMA JasperCOMMA 1775-1856
Unidentified People: Miss TalbotCOMMA Miss Field
Subject: Boardinghouses;  Women educators; Freedmen--United States; Society of Friends; Education; Domestics; Clothing and dress--Care; African Americans--History--1863-1877
Notes:
Although this letter was dated May 1865 by the archivistCOMMA it was probably written earlier. Because the letter describes Clementine’s journey to BaltimoreCOMMA it may predate her first letter written from Baltimore in March 1865.

The boardinghouseCOMMA run by Miss TalbotCOMMA at which Clementine stays is located at 190 Calvert Street.
Transcript:
2nd day eve
190 Calvert st

Dear Mother & sistersCOMMA Tired as I am I must write you a few words to nightCOMMA as I shall probably be at the schCOMMA in the morn & the mail closes at 1 P.M. & I thought you’d like to know that we arrived safely about 5 this aft. & I am installed in my new boarding house wh. promises to be very nice. They ladies were exceedingly kind & welcomed me as if I had been an old friend They are so free & easy. One of them Miss Talbot came right up in my room & talked to me while I was getting dressed – & was as kind as possible They used to know uncle Jasper & quantities of our friendsCOMMA so that I begin to feel quite at home already It is a large 4story house with a very nice pleasant parlorCOMMA & a comfortable dining roomCOMMA where we had tea on a little refreshment table—the 4 school “marms”—as cozy as possible. They say “thee” & call me by name wh. makes me feel much less strange
Jesse called a few minutes after we arrived in his elegant carriageCOMMA having been to one of the dipots to meet usCOMMA but we unfortunately had got out at the wrong one; & very much out of our way. The ladies seem in very moderate circumstances only keeping one servantCOMMA & a sch. of near 40 day scholars. consequently they have not much time to attend to housekeeping nor much talent in that way I shd. think. Their kindness however makes amends.The house is on a very high situation & there is a fine view of the city fr[m]. my roomCOMMA wh is in the 2nd story & very airy & pleasant. But there is no closet unfortunatley wh. is remarkably home like & seems to be my fate. Not a place to hang a dressCOMMA but I have 5 beaureau drawers & can make out. So much for the house. 3rd day morn. We went last evening to see the sch. & I was most agreeably disappointed in it in every respect.. The rooms are well ventilated & airy & no disagreeable odour. & their state of advancement is surprising. There were a few to be sure who reminded me of Busy—in his attempt to spell girl—but mostly they were astonishingly quick--& cld. add & subtract like quite accomplished arithmeticaians. Quite as fast as I cld. myself. They were mostly adults. In the morningThey are children.
I am to have a class of 30 & am very glad to find that I shall be in the school with Miss FieldCOMMA who is a very pleasant young lady about my own age I shd. judgeCOMMA & we can go backwards & forward to getherCOMMA & shall be companionable I hope. The morning session is frm. 9 till 1 1/2 not 3. The evening teaching you can take part in or not as you choose. So it will not be very laborous & in every respectCOMMA it is going to be I thinkCOMMA much pleasanter than I had anticipated. & if you are only satisfied I think I can be very comfortable & enjoy the work & the change.Love to Cousin Sarah.

Title: 1848 to Francis R. CopeCOMMA Philada.
Creator: Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Identified People: CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; HartshorneCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1823-1897; HartshorneCOMMA Mary Elizabeth BrownCOMMA b. 1823; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; TaberCOMMA William C.
Unidentified People: Addison
Subject: American poetry--Quaker authors; Betrothal; Health; Voyages and Travels; Classical literature; Letter writing
Notes:
Annotated in pencil on last page:
“Poem apparently alluding to Henry Hartshorne engagement & his loss to his companions.”

“Miss B.” is probably Henry Hartshorne’s wife-to-beCOMMA Mary Elizabeth Brown (later Hartshorne).

The watermark consists of a BCOMMA under which there is an ornate crest.
Transcript:
Oh Poesy! what wight of Wretched State
Een at the lowest bottom of his woe
When griefs surround him or sad toils await
When cold misfortunes hand doth round him blow
But calls on thee to aid against the foe?
Come gentle soother of wan misery’s train
Before the scowling can away doth go
Come shower thy spirit down on me again
*For Frank Cope wants a letter – shall he want in vain!!!!
*Here the Poet alludes to Danae & Jupiter olympus an ancient buck

So Henricus is dead! dead ere his prime!
Alas! that he should share the doom of man!
Who now is left to build the lofty rhyme?
Although his altitude was but a span
It [overtopped] his years. = But no man can
Add cubits to his stature or his days –
Vain task to stop the fateful cruel hand
That wields the gory scissons. -- Worldy praise
High thought – nor noble deed its destined course delays. –

(Now all that second Paragraph is gammon
But if you really think it worth the trouble
If twill not seem like too great love of mammon
I think you can get quite as much or double
Prime cost – besides – perhaps – who knows the bubble
Called Fame / which you’ll keep for commissions
I want the rhino – all besides is stubble)
By handing it about without omission
‘Mong'st those who loudest wail that he's gone to Perdition)
I want you to hand it particularly to Miss B. --------. Send on the amount collected for the benefit of the author as soon after the funeral as possible.---

But as in olden timeCOMMA when-freshly sprung
From the great Maker’s hand – all Earth was fair
Excelling in its beauty – fresh & young
When strength & health perfumed with the balmy air
And all Earth’s Gifts were far beyond compare
With what now ‘neath Heaven’s weary blessing grows
What time the grove Hesperia apples bare
From out the salt salt wave fair Venus rose
Graceful her dripping locks she round her did dispose

So from the Sorrow tearful deep & sad
Which mourns thy memory departed Shade
While oer the dust which erst thy spirit clad
And the loved link which bound thee to us made
We grieve thou coulds’t not Death’s cold hand evade
Who plucks the brightest flowers – hard to please
[While] tears fall fast from all that thou shouldst fade
Love ever radiant though steeped in tears
Love-rosy tints the clouds – Love sooths the foamy seas
or Love heavenly love appears
Just as you please

all the while alluding in an inexpressibly delicate manner to the very peculiar situation in which Miss B. ----- and I find ourselves since Harry’s departure You may show them to the lady. Present them as the first fruits. ----
But enough of this nonsense - If you are heartily tired of it remember you began it. -- and when my Muse gets well under weigh – like Addisons there’s no stopping her. ------- Father has been unwell for some time and so much so that a good part of the business devolves on me – in connection with some other domestic affairs – putting a very unlooked for and regrettable veto on my proposed trip to Philada –
Perhaps another year may bring around the same expectations which I hope will not be disappointed
Before that time however I trust to see you on [here] for although it is not to be presumed that New Bedford alone should possess sufficient attractions – to be the terminus of your visit it may serve as a [stepping] stone to some place that has more ---
Remember me to [Tom] [&] your friend
Charles Taber
Francis R. Cope
care of H. & A. Cope
Philada.

Title: 1853 December 5COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Clemmie
Creator: William Newbold
Unidentified People: Nellie; Maggie; catter; Carrie; Aunt Susan; Uncle William
Subject: Faith;
Transcript:
Phila. Decr. 5/1853

Does thee not dear ClemmieCOMMA open my letterCOMMA with at least a coldCOMMA if not a repulsive feeling?COMMA thinking to thyself--again the unwelcome subjectCOMMA--would it had not come so soon--&c &c? I have but one or two ideas to present at presentCOMMA yet am thankful to be permitted to do this.--Thy occupation about many thingsCOMMA I do appreciateCOMMA and would never chide thee for--delay or--naught else in answering me;--on the contrary can truly say I have rarely received letters more truly satisfactory than thine;--but one thing they lackCOMMA the joyful news that thee has accepted the offer of salvationCOMMA and the effect of this change in all thy words and feelings. I will hope for this also;--for nothing is impossible with God.

over
One thought is this; thee says thee has an unwilling heart;--that the only reason thee can give for not resolving isCOMMA thee is unwilling to resign the world;--did thee ever think of this text "He will make them willing in the day of his power"? God can give a willing heart;--Thy will is corruptedCOMMA as well as all thy powersCOMMA--ask of him.--But thee wld know if it is not better to omit prayer than to ask "when I do not in reality desire these blessingsCOMMA when my mind is not in a fit state for prayer".--But if this is one of thy necessities why not pray for it; prayCOMMA that thee may pray aright; that thee may receiveCOMMA first the desireCOMMA then the blessing. Would thee neglect the only source from whence salvation can come?--Satan will tempt thee toCOMMA and if he succeed in thisCOMMA needs no other temptation to insure his end.--
Let me tell thee of a fact; a friend of mine (the person who told me the circumstance/accompanied a young lady when she visited a minister to speak of her soul's salvation;--he urged that she shld. accept the offer of redemption thru ChristCOMMA that
she should resolve whom she wld serve; she replied she cld. not give up the worldCOMMA but that she wanted to be a christian;--"but you must chooseCOMMA between the world & deathCOMMA--or--Jesus & his salvation.--I will leave you;"--he did so for--some moments &retd.COMMA--"have you resolved"COMMA--she cld. notCOMMA--"You must determine whether you will be savedCOMMA or lostCOMMA" he waited a few momentsCOMMA and with the deepest emphasis she said "I will resolve".--from that day she was a new creatureCOMMA & for years past hasCOMMA &now hasCOMMA adorn her profession.--Dear ClemmieCOMMA for a long while thee has been halting; the Holy Spirit has not yet deserted thee; but he may; and that is the second that I wld offer;--if thee rejects him now he may not returnCOMMA thee will succeed in stifling his voice in thy heart--he will be grieved awayCOMMA and thy soul will be lost; can thee take this responsibility?--Would it not be thy "soul's suicide"? Other than wldst hearken even then in this thy day."--Sinner turn why will thee die?
God the Spirit asked thee why:
He who all thy life has stroveCOMMA
Wou'd thee to embrace his love.
Will thou not his grace receive?
Will thou still refuse to live?
OCOMMA thou dying sinner whyCOMMA
Why will thou for-ever die? A little tract enclosed speaks in the same strain.--But thee fears to possess a Christian's portionCOMMA because of trials &cCOMMA the word of God says "Godliness is profitable with all thingsCOMMA having the promise of the life that now isCOMMA & of that wh. is to come."--And from my heart I can say that it is a most delightful portion; I cannot tell thee all I think of itCOMMA thee would wearyCOMMA & time is not;--but I wld not exchange the joys I have had for all the world can give; & that which we hope for is "a far more exceedingCOMMA and eternal insight of glory."--and this is freely offered to thee.--Now my dear Cousin I leave thee for the presentCOMMA--will thee not resolve?--
Let me give thee some news; we are only pretty well all having colds; Nellie walks down stairs & round the yard & is pretty bright; Father not retd yetCOMMA are hoping for a letter to say when; Maggie & [-oll] are with us Catter has been sick but is better. Carrie spent an aft. & eve at our house & is as lovely as everCOMMA comes soon to stay several days.--Have not seen our fds at Bristol or recd aught fm them since I saw thee. Love to Aunt Susan & Uncle Wm.--Hoping--yet fearing for thee; As ever

Willie

Title: 1862 September 17COMMA to Chellie
Creator: Anna S. Biddle
Identified People: CobbCOMMA HowellCOMMA 1815-1868; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; JacksonCOMMA StonewallCOMMA 1824-1863;
Unidentified People: Cousin George Biddle; George Emlen; John Thayre; Cousin Sam Cox; Martha Henderson; Uncle James; Uncle Clem
Subject: EuropeCOMMA Western;  Travel--Religious aspects--Christianity; Family; Military history; Postal service; United States--History--Civil WarCOMMA 1861-1865; Recruiting and enlistment; Military serviceCOMMA Voluntary
Transcript:
Sept. 17th. 1862.

Dear ChellieCOMMA
I have been waiting for newsCOMMA before answering your last letter and am now not much better offCOMMA but you write such very short letters that I am not at all conscientious about making mine short also. I wish my dearCOMMA that you would make your letters a little longerCOMMA & if you do not you will see mine gradually decreasing in lengthCOMMA till there is hardly any letter at all. Uncle James went off to Harrisburg on Monday as did Uncle Clem George Emlen John Thayre (my cousins) and Cousin George Biddle. Uncle Clem never told a soul that he was going and on Sunday night when John went to the Baltimore depot to see Gerge Emlen and John Thayre off to his surprise he saw Uncle Clem.He was going off without bidding us good-bye when perhaps we may never see him again. He always was very queer but this beats every thing. Is not the war news splendid? I have not been so glad since the battle of DrainsvilleCOMMA particularly about Howell Cobb the old traitor. There is now not the slightest fear of our having Stonewall Jackson in Philadelphia but I pity the poor citizens of Cincinnati. Cousin Sam Cox was called to a churchthere (St. Paul’s) and he accepted. He left town two weeks from yesterday and when he arrived at Cincinnati he was not allowed to enter the city but was sent to a boarding house about two miles from the city. There he is now with his wife children and father. Of their furniture they know nothing and are not allowed to go to the city to see about it. Every morning at five o’clock all the bells in the town ring and every man who is able to carry a gun assembles in some perminent place and from thence they go out into the country to wait for the enemy. Even clergymen are forced to fight & Cousin Sam is in almost hourly fear of being made to serve. I received a letter from Martha Henderson just now.They are at present in Wiesbaden and Martha says that if her relations were with her she would never again wish to leave thereCOMMA not even for America. That I cannot understand for no place can or will ever be the same to me as dear Philadelphia. But I am forgetting my determination to make my letter short and although I am burning to go on I deny myself for your good as I think a little correction will be very beneficial to you so I will sign myself y
your ever loving and for long letters begging friend
Anna

Title: 1833 May 25COMMA to My dear Sister
Creator: Martha Leeds:  1810?-1888

(Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; RandolphCOMMA JohnCOMMA 1773-1833; PleasantsCOMMA AnnCOMMA 1774?-1844; PleasantsCOMMA Laura
Unidentified People: Sally (kitchen servant?)COMMA Aunt (sister of Samuel or Ruth ReeveCOMMA Martha and Rachel’s parents?)COMMA Sister Ruth (sister of Caleb or of self?)COMMA Harriet (the cook?)COMMA Ann ClementCOMMA Dr ThomasCOMMA Aunt M Leeds
Subject: African American domestics; Domestics; Voyages and Travels--Health aspects; Health; Whooping cough--Vaccination

"Aunt Martha Pleasants to her sister Rachel R. Cope
May 25thCOMMA 1833 - )

[x in pencil next to Sister Frances; at bottom of pageCOMMA in pencilCOMMA in another handCOMMA is written: x her sister in law Frances Pleasants Legate]

[in pencilCOMMA in different hand: Describes F.R.C.COMMA T.P.C. & M.D.C. as children
