Bridgeton is located in Bucks County.

The City Hotel in Philadelphia was located at No. 41 N 3rd StreetCOMMA and its proprietor was Edmund Badger. Both Badger and Dr. Joseph Parrish served as witnesses at John Randolph’s death to ensure that his slaves would be manumitted and provided for as explained in his will. From Joseph ParrishCOMMA “John RandolphCOMMA born June 2ndCOMMA 1773COMMA died May 24thCOMMA 1833: remains removed from Roanoke to RichmondCOMMA December 13thCOMMA 1879: From the deposition of DrJoseph Parrish in John Randolph’s Case” (Philadelphia: George H. BuchananCOMMA n.d.).
Transcript:
My dear SisterCOMMA

Mother had just sent Sally up with an epistle from thee to her for me to read and with directions that as I intend writing to do so this afternoon and say that she is well and getting along admirably – hopes you will not feel uneasy about them and not hurry home on account of home – Indeed she and Aunt look so happy there together that thee need not console with her in the least on account of loneliness – Mother now can ransack and make and mend at her leesure and without interruption – Sister Ruth with her husband & baby and nurse and I with my ditto ditto ditto spent one first day with her very pleasantly and since I have [been] taken tea with her but cannot call very often to see her on account of family affairs Harriet is still with me and doing her best We still have homemade bread and a very good table in regard to cookery I had no prospect that she could have done so well but I have had to work quite merrily or I should never have things to get done in time – We have a good black boy and Ann Clement has come and suits very well and now if I could meet with a goodSally in the kitchen I should be better fixed than ever if thee should see one on the road thee is travelling do tell her the direction of our house – I have no prospect of getting one to suit except indeed a faint one of a girl from Bridgeton that Harriet knows of – Several have applied but I am very particular as I do not wish to change very soon again – Laura continues as good as she can be sleeps all the morning and all night without waking – She has a cough now and I am little afraid it will prove to be Whooping Cough as Ann has some thing like it – Dr Thomas came yesterday to vaccinate her and says it is a favourable age and season to have it –
I am pleased to hear that you are all well and that you are enjoying your travel so much I very much hope that it will prove particularly beneficial to thee – Tell the boys I quite long to peruse their interesting journals. I hope they relate anecdotes and retail conversations – tell Tommy I expect his will be humourous and Franky’s abstruse – Mary’s no doubt will be quite correct and modestly written as she is so quiet about it
How gratified William must be with your visit do persuade him to fit up his handsome house and get a wife to take care of it.– I wonder that the idea should have to be suggested to himSister Frances in her last letter to me desires me to write particularly about thy health and Sister Rs and desires her love to be given. Is she not a lovely woman? She is so intelligent affectionate and sprightly – I love her very much – She says that she would have been delighted if we had visited her but that now she could not ask us at [a--] [s--] as her children have the whooping cough – Mother Pleasants has gone to New York yearly meeting to be absent a couple of weeks – She invited Mother and Aunt M Leeds to spend the day with her before she wentCOMMA with us but it rained and we did not get to go
Nothing new or interesting here I tell to thee I believe in private annals and of public events the newspaper will inform – John Randolp of Roanoke died day before yesterday at the City Hotel
Give my best love to brother Henry and the children I shall be glad to see you home again returning with renewed health and spirits – that it may be so in the ardent wish of thy affectionate sister –
Martha.PHil 25 May; Paid
Rachel R. Cope
Care of William D Cope
Woodbourne. Susquehanna
Penna.

Title: 1818 November 20COMMA StoddartsvilleCOMMA to Thomas P. Cope Esq.COMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Henry W. (Henry Waln) Drinker:  1787-1866
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; HowellCOMMA ReadingCOMMA 1743-1827; StewardsonCOMMA ThomasCOMMA 1762-1841; DrinkerCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1757-1822; GibsonCOMMA JohnCOMMA 1740-1822
Unidentified People: CaseCOMMA B.J. (of Susquehanna Co.); ClarkCOMMA William (Luzerne Co.); ClymerCOMMA Henry (of Wilkesbarre); DrinkerCOMMA William (either of two people: 1767-1821 or 1795-1836); MeredithCOMMA Thomas (of Wilkebarre); MorganCOMMA Benjamin R. (Philadelphia); RaquetCOMMA Condy (Philadelphia); ReedCOMMA John (Philadelphia); RyneersonCOMMA Isaac (Susquehanna Co.); WardCOMMA William (Susquehanna Co.)
Subject: Transportation; Shipping; Roads--Pennsylvania; Livestock; Businesspeople; Interstate commerce--United States; Pennsylvania--Politics and government--1775-1865; Newspapers; Public opinion
Geographic Subjects: Lehigh River (Pa.); Martins Creek (Pa.); Pocono Mountains (Pa.); Susquehanna River
Notes:
The following text was written in another hand on back of letter:
11mo. 24
Hy W Drinker
Nov. 20. 1818
Transcript:
Thomas P. Cope
Stoddartsville November 20th 1818.
Respected UncleCOMMA
From Father from Wm Drinker & from B.[T]. Case I have understood that Susquehanna County Has recd from thee a recent visit & also that our Philadelphia & Great Bend Turnpike was not without interest in thy sight–
That this Road Should be deemed of importance By thee & yet not through my representations of its incalculable Value affords me much pleasure– Directly Interested in it myself & anxious by every Honest means to ensure its success Still there were insurmountable objections to my endeavoring to influence Thee in its promotion– I hope I need not explain from whence these objections proceeded – they are inseparable from the History of my life & my powers of Memory–
On the 14th I proceeded to Wilkes barre in order to See Mr Henry Clymer- Thomas Meredith & others and to definitively establish the Route of our Turnpike – also to nominate Commissioners & to Petition the Legislature– without Know[ing] who would or would not Serve in Philada we nominated the following subject to alterations if necessary–
Thomas Stewardson – Thomas P Cope – John Reed – Condy RaquetCOMMA Benjamin R Morgan & John Gibson – for Philada–
Henry Clymer – Henry W Drinker & Wm Clark – for Luzerne–
Isaac Ryneerson – Thomas Meredith – Wm Ward & B[T] Case – for Susquehan[a]
A New Route Had been Explored By Mr B[T] Case to the Westward several miles of the one contemplated & Explored for Thomas Stewardson – shorter in distance & less Hilly than the [first] & far more interesting to thy Estate on the Meshoppen–
after minutely examining the apparent advantages of the two Routes. I gave my assent to adopting the one last explored & Our Petition was Drawn in conformity thereto–
For want of a Better map of Common Reference I must make use of Reading Howells map of Pennsylvania to carry to thee an Idea of the Route though from the incorrectness of it our Road will appear more crooked than it will be eventualy found–
Our Road begins at One Matts Tavern on the Coskectune and Great Bend Turnpike Towards the Head of Salt [Lick] Creek – where the Road from Tyoga Point crosses the said Turnpike – Thence across the Milford & Owego Turnpike – & thence between Martins Creek & the North Branch of the Tunkhannock Creek–Thence across the South Branch of the same – & Thence through Leggets Notch (or Gap) in the Lackawannock Range of mountains [Formed by Leggets creek a small stream pretty into the Lackawannock about 15 miles from the Susquehannah according to Reading Howells map & scale] then across the East & West Road at one Swartz Tavern – & then across Roaring Brook or Deep Hollow Creek – Thence nearly Parralel with the Same to the main Branch of the Lehigh River– Thence S. 10 E across Tobyhanna Creek & its Branches to the Sullivans Road & thence by the East End of the Large Pond to the Turnpike Road on the top of the Pokono mountain at or near the 30 mile stone from Wilkesbarre– The whole Distance Being from Point to point as Explored & measured about Fifty Three miles – & the Estimated Expence $1000 per mile– Our Petition asks the Legislature to incorporate a company with a capital of $75COMMA000 – but entre nous this is but a [Ruse de Guerre]–
I do not pretend (from my imperfect knowledge of the precise situation of thy lands upon the Meshoppen) to be able to say How far thy interest may be advanced by the completion of this Road But that it will be more or less appears evident and plain – That the Whole of Susquehanna County – a Part of Luzerne Co. & a part of Pike will feel its Blessings is not to be denied– Neither I think will it be doubted that the Road is interesting to parts of Northampton – Bucks & Montgomery counties & as will be shown Peculiarly Interesting to the City & county of Philadelphia–
We have called it The Philadelphia & Great Bend Turnpike & with good reason.- it forming the most Important Link in the chain of communication & the only one wanting to secure to Philadelphia incalculable advantages– From the Pokono a good Turnpike Road now Exists (not Log Turnpike) to the Wind Gap & from thence [are] two good county Roads to Easton – on to Bethlehem by the way of Nazareth – or to Janets Bridge in Lower Saucon where a Turnpike Road is laid out – then by good Roads to either the Willow Grove or Germantown Turnpikes to the City of Philada–. We might Have called our Turnpike The Counteracting Turnpike – it being the Only one Ever projectedcalculated (By Intersecting the Turnpikes Leading to the City of New York in important points) to counteract the Influence that City by Her Liberallity Her Geographical Wisdom and foresight in despight of natural obstructions – Has obtained–
There is One advantage which will result to Philada from this Road which (amongst many others) I select Because it will reach the comprehension of Every man & is capable of undeniable proof & is indeed Known to very many persons in Bussiness in Philadelphia– I speak now of the Cattle Trade or the Driving of Horned Cattle Sheep & Horses to the Philadelphia market– I shall speak of such Facts as are Known to me – some of which are Known to our Dry good merchants – some to our Graziers and all to the Drovers themselves–
The persons Engaged in this Trade are nearly to a man Store Keepers from the state of New York– They receive cattle sheep & Horses in payment for various merchandize sold by them to farmers in their vicinity. Or purchase them with the monies they Receive for their goods– Their Best market for these cattle is found at Philadelphia & notwithstanding the circuitous Route they are obliged to take & the most miserable & wretched Roads which alone Exist to this market they Drive Annualy cattle sheep & Horses to the amount of One million of Dollars– (I [think] this season of Horned cattle alone that near if not quite 1/2 a million of Dollars in value Has passed By this place & through the N & South Road at least I am persuaded that I may rely on the account I have Received of the number) – if then it be a fact that near one million of Dollars in cattle sheep & Horses reaches Philadelphia Every year from the State of New York and that for want of a Road from Philada- to the Western part of that state – the whole Sum is Drawn in cash from Philada and goes to the City of New York & there is Expended in the purchase of Merchandize Because of good waggon Roads Connecting that City with the Said western part of the State – will it not be apparent thatOur Road in Truth is a Philadelphia Turnpike & well Worthy the Patronage & Support of every liberal minded Citizen– But that this is the fact Every Drover will admit & I beleive that they will very generaly declare that they would much rather purchase their merchandize in Philadelphia than in New York if it were possible to waggon [their] goods through Pennsylvania to their Homes– at least this is the Sentiment expressed to me as far as I have conversed with them – in addition Then to these facts – I may state That Though Cattle forms perhaps a principal Remittance from Store Keepers in the Western pt of N York– Yet it is not the only One – a good deal of Cash also is brought Down by these persons & this cash also goes to the City of New York which would if our Road was made Remain in Philada–
I may State too without fear of contradiction that this Cattle Trade in despight of Obstacles Has constantly & rapidly increased that in spight of them it will increase & that if nothing is done to Counteract the Evil we shall still continue to pay to the City of New York for the Beef we Eat – or in other words that the Philadelphia merchant. shall continue to pay the New York merchant for the whole amount of cattle Driven from this quarter to Philadelphia– an Enormous Annual Ballance Indeed for this one article of our Consumption – again – This Highly Interesting Section of the State of New York – [is] Hourly increasing in Wealth & Importance – in wants of Foreign articles & Resources of Domestic Wealth – And let me ask where can the merchants of Philadelphia Find a Body of such customers as exist Here – where Such a certain& constant Trade– Where such an increase of Trade where such certain remittances– Presenting also at Least one Million of Dollars per annum Being Drawn out of the City at this Time & How much Hereafter it is not possible to predict– This However may Be reasonably [assumed] as a fact – that if such now is the amount of this Trade with all the difficulties which want of Roads present – a good Road will very materially increase it – in [----] to Enumerate the advantages to be reaped by Establishing a Free communication with this Most Fertile Section of New York would more properly form a Volume than suit the limits of a Letter– Yet I may add that This Cattle Trade – though in itself of no mean Importance to Philadelphia is only One amongst many Valuable Blessings which New York has taken from Philadelphia By the Superior Foresight of Her Citizens – There it Has been Esteemed Honorable & not unworthy the attention of Her first merchants to Examine in to The Internal Resources of Her State as well as of Her Sister States – whilst the [reins] of Philadelphians Seems to Have Been almost altogether Turned Towards the Sea – to Maritime ports & Latterly to the Great Western Waters– Yet what assisted to raise Philadelphia to Her present prosperity & Rank more than all other Things was the Internal resources of Her own State & those Sections of other States within marketable Reach – and it is only as these Blessings multiply & Have facilities given them to Extend to & Support Her that She can on any Just grounds expect to advance – If this possition is True & if I Have notfailed in making good my ground of the Vast advantage of communication with a Section of the State of New York to Philadelphia is not our Road in Truth a Philadelphia Road & entitled to the Best wishes & aid of that City– in the Magnitude of the Advantages to Be reaped from the State of New York through the Medium of this Road ??? I must not loose sight of the Trade of our own Counties which also at present for want of Roads lead[ing] to Philadelphia likewise goes to the City of New York ??? The amt of this I Have not the present means of ascertain[ing] But it must be considerable & is rapidly increasing??? The Coskectune and Great Bend Turnpike & the Milford & Owego Turnpike are striking at the Best Interests of Philadelphia??? New York City is By these Roads Establishing to Herself a Course of Trade which Though Now Easily Diverted from Her to Philadelphia is growing every day more & more difficult ??? a Timely Exertion an application of one mite of the Vast money Resources of Philada at this time in aid of this apparently insignificant Road will do more than the Expenditure of much Greater sums on Seemingly much Greater undertakings Our Road will cut the Milford & Owego Road & the Coskectune & Great Bend Turnpike in so delicate a part that the whole Eastern Section of Each will be benumned & rendered lifeless ??? Their object (the secur[ing] the Trade to the City of New York)will be effectualy Counteracted & Defeated – & The Proverb Be good to Philada – “One man Sows & another reaps the fruit of His Labour”–
I have gone into a length of detail & [-----] reasoning that I had not contemplated & I fear Have tired Thee as well as myself.– I crave forgiveness for my fault– I nevertheless would be much pleased if Thee Should Think a Publication of Any of these Views – Couched in different Language and Respectfuly dressed would in any way be of advantage to us in gett[ing] through with our important Road – for though I have made it appear that there is abundant Riches to the West & North West of us & more wealth than foresight in Philadelphia Yet the fact must be told that We are miserably poor – & that unless the City aids our Road it may Be as long as Troys Seige before it is Travelld–
Now if Thee would undertake the Herculean Task of Picking the marrow (if there be any to be found) out of this Long [map] of writing – Dress it & Suit it to the palate of our Philadelphians & Serve it up to them in a News paper I should Hope that it might in time of need possibly aid us in Subscriptions to our Turnpike Stock – This However I leave to thy Better Judgement–
My Best Respects to Aunt Grandmother & my cousins Generaly remain[ing] as Ever affectionaly
thy Nephew HWDrinkerStoddartsVille
Novembr. 21st
Paid 25
Thomas P. Cope Esq.
Merchant
Philada

Title: 1896 August 3COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Frank
Creator: Witmer Stone:  1866-1939
Identified People: SmithCOMMA L. A. (Latham Avery); JenningsCOMMA Jasper T.COMMA b. 1846;
Unidentified People: Dr. L.A. Smith of New Milford
Subject: Ornithology;  Birds--Collection and preservation;
Notes: The letter refers to Centennial History of Susquehanna   CountyCOMMA PennsylvaniaCOMMA 1887COMMA by StockerCOMMA Rhamanthus MenvilleCOMMA   1848-. The The passage on ornithology is from chapter VICOMMA   page 42.
Transcript:
Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia Aug 3rd. 1896

Dear Frank

I saw a history of Susquehanna Co Pa. the other day and in it were a few notes on birds & mammals contributed I think by a man named Jennings The notes were sufficient to show that whatever else Mr. Jennings may be he is not much of an ornithologist.

He says however that Dr.L. A. Smith of New Milford has a nearly complete collection of the birds of Susquehanna Co. mounted.

How accurate this statement may be I cannot say but as I see that New Milford is not very far from Montrose I thought you might be able to drive over there and hunt up the Dr. and perhaps he could give you some valuable notes. At any rate I thought I had better let you know about him.

I expect to leave next week for the Catskills

With kind regards to your family I am sincerely yours

Witmer Stone

Title: 1864 October 9COMMA NewportCOMMA to Elizabeth S. CopeCOMMA Awbury
Creator: Thomas P. (Thomas Pim) Cope:  1852-1944
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1857-1897; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909
Unidentified People: Craig; Dr. Thomas (possibly ThomasCOMMA James CareyCOMMA 1833-1897)
Subject: Family; Brothers and sisters; Hotels; Quakers--Travel; Shipping; Women--Travel; College students--Conduct of life; Postal service; Interior decoration
Notes: The second half of the letter is a long postscript written by Anna Stewardson Cope.
Transcript:
Newport Oct 9th 1864COMMA 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at least hoped it did not contain nonsense. I was glad to recieve such information as thy note containedCOMMA & thought it was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombodyCOMMA although I do not think father was much complimented by having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I did not lose my heart with herCOMMA although I think I must have seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my knee was not equal to it. I could have found some time to write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here. I delivered thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has forgotten about itCOMMA so I will remind him of it & now I must close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are doing when there is some thing to tell about of more consequence. I believe Mother intends writing a P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S. when I said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel & thyself. TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any mistake about Dr. Thomas I thought I told youCOMMA you would have to send him word when you were ready to begin You had better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not called on before. So much for that - the burden of my [----] is “painting.” It is the burden on my mind & must of course show itself in words. Uncle Tom sent me word that he had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for our inspection. I suppose we may get the package tomorrow – but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have it all done so we could come back the 20th. If he has got to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will not be ready for us. We are getting tired of this plan & anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about getting intoour house on the 22nd. Seventh day week - We have to engage Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms. Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry– I feel sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a message – try to do better next time. It has been blowing strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf & Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows nowhere more.


Elizabeth S. Cope
AwburyNewport Oct 9th 1864COMMA 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at least hoped it did not contain nonsense. I was glad to recieve such information as thy note containedCOMMA & thought it was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombodyCOMMA although I do not think father was much complimented by having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I did not lose my heart with herCOMMA although I think I must have seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my knee was not equal to it. I could have found some time to write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here. I delivered thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has forgotten about itCOMMA so I will remind him of it & now I must close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are doing when there is some thing to tell about of more consequence. I believe Mother intends writing a P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S. when I said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel & thyself. TP Cope Jr.

I am sorry there should be any mistake about Dr. Thomas I thought I told youCOMMA you would have to send him word when you were ready to begin You had better tell him of myabsence from home so that he may understand why he was not called on before. So much for that - the burden of my [----] is “painting.” It is the burden on my mind & must of course show itself in words. Uncle Tom sent me word that he had expressed a sample of color which Craig has prepared for our inspection. I suppose we may get the package tomorrow – but what troubles me is the delay – Craig said he would have it all done so we could come back the 20th. If he has got to put on two coats after he hears from us I fear he will not be ready for us. We are getting tired of this plan & anxious to know whether there will be any difficulty about getting intoour house on the 22nd. Seventh day week - We have to engage Staterooms two weeks before to get good ones & I intend tomorrow to engage them for 6th day the 21st & if you find the house cannot be got ready by that time you will please send us word at once so that we can disengage the rooms. Perhaps if Craig can not get all done & dry he can have the kitchen & back passages finished & if the last coat is on the parlors &c we might come in before it is dry– I feel sorry to have filled up Toms sheet with nothing but such a message – try to do better next time. It has been blowing strong from the N.W. all day & is cold as charity Alf & Hazen went to meeting with me in the morning & your [br]other in the afternoon but its dull work here either at the larger or smaller body Yankee self conceit shows nowhere more.


Elizabeth S. Cope
Awbury

Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown  Cope:  1822-1916

Newport Oct 9th 1864COMMA 1st day morn

Dear Sister–
I recieved thy note (for I cannot call it a letter because it contained so much nonsense) yester-day morning; but I did not say poo! because I had an idea it was from Rachel or at least hoped it did not contain nonsense. I was glad to recieve such information as thy note containedCOMMA & thought it was a great compliment to be called handsome by sombodyCOMMA although I do not think father was much complimented by having his hair called an iron gray color; unfortunatly I did not lose my heart with herCOMMA although I think I must have seen her & was very sorry I could not go to meting but my knee was not equal to it. I could have found some time to write to you or thee butI have been very lazy since I have been here. I delivered thy message to Father (about Dr Thomas) but fear he has forgotten about itCOMMA so I will remind him of it & now I must close for I am getting lazy & will tell thee what we are doing when there is some thing to tell about of more consequence. I believe Mother intends writing a P.S.
Affec thy brother
TP. Cope Jr
P.S. when I said you on the first page near the bottom I meat Rachel & thyself. TP Cope Jr.

Title: 1865 March 15COMMA Locust ShadeCOMMA to Annie
Creator: Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?
Unidentified People: Lizzie Cope; John & Sallie Hilles; Charles Rhoads; Lilly Collins; Edward Balderson;  Maggie; Richie; Cousin Mary; Dr. Fell; Cousin Eliza
Subject: Letter writing;  Education; Widowers; Women educators; Freedmen--United States; Weddings; Child caregivers;
Transcript:
Locust Shade. 3. 15. 1865

My dear Annie

Does thee think I have quite forgotten thee and all thy kindnessCOMMA & my delightful visit to you? That I have been such a long while without writing to thee. Indeed I have notCOMMA & never shall I hope- but my wonderings [early] terminated last 7th day & since then I have had a very bad coldCOMMA which thee knows makes one lazy. - I have wanted to know how thee faired after our parting on the hill. My walk was brisk & I did not keep Maggie’s [---] waiting longCOMMA and did not feel tired. I fear thee did not fare so well. Our visit to our Wilmington friends was very pleasant.
RichieCOMMA thee knowsCOMMA joined me in that. Tho he was not well enough to enjoy it thoroughly. Lizzie seems very happy & we hope is learning somethingCOMMA - at least she gets very good numbers. - The roads were so bad it was not easy to get about & my journey to Faulkland was a [arduous] one. but the pleasure of cheering cousin Mary a little & hearing Dr [Fell] talkCOMMA- a great deal more than repaid me for it.-

When I returned to Phila John & Sallie Hilles & I went over to see Charles Rhoads. It was very touching to see those five little motherless children. Charles looks tens years older and much broken down.- His sister was very pleasant- I never knew her before. They are certainly much favored in having such kind caretakers & hardly feel their loss as they will after awhile. - I often think of what

thee said to me in the car after our visit to Clemmy. dear AnnieCOMMA with loving sympathy. Deserving too that I may fully appreciate the blessing of a mothers love while mine is still spared to me. - I hear Clemmy is goingCOMMA or has gone to BaltimoreCOMMA to teach the Freedmen. What do you think of it? It seems to me that anything that would give interesting employment to both mind and bodyCOMMA would be good for her. Tho I’m right sorry to have her go so far away. - Thee will miss her too. - Do write some & tell me all about her plans. - Lilly Collins seems to like her situation very well. I found a letter from her awaiting me on my return.- She gives an amusing account of a colored meeting which she attendedCOMMA - a real happy [----------] affair.- Lilly enjoys the variety I should think & it keeps her from being homesick.- Cousin Elizalooked & seemed more cheerful when I called - but she certainly is very weak.-

I suppose the preparations for the wedding are proceeding briskly- Does the go? I quite want to hear about it. - Lizzie Brown’s sister is to be married tomorrow & I hope the threatened storm will not come to spoil all their nice dresses.- Lizzie’s friend Edward Balderson stayed with us last night. He is to wait on a young lady from Jersey - so I fear the love affair between him & Lizzie is all over - but time will make manifest. Has thee seen anything more of the interesting students- Till thy brother Thomas his opinion of the [-----] position of Carpenters is very family impressed upon my mind.- It makes me smile now to think how frightened I wasCOMMA I deserved rebuke too.- Do please write to me soon dear Annie.- My love please to thy father & sister E & with a large share of the same for thyself I am thy sincerely attached & grateful friend

S. S. Reeve

Title: 1805 September 18 to Henry CopeCOMMA Wesston
Creator: Rachel Drinker
Identified People: CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865
Subject: Westtown Boarding School; Education; Letter writing
Notes: “WesstonCOMMA” written in the mailing information is the Westtown Boarding School.
Transcript:
9 mo 18 1805

Dear Henry

I am Still in townCOMMA and was present when thy letter and [---] cameCOMMA It gave me great pleasure to see thy improvement in writingCOMMA and to find that you ar so well ContentedCOMMA and I must note the acceptance of thy acepable letterCOMMA and present; I am desireous of Comeing to See my Dear Boys if I canCOMMA If I Cant I must wait with patience your coming; I have been a thinking what a favour it is to have the Company of T-S with you so long; as I beleive he has the good of the Youth much at Heart I hope you will proffet by itCOMMA I am going to farehill and cant’ tell when I shall be in town againCOMMA I should be glad to see the [---] fill’dCOMMA butCOMMA I shan’t have timeCOMMA I expect to be Call’d for Every minute

I Continue to be your Affectinate Grandmother Rachel Drinker9 mo 18th 1805
Henry Cope
Wesston

Title: 1806 June 17thCOMMA WestonCOMMA to Dear Mother
Creator: Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Identified People: DrinkerCOMMA Rachel; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; ThomasCOMMA John D.
Unidentified People: Cousins Henry and Arthur
Subject: Family; Health
Notes: Drawing of Quaker man with walking stick on page 2.
Transcript:
Weston 6.th mo. 17th 1806.
Dear Mother.
I cannot express my feelingsCOMMA when I first read thy letter. To lose two such nearCOMMA and belovedCOMMA relationsCOMMA so near the same timeCOMMA and also to see the dangerCOMMA our dear cousins HenryCOMMA and ArthurCOMMA have escaped. I feelCOMMA I scarcely know how. I feelCOMMA very unhappy. I hope you will not refuseCOMMA to let us come home soon. We have but 11 days to stay before our time is up. I promise I will not be running about the streets as thou has mentioned in thy letter. I will stay with youCOMMA read to youCOMMA and promise I will do all I can to make you happy as I know thou and Father must undergo a great deal of anxiety on account of our dear uncle and cousins. I wonder why you did not inform us of grandmoth-er's illness or perhaps she was taken very unexpecdedly. I am ashamed to sayCOMMA I know very little about the eclipse. All that I know is that is occasioned by the passing of the moon between the sun and the earth and that part of the sun that the moon passes over appears dark to us. Please to give my love to Dear Father and uncle and cousin John Thomas.
From thy affectionate and loving son
Francis Cope.6 mo 17th 1806

Title: 1856 March 9COMMA to Ed
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: ReeveCOMMA Julia K.; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900;
Unidentified People: Jonathan; Joseph; Geo. (George?); Harry;
Subject: Health; Education;
Transcript:
3rd 9th 2nd day [morn]

Dear EdCOMMA Got thy cousin Thomas letter [for] 6th days mail - Suppose the credit of it is due to him not to thee - Therefore thee will not have looked towards getting an answer That was rather an awkward sort of a business wh. Joseph & Jonathan enlisted in where they undertook the Italian Opera I guess Joseph thought it did not operate very well- & he must have felt decidedly the most awkward of the actors. WellCOMMA for you was itCOMMA that the charge this time happened to be false. For I greatly fear me that some of youCOMMA at some other timesCOMMA have not been overly scrupulous about such transgressions. - So for this consideration let us try & be lenient to the poor Professor remembering that poor human nature is apt to err. & if you are only innocent it will not trouble you much.
Wish regard to my coming down! (every body has to "come down" She knows & as you all seem to be trying to brings me downCOMMA I shall not wonder at finding myself fallen in among you some of these days. If they dont get well before Geo.gets ready to start - I shall think it incumbent upon me to go with him. (I do want them to keep very sick on my acct only a very little will be enough) for me to come onCOMMA as I have been on the look out for some excuse this Great while. (Don't for pity's sake think that's earnest.) I was sorry enough to hear how really sick poor Harry had been & I feel right anxious to know how he is. If thee hears from them wont thee let us know. It will be sad if they shd all get the measles together as Julia anticipates.
I wrote to thee so lately that I do not seem to have much on my mind just at present. "The storm's rose & the winds blew (blew) might be said of our weather. If I do go down with Geo. I will endeavor to get out to see thee. If I do I've got no time to spend writing to thee that's another thing so adieu adieu [jusqu an remain]". Find out what what means in the French Dic. Thee can tell cousin Thos. I seem to be humble & willing to come down. But this world's a region of certainty - Write at an early period & remember thy ever affec Sister

Title: 1821COMMA February 22COMMA TrentonCOMMA to Brother
Creator: Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; CopeCOMMA Rachel ReeveCOMMA 1794-1863; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873;
Unidentified People: Caroline; Hannah Bolton; Grandmother; Mary;
Subject: Education; Family; Health; Letter writing;
Transcript:
Thee will reccollect my dear Brother that when I last saw thee I promised to write to thee in a short time. Thee will conclude that my short time is a pretty long one but I have been pretty constantly employed since I returned and have not felt in a very letter-writing humour. I wrote to Caroline about 3 weeks ago and have not yet received an answer I hope thee will prove a better correspondent than she or I shall have but little encouragement to write. I have begun tolearn french and I like it very much as far as I have gone. Sister Rachel told me when I was at [Home] that Hannah Bolton had returned from Weston I should be obliged if thee would give my love to her when thee sees her. Thee desired to know what I was studying. I am studyingCOMMA GeographyCOMMA GrammarCOMMA history and spelling and at present how to write a letter worth reading. Tell sister Rachel I should be pleased to receive a letter from her though I am not willing to risk writing just again but if she will write to me I will endeavour to be more punctual in the answering of her's than I have been of thine.
When thee writes please to tell me how mother is for I believe all ourfamily have forgotten me and therefore I need not look for a letter from any of them. Tell Alfred I will answer his letter as soon as I possibly can. mean-while he must wait patiently. I must now stop for the present as school is just going to close.
Thee desires to know how the swelling is behind my ear I believe it is much the same as it was when I left home.
Please to give my love to FatherCOMMA MotherCOMMA GrandmotherCOMMA RachelCOMMA WilliamCOMMA Caroline & Alfred and accept a large share for thyself & little Mary From thy affectate sister
Elenor

Trenton 2nd mo: 22nd 1821.Henry Cope
No 36 north 4th st
Philada

Title: 1842 August 17COMMA Schooley's MountainCOMMA to Rachel Reeve Cope
Creator: Eleanor Cope Tyson:  1807-1847
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; TysonCOMMA Job R. (Job Roberts)COMMA 1803-1858; YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865;
Unidentified People: George; Elizabeth Gummere; Judge Gordon and his wife; Carry; John Jacob Astor's Grandaughter; Mr. Kane; Governor Coles; Anne;
Subject: Country life; Family; Health; Voyages and Travels--Health aspects; Weather; Letter writing;
Geographic Subjects: Albany (N.Y.); New Jersey; Susquehanna County (Pa.); Trenton (N.J.); Schooleys Mountain (N.J.)
Notes: Note in another hand: Eleanor Cope Tyson to her sister iin law Rachel R. Cope; Schooley's Mountain (N.J.) note from OCLC: History of Morris CountyCOMMA N.J.COMMA 1914 (Schooleys Mountain; health & summer resort with mineral spring)
Transcript:
Schooley's Mountain Aug 17. '42

Dear Sister Rachel

We had so uneventful a journeyCOMMA I have been so quiet since our arrival hereCOMMA that I have scarcely material for a letter. Travellers are expectedCOMMA I believeCOMMA to be particularly entertaining. NowCOMMA there is no time when I feel less so. FatigueCOMMA change of air & dietCOMMA always for a timeCOMMA affect my health unfavorably; and thenCOMMA the turmoil & bustle scatter the little wits I possess. So thatCOMMA from homeCOMMA I am an especially stupid correspondent. StillCOMMA as you were kind enough to wish to hear from usCOMMA and as we exchanged promises about writingCOMMA I will not wait for any thing worth sayingCOMMA --as I may not have it at allCOMMA thee knows; -- and my delay may occasion me the disappointment of not receiving hereCOMMA the speedy return letter from Fourth StCOMMA which is to be my reward.--

We had quite a pleasant time so far as TrentonCOMMA for our first day's exploit. We arrived there about half past five o'clock; and George with our baggageCOMMA via. steam-boat and rail-roadCOMMA very shortly after. In the eveningCOMMA we made a little visit to Elizabeth GummereCOMMA who lives near the Hotel. They have a fineCOMMA large houseCOMMA in a pleasant part of townCOMMA & express themselvesCOMMA the young folksCOMMA most emphaticallyCOMMA pleased with their change of residence. As we were in the immediate neighborhoodCOMMA we went with Eliza..thCOMMA to spend a few minutes with our old friendCOMMA Judge Gordon's wife. She looks and seems just the same asI recollect her in the days of my childhood. So it appears that in this bustling lifeCOMMA there are some not easily jostled out of their way. We found the JudgeCOMMA some years agoCOMMA busy with his attempts to sell his map of New Jersey. It still seems a most interesting theme to him; & if we come this way six years henceCOMMA I dare say he will even then be ready to speak of its merits & to state that his stock is not yet exhausted.-- Fifth day night brought us within twelve miles of the mountainCOMMA and the next day at noonCOMMA we reached the end of our journey--and over such roads! I was thinkingCOMMA perpetuallyCOMMA of the children's song "Here we go upCOMMA upCOMMA upCOMMA & here we go downCOMMA down" &c &c. To adopt little Cary's favourite styleCOMMA the rain had washed such gulleys in the roadsCOMMA & the stones were so bareCOMMA & there were so many of them!--
The first two days after we got hereCOMMA we had three or four showers per day. By way of consolationCOMMA we were toldCOMMA this was a favorable specimen of their weather this season. For the previous ten daysCOMMA it had rained all the time. "Recorder [Vaux?]" who is hereCOMMA calls it temperance weather. I wonder if [Espy] is a tee-totaller.--We were beguiled COMMA when we first cameCOMMA into taking a room in "the cottage" Its superior dimensionsCOMMA privacy &c were warmly insisted upon. And as we like plenty of roomCOMMA and don't like much noiseCOMMA we thought it quite a prize. The sun shone so flatteringly upon the [compact?]COMMA that we never thought of the inconvenience of being drenched in going to our mealsCOMMA or having them drenched in being brought to us. As we have now had ample opportunity of trying it both waysCOMMA and don't relisheitherCOMMA we begin to murmer. Coming in search of HealthCOMMA we fancy tooCOMMA that a sleeping apartment on the ground floor is not exactly the place to meet with her ladyshipCOMMA this damp summer. We have some of the inconvenient "[Fine-ear]" familyCOMMA moreoverCOMMA next usCOMMA who have been very near getting us into a scrape. A grand-daughter of John Jacob Astor has been stoping with a Mr KaneCOMMA from AlbanyCOMMA andCOMMA under what her friends considerCOMMA very aggravated circumstances. They came here to spend the Honey moonCOMMA & unfortunatelyCOMMA were placed in the room adjoining ours. Job related to meCOMMA one dayCOMMA in a confidential tone of voiceCOMMA the history of their flightCOMMA as just detailed to him by Governor Coles. This they contrived to over-hearCOMMA & being displeased thereatCOMMA they imagined a series of questions and answersCOMMA-- Job & I being the speakersCOMMA-- about the pedigreeCOMMA personal consequence &c of many of the boardersCOMMA which they carried directly to the individuals about whom we were said to be so curiousCOMMA & from thereCOMMA they came immediately back to us. HappilyCOMMA they fixed upon people whom we knew perfectly wellCOMMA & thus the absurdity of our asking who they were whom we had known all our livesCOMMA was sufficiently apparentCOMMA & created only a little merriment. But we were somewhat annoyed until we discovered the full extent of this eaves-dropping. ThusCOMMA the storms withoutCOMMA & the treachery within doorsCOMMA have given us a thorough distaste to this part of the premises. BesidesCOMMA there is more of a crowd than we wished to get intoCOMMA & if the company does not diminishCOMMA we shall want to try some quieter region. DirectCOMMA hereCOMMA howeverCOMMA as we shall leave instructions for letters tobe sent to us. -- We have had it very warm & almost clear now for a couple of daysCOMMA & have been enjoying it by driving about. The country is sufficiently beautiful to render the slow climbing of hills by no means a tedious affair. The roads are kept in quite tolerable orderCOMMA & occasionallyCOMMA we come to a level piece of ground where we trot away quite merrily. People tell us wonders about the flush gained and the disease lost among these hills. I hope our cases may add to a reputationCOMMA so richly earnedCOMMA according to all accounts. -- I should write to CarolineCOMMA but I am not a very disinterested letter writer; sowing only where I may hope to reapCOMMA --& I fear she is scarcely yet at home.--I should like muchCOMMA to know how you all areCOMMA where you now areCOMMA & where you are to be for he next few weeks.--Does thee know where Father & Mother are & when Cara returns? When do you go to Susquehanna [---] & how are Anne's eyes? Tell her I have not seen a single cat since I left home; but we have plenty of little ducks & chickensCOMMA the feeding of which is a daily source of amusement to the children. I heard them complaining this morningCOMMA that the older ladies were interfering with thisCOMMA their peculiar privilege. Indeed the belles and beaux seem to find it quite as entertaining as they--rememberCOMMA my dear RCOMMA that thee is bound to procure me a letterCOMMA in some way. Either from under thy own handCOMMA (how is it?) or from one of those to whom thee can say "do this & he doeth it." If thee is not well enoughCOMMA I shall calculate a littleCOMMA tooCOMMA on the affection & kindness of my nephews & niece. I do not know whether it will be any thing of a bribe-but I always make it a point to answer letters addressed to me--some time or other. If I should not


Henry Cope Esq.
For R. R. Cope.
N. 4th St.
Philadaget time during the excursionCOMMA I shall recollect my indebtedness on a future occasion.--Our love to brother HCOMMA to your segment of our family circleCOMMA & to all othermembers of it who are in the city. The carriage is waiting for me. Fare thee well! in hasteCOMMA but very affectionatelyCOMMA sayeth thy sister
E. C. Tyson:----We have determined to leave here on Second day. Will you not so arrange it as that a letter may reach us before then? It will gratify us very much.---

Title: 1806 MarchCOMMA to Henry
Creator: Rachel Drinker
Identified People: CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816;
Unidentified People: J.D.T.; Wilcox; uncle; cous H.D.;
Subject: Health; Letter writing; Grandparent and child;
Transcript:
[3. 1806]
Dear Henry
I receiv'd thy letter & was glad to here that you were wellCOMMA I still enjoy that Blessing.
Your cousin J D T is in a poor state of helthCOMMA we red thy letter to himCOMMA he is very willing the should have the BookCOMMA a man of the name of Willcox Drank Tea with as last evening liv's about 2 miles from WestonCOMMA he gave thy Uncle & my self [pressing] invitation to come and spend a few days at his houseCOMMA thy Uncle say'd hed try if he could make it convenient to take me to Weston as I was desirous of going thereCOMMA and then we would go and se him. your cousin H D sent a very sattisfactory Letter from the CapesCOMMA in which he sends his love to you with desir's for your happiness here and hereafter I conclude your loving Grand Mother.
Rachel Drinker

Francis what is the matter with theeCOMMA is thy finger sore or is it indolence that the dont writeTo
Henry Cope

Title: 1874 August 10COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Lilly
Creator: Anna Brown Cope Stork:  b. 1862
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?; HartshorneCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1823-1897; HartshorneCOMMA Mary Elizabeth BrownCOMMA b. 1823; CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883
Unidentified People: Anna; Brother Jonnie; Mary; Henry; Tom
Subject: Family; Health; Weather; Drowning
Notes: Note written in another hand on envelope: "From Anna B. Cope aged 13 & R.C.E- Floods in Germantown-  2 men drowned on Armalt St. !!"
Transcript:
Awbury
Aug 9th 1874

Dear Lily
I got thy very nice note day before yesterday and was very glad to get it. Yesterday was very rain and about 7 o-clock it just poured. Haines and High Street & Locust Avenue bridges were all washed away and a man and a and a boy were going along Locust avenue after darkand the lamps were not lit because of the rain I suppose and the both of them were drowned. Uncle Harry & Aunt Mary and Anna are staying over here and we are having a splendid time. Brother Jonnie & Chellie & Hazen came home yesterday to dinner and we think they look better except Hazen but we are going to sent him down to Atlantic City tomorrow to get fat. Cousin Clemmie came over to meeting today and went to Uncle Tom's to dinner. I am going to wait till Alexis is smart enough to writeto me before I write to him. As I have nothing more to say I will close. Hoping thee will excuse this very great scribble I remain they very affectionate sister
Anna B. Cope
P.S. Please give my love to the rest of the party remaining.My dear [Lulu] - As A.B.C. has left a blank page I concluded to fill itCOMMA having had it on my mind to send you a word of greeting all day & not having accomplished it. J. & I are at father's this evening ['leaving"]COMMA & are now sitting in the library with quite a party. Title: 1869 October 10COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Anna Brown Cope Stork:  b. 1862
Identified People: LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953;
Subject: Family;
Notes: ink blots; original envelope
Transcript:
[10.10.1869]

Dear Mother
I am at home. I am glad to get home. I was nearly home-sick at Haverford. Carry wrote a letter to thee. Carry sleep in father's room and she has stopped taking her bottle. I left my hat at Haverford. Thy affectionate daughter.

AnnaDear Mama

I stay home a day

ie. sister Lilly & muda went a Newport

C M CopeAnna S. Cope
Care of Mary Williams
Newport R.I.

Title: 1862 May 8COMMA CliftonCOMMA to Henry Cope
Creator: Rebecca Waln Drinker:  1792-1878
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875
Unidentified People: Uncle John Thomas; Father; brother Henry; brother Richard; Nephew Charlie
Subject: Businesspeople; Pennsylvania--Politics and government--1775-1865
Transcript:
Clifton May 8th 1862

Dear Cousin.COMMA

It has occurred to me since writing my last letter that it might be best to inform thee how my father acquired the title to the lands Ive inherit from him. They were purchase by himCOMMA by Uncle John Tomas of the State of Penna. The Legislatures Land office being about that time / 1772 in Philadelphia. The Legislature at that early period - had made a rule that the public lands should be sold in tracts not exceeding 480 acres each- and that no individual should be permitted to purchase more- but finding this plan did not answer- they concluded to allow purchaser to buy more largely. On condition that they would find a number of nominal purchasers of 400 acre tracts- each receiving a deed poll for every tract- and then transferring them to the purchaser. Accordingly Father and Uncle John found a number of their friends & acquaintances to do this - and in this way bought of the state about 2500 acres of land under different Warranter homes. Uncle J Thomas becoming embarrassed and owing a debt to the firm of Adams and Loughey - his interest was free wh to sale- and bought by my father - who became sole owner of these lands. this transaction- is mentioned in the [land] deed now in my possession- which I am persuaded gives a clear title to the land. The deed polls for these traitswere in Brother Henry's possession but were consumed with other important papers by the bank fire. --- The record of these deed polls must have been in the Land office in Philadelphia - and taken to Harrisburg when the office & Legislature removed there.

10th [may]
Dear Cousin--- I rec'd thy letter of the 8th ins yesterday & I am very sorry thee has had so much trouble on my account. We had hoped our statements would have satisfied thee as to the clearness of the title to the lands. It is thought by some that if I had gone to the city - a personal interview with thee might have resulted differently- but I could not see that this was a right course-- I should be glad to sell our lands as thee suggests and it seems probable we may; but dear cousinCOMMA I fear we could not do in it time to save ourselves-- but I believe if I could sell my own land which is clear of all encumbrances - it might be a benefit to me as well as others- By offering to sell and pay part of the purchase money to be applied in reducing the mortgage on Henry's property- Wm L Gildersleac might be induced to free me from the lien he holds on my own. though a money makings he is said to be a religious man- and a friend to the poor- and if in addition to dealing his "bread to the hungry" he will also "let the oppressed go free" by releasing me "from this bond" he may be a gainer in the best sense without losing any of his earthly gains -- By selling some & gettingthe rest of my property clear it would reliever me from much embarrassment & trouble- there is not mortgage on them the taxes all paid by brother Richard with his [mon] - except for this year I believe and I can pay them with a small sum reserved in [Levanton] for such purchases- the lands are well timbered and in a good locationCOMMA where they can easily be seen after. Those I propose to sell (as most advantageous to a purchaser are in a black - except one a valuable timbered lot No 81 - which is not far from the railroad it corners on No 82* containing 200 acres a lot for which I am offered $1218 = but I would rather be intently clear of any interference before I make a sale- The lands I want to sell are all mentioned and described in the large Deed I have in my possession which was drawn up by brother John who was considered a very good [--------] as well as a Lawyer. The lots are No 30.. Nos 42 52 53 54 & part of No 41 in all with lot No81 about 650 acres--- no 42 contains about 82 acres 26 of this lot being sold and a small clearing made- I suppose there is a drawing of there lots in the [m---] drawn by my nephew Charles which will show how they are situated. My cousins Cope Brothers in their last letter to me asked at what price it would be desirable to sell my property. Expecting to sell the whole property. I had to consult others about the price- but in regard to the lots I have mentioned I will say just what my friends may think it right to give- If I can by selling there lands pay W Gildersleac what he may require and leave enough to settle some debts and pay the arrears of taxes on some lands now in the hands of the [common coiners] in Wilkes Barres. I shall be glad to do so. the sale of our lumber will then I think carry as through

*this lot was under construct - previous to the lien on my other property. Which makes some doubt as to whether W L Gildersleac would claim it.and if in time- we can succeed in paying off the mortgage or sell our lands. I can then be repaid for the money. I may advance now to help others as well as myself. If times become more favorable - I have hopes with prudence & care- we may yet be extricated from our difficulties & be enabled to pay all our own liabilities. I am much in need of good council- I have suggested the sale of part of my lands as a means of relief but I am not certain even if I could effort it- that I could obtain a release from Wm. L Gildersleac--

do as thee thinks but dear cousin- in regard to returning the papers- but if thee can help me in any way by advice it will be a great favor to thy
affectionate cousin
Rebecca Drinker

Title: 1806 August 5COMMA to GrandmotherCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Identified People: CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865
Unidentified People: Arthur
Subject: Grandparent and child
Transcript:
Weston 8th mo. 5th 1806


Dear Grandmother
I have taken this opportunity to inform thee that we are well and have had a pleasant time of it since we left you. I should like to hear from you for we have not had a letter since we have been back. I would wish to know if anything is the matter as Henry has written several times I beleive. We have had apples handed out several times and once we had 5 a-piece and I expect we shall have the liberty of the peach orchard when the peaches are ripe. I would like to know if Arthur and Henry intend to go out to sea again and if they do where they will go to. Thou must write to us as soon as thou canst either third fifth or seventh days will do. Please to remember me to all your an our families.

From thy loveing grandson.
Francis Cope.8 mo. 5th 1806
Rachel Drinker
Care of John Thomas
No. 19 North Second Street
Philadelphia

Dear BrotherA letter of thine has just come to hand in which thee mentions the arrival of William Laurie. I have no doubt but that thee was very agreeably surprised upon seeing him? he will doubtless be a fine addition to your circle???????????? I am glad to see you have the company of [----] Scattergood I beleive him to be a very good man? He was at Weston 2 whole summers while I was there and spoke frequently in meeting?????? I hope your [-----] & butter was very good? take care thee dont choak thyself eating it????????? I dont know how I could send those books to thee conveniently? but perhaps I may bring them myself before long?? wont that do ????????????????????????????????? But I tell thee what?? I sha'nt write thee many more letters if thee dont acknowledge the receipt of them???? there was one in particular that I wrote in verse and with which I send thee some [----------]?I dont know to this moment that thee ever got them??????? pray tell me in thy next ????????? O dear O???dear O??? Bill???? I'me tired of writing with such a pen???? and I'me too lazy to mend it????? so give my love to Wm Laurie and tell him to write to me???? write thy-self soon???????? Written or scribbled by thy brother???Francis Cope Philadelphia1810William D. CopeWestonFrancis Cope Philadelphia
1810
William D. Cope
Weston

Title: 1810 February 9COMMA to Brother
Creator: Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Identified People: DrinkerCOMMA Rachel
Unidentified People: E. Drinker
Subject: Pets--Death
Transcript:
February 9th 1810

Dear Brother.

It seems as if it always came to my lot to write to theeCOMMA and although I have not much objection in commonCOMMA especially when I have any thing to tell thee of that may give thee pleasureCOMMA yet when anything of a contrary nature happensCOMMA I think I had rather give up the pen to an able hand which while it informs of the afflictionCOMMA can at the same time mingle some portion of consolation therewithCOMMA but as no other has time to writeCOMMA I mustCOMMA however unpleasant the taskCOMMA proceed to inform thee of thee sorrowful loss we have sustained in our familyCOMMA since thee last heard from us.

Death stalks forth in darknessCOMMA his approach is silent as the graveCOMMA his hand is ev-ry where; no one can say he will see the light of tomorrow; our dearCOMMA our belovedCOMMA our affectionate Samuel is no more. The unrelenting tyrant has taken him from us in the prime & vigour of his life; that sweet voiceCOMMA which has oft been the first soundCOMMA that has struck my ear upon awaking in the morningCOMMA

alas! is silenced forever; that little tender bill that so oft hath received its food from my hand is stiffCOMMA coldCOMMA dead! On fourth day evening just before I went to school I got up and look'd at him in his cageCOMMA he was sitting sorrowfully in one corner. "If he lives till tomorrow" said ICOMMA "I will take him up stairsCOMMA put him out at the windowCOMMA perhaps the sun & fresh air may revive him." I then went to school. After school I again look'd at himCOMMA he was sitting in the corner as beforeCOMMA very sorrowfully and look'd very poorly indeed. I went down cellar & caught him 3 or 4 spiders he eat themCOMMA poor fellow! it was the last morsel he eat. after havinggiven him the spiders I sat down to read. I had not read long before I heard him struggling. I immediately got up & look'd in the cage he was lying on the bottom apparently dead; I opened the cage & took him outCOMMA I hold him to the fire & warmed himmy hands & breathCOMMA it revived himCOMMA he sat up on my hand & seem'd considerably better; Grandmother then took he sat on her finger for awhile & he flew off on to the floorCOMMA Grandmother then said she was afraid he would fly into the fireCOMMA & we had better put him into the cageCOMMA we accordingly put him in & got some tow for him to lie onCOMMA for poor fellow he was so weak he could scarcely stand. Sally was the afraid he would get his feet entangled in the tow & accordingly she took him out & took the tow away & put a piece of muslin in its plase. I believe the exertion of taking him our & putting him back again was too much for himCOMMA he laid down on the muslinCOMMA struggledCOMMA strech'd himself outCOMMA and ----died----peace to his ashes. The next morning I sat myself down & wrote the following little tribute to his memoryCOMMA And is thy little spirit fled? And art thou number'd with the dead? Thy little heart has ceas'd to beat; And lifeless lay thy little feet; How stiffCOMMA how coldCOMMA thy tender wing; Thy warb'ling throat hath ceas'd to sing; Thy spark'ling eyeball erst so brightCOMMA Is clos'd forever from the light. And is thy little spirit fled?And art thou number'd with the dead? Sweet warblerCOMMA now my gladden'd earCOMMA No more thy tender notes shall hear. No more thy voice at early dawnCOMMA I shall welcome in the summer morn. No more thy little nimble feetCOMMA Shall run the offered food to meet. And is thy little spirit fled? And art thou number'd with the dead? How oft enraptur'd have I heardCOMMA Thy warbling notes sweet gifted birdCOMMA And thought as all amaz'd I stood; I heard each songster of the woodCOMMA Alas! no more my gladden'd earCOMMA Thy tender warbling notes shall hear.Alas! thy little spirit's fledCOMMA And thou art number'd with the dead.We have found thy books and I expect we shall send them along with this letter. Grandmother sends her love and says "tell him nobody was present when the bird died but thee & ICOMMA we attended on it the last."
From thy affectionate Brother
FrancisWe have found thy books and I expect we shall send them along with this letter. Grandmother sends her love and says "tell him nobody was present when the bird died but thee & ICOMMA we attended on it the last."
From thy affectionate Brother
Francis
NB I have neither seen nor heard anything of a letter to E. DrinkerCOMMA pray what is the reason of this? is thee mad?Francis Cope - Philadelphia 2 mo. 9 1810 elegy of [?] mockingbird William D. CopeWeston

Title: 1811 January 11COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Bill
Creator: Francis Cope:  1794-1816
Identified People: DrinkerCOMMA Henry SandwithCOMMA 1770-1824; YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881
Unidentified People: Betsy; Ann
Subject: Family
Transcript:
January 11th 1811

Dear Bill

Mother not being very well she desires me to write to theeCOMMA and I being in no great humour for writing just now shall cut the matter as short as possible. Glad thee examined the date of mother's last letter thee would have perceived the reason of her not acknowledgeing the receipt of thineCOMMA they both having been written on the same day. She sends thee thy gloves and pantaloons and a little something to pull sleds wherewithal. Grandmother sends her love to theeCOMMA she has not been very well these days past but is better. All well besides.

Francis

Feeling something betterCOMMA I would add a little to thy Brothers short communication. He had forgot thy complaint that my letter was not dated. I expected Henry S.D. would hand it to thee on the 26th of last yearCOMMA the next day after it was written; but was not done. I desired him to tell thee how it wasCOMMA and likewise that we had found the Elements of Morality -- but he forgot both. C. is willing to wait till thee comes for the other book. I cannot help thinking that the perusal of thy last letter was of use to her; I fancied I could percieve thee caught a little of the spirit of itCOMMA for she has been more dutiful since in her behaviour to me. I mention it for thy encouragement. I suppose thou will hardly believeCOMMA what is nevertheless true -- that isCOMMA the great good even children may do by their example; especially the elder set of children inFamily's.
I could but be thankful to Great Inspirer of all virtue in thought and deedCOMMA for the disposition thy last letter evinced. The propriety of manner -- the modesty of thyrequests -- the gratitude it breathed -- and the discernment so indicative of good senseCOMMA that it is thy happiness alone I seek -- were all such symptoms of promise -- such signs ofripening worthCOMMA that my heart rejoiced as in the embryo buds which in the spring time of Life [shew?] forth the beginnings of those excellent fruits whichCOMMA bye the Sun of RighteousnessCOMMA shining in the SoulCOMMA are in due time brought to perfection. Dearest William! the desire to do rightCOMMA and the fear of not doing so exactlyCOMMA are precious sensibilities. May they never be extinguished in thy Breast!
Betsy was pleased with thy becoming notice of her part in the present -- it was becomingCOMMA according to thy apprehensionCOMMA whether thy idea was just or not. In reallity tho'COMMA Ann had the largest share in the cake making & baking business -- Betsy was very busy about other things and Ann & I had it chiefly to ourselves -- I believe she was determined howeverCOMMA if the acknowledgement did not belong to her thenCOMMA it should e'er long -- for she has set her mind upon sending the some mince pyeWilliam D. Cope.
W
W Westone
William D. Cope

Mary Cope & Francis Cope.
Philadelphia.
