Title: 1819 October 9COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Ellen
Creator: Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope) Haines:  1819-1890
Identified People: TysonCOMMA Eleanor CopeCOMMA 1807-1847; YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; CopeCOMMA Mary MendenhallCOMMA 1738-1809; CopeCOMMA FrancisCOMMA 1794-1816; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; CopeCOMMA IsraelCOMMA 1770-1855;
Unidentified People: Louisa; Joseph; Jem; Mariam; M.G.; Grandmother Drinker;
Subject: Etiquette; Family; Letter writing; Parent and child; Obedience;
Notes: Although the author addresses the letter to "Ellen"COMMA the context indicates that she is probably writing to her daughter Eleanor.
Transcript:
I have just recieved my dear Ellens Letter of 5th addess'd to me; and am much more pleased with the stile in which it is writtenCOMMA than I was with the one that preceded itCOMMA address'd to thy Sister. The latter done no credit either to thy heart or judgement. Thy Father condemned it in to-toCOMMA as the sauciest little girls Letter he thought he had ever seen; & thou knowest he is not very rigid; or as some would sayCOMMA not at all particular or precise; so when he is offended thou mayest conclude thy improprieties must be very striking indeed. My Daughter should ever recollect that when she asks a favorCOMMA it should not be in the high tone of a demand: it should not be claimed as a RightCOMMA which if not immediately complied with is to be forthwith resented as an injury; but when she wishes for attentionsCOMMA her wishes should be modestly insinuatedCOMMA not as tho' she believed them due to her meritCOMMA on account of her great worth & services for which she expected extraordinary returns; but as tho her Affection prompted her to desire themCOMMA at the same time that she was conscious she could do & had done but littleCOMMA for her friends; while their time & thoughtCOMMA & industry was often exerted in providing for her WantsCOMMA & promoting her Welfare. This would lead her to be content with such portions as they could conveniently bestowCOMMA & grateful when she recieved them: she would dwell upon every instance of their kindness & cherish the remembrance of itCOMMA as an evidence of love for which she had neverCOMMA as yetCOMMA had the power to render an equivalentCOMMA & she would hasten to qualify herself to become useful to themCOMMA in her turnCOMMA especially to her MotherCOMMA whoCOMMA if she livesCOMMA must shortly be overtaken by Age & its attendant infirmities. Then the kind officesCOMMA the endearments & domestic services of a dutiful affectionate DaughterCOMMA are an invaluable treasure. These considerationsCOMMA when once embracedCOMMA cannot fail to sink deep in the heart of sensibility" & willCOMMA if cherishedCOMMA bring forth those substantial [-------] of Virtue in my beloved daughterCOMMA which my heartincessantly longs for. After all my dear EllenCOMMA I still flatter myselfCOMMA that in regard to the said saucy letter the fault lays more in the manner & languageCOMMA than the heart that dictated it: I am by no means displeased that thou should'st prize our love & cover the marks of it; & am in hopes that the fearCOMMA the dreadCOMMA & horror of being hated (so earnestly express'd & often repeated) will operate to induce thee to be best calculated to win back affectionCOMMA even if it has fled. But on this subject I need not enlarge. Thou knowest well what my desires for thee are. Thou hast only to look back & reflect on my frequent labors of loveCOMMA & painful anxieties on thy account (lest thou should not be what my heart cravesCOMMA) and it will be enough: - yet there is one still remains untouch'dCOMMA on which I feel in duty bound to refresh thy memory. I mean the observance of respect to thy Teachers & superintendants; absolute & complete perfection is seldom found among Mortals; as least it takes (in most of us) nearly a whole Life to attain it: do not therefore indulge a disposition in thyselfCOMMA neither take part with any who do soCOMMA to make exceptions or look out for faults in those who have so great a weight of Care & responsibility upon them; but rather turn thy attention to thy own deficiencies & need of improvement. If their patience & sweetness is not uniformCOMMA recollect that thy ownCOMMA if in their situationCOMMA would probably come far short of what is expected COMMA remember that it is for the sake of orderCOMMA & for thy ownCOMMA or the general good. By forgetfulness or ignorance of these truthsCOMMA Children often display the weakness of their understandingsCOMMA their excess of selfish feelingCOMMA & total want of feeling for others. It is never too early to begin to do goodCOMMA & few little girlsCOMMA who were resolved to make a firm stand against these errors: but it must begin at oneCOMMA & how proud should I beCOMMA would but my Ellen resolve to be that one what a happiness would it be to know that she had been the instrument of giving a new tone of feeling & action to the whole of the little community of which she is a Member - a tone so correct & beautiful tooCOMMA as to excite general approbation!on the contraryCOMMA what a pain to find her banded with a company not only so childishCOMMA but so vulgarCOMMA so void of all true taste ; so void of all gentilityCOMMA refinement & delicacy - so completely lowCOMMA as to speak of "throwing old shoes &c" - Indeed I am almost ashamed to write itCOMMA or think of it. Those who desire respect or attention for themselves - who expect ever to be esteemed as gentlewomenCOMMA should have more regard to propriety & true dignity of character.

Thy copy of Verses is very prettyCOMMA & if they express thy own thoughts & feelingsCOMMA very acceptable ; except the last stanzaCOMMA which represents a forlorn destitute stateCOMMA not at all applicable to thy situation. As to thy request about a jingling LetterCOMMA I must inform thee that such music is not always at my finger ends - & for thyself I would much rather thou would'st improve in good prose-writing COMMA before any attempt at poetry is made - unless indeed it should come of itself without such "hard striving".
It was singular I think that thou should'st dream of thy Grandmother Cope never having seen her - but I have no doubt the inscription on whiteCOMMA which thou could'st not read is indeed of thy admirable Brother. For him was exemplified all that gentleness & delicacy of characterCOMMA which I so warmly recommend to my Ellen. In whatever School or family he was placed his behaviourCOMMA & his memory nowCOMMA that he has left the World & all usCOMMA [--] less pure inhabitants to mingle in the Society of angelic Spirits; & his watery Urn has been plentifully bedew'd with those tears of sadness which mingledCOMMA as it were with the waves that overwhelmed him; nowCOMMA henceforth & foreverCOMMA will the remembrance of him be precious; yeaCOMMA sweeter than a garden of Roses after the Summer.

I expect thy Grandmother D-r every minute from Burlington-- Thy various messages have mostly been deliveredCOMMA & all desire their love in return - (Mariam in particular) - thy Brother Henry cannot recollect about M.G.'s Letter: but if he had the charge of it I dare answer for his punctuality. If he does not often send his love in formCOMMA he loves thee none the less. I believe he has hope of theeCOMMA for he sometimes comforts me by saying he thinks thy faults are much like his own were at thy age; onlyCOMMA his were in thoughtCOMMA for he was affraid to shew them because he knew they were not allowed: indeed he did not dare to let them be seenCOMMA lest he should give offence: for he loved his parents tenderlyCOMMA & could not bear to give them pain; & I have heard him say when a BoyCOMMA on seeing others misbehave - get into disgrace - & excite disgustCOMMA - I am glad my parents never suffered me to get into such habits. Now there is this difference between youCOMMA supposing you both to have been under the same temptations to evil in your childhood - that all thy virtue will be voluntaryCOMMA & therefore more meritorious - that isCOMMA it will originate in a love of goodnessCOMMA & desire to attain itCOMMA in thy own breastCOMMA & for its own sake - whereas he was assisted in his endeavours by the Authority of his parentsCOMMA & the divine blessing superadded to both; and thou hast beenleft more to thyself: at least in thy educationCOMMA persuasion has been used more than compulsion. Let me entreat thee therefore my DaughterCOMMA not to dissapoint thy Father; when belief has been so sanguine that his Daughters could be won to Virtue thro' the medium of the UnderstandingCOMMA by the force of Reason & good counsel; yet tho I entreat theeCOMMA I know - & I am in duty bound to tell thee so - I knowCOMMA that without earnest & frequent intercessionCOMMA with thy SaviourCOMMA in true humility of heartCOMMA accompanied by love of his divine perfectionsCOMMA & fear of offending him - in shortCOMMA without his aid & blessingCOMMA thou can'st do nothing: As he said himself - "Without me of yourselvesCOMMA ye can do nothing": - SoCOMMA tho' it is possible to conform to outward rules of good behaviourCOMMA at timesCOMMA & for a timeCOMMA (which is better than being always bad) yet to become establish'd to be immovable in virtuous intentionCOMMA to be steadfast in resisting every temptation to evilCOMMA is impossible without him: for this cause is he stiled a SaviourCOMMA a Redeemer from the bondage of Sin; and we are assured by a revelation from God "that there is no name given under Heaven or amongst menCOMMA whereby they can be savedCOMMA but by the name of Jesus" - How great then is his goodness & how much do we owe him who tho' he needs nothing from usCOMMA has given his Life for us in the body of flesh be assumed; & ever standsCOMMA as it were knocking at our hearts by his gentle checks & intimations wooing us to good - meeting & strengthening our feeble desires after it - & all for the sake of our eternal happiness!

Well my dearsCOMMA thou wilt perhaps thinkCOMMA if I have not written thee many LettersCOMMA I am making up for it in the length of this: and not to tire thee quite out I will now conclude
Thy truly loving mother
Mary Cope
P.S. Mother is not come; but we hear is coming the last of next Week. Thy Capes are doneCOMMA I was pleased with thy proposition to make them thyselfCOMMA as a mark of industry; but would rather thee would make the shirt to learn to darn neatly. We have had so much company (not many at a timeCOMMA but almost constantly somebody) - & have had so much to do since we opened the houseCOMMA that we have been pinched for time to do all. LouisaCOMMA tooCOMMA having a gathering on her hand could not workCOMMA & did not come home when we expected her. She is not come yet. Does thee know her? She is Uncle Israels - Jem's sisterCOMMA & our Joseph's CousinCOMMA & my Cook.
Philada. 10 mo 9. 1819.

Title: 1865 March 27 to My dearest children
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; YarnallCOMMA Francis CopeCOMMA 1830-1890; ThomasCOMMA Deborah C. 1817-1889; TysonCOMMA Jesse; YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881; CopeCOMMA EdgarCOMMA 1838-1895; WalkerCOMMA Sarah MillerCOMMA 1799-1874; MillerCOMMA Thomasina T.; ThomasCOMMA James CareyCOMMA 1833-1897; YarnallCOMMA Mary
Unidentified People: Dr. ThomasCOMMA Margy CoaleCOMMA Mary SayneCOMMA Mary ElicottCOMMA Miss TalbotCOMMA Miss FieldCOMMA Mr. (Leander) WatermanCOMMA and Tom & Harry
Subject: Baltimore (Md.)--History; Freedmen--United States; Society of Friends; Freedmen--United States; Clothing and dress; Boardinghouses; Domestics
Notes: 1865 written in pencil next to date; handwriting changes midway through letter due to Clementine⼯a>??s change of posture/position and then reverts back to normal again.
Transcript:
Second day morn 3. 27.

My dearest children
I have just come home from school & found yr. letter on the card plate in the entryCOMMA wh. is where they always put themCOMMA so we can be refreshed by the sight the moment we get inCOMMA & I was refreshed I assure you. Miss Field gets a great many & I began to feel as if it was quite time for me to be having my turn too. You must remember that I never was befor so entirely among strangers. & that your letters now will be my best substitutes for homeCOMMA as I shall depend on them greatly I tried to write yesterday but did not make out much. It was my first 1st day in Baltimore. Do you remember last 1st dayCOMMA when [were] were walking on the piazza & wondering whether I shd. be here? I did not much think I shd. then but it seems I am. Went to meeting yesterday morn. wh. I quite enjoyed. The only faces that I had ever seen before were Deborah ThomasCOMMA Margy Coale & Tammie Miller. I was introduced to lots of others who were all very kindCOMMA & said they were coming to see me. There was a frd. named Elicott & her two sisters who I think said they knew Mother. We had a sermon [fmr.] Deba ThomasCOMMA the DrCOMMA & one or two others. After meeting in the aftnoon I set out to take a walk & was joined by a young lady named Mary Elicott & & JesseCOMMA who took me a beautiful walk out to whats called theReservoirCOMMA where there is a fountain and a splendid view of green hills & also of the distant waters of the bayCOMMA as well as of parts of the city. & yet it was not a walk of more than a mile I shd. think
Baltimore is certainly a beautiful place & I never realized before so fully what an advantage what an advantage a hilly city possesses over a flat one. It quite throws Philada into the shade as far as beauty is concerned. There is such a refreshing variety in the style of the housesCOMMA & other [buildings] & the hills show them off to great advantage. Charles St. seems to be one of the most aristocratic in wh. the monument is situatedCOMMA a very beautiful column of white marbleCOMMA 170 ft high wh. as it stands upon a hill serves as a land mark for a long distance round. as you ascend the street with the monument towering high above you the stars & stripes floating over it & the city as you catch glimpses of it at certain points apparently beneath youCOMMA the effect is very imposing. I think Phila. wld. strike one as flat after this. It has its advantages tho’.
Jesse has not come to take us any rides yet. tho he has promised to. They say he is very attentive to a certain – young lady here so we shall not be so likely to derive as much benefit. [---]. He has been very polite so far. & the ladies of the house are continually laying plans for our entertainment wh. is exceedingly kind in them. I really feel more at home here than I wd with some relations!Miss Talbot who is the housekeeper is one of the easy talkative kind & makes me think a little of Mary Sayne. Only far Superior. they are exceedingly informal & get up & wait on table & clear the things away in what theeCOMMA NatCOMMA wld. call a very shocking mannerCOMMA but they are perfect ladies for all – hospitable & fond of societyCOMMA & they seem to have a great many pleasant frds. Their one girl is not the most efficient cook in the world but I have such a good appetite that I get along very wellCOMMA – I feel most as hungry as when I get home frm. school as I remember I used to when I was a scholar. We have breakfast about 7 1/2 go to sch. about 8 1/4. it is only 10 min. walk — get home about 1. pretty tired with the 4 hrs. standing & ready to lie down till dinner time at 2 1/2. After dinner we get dressed & go out or see company. We most always have one or two callers. at 7 again we have tea & then get our work and sit in the parlorCOMMA & wonder who is coming when the bell rings. Miss Field I like exceedingly. She is a Presbyterian & a very superior girl I shd. think so that in the matter of companionship I need to have had fewer fears and trepidations than I had
The school duties are not long but pretty arduous while they last. We have to stand nearly all the time. At least the model teachers doCOMMA but we inferiors take the liberty of popping downoccasionallyCOMMA but it is at the risk of [good] order for there are so many in the room that unless you stand up to itCOMMA & keep your eye on all 30 or 40 at once they are very apt to get wrong in the back seats. One of the first points is to get [them] disciplined. Mr Waterman the principal – drills his class just as you wld. soldiers makes them fold their arms put out one foot & finally stand up just as a general wld. his troopsCOMMA & when school is dismissed they file out in quite an imposing manner. That is to teach them obedience I supposeCOMMA wh. is a great point gained. They also teach them a kind of gymnastic exercises by way of recreation. as they have no place to play & consequently no regular recess or almost none. Mine is the next to the smallest class. & only studys reading & spelling in words of 4 or 5 letters wh. is not very interesting. I have’nt discovered that there are any specially smart or Topsy like ones among them. We dont stop to talk or get acquainted much but just keep them doing something or other the whole time. Upon the whole I enjoy the effect of the work very much. & outside of that it is all very pleasant.
Jesse has just called in a splendid barouche to ask for Miss F or I to ride. As I had’nt finished my letter & she had’nt been out for sev. days I persuaded her to go. Yesterday was the first pleasant one we have had. since I have been here. I was so sorry I took my purple dress out. It is just what I want this cool weather for afternoons. I want twice as many clothes here as at home. Caroline dont thee want to be benevolent and cut me out a pair of those round cuffs like thee made me for undersleeves. Thee can work the button holesCOMMA & have them starched & ironed. I have a pair of sleevesthat I can sew them on. I wish if you shd. have any opportunity you wld. send me my old blk silk body wh. hangs in the back room closet. Tammy Miller is going to P tomorrow & out to Mary Morris’ so I told her to tell you that she saw the school “mam” Give my love to Cousin Frank & Mary Tell Cousin Mary I had the pleasure of seeing her mother & I think her father yesterday. Give my love to Cous. Sarah & to Tom & Harry & to all Aunt Carolines & any other enquiring frds.
I have written you a lengthy epistle I hope there’ll be an exception in favor of mistakes & bad writing as I have written lying on my back I was so very tired this morning that I was too lazy to sit up. I do not get much time to [sun] as my room is too cold to sit in & they do not seem to bring their sewing into the parlor much. With much love

Your affec
Sister C

I am going to send you a drawing of my house when I get time so you can imagine how things are a little better. I hope Edgar will get the drafting business all settledCOMMA satisfactorily

Title: 1865 May 7COMMA to Mother &c.
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; YarnallCOMMA Mary; CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; CopeCOMMA EdgarCOMMA 1838-1895; TysonCOMMA Jesse; HopkinsCOMMA Joseph SchofieldCOMMA 1840-1926; ParryCOMMA Emma; MatthewsCOMMA Thomas R.COMMA 1792-1873; HopkinsCOMMA Josephine
Unidentified People: E. Smith; Cous. Mary; Mary Yarnall
Subject: Gossip; Clothing and dress; Baltimore (Md.)--Social life and customs
Notes: Joseph Schofield Hopkins and Edgar Cope both attended Haverford College in 1855.
Transcript:
[1865]

First day eve 5/7

Dear Mother &c

Altho’ it is after 10 o’ck I want to just drop you a line to tell you to look out for a call from a young gentleman this week. Jesse sent me word to day that he was going [on] himself to P & out to Mary Yarnalls & that he wd. give you a call & bring or take anything I wanted so here is a chance again for the silk skt. only I wld nt like to ask him to bring itCOMMA as I think he only offered out of politeness & will probably take nothing with him but a valise & as mine is a plain silk & wd. not bear rumplingCOMMA I guess it had better not be sent altho’ I told him I shd. be obliged to him to bring a small package. If thee Mother cd. sendme thy old light silk skt. (wh. I believe thee offered) it wld. do as well to wear with white bodiesCOMMA & cld be put in smaller space. But I really wd not like to ask Jesse to bring itCOMMA for he is so polite that he wd. say it was convenient whether it was or not. If however you cd. manage to get up a sack or shawl that wd. do for sch. (wh. subject I mentioned in my last letter) I shd. be very glad to have it. Jesse returns on 5th dayCOMMA--so his call will be sometime between this & thenCOMMA He proposed that I shd. go with him & pay a short visitCOMMA wh. I declined of course. His dinner party did’nt come off last week as we expectedCOMMA but probably will next. Tell C & A that at a tea party a few eve since at frd. Janney I met their old sch. mate Josy Hoag She asked after them & quite amused me by saying that she had often heard of [---] “Sister Clemmy.” She’s a sort of bride having married a person by the name of Hopkins. She seemed to be more interested in her husband than anything.. Tell Edgar I was escorted home by a youth named Joe Hopkins who asked me if I was any relation to Edgar Cope an old school mate of his--I said yes & asked what kind of a young man he was--”a very clever fellow he said but very lazy”COMMA in wh. lattercharacteristic he said they greatly resembled each other Mister H. is what you’d call a rather fast young man I shd. thinkCOMMA a variety wh. I think a good many of the young men here belong to.

On 6th day eve took tea at Thos. Matthews about 5 m. in the country. We met there E. Smith of West Chester. An Aunt of the Rileys & sister of Rhoda’s. She is making a visit to these frds. & is a very pleasant person A great many Phila’s seem to [stray] down this way. Emma Parry & some of the Perots are here now I believe. The Coales told me to day that Cous. Mary was talking of coming. Margy amuses me very much by saying she does hope she’ll see a good deal of me when she is in P this summer she does not seem to think that in B it is [deemed] as I have never been invited there.

Title: 1852 July 12COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to Ruthanna Cope
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: ReeveCOMMA Julia K.; CopeCOMMA Susan L. NewboldCOMMA 1805-1872; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; CopeCOMMA Rachel ReeveCOMMA 1794-1863; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900
Unidentified People: cos Frank; Aunt Fortune; cos Anna; cos Elizabeth; Grandfather;
Subject: Transportation; Weather; Voyages and Travels
Geographic Subjects: Philadelphia (Pa.); Wilkes-Barre (Pa.); Tunkhannock (Pa.); Pottstown (Pa.); Port Clinton (Pa.); Tamaqua (Pa.); Wyoming County (Pa.)
Notes: Stationer's mark: "SUPER FINE" surrounded by leaves.
Transcript:
Woodbourne 7th mo 12th 1852

Dear AnnieCOMMA

This is the first sheet of that ream of paperCOMMA but for fear thee should be appalled with the anticipation of having the whole of it filled up to thy accountCOMMA I am going to tell thee in the first place that I ai'nt going to be quite so unconscionable tho' I wont promise how I far I shall short of it. I thought maybe you would like to know something about my gettings along on my journeyCOMMA so I will begin at Pottstown up to which place you are informed of what transpired. Well after taking the last look at youCOMMA I turned round & felt a little forlorn at finding nothing but my carpetbag to keep me companyCOMMA so as I had nobody to talk to (I was very glad I had'nt) I thought I would occupy myself with thinking about you & wondering how you were getting along. Directly after we started we came whizzing past a train of carsCOMMA which I supposed were the ones wh. were to convey you back to Philada. I was very glad to see them because I knew you would be & I was afraid you might have had to wait there a good whileCOMMA but it was'nt very pleasant to think that we were speeding away from each other as fast as we could go. I hope you did'nt feel as [worn] & dusty when you got to Phila as I did when I reached Port Clinton I had'nt much time to think about it however for I had to go quite in traveller like style & superintend as well as I could amid the bustle & din the transportation of our baggage from one car to anotherCOMMA that seen toCOMMA I joined my companions & weput ourselves on board the cars for TamaquaCOMMA a ride of two hours brought us to that place about 1 o'clockCOMMA there we staid about half an hour most of wh. time I spent in trying to restore my face to a decent shade of colorCOMMA for I found it in the funniest looking condition thee can imagineCOMMA the dustCOMMA & the tears occasioned by the cindersCOMMA (& something else) had covered [skin] spots with a sort of black paste wh. very much resembled mud & wh. I had some difficulty in removing. I thought it expedient to [see first] watering place to get out & wash so I performed my ablutions quite comfortably under the spout where the horses were drinkingCOMMA it reminded me of Aunt Fortunes style of face washing. The ride over the mountains was just about as usualCOMMA except that it was a little bit hotter & dustier & disagreeabler than ever. We had 9 passengers in the stage not counting carpetbags & blanket shawls wh are an important item in hot weather I hope I have left mine for the enjoyment of somebody who will take a cooler time for it. We lived all the afternoon in the anticipation of a cooler ride after sunsetCOMMA but it seemed to grow hotter instead of colderCOMMA most of the passengers seemed to forget their discomforts in a nap so I was left to my own entertainment & sat very quietly in one corner thinking about different things among others I amused myself with imagining what you were about atCOMMA OaklandCOMMA & wishing I was there with you instead of where I wasCOMMA about 11 1/2 P.M. we were wheeled up before the Phoenix Hotel in Wilkesbarre where as soon as possible (tho' not until morning) we made our way to our sleeping apartments mine did not prove to be much of a sleeping apartment however tho' as much as could have been expected of a roomwithout windows & with featherbedsCOMMA they were very full at the Hotel & we were obliged to be content with the kind of accomodations we could get. Thinking to better my condition I got up the next morning at half past three & found it a decided improvement upon lying in bed We left [W] about 7 o'clock & had a pleasant ride thro' the valley of WyomingCOMMA it is by far the pleasantest part of the journey I thinkCOMMA the country is looking beautifully nowCOMMA only it was too hot to enjoy it. We reached Tunkhannock about 12 1/2 PMCOMMA & now comes the very dismalest part of allCOMMA at this place the two lades with whom I had travelled from Phila & whom I knew very well left me unexpectedlyCOMMA & I was packed without any ceremony into a kind of open arrangement upon wheels (for it hardly deserved the name of a wagon) & after considerable crowding & pushingCOMMA & groaning I managed to squeze in between two fat women & an indiscriminate collection of trunksCOMMA & handboxesCOMMA & men. Under these auspicious circumstances we startedCOMMA the sun basking down upon us in one directionCOMMA & some ominous looking black clouds in anotherCOMMA so [hot] I scarcely knew whether to wish most for a drenching or a coo[k]ing I an addition to this the driver was entertaining us with all sorts of awful predictionsCOMMA he said the roads were terribleCOMMA that the bridge had been washed away & he expected we would all be drowned in crossing the creekCOMMA & as to his horses he was perfectly certain they never could stand itCOMMA & so I thought I shd never get home in the worldCOMMA that something awful certainly could'nt fail to happen among so many dismal predictionsCOMMA & they were such a queer set of peopleCOMMA & altogether I felt such an utter sense of forlornness that I eddified them by beginning to cry. I was provoked at myself for being so foolish but I really could'nthelp itCOMMA it did'nt last very long howeverCOMMA for directly one man who seemed to quite pity me turned round & said in the most compassionate toneCOMMA "you feel kind'er used up do'nt you." I was so struck with the applicability of the expression (for in truth I did feel a sort of sense of "goneness") that I began to laughCOMMA & seeming quite pleased that his efforts were so successfulCOMMA the man set himself to work to entertain me during the rest of the wayCOMMA he said he always kindCOMMA o' hated to see people discouragedCOMMA that he never got discouraged in his life & he thought it was'nt a good planCOMMA & so he got me into quite a composed state of mind & I was enabled to bear the rest of the journey with a tolerable degree of calmnessCOMMA it is well disagreeable things come to an end as well as agreeable onesCOMMA thee may imagine how delighted it was to be safely landed at home after all thisCOMMA without being either drowned or drenchedCOMMA they were quite surprised to see me arriving in such a forlorn condition. If Father & mother had known they wd have met me at Tunkhannock. I believe the reason of our having such a miserable affair was that the stage had broken down the day beforeCOMMA & this was all they had to send. They are all very well here excepting father who is somewhat stiff yet with the effects of the rheumatismCOMMA the children have grown very much. And now that I have almost filled my letter with an acct of my own doingsCOMMA let me ask thee about yours. I want to know how you are getting alongCOMMA it seems ages since I have heard anything about you. I do hope thee'll write very soon & tell me about everything. I feel somehow as if I was farther away than I ever was beforeCOMMA do come up this summer if you possibly canCOMMA any of youCOMMA we shd be so delighted Mother requested me to give her love & tell you so. I suppose whether you remember'd our agreement for last night. I did & thought about it too. I suppose Julia is in Reading. Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Henry & Aunt RachelCOMMA Cos Frank & Cos AnnaCOMMA Cos Thos & Cos Elizabeth & all the rest of the cousinsCOMMA to Grfather of course & every body else to whom thee sees fit. Of course thee will write to me [very] soon. I am at the end of my paper & must concludeCOMMA thy affectionate Cos Clementine CopePS. I gave such a dismal acct of our proceedings up here that I am afraid it will not be any encouragement to comeCOMMA but let me tell thee that things ai'nt always at such a forlorn passCOMMA it only happened to be so at that particular time.
The children send their love & desire me to thank Cos Frank for the books with wh. they were very much pleased.

Title: 1861 April 10COMMA to Sisters
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA EdgarCOMMA 1838-1895; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA Susan L. NewboldCOMMA 1805-1872; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873; GarrettCOMMA Philip C. (Philip Cresson)COMMA 1834-1905
Unidentified People: Aunt K; Anne; cous Lizzie; cous Sarah;
Subject: Family
Transcript:
1861
Third day 4/10 -- 60
My dear sistersCOMMA
Have just rec' yr. letters & will write right off before what you say has time to get out of our minds It was quite refreshing & encouraging to me to get yr. letters for do you know this morning I was pretty near giving up in despair of having anything pretty or uncommon about our house. Mother got aunt R & Anne & cous Lizzie to go with her after meeting to a furniture store & there they selected just about as ugly a set of hair cloth chairs as I wld. wish to see. Of course they think its not a very important matter & Mother is just willing to havemost anythingCOMMA that they likeCOMMA wh. very much goes against the grain with me. This thing of getting things that "will do" I never had any unity withCOMMA & as you say I had much rather take trouble now & get pretty things than to be dissatisfied with them afterwardsCOMMA & I do think we might as well get what suits usCOMMA as what suits other people. It seems foolish to be so particular & objects to what is thought bestCOMMA & I'd give anything to have one of you here to consultCOMMA without having to ask the rest of the folks. To be sure the furniture is not everything. I wld give all the select sofas in the world for a pleasanter situation but as that cannot be had we must have it as pleasant as we can 'a [propos] of sofasCOMMA it is thought very unwise indeed to get plush onesCOMMA they are hot in summerCOMMA & very hard to keep clean &c &c. Moreover they cost several dollars more than the hair cloth & I am not sure that they wldbe advisableCOMMA tho' much prettier no doubt. My plan is to leave as much as possible till you come down & then we can [fix] & arrange what we want. But they all say oh! no get everything now. Make [yr] minds easy about the parlor carpet at least. We have concluded to leave that & get nothing. But then if we get plush chairs we wld. not know what color to get till we get the carpet. Plush armchairs cost 30 & 40 dollars hair cloth 10 dollars less. They want to get a hair cloth sofa for the entry. I want to get some kind of a fancy lounge or [settee]. As you say its dreadful unsatisfactory to write about such thingsCOMMA & I think I'll just trust to getting them afterwards & come homeCOMMA & then we can talk things over & get them arranged. I am hoping all the time that something will happen so that we wont get off till fall at any rate.another thing I have forgotten to tell you wh. will greatly comfort you & that is that good Cousin' Thos' is going to buy us some nice kinds of vines to plant. Wisteria & honeysucklesCOMMA & rosesCOMMA &c &c. Edgar thinks of small importance but I'm going to stand up for that. I planted when I was out there two poor little bits of ivy (the best I cld get)COMMA but that takes so very long to grow. It will seem like a different place with vines growing. It seems so forlornCOMMA down in this populous county to live on a public road without a tree or a vine to shelter you what cld. have possessed anybody to build a house there when there were so many other spots more secluded & inviting. I cant imagineCOMMA but theres no use now. I must tell thee Carry that I was talking to a young man named Philip Garrett a few days agoCOMMA who was expressing his regret that [He] (C) had declined being [brides] maidCOMMA as he said he had expected to have had the pleasure of [waiting] on thee.Yet I cant imagine why thee wants so many small quantities of double [zephyr]. I believe they do not [sell] it in less than half [an] [gr.] of an oz. We wish endeavor to get the other things. Mother has told you what the prospects are about coming Do'nt expect her on 7th dayCOMMA for I do not think there is much probability of her getting off. Edgar & I may stay a week longer but I shall not consent to stay long. Am going to take tea at Dr [Morris] with Cos Sarah is'nt it [awful]. With love to [Father] & Love Ever yr sister C

Title: 1861 April 10COMMA to Sisters
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA EdgarCOMMA 1838-1895; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA Susan L. NewboldCOMMA 1805-1872; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873; GarrettCOMMA Philip C. (Philip Cresson)COMMA 1834-1905
Unidentified People: Aunt K; Anne; cous Lizzie; cous Sarah;
Subject: Family
Transcript:
1861
Third day 4/10 -- 60
My dear sistersCOMMA
Have just rec' yr. letters & will write right off before what you say has time to get out of our minds It was quite refreshing & encouraging to me to get yr. letters for do you know this morning I was pretty near giving up in despair of having anything pretty or uncommon about our house. Mother got aunt R & Anne & cous Lizzie to go with her after meeting to a furniture store & there they selected just about as ugly a set of hair cloth chairs as I wld. wish to see. Of course they think its not a very important matter & Mother is just willing to havemost anythingCOMMA that they likeCOMMA wh. very much goes against the grain with me. This thing of getting things that "will do" I never had any unity withCOMMA & as you say I had much rather take trouble now & get pretty things than to be dissatisfied with them afterwardsCOMMA & I do think we might as well get what suits usCOMMA as what suits other people. It seems foolish to be so particular & objects to what is thought bestCOMMA & I'd give anything to have one of you here to consultCOMMA without having to ask the rest of the folks. To be sure the furniture is not everything. I wld give all the select sofas in the world for a pleasanter situation but as that cannot be had we must have it as pleasant as we can 'a [propos] of sofasCOMMA it is thought very unwise indeed to get plush onesCOMMA they are hot in summerCOMMA & very hard to keep clean &c &c. Moreover they cost several dollars more than the hair cloth & I am not sure that they wldbe advisableCOMMA tho' much prettier no doubt. My plan is to leave as much as possible till you come down & then we can [fix] & arrange what we want. But they all say oh! no get everything now. Make [yr] minds easy about the parlor carpet at least. We have concluded to leave that & get nothing. But then if we get plush chairs we wld. not know what color to get till we get the carpet. Plush armchairs cost 30 & 40 dollars hair cloth 10 dollars less. They want to get a hair cloth sofa for the entry. I want to get some kind of a fancy lounge or [settee]. As you say its dreadful unsatisfactory to write about such thingsCOMMA & I think I'll just trust to getting them afterwards & come homeCOMMA & then we can talk things over & get them arranged. I am hoping all the time that something will happen so that we wont get off till fall at any rate.another thing I have forgotten to tell you wh. will greatly comfort you & that is that good Cousin' Thos' is going to buy us some nice kinds of vines to plant. Wisteria & honeysucklesCOMMA & rosesCOMMA &c &c. Edgar thinks of small importance but I'm going to stand up for that. I planted when I was out there two poor little bits of ivy (the best I cld get)COMMA but that takes so very long to grow. It will seem like a different place with vines growing. It seems so forlornCOMMA down in this populous county to live on a public road without a tree or a vine to shelter you what cld. have possessed anybody to build a house there when there were so many other spots more secluded & inviting. I cant imagineCOMMA but theres no use now. I must tell thee Carry that I was talking to a young man named Philip Garrett a few days agoCOMMA who was expressing his regret that [He] (C) had declined being [brides] maidCOMMA as he said he had expected to have had the pleasure of [waiting] on thee.Yet I cant imagine why thee wants so many small quantities of double [zephyr]. I believe they do not [sell] it in less than half [an] [gr.] of an oz. We wish endeavor to get the other things. Mother has told you what the prospects are about coming Do'nt expect her on 7th dayCOMMA for I do not think there is much probability of her getting off. Edgar & I may stay a week longer but I shall not consent to stay long. Am going to take tea at Dr [Morris] with Cos Sarah is'nt it [awful]. With love to [Father] & Love Ever yr sister C

Title: 1851 September 19COMMA DublinCOMMA to Thomas Pim CopeCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Jonathan Pim:  1806-1885
Identified People: PimCOMMA William Harvey; BewleyCOMMA JosephCOMMA 1795-1851
Unidentified People: Mary MurphyCOMMA Isaac Murphy
Subject: Health; Deafness; Ireland--History--FamineCOMMA 1845-1852; Textile industry
Geographic Subjects: Dublin (Ireland); Philadelphia (Pa.); Belfast (Northern Ireland); Connacht (Ireland); Newcastle (Northern Ireland); Down (Northern Ireland : County)
Notes:
This record contains two associated lettersCOMMA one enclosed within the other.

The watermark reads A Cowan & SonsCOMMA 1851COMMA Patent.

Connaught is one of the four ancient provinces of IrelandCOMMA with UlsterCOMMA LeinsterCOMMA and Munster comprising the other three. Connaught contains the present-day counties of MayoCOMMA SligoCOMMA RoscommonCOMMA GalwayCOMMA and Leitrim. ConnaughtCOMMA located on the midwestern coast of the islandCOMMA relied heavily on agriculture for its businessCOMMA and the Famine of the mid-nineteenth century especially affected this area.

Newcastle is located in County DownCOMMA which is part of present-day Northern Ireland. Newcastle remains a seaside resort town known for its scenery. The town lies at the foot of Slieve DonardCOMMA Northern Ireland⼯a>??s highest pointCOMMA and its beaches and golf courses attract thousands of summer vistors.

The Belfast Ladies Relief Association for Connaught was an interdenominational group dedicated to providing for those left hungry and destitute by the potato famine in 1845. The Association was begun on January 1COMMA 1847COMMA by Rev. John EdgarCOMMA whose prior public work dealt with temperance issues. Its primary focus was raising moneyCOMMA although many of its members did involve themselves more personally in relief work. Their primary methods of funding involved door-to-door canvassing and the operation of a Bazaar of Ladies⼯a>?? Work in Belfast. Circulars with statistics and stories of the devastation were published to aid the ladies in their appeal.

Although food and clothing were at first the items most soughtCOMMA the women had loftier goals: "to ⼯a>??improveCOMMA by industryCOMMA the temporal condition of the poor females of Connaught and their spiritual [condition] by the truth of the bible.⼯a>??" (from Luddy 22) Schools teaching needlework and knitting were established throughout Connaught. Information from Maria LuddyCOMMA "Women and Philanthropy in Nineteenth-Century IrelandCOMMA " in WomenCOMMA PhilanthropyCOMMA and Civil SocietyCOMMA edited by Kathleen D. McCarthy (Bloomington: Indiana University PressCOMMA 2001) and the First Report of the Belfast Ladies' AssociationCOMMA BelfastCOMMA 6 March 1847.
Transcript:
Dublin 19th of 9th month 1851

Thomas Pim Cope
Philadelphia

Dear Kinsman

I have to thank thee for again making me the medium of thy bounty to the "Belfast Ladies "Relief Association for Connaught". I sent the Fifty Pounds on receipt to my friend Mary MurphyCOMMA and have the enclosed acknowledgment from her son. In a few days I hope to receive from her some particulars of the present condition of the AssociationCOMMA and some statistics of the trade in sewed muslinCOMMA which is now a very important branch of Irish manufactureCOMMA and to which their labor largely contributed.

Since receiving thy letterCOMMA I have (in common with many others here) received a painful shockCOMMA by the sudden & unexpected death of my co-secretary to the Releif Com–& very dear friend Joseph Bewley. He had been unwell some weeks sinceCOMMA but was much betterCOMMA and had goneCOMMA with his son and two daughtersCOMMA to spend a few days at NewcastleCOMMA a bathing place in the Co. of DownCOMMA hopeing that the quietude & country air would restore his usual strength. They were there only two daysCOMMA and on the third he was walking with hisfamily in a neighbouring demesneCOMMA when he fell suddenly and life was extinct. Up to the moment of his fall he appeared to be perfectly wellCOMMA and in good spiritsCOMMA and seemed to take much enjoyment in the scenery around them.

In him our Society in this land has lost its most conspicuous & active memberCOMMA on whom a heavy burden often lay as respects the care of its temporal as well as spiritual concernsCOMMA and his immediate friends have lost a kind and liberal friendCOMMA whose sympathising advice and assistance was always ready for those who needed it.

His loss will be much feltCOMMA and by many to whose necessities he administered liberally.

His death took place on second day the 15th [----]

My Father and the other members of our immediate family are well. My brother William enjoys good healthCOMMA but has become increasingly deafCOMMA which is a severe trial to him. I hope thy health is good.

I remain thine affectionately

Jonathan Pim

A Bell and Co have not yet sent me the papersCOMMA but no doubt they will do so.
[enclosure]

Belfast 16 Sept 51

Respected Friend

Jonathan Pim –

When my mother left home for DublinCOMMA she left orders to have all her letters opened.

I have accordingly to acknowledge in her name rect of BR order for £50 which duly arrived this day. I feel much gratitude toward Thos Pim CopeCOMMA the liberal friend of this country.

The information whthou asks / forCOMMA my mother will have much pleasure in communicatingCOMMA & I in procuring.

Believe me
Thine vy sincerely
Isaac Murphy

Title: 1896 July 13COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Frank
Creator: Witmer Stone:  1866-1939
Identified People: BicknellCOMMA Eugene P.
Unidentified People: Stew Brown
Subject: BirdsCOMMA Protection of--Law and legislation; Ornithology; Shooting
Transcript:
[Letterhead: The Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia -- Logan Square.]

Philadelphia July 13. 1896.

Dear Frank

I enclose the statement of your fitness for holding a license. You have also I believe to file a bond signed by two residents of the county (your mother I suppose would do for one) which is only forfeited in case you shoot for miliners or something of that kind which of course you won’t do. The blank bond form can be obtained at the [Bothonotary’s?] office I think. The only cost is $1 per year for your license. The bond & certificate need not be renewed every year

We are just getting overhe worst of that museum “moving” that I spoke of & I am glad of itCOMMA for it has been hard work for this time of year.

I am delighted to hear of your additions to the list. The Prairie Horned Lark I always thought would turn up in your vicinity.

Stew Brown found the Wilson’s Thrush at Tannersville Pocono Mts. & was as much taken aback by the notes as I wasCOMMA but as he had Mr Eugene P. Bicknell of N.Y. in the partyCOMMA he had no trouble in ascertaining who the songster was

With kind regards to your family I remain sincerely yours

Witmer Stone

Title: 1841 February 28COMMA New BedfordCOMMA to FrankCOMMA Philada.
Creator: Charles Taber:  1822-1887
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865; HardyCOMMA Benjamin F. (Benjamin Franklin)COMMA 1808-1886; HusseyCOMMA Gertrude Colden MurrayCOMMA d. 1848
Unidentified People: George H. Dunbar
Subject: Letter writing; Voyages and Travels; Public worship--Society of Friends; American poetry--Quaker authors; Periodicals; Women authors
Geographic Subjects: New Bedford (Mass.); Mecca (Saudi Arabia); Philadelphia (Pa.); Haverford (Pa. : Township); France; Salem (Mass.); Kennebunk (Me.); Lyme (Conn.)
Notes:
The stationer's imprint on the front page of the letterCOMMA upper left cornerCOMMA is an upright rectangle with cropped cornersCOMMA and the word BATH written inside.

A bobwig is a wig in which the bottom locks are cropped to make short rather than full curls. (Oxford English Dictionary)

St. Crispin is the patron saint of shoemakers.

The line "Othello's occupation gone" comes from Act IIICOMMA scene iii of the play. In this scene Othello is lamenting that he will no longer be a soldier.

Listed in pencil on the back: Creighton & Wilson R [Ashurst] J Brown J W Bates W Brown Bray Bancroft J Barton P Brady E Carr G [&] Evans L. Duy. G B & J B [Engl---] Thos Evans [Huskel Herkins] Hendrickson C W H [Love] [-] Mellon Patter [O Reeve] Ralston T Sharpless J & D Samuel [----] & Wallace A Plade H [Winkley] [--------] Shread Shaw
Transcript:
New Bedford 2 mo 28 1841

Dear Frank

Among the many sins of omission & commission with which my Conscience has been burdened of late – none has laid harder on my stomach to speak in a physiological metap[h]or than my not having answered [thine] epistle of – mo. – 1840. This sheet then intended as a peace offering and mediator for past offences “by-gones” comes to thee by the hands of Geo. H. Dunbar – (a young man of our religious denomination- somewhat diligent attender of meeting – (where He in company with the majority of our young men occupies the seat fronting the women friends – pardon the digression but the fact is worth recording that as the Mahometan prays with his face towards Mecca – thou canst draw the parallel) not so much distinguished as would be best for plainness of speech. [behavi] and apparel – and inheriting with the rest of us some failings I fear from Father Adam - ) who is to pass thro Philada. on his way to Haverford and then to France in a New Lock Haven packet next week. – A poet moreover and somewhat unique personage. & can either roar like a lion or a sucking dove at his pleasure – rhyme to the moon or swear like a pirate. – I don’t know how long he stays in Philada. but if you fall in with him you’ll know him.

The greatest attraction in these parts this winter - & which must take its share of the blame of having kept me from attending to my Philada correspondence is a new periodical entitled “L’Entreprise” which has originated among us and has claimed a goodly portion of my leisure
The great charm about you must know is that we have Lady contributors – Gertrude Hussey “Murray” quondam –
with sundry & divers others – too tedious to mention as the advertisements would say – with a respectable lot of Quak[er] lady make considerable of a coterie. –
Dr Hardy undertook to join but whether he did not succeed [to] his mind or whether his practice is too extensive & laborious to admit of his wasting his time so idly I know not – but he has not yet contributed – This much however must be said of him whether through his intrinsic merits or accidental circumstances he has in fact succeeded in getting into an extraordinary practice and seems likely to settle down here and live easy. – Ah! Francis if I were only as goodlooking a young man as thou art I should then think that Destiny had cut me (too) out for a Doctor
Ben Hardy’s whiskers were always irresistible – but a new bobwig which I find I had the honor of bringing home from Philada. in one of those boxes you remember – that new bobwig with the [portage] of which I was so unconsciously honored – that new bobwig is worth a thousand dollars a year to him –

The old gentleman that was at our house a little while since from Salem – gave us a few particulars in Ben’s history that will be useful to any one who shall hearafter have the honor of compiling his biography – It seems that such was his enterprise and such too his earnest zeal in the laudable task of pleasing the women even in early life that after having studied the art of Crispin in his nativevillage of Kennebunk he was at the pains of a journey and long residence at Lyme to be initiated into the art & mystery of making woman’s shoes

How instructive the lesson that such heroism and model-gallantry teaches – Frank! that mans life is a lesson to all posterity – Raised very probably on a [shingle] in that bleak [-egion] described so emphatically by the poet –
“Away down East dere
[Clow] [by] de moon”
then as he grew up from [clouts] to petticoats from petticoats to breeches to trace the ardent aspirations of a full soul. – panting after greatness and distinction. – from the time he first drove a peg to the time when he last [drove] a peg – still his potentialities are visible [from] germ to perfection and full maturity of cobblerhood. – Ah! if I were only good=looking enough!
One sin of commission too I must confess & be shrived of – As I was turning over some old papers of mine the other day – I accidentally opened an old letter of thine containing “a Serenade” [which] being forthwith tempted by the Devil I inserted in a forthcoming no. of my periodical – Now I am of opinion that the temptation proceeds from that source because unintentionally I find I have eclipsed myself altogether I having “done the poetry” in that [line] till now finding that I shall not be able to write anything as good myself why “Othello’s occupation gone”. –
and I shall be obliged to cultivate a little taste & genius which I flatter myself I possess [as] “dea[t]h is [shocking] accident – and suicide Songster.” – By the way I have begun a pastoral

“Jocund lambkins softly warble” which when finished shall be forwarded for your criticism and another –
[Thus] fair brow thoughts richest mine
When thy bright as diamonds shine
Rivalled only by the glow
of the bright orbs below – there’s a [touch] for you –

Remember you dont pay any postage for this letter
So it is no matter if it is not worth anything
very sincerely yours
Charles Taber


Francis R. Cope
care of Henry & Alfred Cope
Walnut St.
Philada.

Title: 1866 April 15COMMA Locust ShadeCOMMA to Ruthanna Cope
Creator: Susan S. Reeve:  1833-1866
Identified People: CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; SmithCOMMA Daniel B.COMMA 1792-1883
Unidentified People: Lizzie Howell; George; Lizzie; Rachel Howland; John Wood &Lily; Maray Ann Morris; Alexander Wood & Mary Emma Stokes;Sue Farnum;
Subject: Letter writing; Family; Health; Death; LincolnCOMMA AbrahamCOMMA 1809-1865--Assassination; Gossip; Weddings
Geographic Subjects: Wilmington (Del.); Germantown (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.); Europe; Yosemite National Park (Calif.)
Transcript:
Locust Shade. 4.15.1866

My Dear Annie

I have been very sorry to see day after day passing away without any acknowledgment sent of thy very interesting & welcome lettterCOMMA which was a real treat to me. I wish there was some hope of thy getting as good a one in reply but what with colds & headache the little wit I ever had seems to have departedCOMMA for which loss I console with my corespondents every time one of my stupid effusions goes to the Post Office.- I think a visit from thee & Clemmy would have an enlivening effect & when summer comes so must you.- It was very kind to send me that excellent Photo of Uncle DanielCOMMA after my negligence in the
matter of which I have been duly ashamed- and I am very much obliged for it.- We had a nice visit to him had we not? If I had not gone thenCOMMA I fear I should not have seen him at all- except that we did meet in the cars the other day- as being sick in Wilmington entirely spoiled my Germantown visit. so that I could make none of the calls I hoped to.-
How thee must have enjoyed having Clemmy so long with thee. You had splendid times I know. Indeed no one can be at your house without enjoying themselves- At least that is my experience.-
Thee knows perhaps that I have been a good deal with my friend Lizzie Howell this winter.- Her mothers death was so very sudden- only sickda little more that half & hour- that the shock was fearful & Lizzie

was a long time recovering from it.- She is yet very sad- and her brother being in poor health adds to the feeling.- She was so sick for some weeks as rarely to get down stairs. nervous & weak- but is now stronger & brighter & very busy she writes me.- It is often a great blessing I think to those in sorrow to have duties pressing upon them with must be attended to & so the mind is diverted from its greif and made to realize that life has yet much in store for them. –
Did thee know our Georgie has been sent adrift from his home into the city? We do miss him sadly- but he likes his situation in a wholesale store in Market StCOMMA very well & perhaps it is the right thing for him.- We hope that he may be preserved from the temptations that summoned him.- Lizzie has come home
for yearly meeting week.- We have been looking for aunt Rachel Howland & her family every day but hear now they are not coming till next week.-
Has thee been after “Trailing Arbutus” this spring? [-] and I went the other day & found some pale blossoms. but very sweet.- Isnt it delightful to hunt under the dead leaves for the delicate things- it seems to make one feel young again fot the time.- Thee asks have I read “Snow Bound”—Only a little of it & have not happened even to see it in a volume. But intend to get it soon if I can.- The part I read was pleasantCOMMA simple & [s-----] COMMA - as thee says more understandable than much of the latter day poetry.- We have been reading “Across the Continent” and I have indulged dreams of someday seeing the “Yosemite Valley” if my finances get into sufficiently prosperous conditions for such a journey.- Don’t thee
want to go to Europe with the party that starts next month?- It must be bery pleasant to look forward to & finer still to experience if all things are fair & no anxieties to follow you.- Wonder if John Wood & Lily will go.- John says he wants to & I guess Lily would not object.- I liked John better than I expected to- but he is certainly neither handsome nor dignified- but [-------] & kind hearted. I should think.- Is’nt it a comfort Mary Ann Morris is so much better? I cannot help hoping she will be entirely herself again before very long.- Their house is very bright & pleasant & I should think they might be very happy there- This to be sure happiness is not a thing of outward circumstances [----]Did thee remember that yesterday was the anniversary of our dear Presidents death? Wonder where another year will find us.- What do thy brothers think of our prospects with such a man as Johnson at the helm.- It is a comfort that the crew of out ship of State are so staunch & true.-
Suppose Marry Emma Stokes passed meeting last third day- I do like Alexander Wood very much. He seems so open & honest.- Will they have a wedding I wonder- or just be married & go travelling.- I hear friends at Arch Street did not accept Sue Farnum’s resignation. Had she violated discipline before presenting it? The usual yearly mtg storms seems to be brewing this evening- but I hope it wont come this.- Does thee go in and out every day?.- Please excuse this [prosy] sheet dear Annie & write very soon.- My love please to thy sister E. – Very loving by thine
S S Reeve

Title: 1904 February 4COMMA CoalbrookdaleCOMMA R. S. O. Shropshire. to Lilly
Creator: H. Simpson
Unidentified People: Mrs MorrisCOMMA Mrs [Mc] Vicar; Ellie; Frank & Evelyn; Sallie
Subject: Domestics; Health
Transcript:
Coalbrookdale. R.S.O. Shropshire.
Feb. 4. 1904.

My dear Lilly.

It is good of thee to spare us a copy of the last reading groupCOMMA & we [mark] thee very warmly. It is a great interest to be able to picture such occasions so much filled in with the dramatic personaeCOMMA though as this saysCOMMA this may not show most of the of the [ladies] to the best advantage- I should however have thought it was not bad of Mrs. MorrisCOMMA whom I once sawCOMMA years agoCOMMA & who isCOMMA as [----] [----] a sweet
looking little lady- I wonder if the lady at the back is Miss [Mc] Vicar? She & his brother were once at Sunny-sideCOMMA manyCOMMA many years agoCOMMA such a heartCOMMA bright woman I remember.
It is ever so good to think of Ellie's & thy bliss in being again togetherCOMMA & what an interest to theeCOMMA in seeing the new home & new life generally! I do hope everything may have favored the placeCOMMA & that you may have had a perfect time in every way. That southern life must be so utterly differentCOMMA & I always

imagine it must be very much as if in another county altogether with a separate race to deal with- but a country with great charm about it for the matter of fact Anglo Saxo n mind.
We have not heard anything of "Frank & Evelyn" for sometimeCOMMA but hope that all is going well with them.
Our own life has been rather circumscribed the last two or three weeksCOMMA & we have been quite absorbed in our own small affairs. One of our maidsCOMMA a sort of family pivot upon which everything hinges & revolvesCOMMA has had a very bad throat for three weeksCOMMA & though at first the doctor thought it was a [------] [------]COMMA it has now turned out a
case of diphtheria. At the same time Sallie was also in bed with severe cold & an absess in her faceCOMMA so that we felt rather a crippled household. Happily S. is quite herself againCOMMA and our maid is steadily improvingCOMMA but the serious nature of the illness makes it necessary to take all kinds of precautionsCOMMA & we are quite tabooed by our neighborsCOMMA naturally. But we hope there may be no other caseCOMMA though the [obscureness] of the attack at first so disarmed our suspicion we were all more or less in contact for ten days!
I expect youCOMMA like ourselves our watching anxiously lest this terrible war cloud bursts in the East! It seems almost the irony of fate that the poor Russian Czar should be freed into itCOMMA in spite of all his Peace Congress agitations. And one shudders to think of all it may involve before it is over! Sallie joins in much loveCOMMA dear Lilly with mine thy very affect. H. Simpson
I enclose a wee reminder of thy old friends.

Title: 1870 August 16COMMA AwburyCOMMA to My dear Frank
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; HartshorneCOMMA Anna C. (Anna Cope)COMMA 1860-1957; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; CopeCOMMA RuthannaCOMMA 1834-1879;
Unidentified People: Elizabeth; Lucy Harrison; bro. John; Anna; Aunt Ruth
Subject: Clothing and dress; Family; Health; Letter writing; Railroad travel; Voyages and Travels; Weather; Wounds and injuries;
Geographic Subjects: Altoona (Pa.); Bellefonte (Pa.); Chicago (Ill.); Detroit (Mich.); Niagara (N.Y.); Philadelphia (Pa.); Snow Shoe (Pa.); Awbury (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.)
Transcript:
Awbury 8 mo. 16th 1870

My dear FrankCOMMA

I rec'd thine & Chellie’s letters to dayCOMMA when Tho's came out from town. They also had one from MaryCOMMA and we are glad to hear of your safe arrival at Snow Shoe and very thankful I amCOMMA that you had a doctor so near at hand to extract the bone from thy throat. I read thy letter firstCOMMA and was much alarmed. before knowing what the accident thee alluded to wasCOMMA but Thomas fortunately knew about it from Mary's letter & told me at once. What a providential thing it wasCOMMA that there was a Dr. so near at hand. the children must have been very much frightenedCOMMA before thee was relieved.--I hope thee will be careful of thyselfCOMMA and not jumpCOMMA and injure thy arch again.—
-
attached wife Anna S. Cope. I hope Tom is provided with warm under-clothing. Mary sends her love & hopes you will have a good time.I hope thee has enough warm clothingCOMMA with theeCOMMA for I sh'd not be surprised of thr warmest weather is past. We are having it delightful here at homeCOMMA the thermometer 68 this morning at 8 o'clock and under 80 at noon. This afternoon Thomas & Elizabeth Mary & I called at father'sCOMMA and afterwards at Ellis Yarnall's leaving Mary at father's. We found them all at homeCOMMA and had a very pleasant visit. Lucy Harrison is very bright & agreeable & Anne is lovely. She told me she had written a note to LillieCOMMA which I would send to her when it comes to hand. She also told me she was sorry not to go to Snow Shoe with youCOMMA but they could not go to ChicagoCOMMA & as their time is so limited they of course felt anxious to see as much as possible before going home. they expect to go to Detroit from Chicagoand then on to Niagara. They expect to leave sometime next weekCOMMA and take the journey alone. We all disapprove of them taking such a long journey by themselvesCOMMA but I suppose Ellis Yarnall will find out some one to look after them. When they go onCOMMA they expect to spend the first night at AltoonaCOMMA and then travel day & night until they reach Chicago. I have sent Lillie & Chellie some under-clothing. 2 flannel skirtsCOMMA 2 under vestsCOMMA 1 cloth bodyCOMMA 2 pairs thick stockingsCOMMA 1 pair drawersCOMMA 1 [Alpaca?] skirt. Anna & Carrie are quite wellCOMMA & the former is invitee to spend tomorrow with cousin Mary [W.?] Brown's little Mary. I did not [?] like [?]-ing her just nowCOMMA but could not well decline. I was at father's this afternoonCOMMA and they were all pretty well. father seems stronger from the change in weather. I saw bro. John and his boys go off this morningCOMMA and hope they had apleasant trip to Altoona. I am glad you met with such a polite reception at Bellefonte. I had no idea beforeCOMMA that there was any such spring of waterCOMMA there as mentions. 63000 gallons a minute is immense. I think you must have enjoyed the ride up the mountain very muchCOMMA if the views are so beautiful. Give my love to Lillie & ChellieCOMMA and tell them I hope they will not be put out at my sending them some warm clothingCOMMA as I am only sorry they did not send for warm dresses tooCOMMA as they have nothing warm with them. It is now bed-time and I must put by my writing; the children are enjoying Anna Hartshorne's company very much. I hope some of you will write tho' I do not want you to tax yourselves. I have already been much favored. Bro Thomas intended sending sister Anne's letterCOMMA but it was not returned from Aunt Ruth's in time. with much love to you allCOMMA ever thy

Title: 1861 November 25COMMA NewportCOMMA to Chellie
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916

Newport 11 mo. 25th 1861
2nd day

Dear Chellie I have been writing a long letter to grandma Brown this morning as we were kept indoors on account of a snow-stormCOMMA and I fully intended writing to cousin Amelia tooCOMMA but the dinner hour came too soonCOMMA and now the carriage is at the door to take us to rideCOMMA and we must be off. I hope we shall get off as we expect on 4th day eveningCOMMA as I am anxious to get home-we are all pretty well-with much loveCOMMA and kisses to the little onesCOMMA affectionately thy mother AS Cope

Mama [Haines?] and I add our [?] while she gets ready which I do with pleasure aftly thy father F.R.CTom sends a picture of a policeman trying to catch a man for [---]1861 with drawing by T.P.C

Rachel R. Cope
care of Cope Brothers
