Title: 1847COMMA August 10COMMA to My dear Mary
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Identified People: BrownCOMMA Susanna SansomCOMMA 1826-1909; BrownCOMMA William A.COMMA b. 1824; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?;
Unidentified People: cousin Wistar; Elizy H[acker?]; Tom; Mr. Williams; Moses; Anna Hazard; S & A Jenkins; Thomas Hazard; Fanny H[azard?];
Subject: Clothing and dress; Family; Health; Letter writing; Newport (R.I.)--Description and Travel; Quakers--Social life and customs; Sailing; Seashore; Transportation; Weather;
Transcript:
Newport 8 mo 10th / 47

My dear Mary

Frank has been writing to William this morningCOMMA and has most likely advised you on all points of interest.- you probably know by this timeCOMMA that we are all in a good state of healthCOMMA and we hope that our sister Susan is improvingCOMMA tho' she still has some head-ache. Frank & cousin Wistar are very kind and devote themselves almost exclusively to contributing to her comfort & pleasure in every way. F is devoted to Susan and does evey thing in his power to promote the improvement of her healthCOMMA his kindness is unparalleled: everything is done for usCOMMA and we have nothing to doCOMMA but join in the pleasant plans laid out for us.- Elizy H & Susan were concluding before dinnerCOMMA that they accomplished very little of any thing on account of the time occupied in changing their dresses for the different labors of the day.- About ten in the morning they prepare for bathing or rather we do when Susan does not go-
/
not arrive on 7th day tho' we intend to do so if possible. the Boat did not leave until 5 o'clock this morning. I expect the irregular lately.- with much love
aff thy sister Anne
Susan will accompany us to Hazard's this afternoon
she is resting since her bath.then return about 12 o'clock. restCOMMA until time to away for dinnerCOMMA then about 5 o'clockCOMMA a different costume must necessarily be adapted for Sailing especially when the boatsCOMMA are slightly fishy & a little dirty.- then we come home about ten-time or little pastCOMMA and another change must be made to appear at [---] which [---] will suffice for the evening.- but all this is done in a good hurry and I cannot say it consumes much time.- I believe I have nothing new to tell theeCOMMA and indeedCOMMA I expect it would be very puzzling to think of any such thing when Cousin Wistar is of the partyCOMMA for he writes home to frequentlyCOMMA and describes every thing that seems with so much minutenessCOMMA that if you are favored with the perusal of his epistlesCOMMA ours must seem quite commonplace; this is my conjectureCOMMA as we joke Wistar & Sue bothCOMMA about writing so often.- Only to think- Sixth day evening we leaveCOMMA if a storm or fog does not prevent usCOMMA and Tom has concluded to remainCOMMA and return with us last evening tho' fog was so dense that the Bay-State" did not go outCOMMA and now we have every prospectCOMMA of the same thick state of the atmosphere for this evening consequently. it seemed hardly worth while for Tom to leave before we did.- The Massachusetts arrived here with Mr. Williams on boardCOMMA about 11 o'clock thismorning having been lying off Point JudithCOMMA even since four o'clock. Susan & Lizzie went to bathe this morning with F & Wistar leaving me at home to pass the time as I could. Tom & Moses had gone fishingCOMMA and I was quiet enough. Susan though it best notwithstanding your messageCOMMA to try the [---] three times faithfully as the Dr directedCOMMA and I hope she will not be any worse for itCOMMA and perhaps it may strengthen her afterwards. She says she likes it very much while in the waterCOMMA but she feels pretty weak for sometime afterwards. we think she is the best judge for what is best for herCOMMA and she does exactly what she wished in the Bathing line; Frank takes her inCOMMA giving her three waves as directedCOMMA he said the water was very warm & pleasant this morning. I quite long to go in again but fear I shall not have an opportunity of going more than once or twice more before I leave.- It suits Elizy Hacker exactlyCOMMA she feels a little tired after coming outCOMMA but it seems to brance & strenghthen herCOMMA and shee looks better I think in this little time of our [---] here. I do hope her father will telegraph her to remain with SueCOMMA if the letter does not arrive in time to answer it before our leave.- yester afternoon we were out Sailing in the bayCOMMA landed on one of the [dumpling?] rocks gathered some sprigs of green to pressCOMMA and enjoyedthe novelty of it highlyCOMMA it was really very pleasantCOMMA altho' by the time we returnedCOMMA our blanket shawls were almost white with the fog. Sailing seems to suit SusanCOMMA very wellCOMMA but I think clear weather as a general thing is preferable to her.- This afternoon we think of calling at fr'd Hazard’sCOMMA we spent a pleasant evening there last Sixth day. they are certainly a delightful family. Ann[a/e?] Hazard called here this morning with S & A Jenkins who are still staying with them – we intend riding out to see fr'd Jenkins before we go.- 4th day morn. I was obliged to leave this shut hastily yesterday afternoonCOMMA as Thomas Hazard & his wife called upon us inviting us to spend this afternoon with them which we intend doing. Elizy & Frank are much disappointed I believe in Fanny H’s beautyCOMMA but they must see her at [---] before they fully decide. She is perfect at home.- my love to all- Susan and Lizzie are taking a nap before dinnerCOMMA and I cannot disturb them now.- there is a thick fog over they bay now 12 at noonCOMMA and it will [---] increase- Tom could not have gone last night in consequence of the bay as the boat did not leaveCOMMA and perhaps it is as well for him to wait for us. Frank & myself do not think it proper to leave here in a fog or storm and Tom must not think it strange if we do

Title: 1858 July 9COMMA AwburyCOMMA to sister Anna
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Identified People: BrownCOMMA JohnCOMMA 1800-1859; CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1857-1897; CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1850-1924; CopeCOMMA John StokesCOMMA 1857-1915; CopeCOMMA Mary StokesCOMMA 1853-1888; CopeCOMMA Rebecca BiddleCOMMA 1812-1876; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; CopeCOMMA William BrownCOMMA 1854-1860; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; HainesCOMMA ReubenCOMMA 1851-1920
Unidentified People: Geo. M. Dallas; Elizy Hacker; Hannah Stokes; Sarah Biddle; Bishop Potter
Subject: Bonnets; Child care; Children and the sea; Health; Letter writing; Whooping cough
Geographic Subjects: Atlantic City (N.J.); Brussels (Belgium); England; Newport (R.I.); Philadelphia (Pa.)
Notes:
A note at the top of the front page by a different hand reads: "Letter from Anna S. Cope to her sister in law R.Anna Cope"

Anna references an "affair" that causes much concernCOMMA especially among ThomasCOMMA father in-law Henry Cope and Geo. M. Dallas
Transcript:
[Letter from Anna S. Cope to her sister in law R.Anna Cope]

Awbury 7 mo. 9th / 58

Dear sister Anna

Thee will think I am very remiss in performing my promises but it is useless for me to make excusesCOMMA as thee knows how time goes with meCOMMA generallyCOMMA amongst the childrenm during the dayCOMMA and by evening thee may imagine how it is that I feel too indolent to write a letter. We are much obliged to father for his kind & sympathetic letter at this time and I hope we may be enabled to take the right view of our troublesCOMMA in this matter. Much love to father and motherCOMMA and tell them that Francis keeps up his spirits very wellCOMMA considering all thingsCOMMA he has received a letter from bro' Thomas to dayCOMMA with Geo. M. Dallas reply to his (Tho's) epistleCOMMA which he hasprobably sent to Atlantic City for father's perusal.- it is shortCOMMA very politely wordedCOMMA and caps the climax for coolnessCOMMA on the subjectCOMMA as he had evidently not troubled himself about the affair in the slightest degree.- I must confessCOMMA I was completely taken aback at such cool indifference on the subjectCOMMA especially as Thomas had consulted him beforeCOMMA when in England. But I suppose there is nothing more to be done about itCOMMA and we must try to hear it with a Christian spirit as father does.-
Elizy sends her love to you all & is in better spiritsCOMMA than latelyCOMMA as she has received several letters from ThomasCOMMA he is still in BrusselsCOMMA and appears to have no very definite idea when he may return home.-
We are glad father has sent for Julia to join youCOMMA as she needs a changeCOMMA I fear she confines too lately to the atticCOMMA and a little of your refreshing sea-breezes will revive her. I think she has been concerned about GeorgeCOMMA as he hasbeen quite indisposed. He is now much better and spent this afternoon here for the first timeCOMMA as the Dr. thought the ride might do him goodCOMMA but unfortunately he did not see much of JuliaCOMMA she having been in townCOMMA and did not reach home until near seven o'clock when he was obliged to go home to tea. He says the Dr. pronounced his lungs quite clear nowCOMMA and I hope he will be able to accompany Julia to the shore.- Hannah Stokes has been here to dayCOMMA and intends staying over-nightCOMMA it is quite cheering to have a little company as we miss you all so much. Thy letter this afternoon was very acceptableCOMMA and tell Clemmy I thought perhaps she would have favored us again. I am glad to hear of the Doctor having slept better and hope he may be benefittedCOMMA my love to sister MaryCOMMA and mention to her if thee pleasesCOMMA that I have not received any reply to my letter to herCOMMA but suppose I am to get a bonnet for her at Jones' according to my best judgment. but they think it is very doubtful if they can procure any other quality of [---]. it is not as fine as thatof which our sun-bonnets are made. Elizy Hacker expected to have gone down to Atlantic City this weekCOMMA but was not well enough.-
Brother John has been here a few minutes this eveningCOMMA Rueben is not entirely well of the poison yetCOMMA and they think he has the whooping-cough. Our Willy has it nowCOMMA also little Johnny & little Mary has it quite badly.-
Our Tom is getting better of itCOMMA and Alfred does not cough now at all; Henry still coughs a good deal at nightCOMMA as well as little Johnny.-
Mary Mayer has arrived in the city of P- and will come down here tomorrow afternoon. How does sister Mary enjoy herselfCOMMA and has she returned to bathe? Tell Clemmy I was not surprised to hear her opinion that it is not equal to Newport. Sarah Biddle mentioned to us on first day lastCOMMA of their having received letters from uncle Alfred and aunt Rebecca- and uncle Alfred is much betterCOMMA thinks the hydropathic system suits him. Bishop Potter’s family are still with them. Thee does not knowCOMMA how much I wished she had offered to show usthe lettersCOMMA as she said they were longCOMMA and very interesting.
It is past ten o'clockCOMMA and F- is shutting up the house affectionately thy sister
Anna

Title: 1858 August 12COMMA AwburyCOMMA to My dear sister
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1857-1897; CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; CopeCOMMA ClementineCOMMA 1835-1903; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth Waln StokesCOMMA 1823-1902; CopeCOMMA Susan L. NewboldCOMMA 1805-1872; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA William D. (William Drinker)COMMA 1798-1873; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939
Unidentified People: Edward Biddle; Julia; Dr Evans
Subject: Child care; Child rearing; Cold (Disease); Gifts; Health; Toys; Voyages and Travels
Notes: The fourth page of the letter is a note by Francis R. Cope to his sister Ruthanna regarding a possible visit.
Transcript:
Awbury 8 mo 12th / 58

My dear sister

When I last wroteCOMMA it seemed so doubtful whether thee would be at uncle William's or on the way home with Edward BiddleCOMMA that I concluded to direct the letter to Clemmy in case thee had left there.- Brother Thomas returned home very unexpectedly on second day eveningCOMMA the very time we were looking for theeCOMMA he was much overcome by the voyageCOMMA and the anxiety of getting off in a steamerCOMMA but I hope is better nowCOMMAand likely to improve; his strength has been much prostratedCOMMA and he has had some fever but the Doctor considers him better this eveningCOMMA and he does really seem betterCOMMA tho’ he is still quite weak. They had a very cold voyageCOMMA and he could not keep warm enough & consequently took a severe coldCOMMA but thee must not be anxious or uneasy about himCOMMA as Dr Rhoads thinks him much better; &he is entirely free of fever this evening. Alfred is also much better to day for the first timeCOMMA but he has changed so frequently from better to worse in the course of twenty four hoursCOMMA that we hardly know how to calculate about him. But I think the Doctor is more encouraged about him this eveningCOMMA and I have great hopes that he will soon be on the well listCOMMA as he has one tooth throughCOMMA and he has not coughed quite so hard to day; the rest of the family are all pretty wellCOMMA fatherCOMMA and mother desire their love to theeCOMMA and say thee had better take the first good opportunity to return homeCOMMA and not to think of coming home aloneCOMMA without hearing further from us; and Francis also adds that in case Alfred continues betterCOMMA perhaps he can come up for the next week.-
With regard to thy medicineCOMMA and salveCOMMA we will endeavor to send it to thee in some wayCOMMA as well as the material for aunt Susan’s duster.- Bro' Thomas has bough various little articles for the childrenCOMMA with which they are much pleased; he bought Lilly & Chelly eacha suit of doll’s clothes made in ParisCOMMA according to the present styleCOMMA hats shoesCOMMA and even night-gown and cap. velvet [---] watch & chainCOMMA little [---] all furnished in the most minute styleCOMMA [---]COMMA &c little beautiesCOMMA- the children are so overjoyedCOMMA that they show them to everyone that comesCOMMA and do not get tired of examining themCOMMA at all times in the dayCOMMA and I do not wonder for they are so elegantly made that you cannot help admiring them. Sister Elizy and Julia sed their love to Clemmy and thyselfCOMMA in which I wish to joinCOMMA also love to Aunt SusanCOMMA Annette & Carry- I am sorry I have no news to tell theeCOMMA such as thee would like to hearCOMMA but as I have not been any where for the last three or four weeks thee must not wonder at it.-
with much love affectionately
sister Anna S. Cope
PS.
I am obliged to close this in hasteCOMMA as it is lateCOMMA and the family have mostly retired
mother is about as well as usual now.-Tom continues to get better- whether I get up for thee or not will depend on how Alfred is. He is a good deal better this morning. I have Aunt Susans cloth which if I do not bring up I will send by envelope. There seems to be no use of sending thy medicine as thee will hardly have a chance to use itCOMMA but I will bring it with me if I come. Dr Evans is not in town now
afftly thy bro

Alfred is also much better to day for the first timeCOMMA but he has changed so frequently from better to worse in the course of twenty four hoursCOMMA that we hardly know how to calculate about him. But I think the Doctor is more encouraged about him this eveningCOMMA and I have great hopes that he will soon be on the well listCOMMA as he has one tooth throughCOMMA and he has not coughed quite so hard to day; the rest of the family are all pretty wellCOMMA fatherCOMMA and mother desire their love to theeCOMMA and say thee had better take the first good opportunity to return homeCOMMA and not to think of coming home aloneCOMMA without hearing further from us; and Francis also adds that in case Alfred continues betterCOMMA perhaps he can come up for the next week.-
With regard to thy medicineCOMMA and salveCOMMA we will endeavor to send it to thee in some wayCOMMA as well as the material for aunt Susan’s duster.- Bro' Thomas has bough various little articles for the childrenCOMMA with which they are much pleased; he bought Lilly & Chelly eacha suit of doll’s clothes made in ParisCOMMA according to the present styleCOMMA hats shoesCOMMA and even night-gown and cap. velvet [---] watch & chainCOMMA little [---] all furnished in the most minute styleCOMMA [---]COMMA &c little beautiesCOMMA- the children are so overjoyedCOMMA that they show them to everyone that comesCOMMA and do not get tired of examining themCOMMA at all times in the dayCOMMA and I do not wonder for they are so elegantly made that you cannot help admiring them. Sister Elizy and Julia sed their love to Clemmy and thyselfCOMMA in which I wish to joinCOMMA also love to Aunt SusanCOMMA Annette & Carry- I am sorry I have no news to tell theeCOMMA such as thee would like to hearCOMMA but as I have not been any where for the last three or four weeks thee must not wonder at it.-
with much love affectionately
sister Anna S. Cope
PS.
I am obliged to close this in hasteCOMMA as it is lateCOMMA and the family have mostly retired
mother is about as well as usual now.-Tom continues to get better- whether I get up for thee or not will depend on how Alfred is. He is a good deal better this morning. I have Aunt Susans cloth which if I do not bring up I will send by envelope. There seems to be no use of sending thy medicine as thee will hardly have a chance to use itCOMMA but I will bring it with me if I come. Dr Evans is not in town now
afftly thy bro
F.R.C.

Title: 1859 August 14COMMA AwburyCOMMA to mother
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916

(Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA William BrownCOMMA 1854-1860; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?; HartshorneCOMMA Virginia; EvansCOMMA Eleanor Tyson StokesCOMMA 1840-1919; CopeCOMMA EleanorCOMMA 1847-1860

Notes:
Letter reports on the birth of Arthur CopeCOMMA who is as of yet unnamedCOMMA to Elizabeth W. and Thomas Pim Cope.
Embossing in top left of first page reads "DELARUE & CO LONDON".
Transcript:
Awbury 8 mo 14th 1859

Dear mother

I wrote a few hasty lines to Frank this afternoon which brother Thomas did not succeed in sending to youCOMMA as the Germantown post-office he found was not open on First-dayCOMMA giving you the good news that sister E. has another boyCOMMA a very fine-looking childCOMMA and the tenth grandsonCOMMA but as yet without a nameCOMMA which is not decided uponCOMMA indeedCOMMA I have not heard one suggestionCOMMA only it is to be a fancy nameCOMMA and Lizzie leaves it to bro' Thomas select. Sister E. desires her loveCOMMA and wishes me to say to theeCOMMA that she is very comfortableCOMMA this evening; and the Doctor says she is doing as well as is possible. The child was born at 1/2 past 7 o'clock this morningCOMMA and the nurse came about 9. Thomas sent to town for her earlyCOMMA and she came as soon as shecouldCOMMA but it did not make any difference as the Doctor thought Mary Sixsmith was entirely competent to attent to all that was neededCOMMA and she proved so.
Bro’ Thomas took HarryCOMMA Tom & Willy to meetingCOMMA and afternoon left our two boys at father’s to dineCOMMA and went for them to return home towards evening. The house seems quite lonely and deserted nowCOMMA and company at the tea-table was very slim this eveningCOMMA only threeCOMMA ThomasCOMMA Harry & myself.
Ellie Stokes with little Ellie left for Riverton yesterday afternoon. Ellie ad been staying with us since 6th day morning.
Sister Susan and Virginia also went home yesterday afternoonCOMMA they enjoyed their visit with us very muchCOMMA and it was very pleasant to us to have themCOMMA as we miss you all so much. The children have kept pretty wellCOMMA tho' yesterday was an oppressively warm day hereCOMMA so damp & closeCOMMA but to day it is lovelyCOMMA tho' quite warm.-
I hope you are all enjoying the sea-breezes notwithstanding the hard bedsCOMMA which must be quite a draw-back to thecomfort of some of you. How is Anne? Sister Lizzie wished me to mentionCOMMA that she hopes Anne will drink plenty of [---] wine as it was particularly recommended to Clemmie by Dr. [Meigs?]COMMA at one time as being very beneficialCOMMA as it has the peculiar quality of enriching the bloodCOMMA and he ordered her to take a tumbler full a day. Lizzie thinks Frank had better take some more of it to Atlantic City for her on 4th dayCOMMA when he comes up. Please give my love to herCOMMA also to fatherCOMMA EmmaCOMMA and sister Lizzie Brown. Dr Rhoads mentioned this morning that Margaret Eliz expected to go to the sea-shore tomorrow in company with Augustus WilsonCOMMA and some one else whose name I did not quite understand. I hope you may meet with her.-
affectionately thy daughter

Anna S. Cope

Title: 1859 August 18COMMA AwburyCOMMA to My dear Chellie
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916

(Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA William BrownCOMMA 1854-1860; HainesCOMMA Mary D. (Mary Drinker Cope)COMMA 1819-1890; YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881;

Transcript:
Awbury 8 mo 18th 1859

My dear Chellie

As Dr Rhoads very kindly offered to take this note to theeCOMMA I thought perhaps thee would like to hear how thy little brothers are getting along at home and therefore take the opportunity to send a few hasty lines. Alfred was very happy in a few minutes after papa and Willy & Tom left us; I went to ride with uncle Thomas the latter part of the afternoonCOMMA and took him alongCOMMA we had a few errands to do in Germantown.-
Uncle Alfred & Aunt Rebecca Cope with AnnieCOMMA called to see us yesterday afternoon and we had a very pleasant visit from them. Uncle Alfred's knee is still rather troublesomeCOMMA but his foot is better. Cousin Edward is going to the WhiteMountains with uncle Edward Yarnall & Aunt CarolineCOMMA very soon. Tell Aunt Lizzie that I saw grandma Brown at meeting this morningCOMMA she told me they were all pretty well except Ridgely and he was threatened with [cramp?] last nightCOMMA but was much better to dayCOMMA indeed quite relieved; they sent for Dr Rhoads who saw him again this morning before grandma came to meeting. Tell papa that wonders will never ceaseCOMMA Aunt Mary Haines & mamma are going to spend this evening with Ann Haines to meet B Yarnall's family.-

in great haste
affly thy mother

A S Cope

Title: 1873 July 24COMMA ConnymedeCOMMA to Lily
Creator: Annette Cope:  1843-1916
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883
Subject: Betrothal; Secrets
Notes: The letter is Annette Cope's response to Elizabeth S. Cope on the subject of her once-secret marriage engagement to her cousinCOMMA Alexis T. Cope (Annette's younger brother).
Transcript:
ConnymedeCOMMA July 24

I know my dear Lily thee has a [have?] spirit by nature as well as by grace; that no gloom or sorrow will ever crush thee; therefore I no more fear for thee in the step thee has now takenCOMMA but wish thee heartily "God speed".

I fancy thee is in a state where most outward impressions now seem very
dimCOMMA & nothing that is said will give either grief or joy; and even if I could I would not fill thee with anxious forboding's after so many months of solemn consideration; but for my own satisfaction I was to give thee a loving heart-felt welcome in the prospect of what we may in time be to each other.

One there is who so often longed to know the secret of your heart and who even at this time perhaps ispermitted to see the happiness of the child she so much loved. And do not let us forget the One kindest & tenderest alone allCOMMA who watches us always; who will do what is for our good now & eternally.

Hoping thee will come to us when thee is ableCOMMA as thee used toCOMMA I am thy truly loving affectionate

Annette.

Title: 1875 July 4COMMA Lake WindermereCOMMA to Tom & Scrubby
Creator: Alfred Cope:  1857-1897
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; CopeCOMMA John StokesCOMMA 1857-1915; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; WordsworthCOMMA WilliamCOMMA 1770-1850;
Unidentified People: Scrubby [recipient]
Subject: England--Description and Travel; CookeryCOMMA English; Health; Mountains--England; Weather;
Geographic Subjects: Ambleside (England); Bowness-on-Windermere (England); Coniston (England); Grasmere (England); Hawkshead (England); Kendal (England); Keswick (CumbriaCOMMA England); Rydal (England); Wales; Windermere (England);
Transcript:
Lockwood Hotel Lake Windermere
July 4. 1875

Dear Tom & Scrubby.

I did write a few lones to thee Scrubby from Kendal but I rec'd such a nice letter from thee last Fifth day that I concluded to send thee a longer one; & as I have already rec'd two letters from Tom I thought it would be well to kill two birds with one stone-so here goes-We saw the first of this lake last Fourth day afternoonand will continue to see it till sometime tomorrow. I haven't the slightest idea where the pictureCOMMA at the head of this sheetCOMMA is taken from;- but I know one thing & that is that I have not as yet seen anything like it nor do I think that there is such a view. At any rate it gives you no idea of the place. Now for the narrative- We took a row on the lake soon after arriving here & on Fifth day took the steamer down to [Bowness?] where we expected to get on a carriage & drive over to Coniston. When we arrived thereCOMMA howeverCOMMA the sky looked so threatening & Alexis not feeling very well we concluded to leave it till next dayCOMMA & returned to Louwood. Arriving in a heavy shower we were at a loss to know what to doCOMMA till I decided to go over to Keswick & get our letters that were probably awaiting our arrival there. So as the stage did not go till 3 o'clock I drove over to AmblesideCOMMA bought a full rubbersuit (coat leggings & cap) hired a horse & started offCOMMA about 1 o'clock. You can imagine me clothed in these things sitting on an awfully rough trotter nothing of my usual self being visible except my eyesCOMMA nose & mouthCOMMA and my shoes. The suit answered admirablyCOMMA keeping me perfectly dry in the hardest thunder-storm I was ever out in- Except my shoes wh. in a few minutes were rather soggy. However it was soon over & I arrived at [Derwentwater?] HotelCOMMA [Portinscale?] at 4 P.M. having ridden on horseback 19 miles. Here I obtainedCOMMA first a lunch then the lettersCOMMA one from each of you. While waiting here another gust came up & when it had gone over the sky looked brighter & more settled. So having engaged rooms for 2nd dayCOMMA at 6 P.M. I set off & had a most beautiful ride past [Thirlmue?] & HelvellynCOMMA Grasmere & Rydal Water back to Ambleside wh. I reached at half past eight. Drove downto our hotelCOMMA took some red-hot tea & then went out to hunt for Lilly & AlexisCOMMA whom I found spooning in a bench & who told me that there were three other pairs in the hotel worse off than we were. Sixth-day we set off for Coniston WaterCOMMA driving alongside of Windermere & crossing below BownessCOMMA through Hawkshead where Wordsworth went to school & finally reached Coniston where Lillie & I made the tour of the lake in the steam Gondolee as they call it while Alexis ascended the "Old Man." We had the best of it forCOMMA although he immortalized himself by leaving his name & address in full on top of pole of stones which has been placed thereCOMMA yet he was caught in such a dense fogthat he couldn't see anything & in turn caught a species of chill & feverCOMMA from which he is slowly recovering. Yetserday we went through Grasmere & Rydal & got Lillie pretty well played out. We rowed down Grasmere Lake & walked to Rydal MountCOMMA (wh we did not seeCOMMA exceptone window & the chimney's) Lillie & Alexis "preferring rather" to keep on a level while I crossed over the hill from wh. I got an elegant view of WindermereCOMMA Rydal WaterCOMMA Grasmere & [Tharlmere?] besides some small 'towns' and the mountains on all sides. On coming down I overtook Lou & Alexis spooning by the roadsideCOMMA On my coming up they had began to talkpleasantly about the weatherCOMMA Lillie suggesting that it was much cooler than the 3rd of July 2 years agoCOMMA at wh. both looked remarkably pleased & mysterious. I looked very innocent but on making "comparative mathematical calculations" have concluded that it must have been that day they drove over from Connymeade together & took two hours & a half (2 ½ hrs) by the watch to get up to the house from the stable-

It’s fearfully hard to get Lillie up in the mornings. She grumbles incessently because Alexis & myself will order breakfast at half past eight & uses as anargument to the statementCOMMA (I wont say in fact) that Father when he was over here did not breakfast till nine. Another instanceCOMMA Tom of the force of example. However we dont give in & in revenge she gener-ally keeps us waiting 15 or 20 minutes. Alexis thinks it is a good thing that we travel from place to placeCOMMA as they must think wherever we go that it is a mere accident that we are late. This miserable climate dont seem to suit me very well. In the first place the voyage knocked meCOMMA clean; for I caught cold some how wh. increased my sore-throat & I haven’t got rid of it yet. It steadily increased till I got to Warwick wh place seemed to agree with it; for it has been improving since. Then I had a boil on my skin which troubled me not a little when I ran against anything or Alexis hit me with his umbrella. I have got it down to a pretty fine point now however & one is coming on my backjust between my shoulders so as to afford me an opportunity of displaying my skill in twisting my arms around. Beer dont seem to be the thing for me at presentCOMMA & I have hardly tasted it since leaving Liverpool. As to the roast-beefCOMMA it tastes very much like the same article at homeCOMMA and they put so much mint with the peas to make them green I suppose that you cant taste any thing else. But the great charm is that every thing is so nice & clean- no greasy knives &c You must excuse this writing; but Lillie brought us out here on a most uncomfortable hill-side & insists on sticking it out. We saw some very pretty little ponies when we were in Wales Srubby; but as we are carrying very small valises & they are pretty full we thought best to defer our purchasefor a season. I commenced writing on this sheet as you may see but Lou thought it was so important to write on pictured paper that I gave in- Consequently the above marks- I hope that Hazen may succeed in getting up his party & also that he will not ruin the horses driving too much in the park. I have just thought of a little map wh. I have in my packet wh. I shall enclose in this letter with 5th and 6th sdays excursions marked on them. Although it may not interest either of you I think mother will like to see it. I will now cook as it is time for me to be poking Lillie up to go down to dinnerCOMMA

affectly your bro
Alfred Cope Jr.[Derwentwater] Hotel.
Portsinscale- Keswick
7.7.75.

P.S.

2 1/2 P.M.

Have just arrived here & rec'd a letter from T.P.C. Jr. giving a fair "a/c" of the babyCOMMA water-works & crops. Also a bill from Holliday & Storrs I [---] amounting to the enormous sum of [Pound] 5.16.6. I have come to the conclusion that he is not the man for me. Lou gaps as much as ever. This morning just as we were finishing breakfast she commenced raising her elbows to the same level as her shoulders (You probably remember that little habit) but I saw it in time & proposed to up to our rooms to stretch. Please remember me to the baby- and Chellie. Also to any other member of the family wh. happens to be at home. I dont wonder John dont know know where you all are-

A.C.Jr.[Alfred's letters from Europe 1875-76

letter

Thos. P. Cope Jr.
Cope Brothers
Philadelphia
U.S.A.

Title: 1880 February 8COMMA CannesCOMMA to Alexis
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; HainesCOMMA Francis CopeCOMMA 1857-1918;
Unidentified People: A & C;
Subject: Child rearing; Community life; Family; France--Description and Travel; Loneliness; Quakers--Social life and customs; Weather;
Geographic Subjects: Cannes (France); French Riviera; Susquehanna County (Pa.); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.)
Notes: Clementine has been in France for the last 2 months and writes to Alexis T. Cope from Cannes.  She expresses eagerness to return to Susquehanna County (Pennsylvania) to again see the familyCOMMA but says that she would no longer like to live at ConnymeadeCOMMA which a very lonely place.  FurthermoreCOMMA Clementine advises Alexis that Connymead would be a bad place to raise children with his wifeCOMMA Elizabeth S. CopeCOMMA as QuakersCOMMA because of the remoteness and lack of Friends community.
Transcript:
Cannes Feb. 8. 1880.

Dear AlexisCOMMA

We recd thy letter of Jan. 16th a few days sinceCOMMA & have been thinking over thy proposition. It wd. be nice to be able to spend part of our summers in Susquehanna Co particularly if you make it your homeCOMMA but we have not been looking forwarrd to keeping house in our return. I do not want to live at Connymead againCOMMA (indeed I do not think any of us want to; unless we cd. find some one to live with us) It was too lonelyCOMMA particularly for me. & if we did not keep house there in winterCOMMA we cd. not keep very well keep house in summer. How or where we shall live when we go homeCOMMA I do not know. Indeed the uncertainties of the futureCOMMA & what it will be best to doCOMMA often weighs upon my mind. Connymead is no placefor any body to live who wants to be a FriendCOMMA or who has any preference for their ways. Life there was a continual struggle wh. I have no desire to renewCOMMA & perhaps we shall never know again [ever/even?] that semblance of a home. I hope if thee and Lily picked to bring your children up as FriendsCOMMA you may be able to keep them in a community where Friends live. For it is pretty hard for a young person who has been uninstructed in what are considered the accomplishments of life to have to live where these are considered all importantCOMMA & are the chief recupations of those by whom you are surrounded. It requires a good deal of strength of character to be able to live aloneCOMMA I [---]COMMA & Friends must always do it more or less when they go out from among their own people. When one has not been brought to play on the piano or sing or drawCOMMA or paintCOMMA or evento play cards- a not very valuable accomplishment certainly- & yet one in wh. English people who are both intelligent & sensibleCOMMA seem to while away at least a fourth part of their waking hours; & never to tire of- When I sayCOMMA one has never been instructed in any of these thingsCOMMA one feels as if one ought to be at least where they are not the chief employment of life. Of course when living in a delightful pension on the Riviera- one is not supposed to be exactly fulfilling the normal conditions of existence- Existence here (the physical part of it) seems too delightful to be long continuedCOMMA & I have wonder since we have been here how long 14 human beings could live togetherCOMMA without apparently a shadow of sorrow or anxiety to disturb the delightful daysCOMMA which seemCOMMA to glide away without a cloud either inward or outwardCOMMA to mar their peacefulness such skiesCOMMA & such weather COMMA & such walks as we have- only one littleshower in all the two months we have been here- It is the most perfect thing in weather certainlyCOMMA that we have ever experienced. If we had come last winter we shd not have had the same experience of itCOMMA for it rained very much even here. But I have digressed widely from the subject upon wh. I intended to writeCOMMA [---] the old house of Woodbourne. Whatever may be my inclincation with regard to itCOMMA (& I certainly shd. like very much the idea of being able to live somewhere near you). I do not thonk C & A have any desire to undertake housekeeping there. The life of a travelling artist- or even of the travellerCOMMA minus the artist- in these delightful regions & pensions where have all the comforts of home without its caresCOMMA does not intend to inspire you with a desire to renew the contest with the [biddy?]- in art less America. If only some plan cd. be devised by wh. Woodbourne cd. be converted into a pension. I have no doubt we shd. spend a good deal of our time thereCOMMA & shd. think the old house wd. need an immense amount of repairingCOMMA & as to the old chairs of the Conklin familyCOMMA I feel as if I had lost my interest in them & I shd. not think they wd. be worth the sum they mentioned. It is provoking to have to buy what is your own. (see 4th page of A's letter)Can thee tell us who paid the drivers on our Naples [---] wh. were packed in the same box with P.C.G.'s- we asked thee to do it & I suppose thee must have- but we have never heard.If not paid

Please pay to the order of Francis C. Haines (who may be too modest to speak of it) 9 francs 15 centimesCOMMA as near as you can come at it.

Clementine CopeAlexis T Cope

(Haines St Germantown)

Philadelphia
Etats-Unis d'Ameriq

Title: 1880 March 21COMMA Hotel de la PaixCOMMA RomeCOMMA to Lily
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AgnesCOMMA 1876-1899; CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; Umberto ICOMMA King of ItalyCOMMA 1844-1900;
Unidentified People: Dr. Muller; Miss brewster; Mr Forbes; [Hare?]; Cousin Anna;
Subject: Community life; Italy--Description and Travel; Quakers--Social life and customs; Transportation; Weather;
Notes:
Clementine describes her visits to various ruins and landmarks around the city of RomeCOMMA as well as the recent birthday celebration in the city for King Umberto I.
br>Before moving on to RomeCOMMA Clementine stayed with the Muller family in the French-Italian border commune of MentonCOMMA or "Mentone" in ItalianCOMMA as she writes it.
Transcript:
March. 21. 1880.

My dear LilyCOMMA Behold us in Rome once more!- dear delightful bewitching Rome- The city of cities- I cannot tell with what delight I find myself again threading its labyrinths & wandering amidst its ruins. We reached here the 6th of MarchCOMMA having left Mentone 2 days beforeCOMMA passing one night in Genoa & thence by the midnight train to Rome. This being the only train (owing to their very insane & uncomfortable arrangements) wh. gets you here at a respectable hour. It was a very uncomfortable journey- but then we were coming to- Rome!! We made a sojourn of two weeks onlyCOMMA at Dr. Müllers- Mentone we thought lovely- Dr M’s house not altogether so. It is not happily [---] being at the end of one of thos dried up riversCOMMA down wh. torrents of cold airrushed from the mountains. We thought it much colder & damper than either Cannes or Nice. & then there was a slight suggestion of boarding school about the household arrangements- & most for much open warfare between the Dr & his spouse to be altogether agreeable. It is a great pity they have not learned to control their tempers a little in the presence of their guests at least- for at times it was rather to peppery to be pleasant. Fortunately the storms seemed to be not very lasting. & they were generally jolly enough- & in fact much more jolly then most people would be who were at their wits ends to make two ends meet. A lady who was staying there with her family (pretty much as a matter of charity I fancy) told me they were over head & ears in debt & that she had come to the conclusion there was no use in trying to help themCOMMA as they never cd. keep any money- altho' they ask a very high price for their accomodations. The excursions at Mentone were truly lovelyCOMMA & the Dr. was alwaysready to take us. In fact we thought he quite preferred the ladies to the boys for he seemed quite put out once or twice at our declining to go. but they were too hard for meCOMMA & I did none of the very long ones. I shd. think however for those who were up to that sort of thingCOMMA Mentone would be one of the most delightful of the Riviera townsCOMMA tho' each one of them seems to have its own peculiar charms. The weather was very warm when we got to RomeCOMMA & took the back bone out of me terribly- It however soon changed from mildCOMMA to coolCOMMA clear & bracing & the last 10 days have been delicious- I never was able to do so much walking in Rome beforeCOMMA & on spring afternoons such as these what luxury cd. be greater than to drive or to wander at will among the ruins all golden in the light of the declining sun- or to watch the funny old models in their gay rags & tatters- (wh. seem to [---] the spirit of the twins-) hanging themselves out on the Spanish Steps to be admiredwith all the rest. Surely there is no place on earth like Rome. Last first day was the kings birthday & there was a grand review- & the king & queen & the [---] kindly [---] themselves COMMA to our admiring gaze in the Borghese. It was quite too gay & disappointing to be proper for 1st day. The usual ceremonies of holy week begin to dayCOMMA wh. is Palm Sunday. We did not attend at S. PetersCOMMA thinking last year it was rather a sell. I went to the little Italian [Waldensian] ChurchCOMMA a great contrast indeed to the pomp & [---] of the great Cathedral. We had got back to our old Hotel della PaceCOMMA where we were twice last winter. We went first to another but did not like itCOMMA & so came hereCOMMA where we found some friends of last summer (the Müllers). It is a good central situation. We look down upon the Piazza Barberinni & the old Tritan who is always blowing his stream of water into the airCOMMA & then catching it again all over his head & back wh. must be pretty well washed in all the years that it has been trickling over him. Then on the other side of the street2

is the Barberrini Pal. & sad eyed Beatrice. By way of variety the other day we went to one of Miss Brewsters receptions. It was a kind of afternoon tea fightCOMMA of [---] & other distinguished persons like ourselves. TeaCOMMA wineCOMMA & talk & many beautiful things to look at.

NextCOMMA we want to go with her. Forbes the archaeologist to hear tge Forum explained on the latest authorities. His explanations one said to be intensely interesting. In fact Rome is so dissipating- there is such an infinity to see & to read & to learn that it is most distracting. I hope we shall be here three or four weeks longer at least. In fact it spoils you so for every thing else that it does’nt seem worth while to go any where afterwards.

I ought to have told thee beforeCOMMA how glad I was to get thine & Agnes' letter at Mentone. I was greatly struck with the advance of the latter's ideas since her first epistle wh. I have carried ever sinceCOMMA in the pocket of my satchel& wh. was composed mostly of kisses. I see she is now advancing to the doll & the baby house interests of the little girl-hood. The way the ideas were put together was very amusing- & the circumstantial acct. of the flight of the nurses & the changing reigns of the lady’s of the nursery very graphic. Give her a kissCOMMA & tell her Auntie has very much obliged for her letter & thought it very interesting. Also that she must’not cut any more holes in her apron with her little scissorsCOMMA but must make some nice little paper dresses for the paper dollys that Aunty sent in the letter.

22nd. Just returned from our excursion to the Forum with Mr Forbes- two hours rummage amoung the ruins- intensely interesting- back nearly broken- head ditto. General conglomeration of podiumsCOMMA TabulariumsCOMMA demolished temples & roman emperors- but quite worth the 4 francs wh. is the price per head at wh. Mr F. deals out his information. He has been on the spot for some years & actually seen & superintended the excavations- so of course knows a great deal about itCOMMA & sees it in a very interesting way- much more so than [Hare?]COMMA who is a dreadfully guide booky old fellow I think- Am too tired to write more

Please tell Alexis that the letters of credit came a few days sinceCOMMA & we are much obliged for his attention to them. Love to all. Tell Cousin Anna I am going yo ans. her letter as soon as I can find time. Thy affectionate Sister

C.C.

Title: 1880 June 14COMMA GenevaCOMMA to Lily
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; CopeCOMMA Francis R. (Francis Reeve)COMMA 1878-1962; CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; CopeCOMMA Mary StokesCOMMA 1853-1888; CopeCOMMA AgnesCOMMA 1876-1899; FooteCOMMA Eleanor Tyson CopeCOMMA 1879-1973; HotchkissCOMMA Anne MariaCOMMA b. 1832; CopeCOMMA MargaretCOMMA 1856-1948
Subject: Boardinghouses; Children; Education; EuropeCOMMA Western; Family; Photographs; Switzerland--Description and Travel;
Geographic Subjects: Geneva (Switzerland); GenevaCOMMA Lake (Switzerland and France); Ravenna (Italy); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.); BlancCOMMA Mont (France and Italy); Awbury (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.)
Notes:
Clementine writes to Elizabeth from Lake GenevaCOMMA on the French-Swiss borderCOMMA where she is staying with a French family met the previous fall. She loves the area and Europe in general (calling it "the living side of the Atlantic").

Clementine half-seriously advises Elizabeth to move from Woodbourne to a cottage on the Lake Geneva hillside and admits that she would do so herself permanently were it not for Elizabeth and Alexis' childrenCOMMA whom she wishes so much to see.

Clementine describes the educational opportunities in the region as exception for those from "moderate circumstances."
Transcript:
Geneve No 5 Chemin de la Tour. 6.14.1880

My dear LilyCOMMA

I expect Caroline will give me "Jesse" as the saying isCOMMA if I presume to enter on the stage with her. Nevertheless as she has occupied the floor for some weeks past in thy favorCOMMA I think I shall dare to add a noteCOMMA tho' she tells me it must be short & upon no account much upon Revenna. Wherefore conclude she has been expending herself on that ancient & delightful city- & forbear. Thy letter of-- containing the childrens photographs came tohand two days sinceCOMMA & gave much pleasure. We think thineCOMMA with little EleanorCOMMA is the best of thee we have ever seenCOMMA & as to the little E I shd. say she was her Mama in miniature just as little F is his Papa over again only with a few shades more of jollity in his face. What a sweet little good natur’d happy kissable face it is & tho' I believe we have understood that he was'nt particularly fond of the latter operationCOMMA I doubtnot he has to undergo a good deal of itCOMMA & he does'nt look as if he wd. be very refractory under any circumstancesCOMMA Indeed such a nice little jolly face must be a great comfort to look atCOMMA &COMMA I need not suggest for Mamas to be proud of. I suppose when we get home thee & Alexis will be a grand old coupleCOMMA sitting up in the middle of your flockCOMMA looking very wise & experiencedCOMMA as you contemplate with "majestic pride" the youthful scions growing & flourishing about you.

I don’t see that thee has a very care worn air however in thy photo-graph. but on the contrary one might suppose that they cares & worries of domestic life were quite [---] & pleasant. by what you say I shd. think the heat must have been of that nature wh. wd. have a tendancy to drive you to seek for a cooler clime. For my part I dont see the use of undertaking to live in such a climate at allCOMMA as the chief object of life seems to be with most people to get away from it. Why not try to liveCOMMA as I said to the Awbury people yesterdayCOMMA where such fearful agonies wd. not have contin-ually to be gone thro' with in order to try to effect an escape.

I am very sorry for Madjy's disappointment as her letter to us showed that he hopes were very much set on EuropeCOMMA & she seems to need some change so much. It is a great pity they have to undergo such alternations of hope & despairCOMMA because they have got [---] on the living side of the Atlantic. At least it seems to be the side wh. is very much below par with most persons who inhabit it judging from the frantic manner in wh.they rush for the other shore. The papers say that pretty much Ole America is now on the way to [---]. We concluded that the pleasure to be derived from seeing the playCOMMA wh. I think wd. be but doubtful at bestCOMMA wd. be very much spoiled by the crowd of cooks & other tourists who will infest the country. We therefore have chosen to spend some time insteadin Geneva in French family No 2. Not that we were disappointed with our experiences in No 1COMMA but that we fell very much in love with this family last fallCOMMA when we took some lessons of them. They are more cultivated people than the others- consequently moreinterestingCOMMA & tho' less well off- they are still frienchCOMMA wh. means that they are practical & know how to be comfortable on a little. We only pay about half as much as we do at the large HotelsCOMMA with more real comfortCOMMA beside the very good advantage of hearing the best of french spoken. The lady has two sonsCOMMA one a professor in the University & one a clergymanCOMMA & two dhrs. all highly educated. The advantages of the education here for those in moderate circumastances are so very great. We shall stay probably a month or more until the weather gets to hot wh. does'nt seem very likely- as we are on pretty high ground just outside the city with plenty of green trees & alps in profusion in the distance.

My advice to you is to come & build a cottage on one of the hill sides of GenevaCOMMA instead of Woodbourne & get a Savoyard maid as we haveCOMMA who with her mistresses aid does the work for a household of 9 persons. We have two dinners dailyCOMMA of several courses & very well cookedCOMMA & how in the world they do it all I cannot conceive. I suspect that Madam is at the bottom of a good dealCOMMA but she does it all with such apparent grace & easeCOMMA that one cannot suspect her of cooking. There are beautiful building lots to be bought hereCOMMA by the wayCOMMA on the high ground along the town with the Lake on one side & Mt. Blanc on the otherCOMMA & there are many beautiful gardens & suburban residences- wh. are quite unseen & [---] by the mere passing traveller. If it was’nt for those children of yours whom we want to see!- I shd. be quite tempted to invest in one of these little spots & settle down for the rest of my days. Will thee please ask Alexis to inquire of cousin FRC if he rec'd a letter fm. me posted June 8. containing a cheque for $200. I also posted one on the 13 June to M.S.C. containing cheque for $100. As there is some risk of these things being lost shd. be very much obliged if A or some body wd. advertise Provident Life & Trust Company of [---] and [---]. of these two cheques payable to the order of the above mention’d persons. Hoping soon to have news of you in a cooler clime & under Mrs. Hotchkiss' hospitable roof. Ever thy affec- sister C. Ever so many kisses to dear little Agnes & to theothers as for as appreciated by them.

Title: 1880 July 11COMMA GenevaCOMMA to Alexis
Creator: Clementine Cope:  1835-1903
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AgnesCOMMA 1876-1899; CopeCOMMA AnnetteCOMMA 1843-1916; CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; WetherillCOMMA John Price
Unidentified People: Miss Wetherill; cous. FRC
Subject: Boardinghouses; EuropeCOMMA Western; Family; Home schooling; Joint ownership of personal property; Quakers--Travel
Geographic Subjects: Geneva (Switzerland); Montrose (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.); Philadelphia (Pa.); Rome (Italy); Awbury (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.)
Notes:
Clementine writes to cousin Alexis from GenevaCOMMA where she has been for the summer months with Caroline E. and Annette Cope. The latter two are eager to return homeCOMMA but Clementine prefers to stay in Europe and expresses he want to do so if it is not completely necessary to return to Connymead to see her portion of it transfered to Alexis and his family.

Clementine expresses a belief that she could get along well with her current French host family were she to remain in Geneva indefinitely.
Transcript:
GenevaCOMMA July 11COMMA 1880

Dear AlexisCOMMA

I want to ask thee a question. Is it necessary in order to effect a division of our property (I mean such a division as shall give thee thy portion at Connymead) is it necessary that I return to America in the Autumn with C & ACOMMA as it has been our intention to doCOMMA (or at least theirs)? For myself I have not entirely decidedCOMMA tho' we have partly paid our passages for the 6th Nov. in the steamer "Illinois"COMMA on condition that we can change if it seems best to another vessel of the line. It is late to sailCOMMA but there seemed to be no good steamer between the first week of October& the lastCOMMA & as there will be no moonlight the last of October we thought it wd. be best to wait until the next moon.

There are many reasons why I shd. like to return in the AutumnCOMMA but the prospect of boarding in Phila is not very attractiveCOMMA & of keeping house at Connymead still less so- indeed I shd. never be willing to undertake the latter again unless circumstances were very much changed. C & A prefer the former. If they were willing to keep house or even to board near GermantownCOMMA where we could have the enjoyment of the childrenCOMMA I shd. come home with the greatest pleasure.

But this I expect they will never wish to do. So that until I can think of some way for me to live in that part of the world. It seems as if I might almost as well stay here- for boardingin Phila wd. not be much better as far as you are concerned.

The thought of staying by myself seems a little dismalCOMMA but I cd. stay very well in the family where we now are & be as well cared for as I cd. expect or wish to byCOMMA by strangers. Then there is an elderly lady (whom we have met several times (& I think have spoken of) Miss WetherillCOMMA Jno. Price Wetherills dhrCOMMA of Phila) who has asked me to join her partyCOMMA consisting of her niece & [Pebers?] of Phila. We were with them 8 weeks in Rome & found them very pleasant. So I could stay very well if I wanted to- Tell me how the idea strikes youCOMMA with regard to the business- asCOMMA if my presence is necessary to the accomplishment of itCOMMA that wd. decide the question.

We still continue in Geneva & still continue to like exceedingly our french family. We intended in comingCOMMA to stay a month & then go to the Mts. But the weather has been almost too cool for anygreat heightsCOMMA & thisCOMMA so far (I dont know how it may be in August) seems a happy medium. We have had a few warmish daysCOMMA but for the most part it has been a delightful summer climate. Then too we have had so much gadding aboutCOMMA that we enjoy the quiet & the thought that we are learning something.

How often I wish I cd. have Agnes here for a few months. It would do for herCOMMA what years of study at home cannot do for any body. I never knew before how badlyCOMMA or rather how little we had been taught at homeCOMMA how to pronounce french. Then too this is such a nice family where it wd. be so safe to place a child. Their ideas about education are good- & they have so much simplicity in their ways & manners- they seem almost like those of friends. The children have never been allowed to go to the opera or the theater- tho' they have oneCOMMA within a few doors of them. Every evening before going to bedCOMMA we have a little "culbe"- Madam Duproix reads out of a big bible- & then makes a little extemporaneous prayer- so very simpleCOMMA that one cannot help but feel as if it came from the heart; After thisCOMMA we separate for the night with much hand-shaking and many "[---]" & "[---]" & "[---]" &c- The great objection to the french is that they have to say so much about every little thing & are really too polite for comfort. I think each person at the table says "par-r-r-don"- about 50 times at each meal (with a very great trill to the r- & a very great accent on the last syllable) if all this wasn't accompanied with real kindness of heart (as in this case) one wd. become "very fatigued" of it.

We suppose that you are now at Montrose tho' we dont know it. It has been a perfect age since anyone has written from Awbury. I sent cous. FRC a letter containing a cheque about5 weeks since & having rec'd no acknowledgement fear it has been confiscatedCOMMA or that he is not well. We are anxious to hear how you perform'd the journey & how Montrose goes. Netty is writing to Lilly as I will not write now

with much love to her & the children

they aff. sister C :

Title: 1865 April 20COMMA HaverfordCOMMA to Clemmy
Creator: E. D. (Edward Drinker) Cope:  1840-1897
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; CopeCOMMA Annie PimCOMMA 1840-1933; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EmlenCOMMA SamuelCOMMA 1829-1920; GarrettCOMMA MarthaCOMMA 1839-1927; HarlanCOMMA Joseph GibbonsCOMMA 1825-1857;
Subject: Bible--N.T.; God; Grief; Marriage; Quakers--Peace Testimony; Spirituality; Suffering; Weddings;
Notes:
Edward D. offers spiritual advice to cousin ClementineCOMMA largely in the way of quotations from the New Testiment on sufferingCOMMA consolationCOMMA judgment and forgiveness.

Edward describes his experience as a groomsman at the wedding of Elizabeth S. and Alexis T. CopeCOMMA which Clementine apparently must not have attended. He was very much impressed with a prayer by minister Samuel Emlen.

Edward plans on maving into the house previously owned by former Haverford School principal Joseph Harlan.
Transcript:
Haverford 4 mo 20 1865

My dear Cousin Clemmy

My thoughts have been with thee at various times since thy departure from our neighborhoodCOMMA and I have been inclined to reproach myself for not having written;- but perhaps it is well enoughCOMMA for there is no telling what effect in one wayCOMMA things said out of seasonCOMMA may haveCOMMA more than what may result in the other direction from things said in season. Much conversation on religious matters thee will agree with meCOMMA is under some circumstances disadvantagious; as when deedsCOMMA actsCOMMA and strivings are the more needful thing.

The great purpose and Love of Christ have been much in my mind in remembering a former time of bitterness and griefCOMMA and how he wiped away such tears frommy eyes though he opened their fountains again for gratitude and joy: and how new roles and a new strength were granted me. And to attain this what is not worthy to be passed through? and what suffered and endured? Truly "men ought always to pray and not to faint" "Be thou fruitful and I will give thee a crown of life." and how little worthy we are of it ever then. We know how that "this brief suffering which [---] but for a momentCOMMA worked for us a far more eternal might of glory." How the business of life tends to wear off the strong gratitude and love which a little view of the glory and goodness of our Maker causes to swell and burn in their heart; and how as it grows dimmerCOMMA and we further from the shadow of his wing [---] words and hard judgements creepin. But can any forget that "with what judgement ye judge ye shall be judged". But we must continually return to the fountain headCOMMA if perhaps He will again bless usCOMMA and "cause our heart to burn within us"COMMA how low do we then sinkCOMMA in the light of glory [---]COMMA and immesurable greatness. In such a state of mind are we fit to do out duty with pleasureCOMMA and find ourselves still unprofitable servantsCOMMA with rejoicingCOMMA for "Grant what thou wiltCOMMA without thee I am poorCOMMA but with thee I am richCOMMA take what thou wilt away." What this duty isCOMMA is the real difficultyCOMMA this is the fight to test the shield of faithCOMMA and the preparation of the Gospel of Peace.May we both bear it wellCOMMA doing the work- or some workCOMMA well & not beating the air. But this and many other weak things/5/22 Lilly was married last 5th day. I was second groomsman with Martha Garrett. All passed off very pleasantly. The meeting was uncommonly favored: I have not often when in so undeserving a state (but we are that at all times) had such a heart-opening grantedCOMMA and the ministers were favored with true fervency and spoke very encouragingly and usefully to the pair just marriedCOMMA and to the others. Samuel Emlen made a prayer which I have seldom heard excelled in strength of feeling.

Thy letter thro' Alexis was very acceptable. I hope thee may feel thy reward either in connection with or independent of results. If thee feels dull about it sometimes- thee will remember that all men do that. I certainly do when I look at results (which I needn't do if I do mybest).

The committee of managers are putting a house in order for me here. Perhaps thee remembers a small establishment by the Rail Road where Joseph Harlan formerly lived. With a few alterations it will be a very nice home. The breast of the pond where the front lane passes will probably be strengthenedCOMMA and the water backed nearer the Rail R. so as to make a very pretty sheet. I will not forget to send thee an invitation in time. Does thee want anything in the book lineCOMMA- or other kind of assistance? I would like to hear more of thy school and its working.

Believe me thy
affectionate cousin

Edw. D. Cope

Annie sends her love with mine.

Title: 1833 July [June] 25COMMA BloomsdaleCOMMA to William D. Cope
Creator: Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Subject: Courtship; Flirting; Forgiveness; Letter writing; Quakers--Social life and customs
Notes:
Mis-dated July 25COMMA actually written June 25COMMA 1833.

The letter was written by Susan to William in the year before their marriageCOMMA describing the concerns of Susan's regarding William's 7-month withdrawl from correspodence. She is noticably upset about thisCOMMA but forgives William and ultimately tells him that she hopes they may retain the friendship they had priorCOMMA and that she should destroy this letter.
Transcript:
Bloomsdale July [June] 25th. 1833.

Thee will probably be somewhat surprised in receiving a communication from meCOMMA in reply to thine- but I have determined notwithstanding my extreme diffidence to employ pen & paper- in order- if possible to dispel some unpleasant and I may ass unhappy associations connected with thy last visit. That I did feel and evince some repugnance to having a private conversation with thee- I freely acknowledge. Why I did so- it is impossible for me to explain- unless it was because I supposed the one- we had previously had- was sufficient to elucidate all difficulties- and therefore a second one useless.- I regret now such a thought should have entered my mind- and why I felt it painful- to have a further explanation- when I saw it wd. afford thee a satisfaction- is a mystery I do not yet understand; but as all regrets are unavailing- I will not strengthen them by indulging inCOMMA or dwelling upon them.- That my manners may have appeared in some instances- as they saysCOMMA cold and repulsiveCOMMA I am sensible- without my intending them to have that effectCOMMA at any rate- let me assure theeCOMMA it was very far from my intentionCOMMA to wound or hurt thy feelings for even as I wd. like my own respected- have I endeavoured to consider thine.------ I certainly meant to imply from what I said- I considered thee in faultCOMMA in not having sent me any intimation of thy feelings with resepct to meCOMMA throughout the whole seven months of thy absense; most assuredly- absense & silence were never calculated to cherish and increase a preferenceCOMMA which under different- and more auspicious circumstances might have arisen; & as thee gave me no intimation I was not forgotten- I had no alternative leftCOMMA but to believe as I did- thee had abandoned all idea of further intercourse- well then- considering myself slightedCOMMA and neglectedCOMMA how could reserve and coldness of manner be entirely avoided? In extending my forgivenessCOMMA I really thought I had something to forgive- but it seems- according to the light in which thee views it- there was no fault committed- and consequenlty no "need of forgiveness." However different thy views of human nature- and the ways of the worldCOMMA are from my own- I must still see those actions- in the light of errors- but will consider them as unintentional- and arising from inexperience. With respect to our correspondence motives of delicacy alone- prevented me from consenting to it- If thee had thought correctly about it- theewd. have supposedCOMMA as our friendship & intimacy advanced those feelings- wd. have been overcome- and however great an effort I still think it wd. be- to maintain a correspondence with a gentleman even after an engagementCOMMA I should consider it a duty- an obligationCOMMA not to be dispensed with.- I do not remember thy suggesting any other mode of intercourse between us- than the one just spoken of- at all events neither of those mentioned by thee- wd. have been very suitableCOMMA or meet with my concurrence. I acquit myself- if thee will not do it- of all design at "flirtation & coquetryCOMMA" however some of my sex may indulge in it at the expense of yours- I am very sure- I do not belong to that class of cruel coquettes- who make a boast of their conquests- & offer encouragement where none is meant. In writing this letter- I trust I am not guilt of an improper act- I thought considering all things- it was nothing more than thy due- & in doing it- my mind which was before ill at ease- is put comparatively at rest.- I beg thee will destroy this letter- and forget anything but friendship ever passed between us.- I have now only to add an assurance of respect & esteem & how earnestly I wish thy happinessCOMMA thee can never knowCOMMA unless thee can read the heart of thy sincere friend
S.....

No eye but thy own must rest upon the contents of this sheet.6.

William D. Cope.
Care T.P. Cope Esq.
Fourth St.
Philadelphia

From S.
dated July 25. 1833.- should be June 25.

Title: 1833 October 17COMMA BloomsdaleCOMMA to William D. Cope
Creator: Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Subject: Courtship; Flirting; Letter writing; Love; Newspapers; Weather
Notes: Susan's reply to Williams of September 27COMMA in which he suggested she may be the true author of critical letter he received from pseudonymous writer "Dorothy Dolittle."
Transcript:
Bloomsdale Oct. 17th 1833.

"I long have thought my absent friendsCOMMA a something to have sent youCOMMA
Tho' it should serve nae other endsCOMMA than just a kind memento."

Thy letter bearing date of twenty seventh of last month- came to hand after some detention- and has determined me to set about writing immediately- as I owe itCOMMA both to my dutyCOMMA and my feelingsCOMMA to send a speedy reply to thy communication- containing intelligence of a nature- which astonished & vexed me not a little. I was astonishedCOMMA thee should suppose me to be the author of that documentCOMMA styled by theeCOMMA the "witty letter;" and vexedCOMMA that any one should descend to such meanness- as thus to endeavour to practice upon thy credulity. As for meCOMMA I must disclaim all knowledge or connection with it in any way- and I do not envy the person who could be guilty of such an action- any of the wit it displayed- or grammatical learning- which if I understood thee rightly it is woefully deficient in.

By the byeCOMMA I am much indebted for the complimentCOMMA of having so fine a piece of wit and learningCOMMA attributed as the production of my hand and pen- at the same time I will frankly own- from some expressions in thy letter- I think the shadow of a doubt more than [---] crossed thy mind as to my being in realityCOMMA the author.

And now the question is- who can have been the offenders and against whom are we to direct our honest indignation? for I assure thee I feel no small share- I have not the slightest idea who it can be and yet some one it wd. seemCOMMA who had some knowledge of the circumstances- must have had a hand in it. I think the want of learning displayed- could only have been a part of their plan to avoid detection- and not from real ignorance of the rules of grammar. I've a womans curiosity to see the letterCOMMA and know all about it.
whether the writing resembles mine- if 'twas dated B........ with my name appended to it; all of which enquired I hope to have answered.

The says in thy letter- ro please the ladies- thee must not broach serious subjects- if thee wishes to please my ladyship- and thee has professed as much- thee may make choice of any subject- whether "sober proseCOMMA or prose run mad"- I shall not object to anything and 'tis quite a mistaken idea- that ladies are never pleased with serious subjects- notwithstanding the author of the witty letter to the contrary.- Although thee may think there is very little like sobrietyCOMMA or a disposition to moralizeCOMMA in my character- I think my heart can duly appreciate and respond to good sentimentsCOMMA whenever it is my good fortune to meet with them.

Have we not had a very delightful Autumn? such beautiful weather for riding or walking- and yet we have not availed ourselves of the bright sunshineand pleasant air- to make any rambling excursions in the woods or along by the banks of the river- the scattered foliage is already strewn upon the pathway- and in a few short days- we shall have the bare and leafless branches- telling us of the desolation of natures beauties. Spring has always been my favorite season- but in all its gaiety and animation- it could not spread a scene more showy or more varied than the one now before us- such a happy blending of colours- but we have no beautiful hills or fertile [---]- where nature at this season appears so prominently beautiful. In the "far off country" which thee inhabits- there must be every variety and beauty of scene- but then the distance is such a barrier- so many hundred miles from all ones friends- I almost wonder thee has not been tempted to move within the reach of those thee holds most dear---

I am sorry thee has experienced any uneasiness onaccount of having read to me those New York letters;- since it is so- I regret thee favourd me with a sight- at the same time I feel very certain of not having betrayed the confidence reposed in me- and have not the most distant idea who the lady can be. I think the young lady- with so many [trunks?] – must have played the coquette very skillfuly- to have secured so many offers in so short a time- she knew her power I suppose- and was determined to excersize it- at the expense of her numerous admirers- Before I close my letter I must not forget to acknowledge the receipt of two newspapers- sometime in the month of August- for which accept my thanks the tale which they contained (the title of it I forget just now) I quite admired.-- The other day I met with something which pleased me exceedinglyCOMMA in one of [Lardners?] papers.- It was an essay on lovers- and described the different kinds of loversCOMMA most admirably- I recognized more than one or twoCOMMA or three of my acquaintance in the descriptions. I wd. like them to see it.- I must now conclude my letter- as I have already written more- than I expected to- or that can afford thee much interest in the perusal. with [---] of rememberance-
I remain sincerely thy friendCOMMA
S.....

Thy letters have all been duly received- Pray admire the beautiful direction- especially the D.10 Mo. 24 at Montrose

William D. Cope.
Woodbourne
Susquehanna Coty.

From S.
date Oct. 17. 1833.- ans'd 10 mo. 18. '33

Title: 1834 March 10COMMA BloomsdaleCOMMA to Wm D Cope
Creator: Susan L. Newbold Cope:  1805-1872
Identified People: YarnallCOMMA Caroline R. (Caroline Rachel) CopeCOMMA 1802-1881
Unidentified People: cousin Edith
Subject: Bereavement; Betrothal; Death; Letter writing; Love;
Transcript:
I am giving thee dear William- a proof of my sincere and unabated affection- in this early replying to thy most welcome letter of the 8th which only came to hand this morning- thee may be sure its arrival was awaited by meCOMMA with more than usual impatience- I could not believe another week wd. be suffered to elapse- without the accustomed message of loveCOMMA and rememberenceCOMMA- and every day I wd. say to myself well- I certainly will hear to day- but very many times have I been doomed to suffer disappointment- how however- I am relieved by the actual presence of the well known hand writing- and will thus evince my greatful feelings- in its early acknowledgement.- Let me tell thee dear William- I think thee greatly undervalues thy epistolary talentsCOMMA thy letters cannot be any thing but interesting to me- and if I acknowledge them to be so- why thatCOMMA- must be as much as thee can desire- as for my own I have long since despaired of arriving at any thing like excellence in the artCOMMA- and the only and slight merit- if merit it may called- which they posess- is the spirit of affection which they [---]COMMA & which prompts me to the undertaking I have not the least partiality for the employment thee knows- and often with merely for the purpose of receiving in return.- To day I was [---] gratified & delighted- for independent of the pleasure thine afforded me- there was one from my dear sister Caroline. I will not tell thee what she saysCOMMA now- but when thee comes- thee shall see it.- I do not know that I recollect to observation thee alludes to- as having been made by me- when last here- at least I am not certain what it was.- The will find in me as usual- a very ready and willing listener to all thee may have to communicate- I hope my presence will not prove talismanic and cause thee to forget what thee had to say- I did not find it necessary to apply to Father for information respecting the time of holding our monthly meeting- it has just passedCOMMA last week- and the next oneoccurs- on the ninth of April- The [---] is- the first fourth day after the first second day in the month.- I had a sweet little note from cousin Edith the other day- it contained an invitiation for us to comeCOMMA or rather go out to make them a visit- I knew it wd. not be very pleasant just now and in my answerCOMMA declined the invitation for myself- and promised to deliver the one to thee when next we met- Edith styles theeCOMMA her "cousin elect" already.- What an appalling spectacle the burning of the Wm Penn must have been- It will have an effect I thinkCOMMA to increase the fears of [---] travellers-. How sorrowful I feltCOMMA upon learning of the death- of R.B. [Thornson?]COMMA during her life we had each of usCOMMA made attempts to become better acquainted- but were never very successful- and now in her deathCOMMA I feel as if I had almost lost a dear friend- her family will feel her loss to be irreparable- I should like to have some particulars of her death- I trust it was a happy one- holding out consolation to her afflicted and berieved family-. Dearest Wm. I must now say farewell! as it is fast-approaching [---] 6 o'clock- and I am encroaching not a little [---] the time usually devoted to the indifference of my friends [---]- with a thousand assurances of undiminished affection
remain as ever thy own
S.

March 10. 1834.

P.S. If thee wd. like to avoid the observation of a certain person in B. who is always upon the look out- thee can do it by going up the street where the market is and round by the [?-nch]*- I hear of our engagement from all quarters- will thee excuse the brevity of this letter- I write this evening because time will not permit to morrow. again
Adieu!
*tis very little further

I cannot make the direction come in the right place.from S. [1834]
dated 3 mo. 10. 1834.

[---]no 6

Wm D Cope
36 N. 4th

Title: 1867 September 24COMMA AwburyCOMMA to blue Brother
