Transcript:
WoodbourneCOMMA 10 month 16 1830
Dear BrotherCOMMA

I wrote to thee on the 20th ult. by James Cockburn's stepsonCOMMA & have received thine of 16 ult. by Geo. WalkerCOMMA accompanying my accountCOMMA stated to 8 mo 23-'30 with Thomas P Cope & Sons (old firm)COMMA for which I am obliged.+- like thyself I have had misgivings with regard to a favourable result of the recent French revolutionCOMMA but at ye same timeCOMMA have been surprised at ye magnanimous conduct of the French people. Such moderation & forbearance when in powerCOMMA was hardly to have been looked for from a mobCOMMA I have also a more exalted opinion than ever of La Fayette. His expressions on the subject of ye punishment of deathCOMMA as well as some othersCOMMA show him to be a man of enlargedCOMMA benevolent & enlightened views. I was rather prepossessed in favour of the late KingCOMMA both his personal appearanceCOMMA & from his having used power with moderation & clemency. But I think it is clear that the present age is too enlightened to submit to ye control & influence of bigotryCOMMA or to consider Kings & rulers as super human beings. On ye subject of anti-masonry as recently agitatedCOMMA I have been slow in forming a decided opinionCOMMA considering that the tyranny of ye people may be as great as that of ye monarchCOMMA & being much averse to all species of intoleranceCOMMA whether practiced by rulers or people. ThereforeCOMMA though I have no partiality whatever for the Masonic Institution or SocietyCOMMA I think it admits of consideration & reflectionCOMMA whether ye mode adopted for attempting to put it downCOMMA is ye most properCOMMA admitting that it may be ye most effectual. There are cogent reasons for objecting to all secret associationsCOMMA but thisCOMMA does not appear to interfere with the rights of others. In ye Morgan caseCOMMAI do not think theCOMMA Institution at large is concerned or implicatedCOMMA & therefore I do not think it quite fair to use it as a handle against masons as a body or community. Providence in its wisdom appear sometimes to permit good to come out of evilCOMMA & it maybe so in ye present instance; but I cannot subscribe to the Machiavellian doctrine that the ends justifies ye means; nor can I believe all ye heinous charges that are made against ye masonsCOMMA when I see among them men of patriotismCOMMA intelligence & benevolence. I think ye purport of some observations of General WashingtonCOMMA in a letter to one of his friends is that the Masonic SocietyCOMMA is a harmless & ridiculous Institution. This I should supposeCOMMA from ye opportunities that I have had of judgingCOMMA is a correct opinion. Please say to FatherCOMMA that I have received the deed for Milton HarrisCOMMA & ye present to him my warm acknowledgement for the kind expression contained of sympathy as I have [received] from my city friends & relatives. They rob misfortune of much of its afflicting power & effect. I had expected that a residence in the country would afford more mental quiet & invite more to mental culture than a City life. But I find that ye excitement caused by the bustle of preparationCOMMA which I though would be but temporaryCOMMA still continues. And whether it arises from the habits of calculation that I have acquired by my mercantile educationCOMMA or from those implanted in me by natureCOMMA I cannot divest myself entirely of the uneasy sensation caused by ye idea of a continual outlayCOMMA without ye prospect of an adequate return although the amount of ye outlay would sound very smallCOMMA to a merchant or banker. I am ready to fear sometimesCOMMA that my present practical habits & pursuitsCOMMA will lead me too much away from the school of fancyCOMMA sentimentand moral & religious reflection. But I will try to keep up the strike for what is goodCOMMA & hope for the best. Geo Walker had reached homeCOMMA & I hope often to be transported to you in imaginationCOMMA as I have already beenCOMMA by ye narration & description of scenes & circumstances to which he was a witness whilst with you.

With salutations of loveCOMMA thy brotherCOMMA
Wm D Cope

I observe in ye same inclosure with my a/eCOMMA a bill of T.S. Tucker of $1.20 for work done 3 mo. 2 1829. It may be correctCOMMA but I have no recollection in regard to itCOMMA nor was I in Philada. at that timeCOMMA having arrived thereCOMMA 1 mo. 10 & left it 2 mo. 6. 1829. If he calls again fro ye amount of itCOMMA I will thank thee to remind him of ye foregoing factCOMMA & if upon examinationCOMMA he still thinks ye charge correctCOMMA I will be obliged by thy paying it.v
Please mention in thy nextCOMMA when ye divd. on intt. on the Union Canal stock is pble.
+ I have examined itCOMMA & find it to correspond with my entries.

Title: 1832 October 24COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to S.
Creator: William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873

Notes: Drafts of two letters to Susan Newbold (later Cope)--dated October 24 & November 7COMMA 1832.
Transcript:
Philadelphia 10 mo 24. 1832

I have often thought of thee since leaving BloomsdaleCOMMA and feel quite desirous to have a little conversation with thee upon paper. there is something animating in placing ourselves in imagination by the side of a fair ladyCOMMA and holding sweet converse with.

"WomanCOMMA lovely womanCOMMA whom Heaven designed to temper man."
"We had been brutes without thee."

I hope I shall have the pleasure ere long of paying my respects to thee in personCOMMA but as I wish to do my best to please theeCOMMA I must not tire thee by too early repetition of my last visit. I hope also that I shall be less and less stiff and formal in my mannersCOMMA as our acquaintance & friendship advances and increases it happilyCOMMA such should be the tendency of things. A young lady possessing the recommendations of youthCOMMA beauty and accomplishmentsCOMMA told a mutual friend at WoodbourneCOMMA not a great while sinceCOMMA that the greatest objects on she had to make against meCOMMA was that of being to reserved. Alas! I could not say the same with regard to herselfCOMMA much as I appreciated many traits of her characterCOMMA she wished she saidCOMMA that she could take the liberty of telling me what she thought of me. As amongst our best friendsCOMMA are those who tell us of our faultsCOMMA I could not but feel grateful for the reproofCOMMA though indirectly madeCOMMA and hope to be improved by it. I shall also feel grateful to my dear friend SusanCOMMA if she will point out with frankness and freedom any faults that I may possess. But I pray thee not to do itCOMMA so as to give the appearance of its being done with the intention of wounding my feelings. I am keenly sensitive to a blow struck with such a view. It is a great mistake entertained by some ladiesCOMMA thatmen have no feelingsCOMMA because they restrain or suppress them. a sensitive mindCOMMA will I think readily perceive the difference between reproves made in a proper mannerCOMMA and form a proper motiveCOMMA and thos made with different intentions. I am credulous enough to believeCOMMA with confidenceCOMMA that none wo be made by them of the improper kind.- besides many things that I think I shall have to say to thee when we meet againCOMMA I have some also to show thee. but I have been hoping that before the suitable time for visiting thee againCOMMA shall I arriveCOMMA I will feel something like being really well. This [---] air that we breathe here is so different from the elastic atmosphere that I have latterly been accustomed toCOMMA that I have not felt right well during any part of my last two visits to the City.- nothing like a Susquehanna County glow! Thee don't know how much better I look when I acquire the ruddy hue that the mountain air inparts. thee knows howeverCOMMA that it will be good policy in me to try to persuade thee that my appearance in generalCOMMA is somewhat more captivating than at present.- the idea has several times occured to meCOMMA that it would perhaps have been well for me to have offered my services as gallant on any excursion that thee & thy sisters might wish to makeCOMMA either to the CityCOMMA or elsewhere. if thee should not should not be procided with one more suitable than myselfCOMMA will thee use the freedom to drop me a line informing whether it would be agreeable or desirable in such case to have my servie? The number of our house is 36. please excuse as well as thee canthe vanity that I have displayed in alluding to myself in the foregoing lines. it is a vice that is very apt to show itselfCOMMA however slight may be our reason or excuseCOMMA for displaying it. I wishCOMMA thee seesCOMMA to forestall thy condemnation of itCOMMA by condemning it myself. I bide thee adieu and wish thee healthCOMMA happinessCOMMA prosperity and an increase of regard for thy affectionate friend.

Will thee do me the favour to refer to & read the 24th chapter of Genesis. I am so great a lover of artlessness and patriachal simplicy of mannersCOMMA that I should be glad if thee would agree with me in admiring the picture of them therein presented.

P.S. Be sure to look very pleasant the next time we meet; thee knows for ladies smiles they say are sunbeams and have a bland & genial influence on thou upon whom they are cast.Philadelphia 11 mo. 7 1832

I have to apologize for not paying thee a visit this weekCOMMA in conformity to the intention made by me at the time of my taking leave on 7th day lastCOMMA circumstance not then thought of having occurred to prevent. howeverCOMMA as there is no necessity that I am yet apprised ofCOMMA for my immediate departure for WoodbourneCOMMA I hope that another week will not elapseCOMMA with my having the opportunity and pleasure of taking thee by the hand. in the mean timeCOMMA wishing thee a continuance of good health & spiritsCOMMA I remain as ever thy affectionate friend.

P.S. Be sure to look very pleasant the next time we meet; for thee knows ladies smiles they say. are sunbeams and have a bland and genial influence on those upon whom they are cast. N.B. my last visit was rather too much prolonged; but allowance must be made in certain casesCOMMA for some slight indiscretions. I will try to have better for the future.

To

There is some business to be attended to relative to my Father's coal lands in Dauphin Co & whether it will be necessary either for my Brother Alfred or myself to go forthwith. I mention the circumstance to account for my absenceCOMMA should I go myself & should it be prolonged beyond what I expect will be the fact.

Title: 1833 March 21COMMA White CottageCOMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to Susan Newbold
Creator: William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Identified People: CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1793-1865

Notes: Draft of letter to Sarah Miller Walker.
Transcript:
I have experienced some little embarrassment in my recent intercourse with theeCOMMA and in that spirit of candour which I admireCOMMA however small may be the portion of it that I possessCOMMA I wish to explainCOMMA or advert to the cause of it. the amount & substance of what I wish to sayCOMMA isCOMMA that I hopeCOMMA if I may have shown that I like theeCOMMA or that I have a partiality for theeCOMMA then wilt not suppose that I am striving to alienate thy affections from another quarter. and injustice has been done me if it has been represented to theeCOMMA that I have in any wayCOMMA made such an attempt. I do not altogether like this formal mode of making this communicationCOMMA but there has not seemed to be a suitable opportunity of doing it in conversation. whatever may be our future connexions or situation in lifeCOMMA I am desirous that nothing should occur to mar the friendship which I believed has always subsisted between us since we have been acquainted with each other. and I think it is not surprising that I should have some feelings on this subjectCOMMA when it is considered that thou art the only person in the communityCOMMA whose sentiments coincide with my own. I have often admired the moderate firmness with whichCOMMA almost single handed and as it were aloneCOMMA thou hast adhered to principlesCOMMA and as I believe correct principles; and not the lessCOMMA because they have been adhered to by theeCOMMA more steadfastly than bythan by myself. I sometimes allow myself a latitude in light or perhaps rather unmeaning conversationCOMMA as well as in some other respects & thingsCOMMA which I would not doCOMMA if I tho’t that I was wandering so far from the conduct of my true & guiding polar starCOMMA as to endanger my return to its salutary influence and correct path. though the trials and vicissitudes that thou hath had to encounter may be small in comparison to those which are allotted to someCOMMA I know that they have been hard to bearCOMMA and I have been pleased to witness the cheerfulness with which thou hast been sustained under their pressure. I hope that in all those which in common with mother may be meted out to thee in the course of thy earthly pilgrimageCOMMA there may be still found alleviating circumstancesCOMMA and a sustaining hand.- I think I shall always remember with gratitude the kind-heartedness shown toward me by thyself and thy dear deceased Sister Priscilla. Indeed my heart sometimes overflows with kindly feelings when I reflect upon it. In PriscillaCOMMA I think I may sayCOMMA I always found an advocate & support in correct principles. I sometimes in the course of conversation with herCOMMA did not at first think soCOMMA but explanation & a free interchange of sentiments generally convinced me that she was correct in the groundwork & substance of true piety.- having now expressed so much as I haveCOMMA allow me to say furtherCOMMA that if thou hath at any timeCOMMA any impropriety in word or deedCOMMA to allege against meCOMMA I hope thou wilt represent it to meCOMMA with franknessCOMMA but with such proper caution as not unnecessarilynot unnecessarily to wound my feelings. I have thought it times pastCOMMA that I observed a tendency to a different course. tho' I believe at the same timeCOMMA that thou didst endeavour to use proper caution on certain occasionsCOMMA if we do wrongCOMMA let us mention & stateCOMMA our faults to each other with mildness. conscienceCOMMA if not [---] is a sufficiently severe accuser. as I think I once before observed to theeCOMMA there are ills enoughCOMMA which we cannot avoidCOMMA without unnecessarily creating others. It is a melancholy reflection that "man is to manCOMMA the sorestCOMMA surest foe." It is however consoling to think that there are exceptions to all general rulesCOMMA and I trust there are many to this. I have not the vanity to think and thou of course wilt not understand me to supposeCOMMA that I have the power of causing a transfer of thy affectionsCOMMA but thee knows the attempt might be made without the power. My Brother Henry mentions in a letter recently received from him that our Cousin A. Barker is slowly recovering her health.

3 mo. 21. 1833.

Title: 1834 January 6COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to Susan

Notes:
Drafts of two letters from William D. Cope to Susan Newbold (later Cope) from January 6 & 13COMMA 1834.
William quotes several times the Scottish Romantic poet Robert Burns and the English poet Alexander Pope from memory with some accuracy.
Transcript:
(by mail)
Philada. 1 mo. 6. 1833
Dear Susan:

As I had hoped and expected I received the thrice welcome communication of which we had been speakingCOMMA the evening of the same day I left thee. it was handed to me by my FatherCOMMA who said that he had taken charge of it in the morningCOMMA upon finding it at the Counting House. so thou had'st been thinking of me during the three weeks' interval of non-intercourse. thee is a a dear creatureCOMMA (pardon the familiarity of the expression) and I thank thee muchCOMMA for it. how delightful to be though of and rememberedCOMMA by those that we love! "Tho' my pen has been idle this longCOMMA my thoughts have not". I recalled these expressions of thy "talking letter"COMMA again and againCOMMA and tho' the construction admits of doubt with regard to its correctnessCOMMA yet the influence that thee was thinking of me was so agreeable that I concluded to assume it as the right and proper interpretation. at all events thy thoughts must have been indirectlyCOMMA if not directly turned towards me. I am unable to answer satisfactorily thy quiery with regard to the authorship of the poetical effusion that I sent thee from Woodbourne. I have frequently recurred to it during moments of calm and quiet meditationCOMMA and have derived soathing satisfaction from the consoling and pious spirit that it breathes. I suppose that I shall in due time be informed by thee who the "intruder" isCOMMA who has had the presumption to invade thy tranquil hauntsCOMMA whilst occupied with thoughts of me. If he shall molest or disturb any moreCOMMA he will incur my high displeasure. restingsatisfied for the present with the expectation or supposition just expressedCOMMA I bid thee affectionaly adieu. I wishing theeCOMMA "Health of bodyCOMMA peace of mindCOMMA quiet by day; sound sleep by night".
ThineCOMMA
[Philimus]

I hope to have the pleasure of seeing thee in a few days.

Philada. 1mo. 13. 1834

I reached the CityCOMMA about dusk in the evening of the day that I left BloomsdaleCOMMA after a tolerably pleasant passage. the coach was not crowdedCOMMA and I did not make any very interesting acquaintancesCOMMA nor any with whom I felt much disposed to enter into conversationCOMMA or to enlarge upon the topics of the day. and if I had felt such dispositionCOMMA it would have been an unpleasant exertion to have attempted to make my voice heard or to elevate it above the noise & rattling of the stage coachCOMMA owing to my coldCOMMA and the condition of my throat. But tho' my voice was "idle my thoughts were not". And I suspect that thou cannot give a pretty good guess as to who and what were the subjects of them. ipon glancing over the pages of Father's copy of the "Sentimental Journey"COMMA I espied the article recommended for my perusal by my friend Adeline. It is contained under the headingCOMMA "The Remise. Calais". Vol. 1 I am highly pleased with the delicate manner used by thee in adverting to the postage subject. It has reminded me of the following stanza by Pope:
"Men should be taught as tho’ you taught them not;
And things unknown rehearsed as thing forgot.Tis not enough your counsels still be true: Blunt truth more mischief than nice falsehoods do.

the sentiment is open to criticismCOMMA but think that there is sufficient truth in it to make it worth of a consideration. I am fearful that I may have been considered by thee remotely or in some measureCOMMA changeable with bluntness in my manner of suggesting to theeCOMMA that it would perhaps be best not to advert to any circumstances that might be of disagreeable or unpleasant nature. the suffered suitable time and opportunity to pass for alluding to the circumstance in the course of conversation with embracing it. As I am now "an engaged man"COMMA I shall be desirous of complying with all the duties and requisitions thereofCOMMA and shall therefore take care not to forget to profit by thy kind hint relative both aforesaid item of those duties. I want thee as to admired applied to anotherCOMMA the following line of the Poet BurnsCOMMA whilst I will admire them as applied to thyself:

"A gaudy dress and gentle air may slightly touch the heartCOMMA
But its innocence and modesty that polishes the dart."
'Tis this in Susan pleases meCOMMA 'tis this enchants my soulCOMMA
For absolutely in my heart the reigns without control."

if it were not however that the metre and force of the third line would be destroyed by so doing I am sayCOMMA this is one thing in SusanCOMMA or this is part of what pleases me. I am not certain that I am literally correct in the quotations that I have madeCOMMA as I depend for their correctness upon my memoryCOMMA but I believe I have nearly the substance. I have made my arrangements to as to be at B. about the usual time this weekCOMMA having concluded to procrastinateCOMMAfare-thee-wells. a thousand good wishes I send thee and more love than I can mention of which last may.

"Thine but the impression stronger makeCOMMA Is stream their channels deeper wear."

Thine unchangeablyCOMMA
[Philimus]

procrastinate the two weeks interval till another time. I thought it would be so. How readily we form plans & [exences] for doing what is agreeable.

Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832

I may say the worst that I have for years I have had a dreadfully bad coldCOMMA and though I think it would have done me good to see theeCOMMA I must now bid all hail! to Susquehanna CountyCOMMA and did not feel much inclined to go into company nor was I in a very suitable condition for so doing. I hasten to the country of cloud-capped eminencesCOMMA invigorating breezesCOMMA placid lakesCOMMA ever-varying surface and romantic scenery.- there to feel myself reinstated in the occupation which is the height of my ambitionCOMMA that of an independent farmer.- an occupation for which I do not think my partiality as yet has diminished. "Ye generous yeomenCOMMA [---] the plough"! before taking my flightCOMMA I wish to let thee know that I did not forget the subject of "Friendship’s Offering" relative to which we had some conversation during our last rural walk. the reason for my not sending the said workCOMMA I will give when I again see thee. this seems to be a small matter to [---] toCOMMA but I think it best thus to do itCOMMA as I have never yet forfeited my word or violated an engagementCOMMA and I do not wish to give any cause for so however slight for supposing that I wd. do so. if thee gets married to any oneCOMMA while I am goneCOMMA be sure that it is to a clever fellow. I am still somewhat inclined I should like to have had one sweet kiss of thy pretty mouthCOMMA beforeCOMMA peradventureCOMMA I should forever be [---] the opportunity (5); however thee knows we ought to learn to submitto submit with fortitude to our fate. I am still somewhat inclinded to the opinionCOMMA which I have before hinted to theeCOMMA that I am not well qualified to undergo the ordeal of a systematic courtshipCOMMA such as is frequentlyCOMMA perhaps generally expected & practiced in this part of the world. if I ever succeed in making a capture of that fair citadelCOMMA or seat of loveCOMMA- a lady’s heart; it mustCOMMA I apprehend be by stormCOMMA rather than by gradual approachesCOMMA long trainsCOMMA dexterous manouversCOMMA or a regular siege.

I have now only to sayCOMMA
"Adieu! a heartfelt warm adieu"! from thy still affectionate friendCOMMA

if thou wilt only be persuadedCOMMA dear SusanCOMMA a drab bonnetCOMMA I will on my part agree to shade my face with a broad-brim. if we do not then attract universal admirationCOMMA who will be so bold as to say that we will not at least command general respect.

I have received a notice requiring my immediate departure from the CityCOMMA if possibleCOMMA in order to attend the next Court to be held at Montrose. excuse haste and all the nonsense contained in these lines.-I expect to have the agreeable company of my Cousin Rebecca Drinker as far as [Stoddartsville]. being of a cheerful dispositionCOMMA I expect she will prevent my spirits from flagging.To SCOMMA
dated Philada. 11mo. 27. 1832.

(3) "Though I to" distant "lands must [---]COMMA Pursuing fortune's [sliddery] [---]COMMA With melting heart & [brimful] eyeCOMMA I'll mind thee when I’m far away."

(5) by some spruceCOMMA fashionable [---]. plague on such I say.

Ph

Title: 1833 June 22COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to S.
Creator: William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854; TysonCOMMA Eleanor CopeCOMMA 1807-1847

Subject: Courtship; Flirting; Letter writing; Love-letters
Geographic Subjects: Bloomsdale (Pa.); New York (N.Y.); Woodbourne (Susquehanna CountyCOMMA Pa.)
Notes: Draft of letter to Susan Newbold (later Cope) during courtship.
Transcript:
Philada. 6mo. 22. 1833.

I wished very much to have had some conversation with thee during my last visit to BloomsdaleCOMMA relative to the subject of our recent & former intercourse with each otherCOMMA but I thought that an approach to itCOMMA seemed disagreeable to thee (2). why did theeCOMMA my dear friendCOMMA deam it necessaryCOMMA in several instances during my two last visits to youCOMMA to display cold and repulsive manners? I do think that the might have spared my feelingsCOMMA considering that I had assured thee that I would not obtrudeCOMMA or press any claim to favour from theeCOMMA beyond what might be agreeable to thee.- ladies are sometimes incomprehensible beingsCOMMA but I understood theeCOMMA to sayCOMMA or it might be implied from what thee saidCOMMA that thee thought I was in fault in not having written to thee after my return to Woodbourne last Winter. doCOMMA I beg of theeCOMMA consider the circumstances of the case. I supposed that thy objections to continuing correspondenceCOMMA arose from delicacy of feelings. I therefore suggested two modes of maintaining an intercourse between us. one through thy FatherCOMMA and another through my Sister Elenor. but thee seemed to think that it would be a severe trial & effortCOMMA to correspond with a gentleman even if engaged to him. thee asked me if I could not conceive it to be so [---] could not make allowance for theeCOMMA or something I think to that effect. the motive which I have mentioned was not that which induced thee to object to correspondenceCOMMA I supposed that the objection arose from want of inclination. if the letter were the factCOMMA would it not have been disagreeable to thee if I had been strenuous in urging the thing? thee asked me during the courseof conversation which we had in the garden last weekCOMMA whether I thought if thee had formed any new attachment or engagement during my absenseCOMMA that thee would not have informed me of it. I did not understand how I was to be informedCOMMA if thee did not write to me. thee knowsCOMMA I might have made myself appear rather ridiculousCOMMA if I should have been writing letters couched in terms of affection & admiration etc.COMMA if the circumstance alluded to should have actually existedCOMMA which was quite within the verge of possibility. thee said that thee would forgive me if thee believes that I have been in faultCOMMA it is praise worthy and admirable to do soCOMMA but where there has been no fault there is no need of forgiveness. I would rather that thee would say that thee tho't I should be exempted from blame yet acknowledge that we are apt not see our faults as plainly as others see them. the more I have reflected upon the subjectCOMMA since our conversationCOMMA the more clearly it has appeared to me that I am not indictable for the commission of offence (3). thou hast had thy own wayCOMMA and I have been governed by thy wishesCOMMA so far as have been expressedCOMMA from the first. I have slighted no pledgeCOMMA I have violated no engagementCOMMA I have receded from no advance that I have madeCOMMA and I have blamed thee for anything unless what I have mentioned in the forepart of this letter. I believe almost all ladies practice more or less in love affairsCOMMA at flirtation & coquetry. but it seems as if we could hardly blame the dear creatures for what appears to be so natural to them. the desire of making conquests by displaying the power of their charms may perhaps be said to be inherent in their nature for practicing the art. I do not mean to sayCOMMA that the passion is not kept underunder restraint when virtuous & religious principles are allowed to have their due weight in the mind.

I tender thee my thanks for the politeness with which I have been treated during the progress of our intercourse. courtship is generally a stiffCOMMA awkward business on the part of the one who is expected to make the advancesCOMMA & places a gentleman in an embarrassing situationCOMMA demanding the consideration & sympathy of the object of his addresses.- I again beseech thee not to blame me for unintentional errors if such have been committed. at all eventsCOMMA I am determinedCOMMA sweetCOMMA amiable lassieCOMMA to continue to like & admire theeCOMMA whether thou art displeased with me or not. I had wished to have shown thee a correspondence between myself and a fair lady of the great City of New YorkCOMMA which thee would have acknowledged partakes eminently of the romantic. there was no suitable opportunity howeverCOMMA of doing it. it would also have afforded thee an opportunity (4) of seeingCOMMA that all ladies to not object to corresponding with gentlemen. I can assure theeCOMMA I was not in love with her!- Wishing thee health COMMA happiness & prosperityCOMMA I remainCOMMA truly & sincerelyCOMMA thy friendCOMMA

+ thee will of course understand that I should have considered myself under a sacred obligation not to have disclosed names. (4) amongst many othersCOMMA

T.O.I confidently trust and believe that I am not mistaken in the opinion that thy sense of honour & propriety will induce thee to withhold from othersCOMMA what I once said to thee with regard to thy Cousin E.D. [?]COMMA what I did sayCOMMA I said with reluctanceCOMMA and only because I thought a full explanation due to thee. I never spoke on the subject in the same way to any other person unless perhaps to my Father.(2) I think howeverCOMMA that I cannot do much amiss by writing thee a few lines. I would not do it if I thought they would cause thee any unpleasant feelings.(3) I offered to try to make thee as comfortable & happy as circumstances would admit.

Title: 1833 September 1COMMA to William D. CopeCOMMA Woodbourne
Creator: Dorothy Dolittle
Identified People: ChesterfieldCOMMA Philip Dormer StanhopeCOMMA Earl ofCOMMA 1694-1773
Unidentified People: Dorothy Dolittle [creator]
Subject: Etiquette; Manners and customs
Notes:
Dorothy Dolittle is a pseudonym for an undertermined true authorCOMMA who chastises William D. Cope on the matter of his poor manners.
See also William's letters of September 27 & October 20COMMA 1833 for reaction.
"Lord Chesterfield" is Philip Dormer StanhopeCOMMA the 4th Earl of ChesterfieldCOMMA who also often wrote pseudonymouslyCOMMA under the name "Jeffrey Broadbottom."
Transcript:
Philadelphia Sep 1 1833

Dear Sir

Nothing but sentiments of disenterested friendship could induce me thus to address you- & with the hope it may be received in accordance with those feelings. I take the liberty to point to a few rules which should be laid down by each person- to be observed & practiced on the journey of Life- I could point to many authors who have written on general rules of Politeness & would not pay so poor a compliment to your acknowledged store of information- as suppose you were ignorant of Lord Chesterfield's codeCOMMA yet am sorry to say I really think a more careful perusal would be much to your advantage- But me thinks there is great latitude to excuse many inadvertancies which is to be presumed arrises from your peculiar situation having no one near youCOMMA feeling a sufficient interest to give a word of advise- & they who mightCOMMA detered from it by your very forbidding manner- did it never occur to you such manners must render you very unpopular- the world is not withheld from speaking its mind of whom it pleasesCOMMA however exalted his situation- for the blast that prostrates the oak passes harmless over the lovely violet- tis a fearful preeminance when our faults are learned & coined by note to be cast in to our [teath]. The great art of confering favour is to do it with apparent good will even when it goes against the grain- if we do not we run the risque of being thought selfish & rude- let not the tribulations of our minds speak too plainly through the countanance- & remember there are eyes of disernment about us.give me leave to observe a few uncongruatives & I have done. There is really a contraditction in your character for which I know not how to account.- for instance you are polite & attentive- then inattentive & rude. easy to take offenceCOMMA yet sometimes dull & incomprehensible never communicative- very prescise &c-

pray forgive this brief synopsis of your apparent characterCOMMA & believe that a wish for your improvement is the only motiveCOMMA & may your future lifeCOMMA be as unclouded & free from all earthly foiblesCOMMA as we are led to suppose the experience of one may beCOMMA who has made the tour of Europe

Ever yours to command
Dorothy Dolittle[9mo. 10-'33]

Willaim D. Cope
Woodbourn
Susque Co.
Pa.

Title: 1833 June 27COMMA PhiladelphiaCOMMA to S.
Creator: William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Identified People: ShakespeareCOMMA WilliamCOMMA 1564-1616;
Subject: Love; Love-letters; Poetry;
Notes:
Draft of letter to Susan Newbold (later Cope).
Includes partially accurate quotation of the second stanza of William Shakespeare's sonnetCOMMA "The Reconcilement."
Transcript:
Thy letter of 25 inst. I have just rece'd & feel a deep sense of gratitude for thy kindness in answering my last to thee. I had made arrangements for my departure for Woodbourne early tomorrow morningCOMMA but I shall postpone my return thither in order to see thee tomorrow. I should come immediatelyCOMMA were it not my plans require some change. I should have left this vicinity with much regretCOMMA without having had another interview with theeCOMMA and I cannot now think of doing soCOMMA without trying to do everything in my power to remove unpleasant feelingsCOMMA and substitute those of a better kind in their place. I shall make thee a full & renewed avowal of my sentiments & feelings to and in regard to theeCOMMA and shall acknowledge my past errors. for such indeed they would seem to beCOMMA when viewed in the abstract. I must confessCOMMA tho' perhaps the acknowledgement will not serve as an extenuationCOMMA that as remarked by theeCOMMA I am inexperienced with regard to that part of human natureCOMMA comprehended in the female character. I shall repose entire confidence in the safety with which I may communicate with theeCOMMA and will thee not Dear Susan do the same in regard to me? let us consider that the heart of each is to be a sacred secure depository of the thoughts & feelings of the other. doCOMMA SusanCOMMA let me see thee look cheerful. it wounds me deeply to see thee otherwise. May we realize the truth of the last but not the first lines of the following stanza:The greatest joys those seldom proveCOMMA Who free from quarres live. O! tis the sweetest part of loveCOMMA Each other to forgive

Let us cast the veil of oblivion over everything that has taken place of an unpleasant nature between us & begin anewCOMMA or rather continue as it were our acquaintance from its most auspicious & happy one.- Believe meCOMMA to be faithful & true and as heretoforeCOMMA thy attachedCOMMA

W.D.C
6/27/1833

Title: 1833 September 27COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to S.
Creator: William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Identified People: ChesterfieldCOMMA Philip Dormer StanhopeCOMMA Earl ofCOMMA 1694-1773; CowperCOMMA WilliamCOMMA 1731-1800; Horace; TysonCOMMA Eleanor CopeCOMMA 1807-1847;
Subject: Bible--study and teaching; Etiquette; Manners and customs; Poetry;
Notes:
Draft of letter to Susan Newbold (later Cope) regarding "Dorothy Dolittle" letter of September 1COMMA 1833. See also William D. Cope's of October 20COMMA 1833.
Watermark on pp.3-4 reads: "AMIES".
Poetry on page 3 from William Cowper's translation of HoraceCOMMA Book ii. Ode x.
Transcript:
Woodbourne 9mo. 27. 1833.

Dear S.
The witty letter was duly receivedCOMMA and I cherished a deep sense of obligation to the fellow mortalCOMMA who takes so much interest in the welfare of a pitiable solitary & disheartened being like myself as thus to set my sins in order and array before me. I hardly think that some of what I should call the worst or most incorrect parts of the letterCOMMA are either the production of lead or pen. at least they appear to me to be different from anything that I have heretofore known to emanate from that source. but even if I am mistakenCOMMA as the intention is good and the act in that view of it such as we should expect from a best friendCOMMA I am still flattered and derive consolation from the reflection. it is all fairCOMMA though I fearCOMMA forming my opinion from a review of the parts alluded toCOMMA that the author may have been partially influenced by clishmaclaver or tea table scandal of some recently assembled party & forgot for the timeCOMMA the just and righteous ruleCOMMA audi alteram partemCOMMA hear both sides. As to Lord ChesterfieldCOMMA I had always supposedCOMMA that there was a better book than hisCOMMA from which to draw "rules' to be practised on the journey of life". he may nevertheless do well enough for the saloon or drawing room. I trust however that I shall always be willing to be put right when I am wrong; and shall therefore scan my Lord’s pagesCOMMA and study his codeCOMMA with greater diligence and attention than heretofore. Mankind is a bundle of prejudicesCOMMA inconsistenciesCOMMA and diverse notions and ideas. in FranceCOMMA for instanceCOMMA customs are universalCOMMA which in England or according to the Chesterfield codeCOMMA would be entirely & arbitrarily proscribed and soCOMMA vice versa. I need only mention the disgust with which a Frenchmansees an Englishmen or an American put a steely blade to his mouth in eating instead of a silver fork.- who then is to decide if doctors disagree? according to the ideas engendered in my narrow conceptionsCOMMA common senseCOMMA rationalityCOMMA regard for the feelings of othersCOMMA benevolenceCOMMA and the various Christian virtuesCOMMA should constitute a large portion of the composition which makes up the sum of true politeness. but I forget myself. if I wish to please the ladiesCOMMA I must not broach serious subjects. If it were not for thisCOMMA I would make a quotation from the book which I have been in the habit of placing above Lord Chesterfield’s; and which I think would have come bearing upon parts of the contents of the aforesaid letter. but it is of particular consequence to me to please the fair. neverthelessCOMMA if thee should happen to be in a contemplative moodCOMMA I do not think it would be prejudicial to readCOMMA 1 Cor. 13 Chap.- but how are we to decide the question and point of politeness? Let us pay "a decent respect to the opinions of mankind"COMMA but let our own sense of propriety have some weight in influencing our decisions. this appears to be rationalCOMMA tho’ my opinion may be erroneous. If it will afford any satisfaction to the author of the letter alluded toCOMMA to know itCOMMA I will acknowledge that it caused me some painful feelings. it also afforded me some amusement. was kind & mercifully & considerate in using the chastening nodCOMMA to administer it in such wayCOMMA as not totally to prostrate and over whelm me. If it were in my powerCOMMA I would cheerfully repay quantity for qualityCOMMA the wit that it contained; but there is not a spark or particle of that pungent commodity in my homespun composition. thus deficient as I amCOMMA I hopeCOMMA that I shall be excused for subscribingCOMMA simplyCOMMA plainlyCOMMA & sincerely as heretofore thy true friend.

Julielmusquere. was the remarkably correct orthography & philologyCOMMA intended as part of the reportedCOMMA of said letter?- howeverCOMMA this does not signify notCOMMA one way nor the otherCOMMA seeing that the substanceCOMMA & intention as I said beforeCOMMA are good. I hope that it may have a tendency to reform & improve me. I should have written this reply sooner than I have; but have lately been considerably busyCOMMA as a Yankee would sayCOMMA with concerns growing out of land agenciesCOMMA closing of contractsCOMMA arbitrationsCOMMA subpoenasCOMMA farming operations etc etc etc!!! I am pleased to learn that our City friendsCOMMA have been all animation & actionCOMMA during the past season of verdure & flowers. Sister E. writes thus:
1st O' all ye kind guardian genie of the landCOMMA and I ardently crave & desire your aid & assistance kindCOMMA in order that I may "please the curious maid"COMMA thy dear self. teach & direct me how to avoid being too preciseCOMMA for that is not to be endured too slovenly & carelessCOMMA for that is intolerable; too troublesome & officiousCOMMA for that is very disagreeable; too cautious & diffidentCOMMA for "faint heart never gained fair lady"COMMA too religiousCOMMA for that debars us from too many of the pleasures of the worldCOMMA too irreligiousCOMMA my for that entails misery on us hereCOMMA & endangered our happiness hereafter. I would fain be just the creature that is perfect if it should please you in your wisdom & goodness to grant my petitionCOMMA and would attain the golden medium which secured for usCOMMA blessed contentment and joysCOMMA moderateCOMMA peaceful enduring:

"He that hold fast the golden meanCOMMA
And lives contentedly betweenCOMMA
The little and the greatCOMMA
Feels not the wants that pinch the poorCOMMA
Nor plagues that haunt the rich man's doorCOMMA
Imbittering all his state."

I have experienced some compunctious sensationsCOMMA on account of having read to thee the letters of the romantic New York Lady. but I considered that it was utterly impossible from anything that I either said or readCOMMA that she could be identified. I have never mention her name in connection with the circumstances attending the correspondenceCOMMA but to one personCOMMA who happened to be acquainted with those circumstancesCOMMA without my having any agency whatever in divulging them. I wish I was so situated that I could pay thee a visit to let thee witness the progress of my reformCOMMA & see how much I am already improved.I do not wish thee to withhold the perusal of my letters from thy parents. other motives than a wish for their concealment from them have induced me to address & direct them as I have done.

I wrote to thee on the 1st inst.

Title: 1833 October 28COMMA WoodbourneCOMMA to S.
Creator: William D. (William Drinker) Cope:  1798-1873
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1768-1854
Unidentified People: Dorothy Dolittle; Eliza G Drinker; thy Father
Subject: Country life; Newspapers; Postal service
Geographic Subjects: Allegheny River (Pa. and N.Y.); New York (N.Y.); Philadelphia (Pa.); Susquehanna County (Pa.)
Notes:
Draft of letter to Susan Newbold (later Cope).
"The witty letter": a reference to the Dorothy Dolittle letter. See also William's response of September 27COMMA 1833.
Transcript:
(1)
Woodbourne 10mo. 28. 1833.

I was much gratifiedCOMMA Dear SusanCOMMA by the rece't of thine of 17th inst tho' it did not reach me as soon at it ought to haveCOMMA if it traveled hitherward by the usual course. perhaps owing to the circumstance of this state not having been mentioned upon the endorsement it may have strayed for a time into another. we usually receive letters in two days after date from New York and three from Philada. it met with a welcome reception however at its journey's end and I was pleased to receive through itCOMMA a confirmation of my misgivings with regard to the authorship of the "witty letter". I am more than ever bewildered and puzzled. circumstance are alluded to in itCOMMA which I had supposed were known to mortal being besides ourselves. I therefore concluded before the rece't of thy letterCOMMA that it must have been written in some measure with thy privityCOMMA thro' an amanuensisCOMMA or else that it presented an instance & example of some very singular coincidences in answer to they queriesCOMMA I may sayCOMMA that th' document was dated PhiladaCOMMA Sep. 1.COMMA post marked at the same place on the 3d. of the same monthCOMMA and was subscribed with the attractive name & surname of Dorothy Dolittle. yet notwithstanding the feminine & harmonious form and fashion and sound of said nameCOMMA I thinkCOMMA judging from the stiff & set stile of the hand-writing to which it is signedCOMMA that the writer and signer one and the same personCOMMA is of the masculine gender. "An enemy hath done this." I said to myself as I perused thy remarks in relation to it. But we have the power and I trust the disposition to defeat his insidious attack. Let us be on our guardCOMMA & not be taken by surprise lest he succeed in his assault. In coming over the various errors and blundersthat I might have been guilty ofCOMMA and which might have been the cause of the reprobatory authourings of this mysterious letter writerCOMMA the aforesaid DorothyCOMMA the subject of the New York LettersCOMMA came up in courseCOMMA and I did not knowCOMMA but that my having read them to thee might have been construed into a breach of confidence. hence the reason for my having mentioned them in mine of 27th. how I wish that I could enjoy with thee some of the pleasant walks of which thee gives such an interesting idea. but do not I beseech thee magnify distances so muchCOMMA or thee will alarm me. thee speaks of the "far off country"COMMA that is of this delightful region which I inhabit as if it were "the far West."COMMA whereas it is so in no other respectCOMMA than as regards climate. to be sureCOMMA a spur of the Allegany intervenes between us and the AtlanticCOMMA and intercepts the damp & chilly winds from old OceanCOMMA but as regards distanceCOMMA faculties of communicationCOMMA and geographical positionCOMMA we are essentially Atlantic and indeed is almost the Easternmost County of the State. Even the obstruction to communication presented by the barrier to which I alludeCOMMA has been greatly lessenedCOMMA and almost overcomeCOMMA by the perseveranceCOMMA industryCOMMA and enterprise of the inhabitants; and railroad carsCOMMA now pass & repass over itCOMMA as it were on the wings of the windCOMMA & with the rapidity of the eagle in its flight. I feel some attachment to the countryCOMMA but after the affairs of may Father's estate hereCOMMA shall have been adjusted and settledCOMMA I expect that I shall not be indissolubly bound to itCOMMA or to remain in itCOMMA if things do not suit "all roundCOMMA" to borrow an expression from the shrewd Yankee. Eliza G Drinker who thee was bro't up in your neighborhoodCOMMA says that she should never have wished to have left it (this County) if she had not have been overtaken by misfortunes of a kind to which we are all liable in the course of our earthly pilgrimage. I think I must have seen the essay on lovers mentioned by thee. I was copied into a Philadelphia paper taken by Des. WalkerCOMMA entitled "The Sun"COMMA and credited to the ColumbianColumbian (Ct.) Regn. I enjoyed a hearty laugh whilst reading it. Pray tell me who was that one of thy acquaintance whom thee recognized in the descriptionCOMMA and in which part of the essay is he described? I should like to know whether I have applied the right part to the right person when I next enjoy the pleasure of seeing theeCOMMA I must beg thee to give me a lesson upon the best mode & manner & means of sealing letters. I admire thy productions in the act exceedingly. how have thy Father’s English potatoes succeeded? Tell him that the product of some of those that I plantedCOMMA are I thinkCOMMA without exceptionCOMMA the best that I have ever tasted. We have had loveCOMMA a very abundant first yearCOMMA more apples and peaches & raspberries than we knew what to do with. I selected 120 bushels of sweet apples from my orchardCOMMA and made of them some of the most delicious cider that I ever drank. Part of it I made into wine. The process of making wine from ciderCOMMA is the most simple and least laborious mode of making it that I have anywhere seen adopted. the red Antwerp raspberries grow here spontaneously and were so abundant this yearCOMMA that I used a considerable proportion of them in my mixture for currant wine.

If I cannot pay thee a visit soonCOMMA I think I must certainly furnish thee with a copy of mother's letter. in the mean time accept of the kindly remembrances and best wish of thy friend.

Gulielmus.

Title: 1813 July 19COMMA East MarlboroughCOMMA to William D. CopeCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Joel Baily
Identified People: LewisCOMMA EnochCOMMA 1776-1856
Unidentified People: John Taylor; John Elliot;
Subject: Beards; Newspapers; School; United States--History--War of 1812; Wounds and injuries;
Notes:
The school references is Enoch Lewis' at New GardenCOMMA which William D. Cope attended.
Letter mentions battle at Far YorkCOMMA a reference to the siege of Toronto during the War of 1812.
Transcript:
East Marlborough July 19th 1813

I now take up my pen to write to thee my much esteemed Friend William D Cope. whose letters of the 15thCOMMA 21th (of June)COMMA and the 1th of July have received. by that of the 15th thee has informed me of a sorrowful circumstance respecting thy dear cosinCOMMA a circumstance which by thee and many others I judge will not be soon forgotten. And altho thee and has been so kind as to inform me of some very important circumstances respecting the affares of the CountryCOMMA yet I believe thee will not think strange of me if I say but little or nothing on that ssubjectCOMMA as what little news I get is unly such as thee has heard thyselfCOMMA for it is principally from the Westchester paper which is extracted from the papers of the City. I was at Ennoch Lewis's about three weeks ago and I think the boys are nether better contented there than they were last winterCOMMA for the rules are somewhat milderCOMMA they are now allowed to go to bed when they please. And as for going out of bounds I believe there is but little attention payd to itCOMMA that I think Friend WilliamCOMMA (altho I was so tired of it last winter) I could spend a few months more there very well. I believe about two thirds of the boys are such as ware there when I was and of think thy all appeared to be in good health.John Taylor was at our house a few days ago and informed me that he had lately received a letter from John ElliottCOMMA which stated that his brother that went into the Army was shot at the time of the battle at Far York. I understood he was not in the battle at the time he was shotCOMMA but was out some distance from the Army with a few others and ware met by about fourty Indian'sCOMMA who immediately fired at them and killed nine. I understood Johns Brother rode about a mile on Horseback after he had received three shots. One in his arm and two in his bodyCOMMA He was then taken off his Horse. But expireed in a few minutes after one of our neighbour's had his barn burned a few days ago by the lightening and his crop was all burned in it which was to him a considerable loss as he was not in very affluent circumstances. I think Friend Cope if thy double letter had miscarried and been broken open by any person he or she would of seen something in it worth a laughing at. I mean the part respecting thy beard. I understand thee is so tormented with thy huge beard that thee has been studying what thee should get that would kill it. But as thee is not likely to get anything that will answer the purposeCOMMA thee has requested thyFriend to take up a resolution and to good for evil (that is for pulling his whiskers) by contriving something that will answer the 8th purpose. but of should not think it a friendly act to destroy that which nature has formed as an ornament for my Friend.

I am thy Friend Joel BailyWilliam D. Cope
Philadelphia

to the care of Thomas P CopeCOMMA merchant

Title: 1813 September 13COMMA East MarlboroughCOMMA to William D CopeCOMMA Philadelphia
Creator: Joel Baily
Identified People: LewisCOMMA EnochCOMMA 1776-1856
Unidentified People: [Ennoch] Lewis (Jr.?);
Subject: Death notices; Health; Influenza; Pennsylvania--Description and Travel;
Transcript:
East Marlborough
September 13th-1813

Esteemed Friend William D CopeCOMMA

I have received thy letter of the 30the of August which informes me that thee has accomplished thy journey Westward and is now at thy own home in Philadelphia. Therefore I now purpose writing thee a few lines by way of answer both to the above mentioned letter and that of the 25th of July. Friend Cope I judge thee thinks I am a very lazy fellow for nether meeting thee at West-Chester nor answering thy letter before this-time. butCOMMA as for the former I think I have a very good reason for I did not receive the intelligence of thee being there till about 5 days after the appointed time which was the only reason why I was not there for I would have been well pleased to of had the opurtunity of seeing my Friend by going the small distance of ten miles.butCOMMA altho thy friend was disappointed of the operturnity he thanks thee kindly for the invitation. The account thee has given me of Lancaster town is very similar to what I expected it wasCOMMA but as for Columbia I did not expect its adjacent lands were so hillyCOMMA orCOMMA had such Mountains in them as thee mentions.I understand Friend E Lewis lately buried his son Ennoch with the flux. but I did not understan that the disorder has spread in the family.
With a hope that these lines may find thee in as good a state of health as I am in I concludeCOMMA and subscribe myself thy affectionate friend.

Joel Baily

William D CopeWilliam D. Cope
Philadelphia

To the care of Thomas P Cope
merchant Walnut
St warf

Title: 1887 May 18COMMA BrooklynCOMMA N.Y.COMMA to Cousin Anna
Creator: Edward Brown
Identified People: BrownCOMMA Susanna SansomCOMMA 1826-1909; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?; DrinkerCOMMA FrancesCOMMA b. 1841
Unidentified People: thy sister Mary (deceased); Henry; Mariann & Anna; Alfred
Subject: Death notices; Health; Pleurisy
Geographic Subjects: Boston (Mass.); Mount Pleasant (Berks CountyCOMMA Pa.); Philadelphia (Pa.); Schuylkill River (Pa.); Wissahickon Creek (Pa.)
Notes: Addressed from 356 Adelphi St.COMMA Brooklyn (N.Y.).
Transcript:
356 Adelphi st
BrooklynCOMMA N.Y.
5/18. 87

Dear Cousin AnnaCOMMA

I recd thy note announcing the death of thy dear sisterCOMMA and it was very thoughtful and loving of them to remember me- though I hadCOMMA the day beforeCOMMA recd a short note from Henry himself. It was sudden as sad to meCOMMA as I had heard nothing of her further declining health or illness. When I saw cousin Mary last was at Mt. Pleasant about 2 years ago. ThenCOMMA though looking delicateCOMMA she seemed as bright and reminded me strongly of the days of her beautiful girlgood. OCOMMA those dreamlike days! of your cousinsCOMMA in your Arch st. homeCOMMA and the several ParadisesCOMMA that the 'Doctor'COMMA and cousin Frank and I need to riflealong the Schuykill and Wissahiccon every spring- for the first and fairest flowers and how you loved to prink your happy parlors with them. I replied quite at length. For me to Henry’s letterCOMMA and told him I hoped to come on to P. to see my brothers soonCOMMA and hoped to see him which I still wish to do. It would have been a great comfort to meCOMMA if I could have come on to the funeralCOMMA but my state of health at that time prevented by a sudden change in the weather I had taken. A touch of Pleurisy which I had to break up I and we allCOMMA Mariann and Anna (who meet Cousin Mary at mt. Pleasant)COMMA were with you that sad afternoon in mournful communion. Is n't itremarkableCOMMA that you allCOMMA of your sisterhood of fiveCOMMA shd. have been spared to Each other so long. And as these days Mary was always so joyous a nature you must all miss her sunshine. How could our hearts bear up under all the partings on our dearest meCOMMA on Earth did we not see the vision of the Angel world and among themCOMMA our "family in Heaven". Where hope assues me we shall meet beyond all partings I fear illegible noteCOMMA will find there and thin in health and with love to all and to cousins Susan & Lizzie & Fanny. I will close adding only that [Marien?] & Anna wish their love to you. Excuse my not replying to thy lettersCOMMA Dear Cousin AnnaCOMMA which I wasvery grateful for. For if the Dr. had not writtenCOMMA I should have heardCOMMA very sorrowfully so I have in several cases of Philada relationsCOMMA when the first news I heard was long after: Knowing of it and I could mingle with you in SpiritCOMMA and live over our happy long days and anticipate those happier ones to come. That Death cannot endCOMMA nor sorrow overcast.
Love especially to cousin Frank.

From thy AfftCOMMA
Cousin Edward

P.S. After I wrote this last note Cousin AnnaCOMMA recd Alfred cards & those for Sister Anna & Henry wh. We have forwarded to Boston. It mush be a very happy affair. All sounds and we should be glad to be present but Anna will have too send cards instead. AffCOMMA EdwardNot Being sure of your home P.S. address I mail this for Brr David to forward.

Title: 1847 December 13COMMA to Anna
Creator: Moses Brown
Subject: Marriage; Weddings;
Notes: Letter accompanying wedding gift from Uncle Moses & Aunt C.M. Brown to Anna Stewardson Brown (later Cope) upon her marriage to Francis R. Cope.
Transcript:
Dear AnnaCOMMA

We have felt a wish to present thee with a little token of our kind regardCOMMA and the affectionate interestCOMMA entertained for thee in reference to thy important engagementCOMMA and having selected the small articles ac-panyingCOMMA would ask thy acceptance with much loveCOMMA & many good wishes.

We both earnestly desire for youCOMMA the choicest blessings. Even thoseCOMMA "which make truly rich"COMMA and that nowCOMMA on your entrance upon a new sphere in lifeCOMMA you may be enabled thro' the blessed influences of the spirit of our dear RedeemerCOMMA very oftenCOMMA to withdraw your thoughts from the pleasing scenesCOMMA which will surround your path. I feel your hearts become more & more penetrated with His loveCOMMA and devoted to His serviceCOMMA whosewaysCOMMA are indeedCOMMA ways of pleasantness. and all his paths are paths of peace".

thus that you may be kept and presevedCOMMA thro' the trials of this probationary sceneCOMMA & be made meet for a far better inheritanceCOMMA is the heartfelt desire of thy affecionate Uncle & Aunt

Moses & C.M. Brown

Title: 1821COMMA to E.S.
Creator: Anna Stewardson Brown Cope:  1822-1916
Subject: Marriage; Poetry
Notes: Includes notation: "written for my dear mother & copied by A.S.C." (Anna Stewardson Cope)
Transcript:
Hsc0504

To E.S. [Elizabeth Stewardson]

At break of day the lark ascends on lightCOMMA
To carol his harmounious anthems there;
And as he wings along the azure skyCOMMA
drinks the refreshment of the dewy air.

But weary soon with wanderings thus aloneCOMMA
He stays his flight and longs his wing to rest.
And swooping from the hieght where he had flownCOMMA
he seeks his tender mate and peaceful rest.

SoCOMMA stretching forward on his errant wayCOMMA
Man gives his wishes & his thoughts to roamCOMMA
But finds at last his warmest brightest ray
Beams from the smile of love that lights his home.

E'en like the mated larkCOMMA may'st thou he bless
To find thy dearest joys where love shall leadCOMMA
And in the quiet of the social nestCOMMA
Enjoy the boon to kindred hearts decreed.The voice of Friendship hurls thy nuptial hourCOMMA
and asks one [benisow] to crown the day-
Even that sweet peaceCOMMA which Earth the power has not
Either to give- or yet to take away.-

May sorrow never dim thy smiling Sun
Nor sadness blight the garlands time shall weave.
But may thy day in one smooth current runCOMMA
Ambrosial morn bright noon and tranquil eve.

Blessing on theeCOMMA and him whom thou hast choosen-
May yours be here a love most truly blestCOMMA
And when at last the stream of life is frozenCOMMA
A love unbrokenCOMMA in the realms of rest.-

Written for my dear mother & copied by ASC

Title: N.D. April 21COMMA St. AugustineCOMMA to Lilly
Creator: William Brown
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939
Unidentified People: Miss Amelia; Aunt Lissy
Subject: Children; Flowers;
Transcript:
St Augustine April 21st

My dear Lilly-

A very kind nieceCOMMA Uncle Will think he hasCOMMA to reply to his letter so soon. He is delighted to hear that she can say so much for herself. About her learning to read and cypher fastCOMMA but what does Miss Amelia say-Does she think that Lilly is as forwardCOMMA as the March Chicks she saw at Grandma' - dont grow too fastCOMMA for perhaps Uncle Will may not know herCOMMA [---] he must ask PapaCOMMA who that little girl is? When he sees her- [---] large thoCOMMA Aunt Lissy says I am fine boyCOMMA what a big family of brothers & sisters you will be if far still grow so fast. You will be [---]big peopleCOMMA & every body cant take you up to kiss them- Chelly will like thatCOMMA for she always wipes them off-

In your next letterCOMMA tell me if you liked the music at the B[---] Asylum-

The flower I sentCOMMA was a rose leaf & now I put in two Honeysuckle flowers- Chelly can have oneCOMMA or whoever Lilly wants to give it to. & now I shall write to momma- for I have not written to her for a long time- & Lilly will not forget to write to her

Uncle Will

Title: 1843 August 24COMMA RoxboroughCOMMA to SistersCOMMA Boston
Creator: William Brown
Identified People: BrownCOMMA Elizabeth S.; BrownCOMMA JeremiahCOMMA b. 1792?; BrownCOMMA Moses; CopeCOMMA Marmaduke CooperCOMMA 1804-1897
Unidentified People: Wistar; English Minister Pease; Harry; Cousin William; Francis B; Frank;
Subject: Clothing and dress; Landscape; Transportation; Voyages and Travels;
Geographic Subjects: Boston (Mass.); Canada; Cape May (N.J.); New York (N.Y.); Philadelphia (Pa.);
Notes: Includes handwritten notes by Elizabeth Stewardson CopeCOMMA daughter of recipient Anna Stewardson (Brown) Cope.
Transcript:
Roxborough 8st Mo 24st 1843.
4th day eve

Dear SistersCOMMA

I presume you started as you expected at 7 o'clock this morning and if I may judge by the coolness of the atmosphere here at that hourCOMMA I should think that you needed your blanket shawls on the riverCOMMA and now perhaps you have them on again pacing the deck of the steamer on the Sound.

But I write now more particularly at Father's request. He wished me to record the uncommon softness and mellow tints of the sky. For the Sun after a cloudy day is setting perfectly clear & the evening is certainly one of the pleasantest we have had this season. Though probably more so to himCOMMA having just returned from his business in the city. We miss your company very muchCOMMA but I have no doubt but that you will enjoy yourselves exceedingly and return refreshed as you expect in body and mind.

I wil now close for this evening and making a short addition tomorrow I will leave the remainder of the sheet to Mary.5th day 24st

Wistar informed Mother last evening that Mamaduke Cope went to New York yesterday in the early line. You must have seen him. He goes to see the English Minister Pease previous to his tour to Canada.

I expect that you have by this time nearly or quite recovered from the fatigue attending your journey. Sue would perhaps feel it the most as she is so unaccustomed to travelling. We intend to send Harry to the city tomorrow and our family will then be very small.

You must write soon as father and all of us would wish to hear. Perhaps you will trouble yourselves to note down some of the most interesting things you see and then you will retain them more fresh in you memory for our benefitCOMMA as will as your own. Please remember me to Cousin William. We are all quite well & hoping that you are the same & wishing you every enjoyment
I bid you adieu-

Your aff Bro William.Dear SistersCOMMA

William & I concluded it would be a good place to set you all example by penning a few lines immediately; accordingly I have seated myself in our old apartment at 12 past 9 o'clockCOMMA whilst the rest of the family are quietly giving themselves up to reposeCOMMA for since your departure we have retired ever earlier if possible than usualCOMMA in order to give you an idea how matters work on School house lane. We feel quite impatient to hear how Sue bore the journey. I hope you experienced no detention in consequence of the [---]; we saw by the paper this eve that the passenger cars from New York were notable to come on [---] day as so large an amount of rain had fallen as completely to deluge the road. Our meeting at Arch st was so as very large this morning as it was expected the English friends would be there but owing to the lat[---] storm they could not arrive till this evening I supposed they are now in the city. Francis B was at Uncle Moses' this afternoon perhaps if Anna had been at home he would have done her the favour to have called but as he has now received information that she is not at home he will take precious care that he does not show his face in these parts for several weeks; he had a letter a few days since from Cape May. the family are all very well and intend coming home in a few days. Frank says if they do not return by second dayCOMMA which is the last day the boat runsCOMMA they will have either to swim or return by land so that it is most probable they will arrive by the the end of this week. Wistar spent this evening with us very pleasantly he says every thing is going on in the city as usual very few persons have as yet returned. Mother wishes that you should buy her a [--] de [---] dress in Boston. If you see any thing that would be suitable; she wishes you to consult your own taste in the matter. If you see one with a small figure that you admire get it or if you see a handsome plain oneCOMMA not too light a colorCOMMA something that would be suitable for autumn. A plain one she would rather prefer if youmet with what suited you. Give my love to Cousins R & Maria and tell the former I regretted exedingly not having an opportunity to bid adieu farewell Mother and I fully expected to have seen him in the city and were quite disappointed in not doing so. I hope you will write soon and let us know how you are coming on as it is the only thing you can do to cheer us during your absence as the evening draws to a close I believe I must now bid you an aff good night. excuse haste. if you either of choose to favour me with an epistle I will promise to answer it immediately and to some length. your aff sister Mary.I suppose the Cousins R. & Maria to whom Aunt Mary refers in this letter where Cousins Robert & Maria Earle. The former was very fond of kissing & Aunt Mary ysed to say that she always kept a pin ready to stick him if he came too near! Mother must have been 21 at this timeCOMMA Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue younger- Uncle Will came between Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue. They were visiting Cousins in New EnglandCOMMA where all Grandpa's relations lived. At the time everybody travelled from New York to Boston by boat.
letters dated.

Title: 1843 August 24COMMA RoxboroughCOMMA to SistersCOMMA Boston
Creator: Mary  Brown
Identified People: BrownCOMMA Elizabeth S.; BrownCOMMA JeremiahCOMMA b. 1792?; BrownCOMMA Moses; CopeCOMMA Marmaduke CooperCOMMA 1804-1897
Unidentified People: Wistar; English Minister Pease; Harry; Cousin William; Francis B; Frank;
Subject: Clothing and dress; Landscape; Transportation; Voyages and Travels;
Geographic Subjects: Boston (Mass.); Canada; Cape May (N.J.); New York (N.Y.); Philadelphia (Pa.);
Notes: Includes handwritten notes by Elizabeth Stewardson CopeCOMMA daughter of recipient Anna Stewardson (Brown) Cope.
Transcript:
Roxborough 8st Mo 24st 1843.
4th day eve

Dear SistersCOMMA

I presume you started as you expected at 7 o'clock this morning and if I may judge by the coolness of the atmosphere here at that hourCOMMA I should think that you needed your blanket shawls on the riverCOMMA and now perhaps you have them on again pacing the deck of the steamer on the Sound.

But I write now more particularly at Father's request. He wished me to record the uncommon softness and mellow tints of the sky. For the Sun after a cloudy day is setting perfectly clear & the evening is certainly one of the pleasantest we have had this season. Though probably more so to himCOMMA having just returned from his business in the city. We miss your company very muchCOMMA but I have no doubt but that you will enjoy yourselves exceedingly and return refreshed as you expect in body and mind.

I wil now close for this evening and making a short addition tomorrow I will leave the remainder of the sheet to Mary.5th day 24st

Wistar informed Mother last evening that Mamaduke Cope went to New York yesterday in the early line. You must have seen him. He goes to see the English Minister Pease previous to his tour to Canada.

I expect that you have by this time nearly or quite recovered from the fatigue attending your journey. Sue would perhaps feel it the most as she is so unaccustomed to travelling. We intend to send Harry to the city tomorrow and our family will then be very small.

You must write soon as father and all of us would wish to hear. Perhaps you will trouble yourselves to note down some of the most interesting things you see and then you will retain them more fresh in you memory for our benefitCOMMA as will as your own. Please remember me to Cousin William. We are all quite well & hoping that you are the same & wishing you every enjoyment
I bid you adieu-

Your aff Bro William.Dear SistersCOMMA

William & I concluded it would be a good place to set you all example by penning a few lines immediately; accordingly I have seated myself in our old apartment at 12 past 9 o'clockCOMMA whilst the rest of the family are quietly giving themselves up to reposeCOMMA for since your departure we have retired ever earlier if possible than usualCOMMA in order to give you an idea how matters work on School house lane. We feel quite impatient to hear how Sue bore the journey. I hope you experienced no detention in consequence of the [---]; we saw by the paper this eve that the passenger cars from New York were notable to come on [---] day as so large an amount of rain had fallen as completely to deluge the road. Our meeting at Arch st was so as very large this morning as it was expected the English friends would be there but owing to the lat[---] storm they could not arrive till this evening I supposed they are now in the city. Francis B was at Uncle Moses' this afternoon perhaps if Anna had been at home he would have done her the favour to have called but as he has now received information that she is not at home he will take precious care that he does not show his face in these parts for several weeks; he had a letter a few days since from Cape May. the family are all very well and intend coming home in a few days. Frank says if they do not return by second dayCOMMA which is the last day the boat runsCOMMA they will have either to swim or return by land so that it is most probable they will arrive by the the end of this week. Wistar spent this evening with us very pleasantly he says every thing is going on in the city as usual very few persons have as yet returned. Mother wishes that you should buy her a [--] de [---] dress in Boston. If you see any thing that would be suitable; she wishes you to consult your own taste in the matter. If you see one with a small figure that you admire get it or if you see a handsome plain oneCOMMA not too light a colorCOMMA something that would be suitable for autumn. A plain one she would rather prefer if youmet with what suited you. Give my love to Cousins R & Maria and tell the former I regretted exedingly not having an opportunity to bid adieu farewell Mother and I fully expected to have seen him in the city and were quite disappointed in not doing so. I hope you will write soon and let us know how you are coming on as it is the only thing you can do to cheer us during your absence as the evening draws to a close I believe I must now bid you an aff good night. excuse haste. if you either of choose to favour me with an epistle I will promise to answer it immediately and to some length. your aff sister Mary.I suppose the Cousins R. & Maria to whom Aunt Mary refers in this letter where Cousins Robert & Maria Earle. The former was very fond of kissing & Aunt Mary ysed to say that she always kept a pin ready to stick him if he came too near! Mother must have been 21 at this timeCOMMA Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue younger- Uncle Will came between Aunt Mary & Aunt Sue. They were visiting Cousins in New EnglandCOMMA where all Grandpa's relations lived. At the time everybody travelled from New York to Boston by boat.
letters dated.

Title: 1908 July 11COMMA Pocono InnCOMMA to Elizabeth S. Cope
Creator: John E. (John Elliot) Carter:  1838-1922
Identified People: CopeCOMMA GilbertCOMMA 1840-1928; CopeCOMMA OliverCOMMA d. 1697
Subject: Books; Genealogy
Notes:
Stationary heading reads "Pocono InnCOMMA Pocono Manor. P.O.COMMA Pennsylvania".

The Cope family genealogy referred to is Gilbert Cope's "A Record of the Cope Family as Established in America by Oliver Cope" (King & BairdCOMMA Phila.)COMMA 1861.

Although Carter writes that he has "always been glad to be a descendant of Oliver CopeCOMMA" his relation to the Cope family was only by way of his marriage to Mary Anna Cope (the second of his three wives).
Transcript:
Pocono Pa. 7 mo.11.1908.

Elizabeth S. CopeCOMMA
Dear CousinCOMMA

Thy letter of the 7th inst. was forwarded to me here and has been read with interest.

I have always been glad to be a descendant of Oliver CopeCOMMA the stock being a strong one with well marked characteristicsCOMMA and am pleased to hear of the prospect of a new edition of Gilbert Cope's book.

A year ago it would have been a pleasure to contribute to the fundCOMMA the same amount as thy ownCOMMA but with the present greatly reduced income and the duty helping in the relief of the great army of unemployed workmenhalf that amount seems to be as much as I should giveCOMMA and I enclose with pleasure a check for $50.xx/100

SincerelyCOMMA thy cousinCOMMA

John E. Carter
