Subject: Haverford College--History; Haverford College--Students; Weather;
Notes: Letter describes the illness and absence of Haverford College President Isaac Sharpless.
Transcript:
Dear Mother
It certainly does not seem over two weeks ago that I saw you at AldineCOMMA and I can scarcely tell what I have been doing with myself. The Sophomore-Freshman debate caame off the Third-day of the week after I saw youCOMMA and so I was pretty busy preparing for that. Unfortunately we lost. It was the first thing the Freshmen had beaten us inCOMMA so we were rather sour. Then the next night came the Entertainment for the Preston Boys' Club. I had no idea of staying till the dance but go to talking and didn't get back till after twelve! It was very good fun and I enjoyed it very much. It is rather good fun to watch other people dance even though you don't dance yourself. It was a success financially tooCOMMA and we cleared $156.25 all of whichCOMMA I am glad to say was given to the Boys' Club through Dr. Babbitt. For a wonder the newspaper report about Emily Fox and the Biddles was true except that I think it was greatly exaggerated. Detectives have been put on the caseCOMMA I believe and they hope to recover at least some of the things. I don't know whether they think they lost it or that it was stolen. It certainly was mighty hard luck as I believe some of Emily's things were valuable on account of being heir looms.

Ernest's kneeCOMMA I think is just about all right. He can walk around on it all right but I imagine it is still weak.

The weather here has been quite warm and the snow has been melting pretty fastCOMMA but there is a good deal of ice over things and it takes a good while to melt that off. To-day however is quite cool againCOMMA though I imagine it will warm up toward the middle of the day as the sun has so much power. It sounds fine to hear of May days and violets and daffodils but it will not be so very long before we too shall be getting springCOMMA for here it is about a third of the way through March. It certainly seems funny to think that there are only three more weeks of the third quarter left; for the fourth quarter goes by like grease-lightening. I am glad I am not in Ernest's shoes.

To-night the gymnasium competition with Lehigh University comes off and I certainly hope we win. Last week our team went up to RutgersCOMMA and when the last event began we were several points behindCOMMA but we won the event and the meet by one point! I hope it will be as exciting to-night.

It is fine to hear of all that Anna can do. Please give her a great deal of love from me and tell her that this letter is for her too. I suppose thee has heard of President Sharpless' illness. He has not been at college for nearly three weeksCOMMA I think. They took him into the Pennsylvania Hospital where Fred Sharpless is one of the physiciansCOMMA but he is better now.

Last Fourth day afternoon we had another festivity in the way of a Faculty tea for the Sophomores. It was rather good funCOMMA though I don't think much of teas. They are too stiff and formal.

I think I shall have to cry a halt as my slender stock of news is about exhausted. With lots of love for you both and thanking thee very much for thy letterCOMMA

Thy very affectionate son Harold.

Title: 1905 September 5COMMA Jamestown R.I.COMMA to Mother
Creator: Harold Evans:  1886-1977

Subject: Books; Leisure; Letter writing; Sailing; Sports; Tennis;
Geographic Subjects: Boston (Mass.); Kingston (Mass. : Town); Plymouth (Mass.); White Mountains (N.H. and Me.);
Transcript:
Jamestown R.I.
Sept 5th 1905

Dear Mother

I was just about to write to theeCOMMA in fact I started a letter last nightCOMMA getting as far as the dateCOMMA- when I received thine this morning. I wrote to Mr. Wood on Sixth day and I suppose he has received it by this time. It is rather a new experience writing to elderly gentlemenCOMMA so I hope I didn't say anything queer.

Art Brown arrived a week ago last First-day and he and Paul and I had a very good time. Art is very different from the rest of mankind- he is so very anxious to please and writes letters at such an awful rate. In one mail he sent eight or nine letters including postals. Isn't that awful? We jollied him a great dealCOMMA Paul and ICOMMA too much I am afraidCOMMA but he was so good-natured about it that it was hard to know when to stop. On Third-dayCOMMA after we had been to tennisCOMMA Margaret Mellor asked us all to go out sailing. I could not go as I had to play in the tennis tournamentCOMMA but Paul and Art went and had a rather amusing time. Then she asked us down to a marshmallow roast on Fifth-day night. We were not very keen about going but nevertheless went and had a very crazy time. In the first place the crowd did not know each other at allCOMMA- some of them were very gay and sporty while others were sedate and sober like myself. Paul and Art spent most of the time having a marshmallow fight. Eleanor Haydock was there (this was the one saving feature of the evening) and so I managed to survive. The consequence of these two invitations wasthat we decided we ought to try to do some thing in return. Sixth-day was Arts last day so we tried to find out what he wanted to do and finally decided to take a sail in the morning and the Ocean Drive in the afternoon. Paul decided he would rather play tennis so Art and I went down to the Bay Voyage and asked Margaret Mellor and Eleanor Haydock to go. I am not especially keen about Margaret Mellorm so sheCOMMA of courseCOMMA wentCOMMA while EleanorCOMMA who was staying at [---] Wharton'sCOMMA decided she had better return and see whether they had anything for her to do. We took three large fat magazines and managed to have a pretty good time. In the afternoon we took the Ocean Drive and nearly died laughing. The swells were out in force with their footmen and coachmenCOMMA andCOMMA as
Paul and Art were not much used to themCOMMA some of their remarks were very amusing. They kept speaking to the different ones they passed and then went off in fits of laughter. We drove back over the hills back of the golf-courseCOMMA and it certainly was mighty pretty. Art left that night and went down to Elsie Smith's house-party the next day. Paul left on Seventh day morning on the nine o'clock train for Boston and went up to the White Mts (as far as Plymouth by the same train as we took). He is at present at the Flume HouseCOMMA and I should not be so very much surprised if he came over your way some of these days. His father and motherCOMMA Ellis and he are going to stay there for a couple of weeks and Paul told me that his father had been going up there for the last fifty years and had only missed about
ten. I don't know whether this is true or not but Paul said so! Alg and the rest of the crowd arrived about an hour after Paul departed this island (You say "departed this life" so I don't see why you should not say "departed this island"). Things began to move [instanter?] and the first thing done was a game of roof-ball in which Art and I defeated Joe and Alg most ignominiously after which we inquired if they could play marbles or any such game! A little baby-in-the-hat was the result but unfortunately was interrupted by swimming. On Seventh-day afternoon Jim asked me to race with him in his new half-rater (15 footer). I accepted with great pleasure and went down to Whitall's to lunch. Six of the little boatsCOMMA all exactly alikeCOMMA started. There were two of E.D. Morgan's (one sailed by his daughter and the other byhis son) one of the Lippitt'sCOMMA on of the Wetherill's and one sailed by Miss Grosvenor. Miss Morgan did not understand the course and started off wrongCOMMA but instead of giving up the race she kept her nerve and came chasing after us. When we rounded the last buoy we were third but were soon passed by another boat. From that time on Miss Morgan and we did not follow the rest but showed our independenceCOMMA and we won while she came in second. I was pretty nearly as glad to see her beat the rest of them as I was that we won. It was Jim's first victory so I think I must have been his mascot! When we awoke on First-day morning a good old southeaster was snoring outside but we braved the elements and went to meeting. Comong home it rained so hard that it went right through my rain coatCOMMAand rendered thy little Willie boy quite damp. Second-day was still fine and wet so we fooled round the house most of the day. In the morning we read a couple of Kenneth Grahame's "Dream Days" storiesCOMMA and they certainly are pretty good. We also read a crazy story by Paul [---] entitled "Love Will Find a Way" and "The Maltese Cat" by Rudyard Kipling. In the afternoon we tried to take a sail but failed as Father had told the captain he could have a holiday. However we went up to Whitall's and Greta and Alg and I went out in a row-boat with a sail in it. The little craft went sideways pretty nearly as fast as it did forwards so we did not get very far. The rest of them went out in the rowboat and took a row. This morning was cloudywhen we got upCOMMA but we had decided to go on a picnic over to Gilbert Stuart's so we did and before we had fairly started the sun shone forth in all his grandeur and we had a fine day. I took Colin along and he behaved very well and seemed to enjoy it though he was pretty tired before we got home. Altogether we walked about thirteen miles so thee sees we had plenty of exercise. After lunch we walked back toward Kingston and got a good view of the country. We had to hustle back to catch the five-thirty boatCOMMA but when we got to Saunders town we found we had time enough to eat some ice cream at a fair that was going on behind the hotel. We walked over from the West Ferry and then JoeCOMMA ArtCOMMA Alg and I took a short swim at Whitall's. It is getting pretty lateCOMMA the news and this sheet are rapidly coming to a close and I am tired so good night.With lots of love for both thee and Anna
I am as ever
Harold

Please give my love to Miss Richardson. Katherine and Jacquee say to thank thee very much for thy letter. If any of you think of it you can remember me to the Leeds and the Hodges. Tell me about the tournament and give my congratulations to the young Miss Hodge if she won.

Title: 1907 July 11COMMA ChesterCOMMA to Grandparents
Creator: Harold Evans:  1886-1977
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; Edward VIICOMMA King of Great BritainCOMMA 1841-1910; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; LewisCOMMA William DraperCOMMA 1867-1949; WestminsterCOMMA Hugh Richard Arthur GrosvenorCOMMA Duke ofCOMMA 1879-1953;
Subject: Kings and rulers; Landscape; Ocean Voyages and Travels; Ruins; Tintern Abbey; Transportation; Wales--Description and Travel; Weather;
Geographic Subjects: Beddgelert (Wales); Bude (England); Caernarfon (Wales); Chester (England); Devon (England); Exmoor (England); Ilfracombe (England); London (England); Lynmouth (England); Lynton (England); Newport (R.I.); Porlock (England); Tintagel (England); Tintern (Wales);
Transcript:
Chester
July 11thCOMMA 1907

My Dearest GrandparentsCOMMA

I have been meaning to write to you for some timeCOMMA but somehow have not got it done so farCOMMA with the exception of one poor postal.

WellCOMMA we have been having the best kind of a time. The voyage was most enjoyable for there were some very jolly people on board and there was lots of deck-room for games.

Since landing we have had a good deal of rainy weather but we don't seem to mind rain at allCOMMA and it has not interfered with our plans except once or twice when we have taken the coach instead of walking in the rain. The cold tooCOMMA for it has been pretty chilly at timesCOMMA has been rather a blessing than otherwise for it has made our walks and sightseeing tours all the more enjoyableCOMMA and the soft coal fires have been very nice and cheerful.

Our trip through Devonshire was a great successCOMMA though we can scarcely call it a walking trip as we walked only two days instead of four. From London we went straight to TintagelCOMMA arriving there Seventh day evening. The cliffs are perfectly magnificent and we spent most of First day morning admiring them from King Arthur's Castle which is on a beautiful promontory. Finding it was impossible to get our bags to Bude on the Sabbath we took the only course open and drove thereCOMMA taking them with us. It was disappointing to miss the walkCOMMA but we had the more time at Tintagel of which we were very glad. Bude was rather uninterestingCOMMA but the walk from there to Clovelly is certainly charmingly quaintCOMMA though the tourists haveCOMMA I supposeCOMMA come in such swarms that it seems as though the place were artificially natural (if you can guess what I mean by that). From Clovelly we went to Ilfracombe by boat and thence we coached to Lynton. Here again we had expected to walk but were again preventedCOMMA this time by rain. Lynton and Lynmouth took my fancy very muchCOMMA and Paul Brown and I had a delightful walk up the Valley of the Lyn to Watermeet (where the East and West Lyn come together)The next day we walked to Porlock in spite of the rain. We were very fortunateCOMMA howeverCOMMA and each time a shower overtook us we were able to reach shelter. The darkCOMMA low-flying clouds with here and there a burst of sunshine rather added to the wildness of Exmoor and it was not hard to imagine that the Doones might almost still be living in some of the wild valleys. We saw a herd of the wild Exmoor ponies but were not fortunate enough to see any of the red-deer which we were told at Porlock are not at all uncommon. From Porlock we went to Tintern by train. It was a rather tedious journey with a good deal of waiting. The two place are only about thirty miles apart in a straight lineCOMMA but it took us six hours toreach our destination.

Tintern Abbey is a fine old ruin and takes you back to the Middle AgesCOMMA giving the whole town an air of antiquity. The little chapel on the hillCOMMA which they say is older than the abbey was also very interesting and we spent last Seventh-day morning (till train time) wandering around them and taking pictures of them.

We came straight to Chester from TinternCOMMA and I must say I was rather disappointed in it. The Cathedral is fine but the Walls do not amount to very much it seems to one. We left here First-day evening and went to Carnarvon where we were very much interested in the Castle which dates I believe from 1256. At Carnarvon the rain again interfered with our walkingCOMMA and this time it rained so hard that the coach did not run and we were obliged to go to Bedd-gelert by train. In some ways Bedd-gelert appeals to me more than most of the places we have seen. It is such a quiet little townCOMMA "far from the madd'ning crowd's ignoble strifeCOMMA" nestled in the heart of the Welsh MtsCOMMA that I felt I should like to have more time there. In the afternoon it stopped raining and we walked down the Pass of Aberglaslyn where they say the cliffs rise eight hundred feet from the road. It is especially fine now as the recent rains have filled the streams very full and the little brooks tumbling over themselves down the mountainsides are very beautiful.

When we awoke the next morning we were again greeted by the pleasant patter of rainCOMMA but we decided to walk to Beltus-y-coed at any rate. I am very glad we did as it soon stopped raining and it was a very pretty walk. At Capel-Curig we again saw the king (we had seen him twice in London) this time in plain every-day clothes in an automobileCOMMA on his way to Carnarvon. The people had gathered from far and near and greeted him enthusiastically. I was interested to her them sing the Welsh national anthem in their native languageCOMMA which is certainly most unintelligible. This morning we returned here and this afternoon visited the Cathedral after which Arthur and I went to see Eaton HallCOMMA the Duke of Westminster's place. As he is now in London we were allowed to go over his houseCOMMA of course for a shillingCOMMA (everything is for a shilling) and were very much interestedto see how he lives. It is a most magnificent placeCOMMA "rich but not gaudy" and somehow seems much more "fit" than some of the summer cottages at NewportCOMMA though I imagineCOMMA as far as money goes that Newport's "cozy little cottages" are quite as grand. Eaton Park is a beautiful stretch of land about three miles (or more) long and the deer grazing in the open fields were very pretty.

I have now come to the end of my letterCOMMA and as it is growing late I must close. Please give a great deal of love to Uncle Tom and to Aunt C. and Uncle W and their family and keep a great great deal for yourselves
from your loving grandson
Harold.

6/17/05
4.15 P.M.
Dear F.
We have been detained all day just off Coney Island on account of the fog. It has cleared off now & we have just weighed anchor. I guess we will be at least a day late on the other side
thine E.W.E.Mr Jonathan Evans
Jamestown P.O.
R.I.

Title: 1906 September 30COMMA AwburyCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Edward W. (Edward Wyatt) Evans:  1882-1976
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; EmlenCOMMA George WilliamsCOMMA 1853-1938; EvansCOMMA Anna CopeCOMMA 1875-1967; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; LewisCOMMA Esther Margaret EmlenCOMMA 1890-1927; ScattergoodCOMMA Mary Cope EmlenCOMMA 1878-1975;
Unidentified People: Miss Richardson; Dr Van Pelt; Dr Bassett; Eleanor Haydock; Anita Downing; John; Billy Haines; Miss Janvier; Thomas Janvier;
Subject: Health; Leisure; Philadelphia Cricket Club; Rhode Island--Description and Travel; Voyages and Travels;
Geographic Subjects: Jamestown (R.I.); Orange (N.J.); Rancocas Creek (N.J.); Wickford Harbor (R.I.); Wissahickon Creek (Pa.);
Notes: Includes news of the engagement between Billy Haines and the niece of Thomas Janvier.
Transcript:
Awbury
9/30/1906

Dear MotherCOMMA

It certainly does seem much more than two days since we parted from thee and AnnaCOMMA Miss Richardson and Harold on the ferry wharf at Jamestown. I don't know why the time should seem so long but it is even hard to realize that only last Tuesday father and I were looking out over the Bay blue as could be in the sunlight of a splendid September day as we sat on the deck of the "General" on our way to Wickford. It seemed a great shame to spend so good a day in that stuffy parlor car.

We got through the packing very comfortablyCOMMA and (although father did say that in the middle of one night he thought we would never be able to get it all done) with very little worry I think. The only thing now is that none of the freight has yet come. We seem to be getting along very nicely on what we have brought.

Since my arrival at home I have been to see two of my doctor friends. Dr. Van Pelt and Dr. Bassett the latter fixed me up without doing anything very muchCOMMA a lucky escape for me because I haven't been to the dentist for over a year and Dr. Van Pelt is going to make an examination of my eyes with the aid of drops later on in the year. He goes away tomorrow and thought there would hardly be time to do it now.

Last sixth day afternoon Father and I took a drive. We went up through the WissahickonCOMMA pretty as usual though the foliage hasn't changed much and then stopped at the Philadelphia Cricket Club grounds where I met Alg. And we had some tennis. Father seems pretty well I think and says he has enough to keep him busy in town for some time so perhaps it is just as well the freight hasn't come yet or he might try to do something at once.

Yesterday I went up the Rancocas with HaroldCOMMA George and EstherCOMMA Eleanor Haydock and Anita Downing. I believe Harold thought some of the members of the house party wouldn't be able to go so did not try to get there to-gether this time. In spite of the fact that it was a threatening day and rained just as we reached the ferry and notwithstanding the fact that Harold and I forgot to eat any lunch we had a very nice time and escaped any wetting. It cleared up before we got back and the moonlight was beautiful. Our only accidents wereCOMMA I thinkCOMMA that Esther [---] on the [---] of a very irascible old Irish woman in the trolley car who swore around at a great rate and was not at all mollified by Esther's apology. Then Eleanor dropped her umbrellaafter meeting broke up. John and Mary Emlen were there and altho. they tried to get off pretty quickly thee may be sure a lot of us caught them and detained them for a word or two.

Alf. is coming to us for supper which will be very nice. Alg. is now reclining on the sofa reading and sends his love to thee and Anna and Aunt Lilly. Before I close I must ask if thee has heard of the latest engagement--Billy Haines to a Miss JanvierCOMMA of OrangeCOMMA NJ and niece of Thomas Janvier who writes for the magazines somewhat.
[---] in Alg's message of love to you all and [---]

They affectionate son
Edward

Title: 1901 February 15COMMA to Family
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Eleanor Tyson StokesCOMMA 1840-1919; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; GoldsmithCOMMA OliverCOMMA 1730?-1774
Unidentified People: Polly; Miss Richardson; Mrs Stedman; Miss Webb; Cousin Hannah; Cousin Sallie
Subject: Books; Clothing and dress; Flowers; Health; Photographs
Notes: Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
Friday the 15th
2/16/01

Dearest FamilyCOMMA

I have just been reading a very nice letter from PollyCOMMA which I was rightly glad to get. If you think of it tell her so with a great deal of love and many thanks from me. Then I have some more beautiful flowers to thank thee forCOMMA Father dear. They were truly beautifulCOMMA and are still lovely though some of themCOMMA the roses especiallyCOMMA show their age! Miss Richardson thought they were packed better and seemed fresher if anything than the ones from [Waltemates?]. I suppose my attack of Grippe was the excuse for my having theseCOMMA but I am afraid it sounded more than it was. I dont think the doctor was atallsure it was GrippeCOMMA & if it was I dont think Ive heard of such a light case! Thank thee [---] so much COMMA dearieCOMMA for the lovely flowers and the letter that came with them. I'd like some more of the last mentioned article whenever thee has time & feels like it but thee really mustnt send me any more of the former. While we are on the flower subjectCOMMA just pay thyself $5.00 from meCOMMA will thee? I have moneyin bank I thinkCOMMA & my flower bill this month or lately will about amount to that I think. I have been indulging myself by sending some to different people. Some violets to Miss Stedman (who has had a cold) etc. People have been so kind to me here.

I havent got to the boys photo. yetCOMMA there are so many things to say. I think it is mighty niceCOMMA & I am so glad to have it. It is a little like seeing them. It stands on my bureau & this morning I burst out laughing just looking at it. I could just imagine from seeing their expressions the kind of time they had getting it taken. Edwards expression especially makes me laugh. Thank you all for it ever so much. You must feel somewhat repaid for all your troubleCOMMA for it is so nice to have it. If AuntLilly or Ellie have room I think I'd like some of my other photos. Any that you can find. Also my other belt buckleCOMMA if you can find it easily. I think I had it at Conanicut. It is a clasp & looks something like silver. It isnt important at all. If you have a copy of "She Stoops to Conquer" that isnt too nice perhaps you would send that too by themCOMMA ormail it to me later if you havent finished reading it by the time they come. I just thought maybe I'd like to read it as you all are. Oh & if you know where my visiting cards are I think it would just as well for me to have some & a card case if you can find one. I dont suppose I need themCOMMA but I might want one for something later on. I'd rather also like to have my black bloomers (sort ofsilk they are made of) sometimeCOMMA but there is no hurry.

I am sending theeCOMMA dearest MotherCOMMA something I started for thee last FallCOMMA but have only finished lately. I thought thy old one was pretty well worn. I dont think I showed thee when thee was here the hound glass I got Miss Webb to get me as a birthday present from thee. Does thee remember thee told me to get one & never did? It is a very nice one I think. The usual shape & white celluloid I think. Now I am talking to thee. I'll just say one or two things I want to. First Miss Richardson asked me to thank thee for thy message & to remember her to thee. She is so nice. Sweet & jolly- I think I am very fortunate. Thee ought to hear us laughing over things sometimes. Sheis young & ready for fun. Then if thee thinks of it when thee writes to Cousin Hannah wont thee give her my dear love and thanks for the little book & the letter she sent me at Christmas. And please give my love to Cousin Sallie too and thank them both for the very nice message they sent me when I was first taken sick. I have on the table in front of me a nice fat looking letter from theeCOMMA Mother dearCOMMA but I'm afraidI wont have time to read it before I finish thisCOMMA as I am going sleighing in a few minutes & the postman may come before I get back. Thank thee for it though ever so much. And thank theeCOMMA dear ErnCOMMA for thy nice one which came the early part of the week. It was nice to hear from thee once again. If there are any loose pictures ofour house & Awbury floatinh around send those with the other photos.

Now good-by. With a great deal of love for each one of youCOMMA dear onesCOMMA I am
Your loving
Anna

PS. Please give my love to the girls & remember me to Simon if he is still with us.

Title: 1901 February 15COMMA to Family
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Eleanor Tyson StokesCOMMA 1840-1919; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; GoldsmithCOMMA OliverCOMMA 1730?-1774
Unidentified People: Polly; Miss Richardson; Mrs Stedman; Miss Webb; Cousin Hannah; Cousin Sallie
Subject: Books; Clothing and dress; Flowers; Health; Photographs
Notes: Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
Friday the 15th
2/16/01

Dearest FamilyCOMMA

I have just been reading a very nice letter from PollyCOMMA which I was rightly glad to get. If you think of it tell her so with a great deal of love and many thanks from me. Then I have some more beautiful flowers to thank thee forCOMMA Father dear. They were truly beautifulCOMMA and are still lovely though some of themCOMMA the roses especiallyCOMMA show their age! Miss Richardson thought they were packed better and seemed fresher if anything than the ones from [Waltemates?]. I suppose my attack of Grippe was the excuse for my having theseCOMMA but I am afraid it sounded more than it was. I dont think the doctor was atallsure it was GrippeCOMMA & if it was I dont think Ive heard of such a light case! Thank thee [---] so much COMMA dearieCOMMA for the lovely flowers and the letter that came with them. I'd like some more of the last mentioned article whenever thee has time & feels like it but thee really mustnt send me any more of the former. While we are on the flower subjectCOMMA just pay thyself $5.00 from meCOMMA will thee? I have moneyin bank I thinkCOMMA & my flower bill this month or lately will about amount to that I think. I have been indulging myself by sending some to different people. Some violets to Miss Stedman (who has had a cold) etc. People have been so kind to me here.

I havent got to the boys photo. yetCOMMA there are so many things to say. I think it is mighty niceCOMMA & I am so glad to have it. It is a little like seeing them. It stands on my bureau & this morning I burst out laughing just looking at it. I could just imagine from seeing their expressions the kind of time they had getting it taken. Edwards expression especially makes me laugh. Thank you all for it ever so much. You must feel somewhat repaid for all your troubleCOMMA for it is so nice to have it. If AuntLilly or Ellie have room I think I'd like some of my other photos. Any that you can find. Also my other belt buckleCOMMA if you can find it easily. I think I had it at Conanicut. It is a clasp & looks something like silver. It isnt important at all. If you have a copy of "She Stoops to Conquer" that isnt too nice perhaps you would send that too by themCOMMA ormail it to me later if you havent finished reading it by the time they come. I just thought maybe I'd like to read it as you all are. Oh & if you know where my visiting cards are I think it would just as well for me to have some & a card case if you can find one. I dont suppose I need themCOMMA but I might want one for something later on. I'd rather also like to have my black bloomers (sort ofsilk they are made of) sometimeCOMMA but there is no hurry.

I am sending theeCOMMA dearest MotherCOMMA something I started for thee last FallCOMMA but have only finished lately. I thought thy old one was pretty well worn. I dont think I showed thee when thee was here the hound glass I got Miss Webb to get me as a birthday present from thee. Does thee remember thee told me to get one & never did? It is a very nice one I think. The usual shape & white celluloid I think. Now I am talking to thee. I'll just say one or two things I want to. First Miss Richardson asked me to thank thee for thy message & to remember her to thee. She is so nice. Sweet & jolly- I think I am very fortunate. Thee ought to hear us laughing over things sometimes. Sheis young & ready for fun. Then if thee thinks of it when thee writes to Cousin Hannah wont thee give her my dear love and thanks for the little book & the letter she sent me at Christmas. And please give my love to Cousin Sallie too and thank them both for the very nice message they sent me when I was first taken sick. I have on the table in front of me a nice fat looking letter from theeCOMMA Mother dearCOMMA but I'm afraidI wont have time to read it before I finish thisCOMMA as I am going sleighing in a few minutes & the postman may come before I get back. Thank thee for it though ever so much. And thank theeCOMMA dear ErnCOMMA for thy nice one which came the early part of the week. It was nice to hear from thee once again. If there are any loose pictures ofour house & Awbury floatinh around send those with the other photos.

Now good-by. With a great deal of love for each one of youCOMMA dear onesCOMMA I am
Your loving
Anna

PS. Please give my love to the girls & remember me to Simon if he is still with us.

Title: 1891 September 20COMMA Hotel Milan & Pension AnglaiseCOMMA VeniseCOMMA to Algie
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: CopeCOMMA AgnesCOMMA 1876-1899; CopeCOMMA Francis R. (Francis Reeve)COMMA 1878-1962; EvansCOMMA JonathanCOMMA 1843-1911; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953;
Unidentified People: Colin; Huntington; Campbell; Hobart; Ellie;
Subject: Family; Italy--Description and Travel; Tennis; Transportation;
Notes: Includes Anna Cope Evans' drawing of a Venice gondola.
Transcript:
September twentieth
ninety-one

My dearest AlgieCOMMA
I think thee is awfully good to keep on writing me such perfect lettersCOMMA and when I got the last oneCOMMA which was a dandy by the wayCOMMA I just decided that thee deserved a letter and was going to get one too. I suppose thee is up at Woodbourne nowCOMMA having a fine time with Frank. I can just imagine you getting up at some unearthly hour of the morning and kicking up such a rowCOMMA so that nobody else can possibly sleepCOMMA because you have caught a mouse or some other poor little animal in a figure four. I bet Aunt Carrie was mad when you waked her upCOMMA I remember she always used to be. Tell Frank I was very much shack[---] to hear of his playing such a wicken trick on Aunt Carrie. I hope he has been severely lectured for it. I think he must be getting very wild. I wish he would write me a letterCOMMA but I suppose he has so many other girls to write to he would hardly have time to spare a few minutes to me. I suppose thee sees from the top of thisletter that we are in Venice at presentCOMMA and I wish I could change places with thee for a minute or twoCOMMA and let thee see what it is like. I am not very good at describing thingsCOMMA as I guess thee knows by this timeCOMMA if thee has [wadded?] through many of my stupid lettersCOMMA howeverCOMMA I will do my best. In the first place it is very beautiful and very different from anything else that I ever sawCOMMA or that anybody ever saw I guess. The Gondolas are perfectly fascinating. They are all painted blackCOMMA and are long and narrowCOMMA with pointed ends curled up. That's graphicCOMMA isn't it? Never mindCOMMA I am going to draw thee a picture of one.There it is! Thee sees the man stands at the back and works the boat with one oar. It is more like paddling than anything elseCOMMA only the man stands up and throws himself forward on the oar each time. It is a very graceful motionCOMMA and they do it beautifully feathering the oar each time. I never saw anything like the way in which they guide the great long boats in and out among each otherCOMMA and around sharp cornersCOMMA without any collissions. It is really wonderful. Oh! Algie! Thee gave me such a scare about Colin. I really criedwhen I heard he was lost. and when I read thy next letter and found it was all rightCOMMA I was too delighted for words. Why I hardly said good-bye to the old fellowCOMMA and to think of not seeing him again nearly broke my heart. Wasn't it queer his going off that way. I hope he wont do it again. We have gotten some lovely letters since I stopped writing and amoung them was a paper tellingall about the Tennis TournamentCOMMA which Papa had sent to me. I enjoyed reading it immenselyCOMMA & got very much excited over the descriptions of the different matchs. I felt almost as if I was there seeing them. Some of them must have been fine. I would love to have seen the one between Hovey and young SearsCOMMA it must have been awfully exciting. I am sorry poor Huntington was not in it this year. I am awfully glad he won the doubles anyway. Campbell must have played beautifully and you must just have held your breaths all through the matchbetween him and Hobart. From what I gathered it was intensely excitingCOMMA wasn't it? I can just imagine how sorry you were when Hovey was beaten. I know how broken hearted I was when Huntington was done up last year. It must have been something the sameCOMMA at least it says that Hovey gave out entirely in the endCOMMA and evidently was not wellCOMMA and that was just the way with Huntington. Now AlgieCOMMA I must stop. I guess thee is sick of hearing me talk about the tournament and will not be very sorry. Good-night old boy! Take a great big kiss and hug and all the love thee wants from
Thy veryCOMMA very loving Sister. P.S. Please give my best love to AgnesCOMMA and tell her I am waiting eagerly for a letter from her. Why don't it come? Give Ellie my love tooCOMMA and tell her she is a perfect jewel to write to meCOMMA and that I will try and answer it if I can find time.

Title: 1901 March 7COMMA to Family
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Ernest MervynCOMMA 1884-1911; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946
Unidentified People: Miss Wendell; Dr. Stedman; Miss Barnard; Dr. Shine; Mary the waitress; Miss Webb; Benjamin
Subject: Boston (Mass.)--Description and travel; Flowers; Measles; Mental illness; Museum of Fine ArtsCOMMA Boston; Photographs; Photography
Transcript:
Wednesday.

Dearest FamilyCOMMA

I have so many things to thank you for & tell you about that I dont know hardly which to begin with. FirstCOMMA dear FatherCOMMA thank thee ever so much for all thy trouble in spending me my photosCOMMA etc. I am afraid it was quite a botherCOMMA but I was so glad to get them & have enjoyed showing them to the different onesCOMMA as well as having them around my room. And then the flowers! They were & still are lovelyCOMMA dearieCOMMA & thank thee ever & ever so much. If you could all see my room nowCOMMA I should have lots to show youCOMMA for I havehad a lot of presents lately! My bureau is decorated with Fathers daffys & some beautiful roses Miss Wendell sent me last weekCOMMA with such a swell little note saying she wanted to come & see me if Dr. Stedman would let her & I felt like seeing her. I told her when I wrote that I certainly did& that Dr. Stedman was quite willing so I expect I may have a visit from her before long. She has gone or is going away from home just now on her Mother's account. You know her Father has just died. Well to go on with my decorations. Around my mirror ivy is twining (that sounds swellCOMMA doesn't it?). Miss BarnardCOMMA one of thr patients have me a plant of itCOMMAas she heard me say I wanted oneCOMMA & I am so pleased with it. Then on my mantel are some of Father's rosesCOMMA & the little daisiesCOMMA & on my table a vase of pussy willows which Mary the waitress brought meCOMMA & what do you think? - a little bowl of gold fish! Miss Stedman brought them to me the other dayCOMMA &they are so pretty- I think it was very sweet of herCOMMA & of them allCOMMA & I feel very rich with so many things given to me. The gold fish are quite an object of interest. Dr. Shine appeared this morning with a long pole with a line & bent pin dangling from itCOMMA & I had to rescue them from his clutches! He is great funCOMMA & I came up stairslast evening with my side fairly aching from laughter. OhCOMMA I forgot in my [---] to mention the dear little witch Aunt Lilly sent me. She brought it in the witch house in SalemCOMMA & it is very cute.

Now what do you think I have been doing this week? Wouldnt you be surprised to hear I had been to Boston to see some pictures? It's all trueCOMMA though. Last Monday Miss Webb & I went in to the exhibition of "Fair Children" at Copley HallCOMMA & I certainly enjoyed it. We didnt stay long & I was very much pleased that I didnt get more tired. Copley Hall is quite near the Back Bay Station so we didnt waste much time getting there. It is jolly beinglanded so near the Library & the Art Museum & allCOMMA for it will be so easy to reach them. I saw the Brunswick. It was funnyCOMMA as we weren't on the street but about 15 minutes all together & met very few peopleCOMMA that one of them should happen to be Bishop Mc[---]COMMA & that I should so have the pleasureof speaking to someone I know.

I have decided to finish this letter up & send it this afternoonCOMMA instead of [---] till some other day. This means I must say good by nowCOMMA however & leave the rest till another time. I have some very nice letters to thank you for. A perfect daisy from theeCOMMA Father with lots of newsCOMMA & a [---] nice one from AlgCOMMA with ditto ditto. I am not sure I ever thanked thee either for the one thee wrote last weekCOMMA which thee started by saying that thee was sleepy & it would probably suffer. I dont know how much more brilliant it would have been if thee had been more awakeCOMMA but I certainly did not find it in the least stupid!I hope thee is [---] all right againCOMMA dear old Benjamin. Thee has my sympathyCOMMA though it is rather late for that I fancyCOMMA & I hope thee hasn't needed it much all along. Does thee remember when we had the real measles together?

And now with a great deal of love to you all FatherCOMMA AlgCOMMA TedCOMMA ErnCOMMA [---] & thee tooCOMMA dearest little MotherCOMMA for they will send this to theeCOMMA I suppose I am
your very loving
Daughter & Sister

Title: 1901 March 21COMMA to Mother
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: Burne-JonesCOMMA Edward ColeyCOMMA 1833-1898; BouguereauCOMMA William AdolpheCOMMA 1825-1905; RomneyCOMMA GeorgeCOMMA 1734-1802; StuartCOMMA GilbertCOMMA 1755-1828; SilverCOMMA Edith Wistar StokesCOMMA 1872-1949; SilverCOMMA William EasterCOMMA b. 1900
Subject: ArtCOMMA American; ArtCOMMA European; Infants; Clothing and dress; Health; Letter writing; Photographs; Photography
Notes: Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
Thursday-
March 21st

Darling little MotherCOMMA

I am going to begin my letter to thee to-dayCOMMA though I dont think I will send it at onceCOMMA as I sent one home yesterdayCOMMA which I imagine thee will receive the end of this weekCOMMA that is if they send it on at once. But as I am expecting to be taken sick to-morrow or next day & may not feel like writing. I dont think I will do any [---] to begin my letter now. I think I have told most of the news in my letter home. Wasn’t it fine about my going in to see the pictures? I think I will mail thee the catalogueas thee might be interestedCOMMA & it is very prettily gotten up. I am sorry that the pictures in the catalogue are not the ones I especially enjoyedCOMMA for I should like to have had copies of some of themCOMMA & the pictures in the catalogue are pretty enough to frame- I mean the finish & all. The coloring of the Blue Boy & his pose IlikedCOMMA also the coloring of the “Little Girl with Doll” was lovelyCOMMA but I didn’t care much for them. The Blue Boys [---] was an unusual shade of blueCOMMA bordering on green but soft & not starey & there were lovely shades of old rose in the Little Girl etc. The ones I marked were the ones I likedCOMMA especially “The Elder SisterCOMMA” & the Romney onesCOMMAa dear little head by Bougereau & perhaps some others I dont just think of. The little childs head by Gilbert Stuart I was interested in & rather liked. I hardly saw the modern ones at allCOMMA as we had only about 20 minutes there.

Wednesday morn.
I am almost sorry I didnt finish this letter up some days ago & send it even if I could say all I wanted to- for I shant be able to do that nowCOMMA as I want it to go by this morning’s mail- I have been unwell since I started this- taken just on the dayCOMMA isnt it fine?- I’ve been as regular as can be lately- in fact ever since last Fall sometime. But I must hurry up &say some at least of the things I want to. I sent the catalogue of the pictures to thee last MondayCOMMA but dont know whether thee will ever receive itCOMMA as I directed it to Berkley- Thee put BerkleyCOMMA MdCOMMA at the head of thy letter so I thought I’d try it & I put my address on itCOMMA so it will come back to meCOMMA I guessCOMMAif it never reaches thee. I also sent thee the little [sagne?] & hoods & socks I have been makingCOMMA thinking thee might like to see them. I hope thy trunk isnt very crowded or they may not be as welcome as I should like. I directed them to DarlingtonCOMMA I dont believe the little sagne would bebig enough for Edith’s babyCOMMA so dont bother about it. Thee will probably be a baby some of these days I shall want it forCOMMA & the little hoods may be usefulCOMMA too. I’m glad to have learned how to make them at any rate.

It is nearly time for the post manCOMMA so I’m going to say good-by & write the rest again. If any one of the boys should want to know something to give me on my birthdayCOMMA I’m very fond of Burne-Jones “Hope” & should like a photo of itCOMMA but remember only if they want to knowsomething. I must finish in a rush & with a great great deal of loveCOMMA darling from

Thy little Daughter.

Title: 1901 April 6COMMA to Daddy
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: Burne-JonesCOMMA Edward ColeyCOMMA 1833-1898; EvansCOMMA Edward W. (Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946
Unidentified People: Miss Richardson; Staton (photographer?); Edith & Ben; Margaret Kim
Subject: Birthdays; Clothing and dress--Alteration; Flowers; Photographs; Weather; Weddings
Notes: Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
Tuesday

Dearest DaddyCOMMA

I amgoing to write a little note just to theeCOMMA thyselfCOMMA to thank thee again for some more lovely flowers and for such a beautiful pair of scissors which came directed in thy handwriting. I dont know whether they are a birthday present or notCOMMA but they are a mighty nice oneCOMMA if they areCOMMA and I am ever so much obliged for them. They are perfect daisies & I have cut out a shirt with them alreadyCOMMA forCOMMA my dearCOMMA I am making a dress! A little [---] & I sayCOMMA "making itCOMMA" but Miss Richardson sews most of it on the machine for me. It is great fun & I hope it is going to be a great success! I shall have to show it to you when you come.Now about the flowers. They havent carried as well the last two timesCOMMA especially the lastCOMMA & Miss Richardson and I both think it is quite likely because the weather is warmer. SoCOMMA dearestCOMMA please dont send any moreCOMMA for I really think it is a waste to send them so farCOMMA especially when I am so well now.

Daddy dearCOMMA I wonder if thee would order me a picture at Staton's for a wedding present for Margaret Kim. I should like to send her a photo of Burne-Jones' [---] of "Hope" in about the $2.00 size framed in a wide dark frame without a matCOMMA like the one Staton framed for me to give Edith & Ben when they were married. Very likely he wont rememberCOMMA but it is not very important that just havent is done. I'm going to enclose a card & if thee can conveniently will thee order one for me? Her address is
Miss Margaret Kim
1735 Chestnut St
At least I think that's the no. at any rate I think it is near enough- Please give my dear love to Alg & Ted & thankthem both for their last letters. I am finishing this in rather a hurry so please excuse everything and take a good hug & kiss from
Thy little Daughter

Title: 1901 April 12COMMA to Family
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA Francis R. (Francis Reeve)COMMA 1878-1962; EvansCOMMA Hannah BaconCOMMA 1839-1939; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; StorkCOMMA Anna Brown CopeCOMMA b. 1862; BrownCOMMA Elizabeth H.COMMA b. 1840?
Unidentified People: Miss Richardson; Miss Barnard; Miss Stedman; Dr. Stedman; Dr. Shine; Miss Webb
Subject: Birthdays; Books; Clothing and dress; Flowers; Holidays; Photographs
Notes: Written while at Bournewood Hospital receiving treatment for nervous breakdown.
Transcript:
Thursday

Dearest FamilyCOMMA

This is a poor way to thank you for all the lovely things I have had from you since I last wroteCOMMA but I can't possibly get 5 letters written at once! So I am going to take this way for the present and maybe later I shall get round to you each separatelyCOMMA I wonder if you have been wondering why my thanks have been so long in comingCOMMA but deariesCOMMA I have been doing so many nice things that letter writing got left. Please don't think I am unappreciativeCOMMA but I know you would be glad for me to do these other thingsCOMMAfor they seem sort of steps toward getting well. But I must tell you about my birthday first of all. It was such a nice one. I started it by reading thy letterCOMMA deares motherCOMMA which came the night before. I suspected what it was and [---] it and think was the first birthday greeting I got.Then in the morning's mail came thy lovely nightgown case thee made me and dearest. I am so much obliged for it. I have begun to use it at once and think it a much nicer place for my nighty than the closet where used to hang. It came in perfect condition in spite of thy fears! A book from Frank also came in the mail and I had a letter from himCOMMA tooCOMMA later. People have been lovely to me and all the people have been so kind.Miss Richardson gave me a dear little stamp boxCOMMA Miss Barnard (one of the patients) sent me a lovely bunch of violets and another beautiful bunch came for me in the afternoon from Miss Stedman . The picture is a beautyCOMMA Father dearCOMMA & I am so much obliged for it. Then the books. First of all "The Rivals"- it is such a jolly little edition& I am so glad to have itCOMMA with the list of the parts you each took. Thanks dear Alg ever so much. Thank theeCOMMA dear DaddyCOMMA so much. Thee gives thy little daughter much too much. The rosesthis time carried better for a wonder- Now before I leave the subject of my birthday- please if you see Grandpa will you thank him so very much from me for the beautiful picture & the lovely acrostic. Your very loving
Anna.

Title: 1907 May 8COMMA Cottage HotelCOMMA to Grandma
Creator: Anna Cope Evans:  1875-1967
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; CopeCOMMA MargaretCOMMA 1856-1948; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; StorkCOMMA Anna Brown CopeCOMMA b. 1862;

Subject: England--Description and Travel; Landscape; Photographs; Voyages and Travels; Weather;
Notes: Includes four post-card photographs of Lynton and SalisburyCOMMA England.
Transcript:
Cottage Hotel
May the eighth

Dearest GrandmaCOMMA
I thought thee might like to see these little picturesCOMMA although this place is too beautiful for pictures to do it justice. You lose the heightCOMMA & also the colorCOMMA which is very lovely- partly because of the red soil & partlyCOMMA I expectCOMMA on account of the wonderful lights & shadows. Yesterday afternoon a shower swept across the water toward us with a rainbow in its midst & theeffect against a dark background of clouds was beautiful. I know how thee would love & enjoy it allCOMMA & I long to send it across to thee. The streams are very rocky & swift & the fresh delicate [---] of the [---] along their banks makes a beautiful picture. The primroses are exquisite- so delicateCOMMA but I have not seen any violets like ours at Awbury!

Miss R. wants me to give thee her love. She has thy little pincushion hanging by our mirror & we feel quite decorated! Please give my dear love to Grandpa & to Uncle Tom & Uncle Hazen & Aunt Margaret. Also to Aunt Anna & Aunt Carrie if thee should think of it. With a great deal for thyselfCOMMA I am thy very loving Anna.Lynton Cottage HotelCOMMAA Devonshire LaneCOMMA Nr Lynton.Allerford bridge.SalisburyCOMMA The CloseCOMMA Pretty Corner.

(Edward Wyatt)COMMA 1882-1976; EvansCOMMA Francis AlgernonCOMMA 1878-1946; EvansCOMMA HaroldCOMMA 1886-1977; EvansCOMMA Jacqueline Pascal MorrisCOMMA 1886-1947; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; GummereCOMMA Richard M. Subject: Flowers; Hymns; Marriage; Public worship--Society of Friends; Quakers--Social life and customs; Weddings;
Notes: Includes detailed description of the marriage of Edward Wyatt Evans to Jacqueline Pascal Morris.
Transcript:
AwburyCOMMA
September 16th

Dearest GrandmaCOMMA

It was dear of thee to write to me & I certainly appreciate thy doing so & thank thee very much. MotherCOMMA Aunt Lilly Alg & I have already enjoyed thy letter & I will give it to Harold when I get a chance. He is over near the polls this afternoon trying to get people to registerCOMMA as this is the last day. This evening he is going3
down to Mrs. [Brabury's]. Thee knows he is to be an usher for Paul Brown next fourth day.

I am sorry not to have written before this to thank thee for the lovely visit I had at4
Northeast. I did so enjoy itCOMMA & you have done so much for us allCOMMA- this summer. Thank thee very muchCOMMA dear GrandmaCOMMA & I want to thank Uncle TomCOMMA too. I am so sorry to have given so5
much trouble with my ticket & hot-water bag!

Well! the wedding came off yesterdayCOMMA & in spite of the rain it was lovely. Jac made such a lovely little brideCOMMA & Edward was beaming.6
They had the ceremony in the large parlor right in front of the Mantel-piece this way-
[illustration]
The mantel piece was decorated with maiden-hair & white7
[---] & there were jars of white daisy-like flowers on each side. Little Theodore & Brewster in white sailor suits & with little baskets of tiny white chrysanthemums stood on one side. They did not8
walk in. Joe & Alg walked in just as we started the first hymn- Dick is bringing thee a leaflet with the hymns on it- Then Theodora & Eleanor came walking in with little Mary be-9
tween them- all with baskets like the little boys- then came Jac & her father. They all stood in front of the fire place. The ceremony was lovely- Joe was fine & Ed & Jac were "dear"10
& it was all so solemn & full of feeling. After the benediction they all sat down- I tried to mark where on the plan- & there was a few minutes of silent worship. Then the last hymn & they11
walked out. They came back soonCOMMA howeverCOMMA & stood in front of the mantel to speak to people. We all sat down to the breakfast. There were 24 at the brides table- I will put in a plan to show12
how we sat. There was an enormous bride's cake in the center & this with white [---] & white china [---] as decoration made the table pretty. The cake had a ringCOMMA thimble & piece of money in it & Jac cut13
it. They had no wedding cake. They got off very nicely in Henry Scattergoods autoCOMMA after running down stairs & through the crowd & getting sprinkled with rice! 14
I expect Dick will be with thee by the time this arrives & will tell thee about the wedding. Please give her my best love & tell her I will write to her soon. Please give my love to Aunt Anna & Uncle Theo. & Uncle Tom & keep muchCOMMA dear GrandmaCOMMA for thyselfCOMMA
from
Thy loving
Anna

[illustration]

Title: 1873 June 8COMMA Cozzens West Point HotelCOMMA to mother
Creator: Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; StorkCOMMA Anna Brown CopeCOMMA b. 1862;
Subject: Honeymoons; Hotels; Landscape; New York (State)--Description and Travel; Marriage; Mountains--New York (State)
Geographic Subjects: Germantown (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.); Hudson Highlands (N.Y.); Hudson River (N.Y. and N.J.); Rondout (N.Y.); Overlook (N.Y.)
Transcript:
Cozzens West Point Hotel
6mo 8. 1873.

Knowing you will be glad to know of our whereabouts and our welfare I suggested this afternoon to Chellie that I should write to thee dear mother- We are now seated on the balcony overlooking the Hudson and enjoying ultimately the lovely view and thoughts of the dear ones left at Germantown-

But to go back to where our sixth day letters left off- It was then our intention to have gone to Overlook yesterday. But Chellie woke up with a headache and as the boat left pretty early in the morning we gave it up- After breakfast Chellie feeling much better we concluded to come as far as this place and spend firtst-day here and go onto Overlook tomorrow. Which plan we have thus far carried out- Our ride up the Hudson was perfectly beautiful- The afternoon being cool with just enough soft flucy clouds floating about to make the hills beautiful in light and shadow. I have never been to Cozzens before and it certainly is a most delightful place- The view is much more extended than from Roe'sCOMMA (and seen when the Highlands are covered with the soft purple light of evening and the western sky filled with a gorgeously colored clouds or when softened by the moonlight pouring over the top of the opposite hills and silvering the waters of the Hudson)COMMA it is remarkably beautiful- I hope you are having a share of the delightfully cool air we are enjoying today and I wish some of you at home and thee especially could be invigorated after all the fatigue both bodily and mentally thee has undergone within the past few weeks with its mountain pureness-

Our plans for tomorrow are to leave here on the steamboat and go to Rondout and go up the mountain the afternoon reaching the Hotel sometime in the evening- As to what we have been doing I guess I had better follow Chellies advice and say nothing about itCOMMA as under the circumstances we should probably be laughed at whatever we did- However I will tell theeCOMMA for I know it will meet thy approbation that we have kept pretty quiet that Chellie (and myself as to that) might rest-

Chellie is going to add a postscript to this so must leave her some room so with a quiet deal of love to father Lily and all the rest at home I will

Title: 1873 June 10COMMA OverlookCOMMA to brother
Creator: Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; StorkCOMMA Anna Brown CopeCOMMA b. 1862;
Subject: Honeymoons; New York (State)--Description and Travel; Railroad travel; Transportation;
Geographic Subjects: Kingston (N.Y.); Rhinebeck (N.Y.);  Rondout (N.Y.); West Point (N.Y.); Overlook (N.Y.)
Transcript:
Overlook 6mo 10th 73

My dear brother

It was very nice upon our arrival here yesterday to find thy letter awaiting usCOMMA and as it was the first tidings we had from home we were not long in opening it- We were very glad to learn that you thought of sending cake to the various personsCOMMA as in the multitude of other things we never thought of that- [---] have received our West Point lettersCOMMA I hopeCOMMA and know of our doings or rather of our goings up to that time- The next morning we left at half past eleven in the Daniel Drew. The weather was pretty warm but when we got on the boat we had a nice breeze- The Drew maintains her old expectation for speedCOMMA and running at the rate of eighteen or twenty miles an hour soon brought us to Rhinebeck which is opposite of Rondout- We got our dinner on the boatCOMMA and were seated at a table with a party of Irish people who amused us very much. As soon as seated they ordered of one of the waiters "three plates of roast beef" which they continued to order of the various waiters as they passed. The waiter of our table having gone out after our dinner of course none of the others paid any attention so them and they waited for some timeCOMMA whereupon they began to talk in a very funny way- When our waiter came they asked him how soon they were going to get their dinner. He said they had not ordered yet whereupon they waxed quite pathetic and said they could not tell who they ordered it of but they had ordered of three or four and they all looked just alike- when we left they were comforting themselves with roast beef but were grumbling that they were missing all the beautiful scenery- When wereached Rhinebeck we found the boat "The Lark" (peculiar name is it not for a boat but we thought in our case rather [---] for this occasion as we felt inclined for going on "a Lark") waiting and were soon landed at Rondout- Here we had to walk about a square to the depotCOMMA depot did I sayCOMMA noCOMMA I dont mean thatCOMMA but to the street corner from which the cars start- Thee would have been amused to see the manner of conducting the railroad- The told us the cars started from that corner and the train would be ready in a few minutes- Some time after the time for starting we saw the engine coming from down toward a wharf and were not a little surprised to see a horse car coming towards us from the opposite direction upon the same track. It occurred to us we would just as leave be where we were as in either- but when they got close to=gether they stopped and did not attempt pass upon the same trackChellie asked out Conductor if they used the same track promiscously and he relieved our minds by saying "no"- After we left Kingston the car was pretty full and some of the people were real characters. The front seat in our car was occupied by a real old fashioned farmer and his wife . Presently a man came though the car and stopped and spoke to him very hard and then it seemed all of sudden to dawn upon him who he was and he hollared ? out "How'd you do my hearty" and pulled him down on to the seat with his wife and himself- The poor little woman was almost crished and the whole thing was very amusing in the realityCOMMA more so I am afriad than I have made it seem. Afterward the two men went to another seat and the farmer sat with his arm around the other mans neck in a most affectionate manner- As Chellieis writing home very fully and as [---] is rather scarceCOMMA I am afraid I shall [repent?] so well bid thee farewell- Please give my love to father and mother Lilly and my two little sisters and with a large share for thyself I am thy attached bro
JE.

Title: 1873 July 26COMMA LondonCOMMA to brother
Creator: Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Identified People: BradfordCOMMA WilliamCOMMA 1823-1892; CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; HainesCOMMA John SmithCOMMA 1820-1886; HainesCOMMA ReubenCOMMA 1851-1920;
Unidentified People: H; Chas & Anna Sharples; Bevan Braithwaite;
Subject: Animals; Arts and religion--Society of Friends; Clothing and dress; Crystal Palace (LondonCOMMA England);  England--Religious life; Great Britain--Parliament; Letter writing; London (England)--Description and Travel; London Zoo (LondonCOMMA England); Monkeys; Quakers--Social life and customs;
Notes: Includes account of visit to painter William Bradford the same year he published 'The Arctic regionsCOMMA illustrated with photographs taken on an art expedition to Greenland; with descriptive narrative by the artist' in London.
Transcript:
London 7 mo 26th 73

Dear brother

I have been intending for some time to write thee a letter but since our arrival in London there has been so much to do and so little time for writing that I have dont next to nothing in that line- And now what shall I tell thee about for between Chellie and Tom both of whom have written I feel as if there was nothing left for me to say- On fifth day last we went to the Zoological Garden and I do wish thee could have been alongCOMMA we were very much amused as well as interested-

The first thing that struck us in particular was the storks. With their long legs (only one of which they stand upon at a time) their necks which they draw well down between their hunched up shouldersCOMMA their grave or rather I may say melancholy expression gives them a ridiculous appearance and when they gyrate or give a great jump as they sometimes do with no apparent object it was perfectly [inesistable]- The monkey house also proved a place of no small amusement- as we visited it about 11 o'clock I suppose it was the hour for the old monkies to be taking their morning naps however that may be a number of them were asleep- One old ape amused us very much he was taking a nap upon one of the bars and apparently the last idea that had entered his head beforefalling asleep was that it would be desirable to scratch his head so he would raise his arm until his hand nearly reached his head and then down it would dropCOMMA this he repeated over and over again- In another cage there were three asleep upon one of the roosts with their arms around each other0 In other cages there were the usual pranks and absurdities going on which monkies indulge in.

The keeper of the laughing hyenas was very obliging and gave us the opportunity of hearing "the very remarkable noise" which the song informs us the animal makes every fifteen minutes"-

In the snake house every thing seemed to be in a very quiet state most of the snakes being coiled up under their blankets- One or two of the Boa Constrictors were tied up in sundry knots and laid out on the tree to sun- We saw quite as much of them as we care to snakes not being our favorites- We next visited the Hippopotomi and Rhinoceros. The former are the most ungainly looking animals I ever saw. There is a little one only eight months old and altho' so young its body so much longer than an ox. The keeper brought some grass to feed them and made them open their mouths- But I will stop for I am afraid I have said too much already about animals- I think thee would be very amused at some of the servants we see here the absurd way they are dressed- Not unfrequently5
we see footmen with drab coats with brass buttonsCOMMA crimson breechesCOMMA white stockingsCOMMA low shoes and with either white wigs or powdered hair-

The other day I saw an old fashioned coach by an old fashioned coach I mean one driven in the style of olden time four horses with a guard who had a long horn which he was blowing as they drove through the streets. I believe it is owned and driven by a young lord who having plenty of money and a fancy for that sort of thing amuses himself in this way- He has men to attend to all the money matters and to the passengers while he just drives- Yesterdat we went out to the Crystal Palace and spent most of the day there- It is a wonderful place so much to see- It is something like our Sanitary Fair wasCOMMA if thee remembers thatCOMMA only on a larger scale. We went around until we were very tired and then we dined. After dinner we continued out investigations visiting amongst other things the "[---] animals"- These are large creatures made to represent what they suppose some of the extinct species were like- They are placed about among the trees and on the edge of one of the lakes in natural positions but it struck us there was a good deal of humbling about it- One sixth day evening last TomCOMMA RuebenCOMMA & I went to Parliament- We couldnot get seats for Chellie and H as they told us they were often engaged a week ahead in the ladies gallery- We had rather an amusing experience- We reached the hall about five minutes of nine and were told we would have to wait for a few minutes as the House was just being made up. We were seated with a number of others upon benches in the Hall and after waiting for sometime the first was told it might go in and then the second- We passed up a long flight of stairs and went into a little toom where our tickets (which Tom had purchased from a man in the afternoon) were examined we were in a bitter trepidation while this was going on as we did not know whether they were good for anything or notCOMMA however they passed us- As soon as weentered the gallery the janitor came to us and pointed us to seats into which we sank he then told us we must park our hats under the seatsCOMMA then he turned to another man and told him he must not raise up to seeCOMMA then he made another man put his umbrella upon the seat behind him not allowing him to hold it in his hand so if he had ordered us to pull off our shoes I should not have been surprised- We heard three or four speeches upon the Army bill and were very much amused- Every once in a while the speakers would get rather muddled and there would come a succession of aws and grunts and hesitations which was absurd- And then there were occasional mysterious sounds which at9
last we discovered was applause in the shape of hear! hear!- How they made such sounds I dont know it was a kind of mingled mumble and rattle it put me in mind of the child that swallowed the bead necklace- We stayed until nearly half past eleven and then concluded we had got nearly two shillings worth and would go.

This morning we went to Westminster meeting and were not a little surprised upon going into see Chas & Anna Sharples and their daughter- After meeting we had quite a talk with them and learn that they are going to sail on the second of next mo:- They have visited Vienna Switzerland France &c [---] trip ideed- We also met Wm Bradford (the Artist) who is spending the summer in London) he was very kind and invited us to come to his studio- Bevan Braithwaite was at meeting and pressed us to come and see him when we return a very warm hearted Friend. We expect to leave tomorrow for the north- Tell mother we are all pretty well- Please give a great deal of love to father and mother and each one of brothers & sisters. Tell them none must feel slighted when letters are not addressed to them individually for all our letters are intended for all. Please give love to them at Uncle Johns & Toms also at School Lane. Chellie joins me in message of love. Please excuse this writing as I am using a quill pen which writes better on this paper than a steel one- With much love I am thy affectionate brother
JEvans First Steamer

Frances R Cope
No1 Walnut St
Philadelphia
Pennsylvania
U.S.A.

Francis Hazen Cope

Title: 1873 August 5COMMA Lowwood HotelCOMMA Lake WindermereCOMMA to mother
Creator: Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA Thomas PimCOMMA 1823-1900; CopeCOMMA Thomas P. (Thomas Pim)COMMA 1852-1944; EvansCOMMA Hannah BaconCOMMA 1839-1939; EvansCOMMA Rachel Reeve CopeCOMMA 1850-1939; HainesCOMMA John SmithCOMMA 1820-1886; HainesCOMMA ReubenCOMMA 1851-1920;
Subject: England--Description and Travel; Honeymoons; Landscape; Letter writing; Voyages and Travels--Health aspects;
Geographic Subjects: Ambleside (England); Bowness-on-Windermere (England);  Cumbria (England); Keswick (CumbriaCOMMA England); London (England); WindermereCOMMA Lake (England); Awbury (PhiladelphiaCOMMA Pa.)
Transcript:
Lowwoord Hotel
Lake Windermere

My dear Mother

Altho I have written to father and Tom has also written a long letter so that I am afraid they will be as uninteresting as "twice-told tales" yet I am going to send thee a few lines in a scrappy way for they own edification. We do so enjoy having Tom with us and he seems to be not only enjoying himself but improving--when he first joined us at London he looked very badly not having recovered from the sea voyage I suppose he was very pale and thinCOMMA but has been gaining pretty steadily so that now his cheeks have quite a color and he looks fuller in the face than I ever remember to have see him--I do not think his leg troubles him muchCOMMA as he says it does not hurt himCOMMA and he walks about a good deal--we shall try to keep him from doing too much--

I think Chellie seems stronger than when we left homeCOMMA as she is certainly able to walk more and does not get as fatigued as she would at home--

She has gained some flesh but is not what you would call stout yet. For a day or two her throat has been a little swelledCOMMA but I shall get her some [tannin?] or a gargle and I think that will relieve her. I have written [---] particularly in regard to health as I know thee would like to know. The weather except a few days in London has been cool so that we have generally not been able to wear our [thin?] clothes. Chellie has not found her waterproof dress to wear for traveling and now that we are going north shawls are called into acquisition. Evening 9.05. I wish thee could look in upon us this evening and see how snugly we are fixedCOMMA seated around a centre table in our cosey little parlor with four candles burning upon on the table and at this point Tom came in and proposed we should take a row upon the lake in the moonlight and as it was a lovely evening we went and now have just returned--I did wish for some of the girls form Awbury for it was so perfectly beautiful that even the [staid manied?] people almost grew sentimental--The lake was just rippled by the gentle wind and the moon was hanging over the western mountains throwing a silvered path across the waterCOMMA and on the shores we could dimly see the outlines of Wray Castle and the pretty residences with which the shores are studdedCOMMA and in which the lights were brightly shining. The rain which continued most of the day stopped toward evening and although the roads were rather muddy we started out for exercise and had a pleasant walk of three miles toward Bowness. [---] tt has cleared we expect to start early tomorrowmorning for Keswick. As this letter is for thy information on little points in travels I will tell thee of our general hours. We find it suits us best not to dine later than three or half past and so whether we take our dinner at the hold or elsewhere try to have it at that hour. We breakfast generally at half past eight and then take tea at half past seven or eight and spend our evening in our sitting room either writing home or in journals or in talking over the scenes of the day and planning for the morrow. In traveling we generally manage to have a car to ourselves and Reuben looks after the baggage and Tom eitherkeeps him or assists Chellie and HCOMMA while I am buying our tickets- We get along very nicely indeed- In the last letters thee said that some of them at home thought "thee was writing too much"COMMA I hope thee will not stay thy hand on that accountCOMMA but only as thy strength will warrantCOMMA for I can assure thee every detail of home news is very interesting- We think of you very very often and I hope the time may come when thee will enjoy the beauties which we are visitingCOMMA but altho the present is so full of enjoyment the future (when we shall return to your midst) looks very pleasant.

The little books dear motherCOMMA which thee gave us just before leaving are our constant compantions in our travels and it is pleasant to think as we read them morning and evening that thee too has them and altho the time may be different yet we read them the same day- I enclose a little bunch of wild flowers which I picked while visiting Swarthmore part of them I gathered at the meeting house and part from the HallCOMMA I wish they were better preserved but they were pressed under difficulties in my pocketbook and I had to arrange them for pressing as we walked. I send them thinking thee might like a little memento of Swarthmore- I am afraid this will prove a scrappy letter and rather uninteresting for it is madeup of little nothings- Hannah desires her love to thee and the rest of the Awbury family- When thee sees them at School Lane please give them my love also a great deal to all at home and at Uncle Toms and Uncle John'sCOMMA Chellie has retired or would join me in these messages- With much love I am thy loving son
J.Evans.
P.S. I dont know if any mention has been made of how Reuben is and as his father and mother were rather anxious about him when we leftCOMMA will thee tell them that I think he is much betterCOMMA but would improve faster if he took more rest especially in writing his letters and journal as he often sets up late and is up early-

Title: 1874 July 20COMMA Greenbrier White Sulphur SpringsCOMMA West VirginiaCOMMA to Mother
Creator: Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Identified People: CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1857-1897; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1850-1924; CopeCOMMA John StokesCOMMA 1857-1915; CopeCOMMA Mary StokesCOMMA 1853-1888; LewisCOMMA Caroline Mary CopeCOMMA 1865-1953; StorkCOMMA Anna Brown CopeCOMMA b. 1862;
Subject: Health resorts; Leisure; Sulfur springs; West Virginia--Description and Travel; Weather;
Transcript:
7th mo 20th 1874

My dear Mother

I hope this evening that no one has written home for a day or two and know thee will like to hear often so I will send a few lines this evening before the mail closes. We have had a very warm day the thermometer standing at 83 [degrees] a good deal of the time and there has been very little air stirring- This morning MaryCOMMA Alexis AlfCOMMA John Hazen and Henry made an excursion to the top of Kate's Mountain. They had an early breakfast and got off about 8 oclock and did not get back until nearly one. They had a pretty rough scramble and some how did not get to the right place and so missed the view- I was glad they went as they thought it paid and I am afraid they find it rather monotonous- The life is a very lazy one and while it is so warm in the middle of the day there is very little to be done in the way of excercizeCOMMA with any comfort- I think Alf seems better and the water suits him but Hazen is not able to drink the sulphur water and does not seemed to have impreoved as much as I hoped he would- I do not mean that he is sick but he still looks pale. He seems bright and much less nervous than when he left home and I hope he will improve more after his return- Lily has bathed twice (yesterday and today) having her bath at about 100 [degrees] and says she thinks it suited her for after lying down she felt refreshed and better- but of course it is too soon for there to be much change- She stayed in the first day only about 2 minutes and today 5 so thee sees she is feeling her way.

This afternoon Lily and Alexis took a drive- I have been disappointed 3
in the air here it is not bracing at all- and as the mountains are all around us often we get but little breeze-

The daily routine of our life here is not thrilling- We rise about half past seven and it is often half past eight before we get assembled at the breakfast table- After breakfast (which we rarely get through until quarter past nine) we walk around the grounds for a little while visiting the springCOMMA Japanese StoreCOMMA Post Office &c and then spend the time until 11 o'ck (when we bathe) either in readingCOMMA writing or talking-. After the bath we put in the time as best we may until dinner time 2 O'clk. After dinner we set out under the trees upon the lawn or upon our piazza and read aloud or talk until tea time and after tea we generally take a walk and then sit in the parlor until bedtime "and thus our days go onCOMMA go on" The boys vary it occasionally by a little walk upon their own account or by going swimming or sometimes we roll a game of ten pins- I have gone very much into details and I have no doubt father and Tom will laugh at the letter and groan over such a life (so do I) but I thought these little nothings would interest thee and moreover there is very little else to tell- Our movements in the future are very uncertain and as yet we cannot say when we shall home or whether some will remain- as soon as some conclusion is arrived at we will let you know. Please give a great deal of love to father Tom Anna & Carrie in which Chellie would join me if she knew I was writing but I am in the gentlemans writing room and she does not know of it- With much love for thyself I am thy loving son J. Evans

Title: 1875 November 28COMMA Church LaneCOMMA to brother
Creator: Jonathan Evans:  1843-1911
Identified People: AlsopCOMMA Samuel; CarterCOMMA John E. (John Elliot)COMMA 1838-1922; CopeCOMMA Alexis T. (Alexis Thomas)COMMA 1850-1883; CopeCOMMA AlfredCOMMA 1806-1875; CopeCOMMA Anna Stewardson BrownCOMMA 1822-1916; CopeCOMMA Caroline E. (Caroline Elizabeth)COMMA 1840-1944; CopeCOMMA E. D. (Edward Drinker)COMMA 1840-1897; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth S. (Elizabeth Stewardson)COMMA 1848-1937; CopeCOMMA Elizabeth Waln StokesCOMMA 1823-1902; CopeCOMMA Francis HazenCOMMA 1859-1909; CopeCOMMA Francis ReeveCOMMA 1821-1909; CopeCOMMA HenryCOMMA 1850-1924; CopeCOMMA James BiddleCOMMA b. 1852; CopeCOMMA Rebecca BiddleCOMMA 1812-1876; CopeCOMMA Thomas P.
